When I realized that the chord was plugged in fully, I was very disappointed, as this is my first experience where an Altec Lansing product didn't exceed my expectations sound quality wise. Increasing the volume helped a bit, but the headphones still pale in comparison to the sound quality I have been getting from a pair of Sony in-ear headphones that are half the price of this offering from Altec. Additionally, I found the earpieces to be rather uncomfortable, and wished that they had fit around the ears in a circular pattern like most other studio headphones do. I'll go with a three star review here because the comfort aspect of the headphones might just be my own personal preference, but I have to say these pale in comparison to the Sennheiser studio headphones I've been using for years in terms of sound quality. The price is reasonable, but I think you can find a better product elsewhere if you're willing to spend a bit more.
summary: Modern Design But Lacks Comfort & Top Notch Sound Quality

reviewText: 8-inch tablets with 4x3 form factor are rare. The Acer A1-830 is lighter and smaller than the A1-810, with better screen color, but without micro hdmi port.Pro: inexpensive 8-inch tablet with sufficiently good screen and performance. Micro SD card slot, micro usb port. Plenty of third party, well-designed yet inexpensive cases. Adequate stereo sound.Con: no micro hdmi port, screen resolution is not high (but adequate for browsing.)

We've got several existing tablets and other devices in our house.  My wife and I both have used iPads for several years, and my daughters each have their own Nexus tablets, while I also have an Android phone.  So I was excited to see what an Acer tablet running Android might offer.  My past experience with Acer has been that they provide reasonably-priced devices that perform well for the price, and this tablet is no exception.There are several factors I like about this tablet:1) Quality packaging makes a good impression and provides security.2) Android Jelly Bean system is intuitive and easy to use.3) Wireless setup was extremely easy.4) Screen size is quite large, makes for excellent web browsing, magazine reading, etc.5) Excellent battery life.The device isn't perfect, and has some limitations.  The front camera is only 2MP, which is lower than you typically find now in Android phones.  And most notably, the screen resolution of 1,024 x 768, which is fair but not outstanding.  However, limitations have to be expected on a device that has been designed with the focus on price and function while trying to keep the price down.If you're looking for the perfect table with price not being a concern, then the iPad or a Kindle Fire should be researched.  For the price, however, this Iconia is difficult to beat.  My girls still prefer their Nexus 7 tablets, but given what we paid for the respective devices, the Acer has a higher cost benefit.  An excellent table choice.

I have used a 2nd Gen iPad for the last three years,  while having ventured into playing with a few Android units in the past, I was not impressed enough to even think about switching over to that operating system, too much lag, glitches and unfamiliarity to overcome in the past.  Not so with this tablet!  Very impressive!  The clarity of the screen, front and back camera, and responsive touch has pushed me to take on the Android operating system.  The size, weight, and thin profile are perfect, small yet a solid quality feel in your hands, at this price, it's a steal!

I ordered this tablet on a gold box deal. I was going to ordered the dell venue 8 tablet.  This tablet is great for 99$. The battery life is a lot better than my Dell venue 7 tablet.  The charge is about the same as my Nook HD. The picture and colors or crisp. Professional reviews complain about lower pixel rate but I can not tell the difference between this and my dell tablet. I do think my nook HD has a better display. I like all the preloaded apps on this tablet. The sound is good and I like the radio app. The only thing I do not like about this tablet is the way my words with friends is displayed on screen. I have tried to change this but can not. I have been playing with this tablet  for past four days since it arrived. It some times takes longer to load than the other two tablets but this is not a deal breaker. This tablet is well made and I like the aluminum case.♥ I wish I had ordered a few more for Christmas presents!! I am always looking for a great deal.
summary: Great tablet for the price. I love tablets only break out the lap top when I absolutely have to use it.

reviewText: This is a very good speaker system for the price, although to be transparent I should say that I got this free through the Amazon Vine program. One thing that I can testify to, however, is that I have never been encouraged by Amazon to give a good or bad review to any of the books or products I've reviewed. Occasionally, I do write a negative review, although I more often give 3 to 5 stars. That's because I tend not to be motivated to review things that I dislike. I will do so in the case of appliances and consumer electronics, however, because I know that other customers depend on honest reviews to guide their purchases.So, having said all that, let me list the 'pros' of the iHome Bluetooth Speaker:- Simple to set up the wireless function, even for novices.- Small size (about 7 inches long by 3.5 inches high. It has a small footprint so will fit on a crowded night stand or counter top.- Good sound. (Not great, but good. More about that below.)- Built-in USB charger for your iPod or other device- Built-in speaker phone. I don't use this, but someone who has a different home office set-up might find it handy. It might also be useful for someone who likes to talk by voice while cooking or doing some other activity.- Comes with a remote control (NFC) and a one-year warranty. This latter is good, as many other manufacturers offer only 90 days.Now I have one con -- This unit has very weak bass. This is a real problem if you listen to music that tends to have strong bass lines -- rock n roll, etc. If, on the other hand, you listen only to classical music or other genres that are strong on treble and low on bass, I believe you will be very happy with this unit.In contrast, I have an Altec Lansing wireless Bluetooth speaker that boasts both a prominent (adjustable) bass, as well as decent highs in the treble range. If you want a unit that you can rock out to at parties, this iHome isn't it. Try the Altec or a Beats speaker instead.
summary: Very Good Wireless Speaker, but Not Great Bass

reviewText: wireless speakes are hard to review, as they all have different sound characteristics, what one person likes, another finds mediocre.  For the price, this speaker is very good... sound quality for pop music, very good... volume is high, but of course, sound distorts, u can only ask so much from a small footprint speaker.  You can have better sound, but expect to pay 2-3x more... no problems with connectivity with several devices...

Please disregard this review if you don't care about using the monitor on OSX.I am running this on a new MacBook Pro 15" with discrete graphics.  I knew I would be limited to 30 hz at full 3840x2160 resolution, and the display included a mini-displayport to displayport cable that plugs right into the thunderbolt port, which is nice.The problem is that you cannot chose to run at a lower resolution.  Display preferences lists ONLY the native resolution.  Using QuickRes (a 3rd party add-on for more resolution choices), none of the lower resolutions work, at least until you go all they way down to 1080p (mine won't even sync at 1080p for some reason though, but it tries).In particular, you cannot use HiDPI on an external display (where the application sees a lower resolution, but the OS renders fonts at full resolution).  (No, it does not help to enable HiDPI with Quartz Debug, nor with the QuickRes "Enable HiDPI" button).  So the menus and all applications are absolutely tiny.You could adjust the size of everything on a per-application basis, but then they won't look right when you're working on the laptop display, unless you use something like QuickRes to run the laptop display at its native resolution.  I guess I will try that for a few days.  But I have a feeling I will end up going back to my older, power-hungry 2550x1600 30" displays.If I could just select the highest of the HiDPI resolutions available for the laptop display in the System Preferences, and mirror *exactly* that to this display, I would be a happy camper.  You can't do that.

I was specially looking for a non-smart TV just for gaming and I picked this one. There seems to be a few problems with Samsung Smart TV's freezing up and I did not need that option anyway. If you are looking for a smart TV, I would recommend buying a Roku with this TV. You can't go wrong for the price since it is a 1080 TV. Also this is not a true 120hz TV, only in cinema mode and I did not see any difference in gaming and I am not using gaming mode since this TV seems fast enough. This TV is also a gloss finish which makes the picture more crisp! Once thing I noticed playing Battlefield 4 on my new Samsung and LG TV, that there is a certain map that has a cave and I can actually see with the Toshiba inside the cave and the LG and Samsung I could not, so I always hated playing that map till nowThe colors are nice and crisp and there is no delay in the response time with the controller. I am using a HDMI connection and did a few adjustments on the colors from a previous review someone did. Amazon can't seem to keep this TV in stock, so I had to buy it from a different dealer. The only thing I did add was buy aPhilips CSS2123B/F7 SoundBar Home Cinema Speakersfor added gaming experience, otherwise it sounds pretty good with the built in speakers. The TV is also very light and can be easily moved around and it also has a VESA mount for mounting on the wall.
summary: Awesome TV for PS3 and PS4!

reviewText: I love my television! Having gone without a television for over five years, having relied on laptops and PCs during that time, I'm so glad I can schlep onto the sofa and binge watch like a true couch potato!

I finally disposed of my circa 1985 TV, with some regret as I still had it connected to my same vintage Denon stereo system, and vcr and dvd player. The Vanity comes in as all the other electronics in the cabinet were "gun metal" and I did not want a black bezel on the tv. Searching for maximum size and gun metal resulted in this HDTV. The bonus is is that it has a great picture (after following suggestion from an earlier reviewer) and the sound is acceptable. I wanted a plain HDTV as I won a Roku 3 and luckily we have over the air digital signals for the local channels. I assembled it, set it up, attached the Roku and life is excellent on the bedroom tv watching spectrum. Regarding the other reviewer's statement about the instability of the stand, if you screw it into the TV stand, and/or apply a strap to the provided rear hook, as Toshiba states to complete the installation with the stand,  no problems with tipping. I live in earthquake territory and all appliances get locked down.So if you want a "vanilla" HDTV of decent size you can't go wrong with this purchase.
This TV was easy to set up and joins more Toshiba tvs in my house. The picture is top notch. I have always had good luck with Toshiba flat screens.

So far, I'm thrilled with the quality of this television.  It was the best price out there and I looked at all the big box electronic retailers.  It is super thin (about an inch) with a great picture.  The screen is 49.5 inches - not 50 inches - but they call this a "50 inch class" television.  The stand is as shown and is a little flimsy, but nothing that is a deal killer.  I tend to prefer the metal foot stands, but this works well.  I coupled this with the Amazon FireTV and I love it - much better than the Smart TV I had experience with.  The remote is easy to use and it plugged in quickly to my cable system and was up and running in no time.  Remember to purchase the AmazonBasics High-Speed HDMI Cable - you don't need the expensive HDMI cable.  I would highly recommend this for the price.

I was unable to align the telescope. Manual says to pick three bright stars to align. I did that on a perfectly clear night and it waits until the third start to tell you that the alignment failed. Tried several times and gave up.Also, lost connection to the wifi while trying to use this thing but my iPad was only a few feet away.The finderscope is very hard to use when your star is at a high angle above you. You need to sit on the ground to get low enough to see through it. It should be a right angle finder.Using the Celestron app has it's drawbacks. Trying to move the telescope with the app requires you to look at the app instead of being able to look through the telescope. I would prefer real buttons on the telescope for moving it around the sky.

Quick and easy way to put your mind at ease that the ConnectR is not going to come loose. The only downsides are that it is1: a little tricky to install and2: It reduces the clearance of the gate on the ConnectR, making it a little more difficult to attach to the camera.
It's rugged and well made, but not needed as I didn't know it came the Black rapid strap. I don't think I will ever use the two extra lock covers.
summary: Ordered not knowing it came with strap

reviewText: I accidentally ordered 5 of these for use on 5 BlackRapid straps (2 single straps, a handstrap and the double strap) only to find out each package includes 2 pieces. With that said, I would have paid the same price even if only 1 were included.The Lockstar connects to the R-Strap carabiner and locks in place - it's made of a sturdy plastic that swings open/closed on the carabiner and can "lock" the carabiner shut when it's threaded shut.The benefit of this is to provide additional security for the R-Strap as the threaded lock on the carabiner tends to unthread itself over the course of the day (which could result in the carabiner opening and the camera slipping off and onto the ground).The product looks good while in use -- it doesn't look out of place or too much like an aftermarket part.. it's very light (but strong) and doesn't add unnecessary bulk. It holds somewhat tight in place, and as a "backup" piece I feel more comfortable with it (as I would often look down and see the threading had undone itself with the carabiner itself)With all that said, most believe the "weak point" of the R-Strap system is in the screw-threading itself (that connects to the camera). If that becomes unscrewed (which isn't too hard to do if walking around), the camera itself will drop, whether or not you're using the lockstar. The lockstar prevents the carabiner from opening.If you are more concerned about the camera unthreading itself, look into the Black Rapid Tether Kit. This includes a "safety cable" which locks onto the cameras metal clip (left side of the camera) on one end and provided a 2nd attachment to the carabiner on the other end. If the camera unthreads itself, the "safety tether" will still be attached and can save the camera from falling to the ground. I ended up purchasing both the tether/safety kit and the lockstar.
summary: Very good accessory for BlackRapid -- Package contains 2 pieces

reviewText: I always thought it would be cool to have a touchscreen with windows 8 but I couldn't justify spending $300 to get it, now that it came down to under $200 I thought I'd give it a try.  This monitor is excellent.  Excellent picture quality, full 1080p, works with screen bright because it has DDC/CI.  The touchscreen works quite well, it's 10 point multi touch.  Don't be counting on the speakers to be amazing because they're about on par with most laptop speakers, they aren't very good but I expected that and use 2.1 speakers anyways.  The touch control is through the usb cable from the monitor to the pc.  The monitor has 2 hdmi inputs and a vga so prepare yourself if you're expecting to have a dvi.  If you're interested in using the speakers anyways, it goes through the HDMI on the monitor as well as a 3.5mm input.  This does tilt back very far as well as being up almost straight, but not quite which makes sense for a touchscreen anyways.  There is a bit of glare if you're using this in a bright room because of the glass that is used for the touchscreen but it's not a deal breaker by any means.  Overall excellent touchscreen monitor.
Good color, easy to set up, crisp, clear and very responsive. It integrated with my Windows 7 system seamlessly. I'm very glad I went with the Acer.

Only had this for one day, but it has a 3 year warranty from a major company. It even has a 90 day software warranty for those who have trouble setting it up.Works perfectly with the surface pro. Just a much bigger screen. Great to have the option of touchscreen, mouse, keyboard!Major CON of getting one of these is that I don't think I will ever use a computer without a touchscreen again.

Here is what their instructions say for installing this device, including their own website:"Does SENTRY's caller id show caller names?SENTRY can only show caller numbers. However, your home phone will show caller id as usual if you use phone line splitter as shown in Option1"Uh, guys, option 1 is NOT correct!I think I'll wait till these dudes get it right!!!!

It's a fun lens to have in the bag, but it's overpriced at $99 and would be more appropriately priced at $69.  The similar Olympus 15mm body cap lens is $49 and given ultrawides are more difficult to design, it would be worth a little more.  For $99, it should have had at least some electronics in it for the EXIF information.Considering the fixed f/8 aperture, there's quite of bit more noticeable chromatic aberration (CA) distortion than I would have expected. Plus, it's not truly a full fisheye, having some fisheye distortion but not as much as the Rokinon 7.5mm.In comparison, the Canon EF 50mm f/1.8 II also sells for about $99 (gray market), but it has full electronics, aperture range, and autofocus, along with very decent image quality.  Granted, 50mm equivalent lenses are easier to design, but still, if Canon can make money selling a more complex lens at $99, I think the Olympus 9mm is a bit overpriced for essentially a toy and best for special effects images.
summary: Overpriced at $99 with No Electronics nor EXIF Information

reviewText: This computer meets all my expectations and I am very happy with it.  I replaced an XP with this so it takes a little getting used to, but it isn't hard to catch on.  It is very fast and most enjoyable to use.

I ordered this for my mother to replace her old Dell Dimension, and WOW what a difference, it is so fast! It was a breeze to set up, I had it up and running for her in about 10 minutes. It has the compact size tower with usb ports and a memory card slot on the front of the tower. With 4 GB of memory and a 500GB hard drive it is just perfect for her to check her emails, upload pics, and surf the web. I like the fact that it has built in wifi so if she wants to move the computer elsewhere in the house, she can do so easily. It came with a corded mouse and basic corded keyboard, but I switched out the mouse to a wireless one. I have always bought Dell computers, and have never had an issue with any of them over the years.

My only disappointment with this machine is that there is only one power cord for the internal hard drive.  I had to go search for one at the local Best Buy so I could install a second hard drive.  At least it was possible and relatively easy to do.
summary: My only disappointment with this machine is that there is only one ...

reviewText: Supports Mac easily and Windows. Very small footprint. This is the only brand I ever found that lets you trigger off one camera off of another for motion detection. For example you might want to turn on a camera around a corner to capture someone as they went from one camera viewpoint to another. I bought this one to support 960H, right now it works fine on my old cameras. Prices have really went down on these things and this one is a bargain with the 1 TB drive.Dealing with their tech support was a pleasure. I had to call them because of an error in their DDNS setup sheet that I was using to setup external viewing on my mobile phone. In the field Domain name they have http:// in front of the domain name, which was wrong, http:// should NOT be typed in the field. Once I just entered the domain name I had set up in their myq-see.com domain service it work great! Also I learned you cannot in any browser configure the masked out area for a camera, that must be only done at the DVR. Once I knew I could not do it, that was fine with me, I just needed to know. I also verified that it will support both 960h and non-960h concurrently which I needed because I will have small hidden invisible led 940nm wavelength 700tvl cameras besides the larger visible red led 960h cameras.In all this was a nice experience.  If you are considering a 4-camera unit, my advice is go with an 8 port with 4 cameras at first as until you get it you don't realize how you eventually want to see more, or you discover holes in your surveillance area.I highly recommend this unit. This is third once I installed, and the second Q-see brand one I installed. To me, I am sticking with Q-see.I want to add that tech support followed up to make sure I was happy and later on they sent a survey on how well they did. I am very happy with their support (which happens to be lifetime). Another brand I had and got rid of had terrible support, these guys Q-SEE are great, even better than I ever hoped for.
summary: Amazingly small. Easy to use. Support 960H

reviewText: Overall I was very pleased with the system.  The contents were well packaged and everything was included to install the system.Cameras -  Camera cables were 60 feet in length and were long enough for my application.  The aiming adjustment system for each camera were easy to adjust and makes it where it is easy to aim and will work in virtually any application.  The camera housings are metal, not plastic and seem to be well made and rugged.  The PTZ camera came with an arm mount and a ceiling mount.  The housing was metal and very sturdy.Recorder – Very easy to set up and get going.  All cables, for different applications, were included.  The instruction  guide was awesome!  It was very easy to read and understand and included screenshots for each step of the way.  The system comes with a mouse so all you had to do is follow along and click.Performance -  Cameras have great coverage with their 59 degree arc with little or no distortion.  Images are very sharp and identifiable.  The IR throws plenty of light out to an advertised distance of 85 feet.  I’m able to get every bit of that with mine and the image is still nice and sharp.The recording ability is motion activated.  An icon appears on the picture frame of your monitor indication which camera has been activated and is recording.  During testing, the activations triggers quickly, as soon as there is movement in the frame.Playback is a breeze, using the provided mouse and screen icons and menus.The iPhone app works great and it was has novel way to transfer the settings from your DVR to the app... just scan a QR code!  The settings then appear in your app and you're good to go.  The web app worked with IE, Firefox, and Chrome.  Unfortunately, you have to be an admin on the computer to install the web software.  I really wish they had a MJPEG push option for viewing so you could at least see what's going on without having to be an admin.One more picky thing I would improve on is the type of screw they use on  the camera angle adjustment.  It is a very small Phillips head screw.  One of the cameras had this screw tightened down pretty tight and was difficult to get out without stripping the shallow head out.  I think an Allen head screw would work better and less likely to strip out the head is torqued down tight.  Also, an Allen head screw can be tightened more easily and it can be reached more easily in tight spaces or against a wall with an Allen wrench verses a screwdriver.Overall I am more than please with the system, its capabilities and performance.

My older DVR would not allow me to access my DVR with my computer over my wireless N home system.  My Windows 8.1 with explorer 11 was the problem.  The manufacturer of my older unit ( Q-See ) told me that there was not fix and that they would not be providing updates to fix the problem.  Their solution was to purchase the newer QT DVR. I installed the new QT dvr and I can now view what is happening live on my cctv security system
summary: This DVR allowed me to remotely access with my computer

reviewText: It's been over 3 weeks. I am not a big technical person like other reviewers. The cloud drive is certainly very fast and easy to transfer file and setups. While within the home network, it works really good. There's a free trial on the Smartware for backups but I upgraded to full version. The only disappointment with software is not able to do multiple different backups to the drive. The music streaming is ok. I wish there is a better music library built in to retrieve the music easier. The mobile apps works really fast and able to retrieve files easily. I wish it is similar to POGOPLUG where it builds the media library for you (photo, music and video) instead of going into each files to retrieve music.The "wd2go.com" is pathetic and useless. I have called the technical support 3-4 times and not really able to help. The last one says something had to do with the JAVA software. I have done what the technical support asked and no result.The main reason I purchased this is that I can access files from a public desktop or office desktop computer without having to install any WD Desktop access software. Totally disappointed.As far as for home network, it a great network drive. It's a great backup and NAS drive.  As soon as you want to access from remote, I am very disappointed.

My house is full of Network Attached Storage (NAS) boxes. For several years I have been running a Netgear ReadyNAS Ultra4+ with, currently, four WD Red 2TB drives which are specially designed for NAS boxes. So it was a delight to see that WD used its own Red drives in the WD My CLoud EX2 - two 2TB drives.While this is advertised as a 4TB NAS, you'd get that much storage only if you configured the NAS as "RAID0", which has no redundancy for data safety. Unlike some other NAS boxes I've tried, such as theBuffalo LinkStation 420, WD appropriately ships the My Cloud EX2 configured for "RAID1", which mirrors the drives for redundancy, but dropping the usable capacity to 2TB. You can switch the WD to RAID0 if you want (as the Buffalo can be switched to RAID1), but I give props to WD for choosing safety as the default.Unlike the Buffalo, the WD My Cloud EX2 was very easy to set up - I downloaded the configuration utility which found the NAS on my network and set it up automatically. The control panel is easy to use with large and clear displays of status and control of features. And, wow, what a lot of features there are! I'm not going to attempt to list them all, but here are some of the things that caught my eye:- Distributed File System and Active Directory support- SSH root access supported (but if you mess things up, it's on your head)- DLNA and Apple iTunes server- The ability to mount an ISO image file on your network and serve it as a diskThere are several "apps" built in, including a somewhat old but serviceable version of the Transmission BitTorrent client. There are also a bunch of apps you can install from WD's web site and there are others you can find in a user forum for the line.Performance was right in line with my other NAS boxes, about 60MB/sec on a gigabit Ethernet network.WD also provides mobile apps for accessing your My Cloud box, and unlike Buffalo's, I found this easy to set up. I did miss, though, the ability to automatically upload photos from my iPhone's camera roll, something Buffalo's app does. You can do this manually, however. The apps interface through WD's MyCloud web service, and as I write this, that service had been down for many users for an extended time. It seems to be fine now, though, and I never saw an issue when I tried it.If you want to upgrade disks, you'll need to replace both at once, something that is nearly universal with two-disk NAS boxes. My four-disk ReadyNAS allows one-at-a-time upgrades. If you upgrade the WD, you'll need to do a full backup and restore of your data. WD offers a backup utility, but I didn't try it.Other than it being only a two-disk box, which precludes easy upgrades, I really like the WD My Cloud EX2. It's the best of the two-disk NAS boxes I've used (which is now three of them over the years.) That WD uses its own NAS-rated Red drives is a big plus in my book.
summary: Well-designed, competent, feature-full and easy to use

reviewText: This package works great with my Hero 3+.  Although I haven't timed them to be exact, they seem to last just as long, if not longer than the original battery that came with my camera.  The car charger is great for weekend outings so I can rotate batteries and be ready to video whenever I need to. Everything is made of high quality materials and seems to be built to last. I would definitely recommend this to anyone who needs a compact and convenient way to stay charged.

The first shipment of batteries were defective.  They won't fit nicely in the GoPro Hero 3+ battery housing.Wasabi Power customer service is superb.  They send replacement immediately.  The second batch works perfectly.  They fit smoothly just like the original GoPro batteries.  The batteries align well with the GoPro battery housing pins and no force needed to insert Wasabi batteries.After fully charged and let it recorded at 1080P Supervies 48 Fps, it lasted for about 1hr and 50mins.  Much better output than the original GoPro batteries.Both batteries can be charged at the same time with the new charger at 2A.  Very fast charging and compact.  I like the new charger because I can use my tablet charger to charge these batteries.  Do no have to bring another charger on the trip.
summary: Great batteries. Love the charger as well.

reviewText: These batteries are high quality and the double charger is a major plus to keep extra batteries charged and ready to go whenever you need them.  The price is unbeatable and the seller is awesome!  I very highly recommend any of the Wasabi products for the GoPro Hero cameras.

I purchased these for a dive trip to use with my new Hero 3+.  It shipped quicker than expected.  I was quite impressed by what you get for the price.  Would not hesitate to purchase this kit again.  Customer support from Blue Nook was great.
Now I have three GoPro batteries and can charge two of them at a time so except for the time to change the battery and memory card I can run my GoPro non-stop. Great product.

These work pretty well, but I can tell the charger is cheaply made.  It sparks big time every time I plug it in.  This worries me.  The batteries perform great though.  The only complaint is that the tape that is used to pull battery out of the GoPro is not as tight as Factory GoPro battery, and pulls away from battery when taking out.  Also, the tape is a tad bit thicker, resulting in issues when opening the battery compartment.  It causes the lid to the battery compartment to stick.  So I need a blade or something sharp to pry open the battery compartment.However, again...the battery itself works fine and lasts just as long as GoPro battery.
Excellent value for money.Batteries work seamlessly with the GoPro and comes with 12V car plug and wall charger.Highly recommended.

I've only had this for a month or two and charged the batteries only 2 or 3 times so take this review accordingly.  The quality of manufacture appears to be quite good. As others have mentioned, the batteries do fit a little more tightly than GoPro battery but it's a very minor issue. Battery life seems comparable to GoPro batteries and the dual charger is very convenient. Bottom line: this battery kit is an exceptional value.

I purchased this because the tuner on my 8 year old HD TV is not the best.  I switch over to this when a channel I'm watching keeps phasing out.  It does pick-up and hold more channels than my TV's tuner. The unit is small and compact.  The remote is relatively easy to use.  The EPG is useful. The recording feature is great (same quality as straight viewing) with a simple quick of the remote using the EPG listing.The two concerns I have are:  1) The picture quality is not as good as my TV's tuner (the colors are more muted).  I think this has more to do with the fact its feed thru one of the HDMI ports (I can't adjust the picture settings).  And it takes awhile to boot-up when turned on (about 1 minute).  And sometimes at the initial boot-up I recieve only audio.  I have to slowly channel up and down until finally the video appears.  I think this has to do with the signal strength. Also, with a poor signal, the picture slows and falls out of sync with the audio.  Again just channel up and down will bring them back in sync.

TV station only, this was not in the description or any of the reviews.The picture is great on my hdtv.I would recommend this to any one who is cord cutting from cable.This is a five star product just not what i looked for in a analog to digital vcr box.

reviewText: Came in on time and well packaged. I've never used one of these before but it seems to be slow and it has glitched a couple of times. I'm glad I don't have to rely on it for everyday hard use. I got it for emergency use and I'll keep it for that.

I also recently purchased an Xbox One and I am so spoiled now I cannot live without my voice commands (Xbox Go To TV, Xbox Watch ABC, Xbox Volume Up, etc., etc.) The HomeWorx HW-150PVR works immediately out of the box with Xbox One (search for MediaSonic in the Xbox One menu). Voice commands are spot on. I love it. I paired this with AmazonBasics High Performance Ultra Thin Indoor HDTV Antenna. I get crystal clear HD channels with voice commands and could not be happier.The recording function is also great. I have a 32gb flash drive attached to the unit for the times I need to record something (or many things). A 32gb flash drive should yield roughly 7 hours of HD footage.

it worked very well at first. then, almost a month later, it kept losing the signal and had to reprogram it. then it would just turn on to the channel search function. the pvr is okay, i recorded live video, but didn't get the timed recordings to work at all.

It has some issues but it doesn't cost much and NO monthly fees. Records well even in 1080 to a lash drive or laptop hard drive. I'm using a 64 g flash drive and it serves my purpose. IF you want a dvr with not much effort on your part THIS IS NOT FOR YOU. But if your willing to take the time to program this and set the recording time this work good.

We got this case/keyboard primarily because I can't type worth a darn on the "soft" screen keyboard on the tablet. This keyboard was like a breath of fresh air for me. While I don't use the tablet for word processing and the like, I do use it for email, facebook and etc. For me the keyboard was very comfortable to type with and had a very nice tactile "feel". I had no problem pairing this with the blue tooth on the tablet but I should point out that I'm very familiar with bluetooth in general. That said, it should be no problem for most people. The case itself is slick and slim looking and snaps to the tablet easily. It is a nice tight fit and is just as easily removed although I usually just leave the case attached. . It has some shortcuts across the top for accessing recent apps and for email which is convenient.The case can be tilted at a nice angle for upright use and also to lay flat (which I don't use much). It's rechargeable via the included usb cable and holds the charge for quite a long time once fully charged (the doc's say 3 months based on 2 hours a day). The keyboard does not have a numeric keypad but that's not a big issue for me.I can highly recommend this case especially if you're like me and benefit greatly from an external keyboard.
summary: Review of Logitech Pro Protective Case with Full-Size Keyboard

reviewText: I read plenty of reviews and watched YouTube vids on the Logitech and Zagg brand.  Hands down I prefer the Logitech over the Zagg which I tried out for 24 hours from Best Buy.  The Logitech case fully covers my Samsung Note Pro 12.2 tablet.  Gives me that extra piece of assurance of protection.  Was easy to pair through bluetooth, and looks great.  Works perfectly with my tablet and none of the keys stick like the Zagg.

I absolutely love Case Logic camera backpacks and own several. This one is not for cameras but it's a good basic laptop pack. That said a few things could be improved. We use this in the field for marine mechanical repair business. We need to carry a diagnostic computer and an ipad. It is nice and lightweight and features well thought out compartments as usual down to a strap at the bottom so you have something to pull on to get the zipper started. One thing I would have liked better is padding on the whole bottom not just at the bottom of the very back compartment and that padding is minimal too. Now this is all based on my particular use so this might not be an issue at all for most other users but on a moving boat padding is a must. I would prefer a waterproof ruberized bottom for my application but all in all it is still a great pack and fits a lot of items. The other thing I loved about their camera bags was the bright yellow interiors, makes it so easy to see your stuff. This one has an all black interior and we carry all sorts of small black items that are very hard to see with no contrasting fabric. I still would recommend this if you just need a VERY well made sturdy basic laptop backpack.

First of all - You can buy this product directly from Tivo for only $50 bucks but you will have to pay shipping which can be as much as $8 so don't expect to save much... (Really Prime!! - this is what my membership pays for? - Inflated Prices!)Product is great though. Seems like a well built product that will stand up for awhile. The back-light is nice and i love the find my remote feature...
$79 - what a joke - this thing is $49 from TIVO where I just ordered it.  Rip-off price and no Prime.  Sorry Amazon - this one's a no go from you.

First off, this is a well-made case that is definitely tough. I like the feel and the different options for wear and handling.Although, I'm having a little trouble coming up with a good use-case scenario for a ruggedized iPad Mini case that is oriented more toward on-the-job or outdoor use. Simply because I haven't seen iPad Minis deployed in those kinds of contexts. The Mini is really a consumption device, first and last, and is operated more comfortably without a large case. This case definitely changes the user experience (not in a good way in my opinion). So, if you really have a need for shock-and-wear-proofing your little iPad for outdoor or on-the-job applications where the multiple handle and wearing options are a necessity, this is a great option. If you're not in need of that particular feature-set, however (and most aren't) you might want to stick with a smaller and lighter case.
summary: A modular case for your top secret ops

reviewText: The case is certainly lightweight, durable, thin, and the straps offer multiple ways to keep your device from getting dropped.BUTThe straps attach to the removable cover which you would move from protecting the front or adding protection to the back, not the case you would always leave on the device. And the cover is pretty difficult to remove to switch positions, especially for kids.That isn't so bad as the cover stays on very well,  It has to be since this cover is what attaches the straps after all. You could just leave the cover on the back unless packing for a trip.BUTThe cover has no hole for the camera!So you will want to leave the cover off and just use the base protection which means you don't have the ability to use the straps, so that leaves me asking what the advantage of this case is.I will say the mute/rotation lock switch and volume controls are done very well, perhaps easier to use in the case than when out of the case... Also all ports are fully useable without restrictions.

I love the sturdiness & solid feeling of this case.  I love the ingenuity of the various attachments.  I've dropped it once & my mini survived.  There are two things I don't like.  First, Like some other reviewers, I sometimes have a heck of a time getting the cover off.  It gets a bit frustrating, and I catch myself not putting the cover back on, which defeats the purpose.  The second thing is, I REALLY wish there was a hole/port for the camera so you could still use it when you have the cover snapped onto the back as you do when using the hand strap.  They would have had to move one of the attachment points but I think it would have been worth it.  I really need access to the camera for barcode scanning and whatnot.  That said, it's a great case and it's the one on my iPad right now.  It could just be a tiny bit better.....

It's a neat idea - a modular case system for the iPad. Using four attachment nodes ("accessory nodes"), you can add straps, stands, and so on as you need.The case came with a couple of straps - a shoulder strap, a wrist strap, and a hand strap. The first two work as you might expect. The hand strap can be attached diagonally or straight. The straight fit seemed more comfortable. It's a very useful feature, but the strap itself could have been made of a more comfy material - it's a little "scratchy" if you have dry hands.The case system is minimalistic and light, providing shock protection. It's a little hard, though, to switch it from open to closed, as you have to pry the case off a bit. While it's in "open" configuration, it takes a bit of pressure to get the lightning cable through both sets of cutouts, as they don't line up exactly (not that they're meant to), but it's possible.Strange thing is when "open", the front cover - now flipped around and attached to the back - covers up the camera and rear mic. Oops. That could be annoying, if you plan to use the camera or videophone capabilities a lot.There's no screen protection when open, but you should have known this before buying it.When you register, you get a prism-shaped, hollow, stand attachment. In the hollow part are a spool for winding your power cable and a little space next to it for your power supply. Neat.Pros:Slimmer and lighter than most casesModular system allows customizationUseful accessories providedCons:When open and front cover attached to back, camera and mic are blockedA little hard to remove and flip front cover open/closed
summary: A nice idea, but some caveats

reviewText: A couple of other reviewers used the word "weird" to describe the ModulR case for the iPad mini. I consider myself pretty open-minded, so I've been trying to figure out how I can use this--and, yes, it does seem weird to me as a casual though frequent but static user (meaning I stay in one place, for the most part, when I'm using it).ModulR says it's made for mobility. They call the product a "mobility system" in the included brochure, and this pack itself is described as a "mini mobility pack." So, first off, I use my iPad a lot around the office and at home. I happen to like the non-slick feel of my leather-bound iPad cover with integrated handle--makes it easy to hold with one hand or two, and in all positions: sitting, lying down, even walking around over short distances. For my purposes, I don't like the ModulR's slick feel.I can see where the mobility system has uses when you're out and on-the-go. And that's what they're after...after all. The shipped product includes a shoulder strap, a wrist strap, and a hand strap. The first two obviously help you carry it around without holding it when you're moving from place to place--whether for work or play (think touring around a city and using your iPad to access travel info and to take photos). That's where I think it would really work well. As for the hand strap, well, one of the weakness of this product, I think, is that it's somewhat slick and difficult to hold securely unless your hands are sweaty and clammy.As for using the high-comfort case at home and the ModulR case while on the go, I think it's a hassle to change from one case to another.I'm going to leave it at that in terms of casual use.Where I think ModulR may have something here is in presenting a mobility solution not for the casual user but rather for the worker who uses an iPad as a regular part of his or her job. Maybe someone is moving around a factory and entering data or scanning/photographing bar codes or objects. Maybe someone is walking around taking orders at a busy restaurant and needs to have hands free for other tasks at times (then you use the shoulder or wrist strap, for example).This seems to be a new concept. Let's see how it plays out and whether ModulR can make something of it. I think the possibilities may be limited for the iPad mini version. The only accessories they sell for that, as far as I can tell, are a storage/viewing stand and a hip/shoulder pouch. For the full-sized version, there's a swing mount, a swing mount with lock, a wall mount, a car headrest strap (for use in the seat behind the headrest), a "quick stand," a "utility glove," a "hip holster/shoulder pouch," and a shoulder strap. Sounds pretty versatile.
summary: It's a "mobility system," best used for workers on the go

reviewText: ModulR describes its "Mini Case" for iPad Mini as a "flip cover," which I assumed would operate in the same way a flip-phone does - it should be easy to "flip" open to get access to the iPad.  Unfortunately, it's not.Yes, the iPad Mini fits snugly into the bottom part of the plastic case - no problem, there.  Then the top part clicks into place over the bottom, keeping the iPad secure but adding little additional weight.  The different straps (several are included) easily snap onto the various ports on the case, so you can carry the iPad in a variety of ways (by hand, by wrist, or by shoulder).But . . . and it's a big but . . . the case itself does not flip open.  In fact, it's fairly difficult to remove the cover so you can actually use the iPad - you definitely need two hands to do it, and even then, it's an awkward process.  And once the top part of the case is off, you have snap it onto the bottom of the iPad, and then unsnap it again when you want to close the thing up.  This doesn't make it easy to carry and use your iPad on the go.If you're looking for a hard case that will protect your iPad and make it easy to carry, then this should work for you.  According to the manufacturer, it is "shock-proof" (and "exceeds military shock standards").  It's also a modular system, meaning additional accessories (like a stand) are available.  But if you want an easily-removable case that will give you quick access to your iPad when you're out and about, keep looking.
summary: Solid, protective case for iPad Mini, but it isn't easy to remove

reviewText: This isn't an average thin and smooth case. It has lots of bumps and ridges but in a way that does not make it too large are cumbersome. It feels nice and secure in the hand. The protection afforded seems like it is very good. I haven't dropped it yet but image that it will protect the corners, edges and back very well. The screen should be relatively well protected too. Overall I have been pleasantly surprised by this case and would recommend it to others.
summary: Nice Case, Interesting Design, Lightweight, Secure

reviewText: This seems like a high quality product, and the modular idea is cool. But there are some weird design choices that make it impractical for me. First, the long strap makes it seem like a purse, while the short strap makes it seem like a women's wallet with wrist strap. Second (and probably the biggest drawback for me) is that the cover is not attached at all. You have to remove it, then flip it around and re-attach it to the back every time you want to use your ipad. Why not use a hinge or something, so it could simply be folded back? It's great if you need lots of protection and don't mind taking a couple of minutes to remove and reattach the cover every time you want to use your ipad, but...I don't. I want quick access. Your mileage may vary, but it's just not for me.
summary: Well made but weird design choices

reviewText: it's thin, but protects surprisingly well. i only wish it had a built-in stand that would fold flat when not in use. the stand is rather bulky, and other ModulR accessories can be pricey.

How is this getting positive reviews?The vast majority of my reviews are positive, but this thing is not impressive at all. When I got a sample for review, I honestly thought it was a ten dollar econo-case. When I found out it cost four times that much I was aghast.Yes, it's very thin and light, and while I'm not willing to test its ruggedness by dropping my iPad on the ground, it instills zero confidence that it would protect against anything substantial. The edges are rubberized... but very thin. I just don't believe that it would absorb much of a shock. As a protective shell, it would probably protect your iPad from a bump, or getting hit by a wayward object, but it probably doesn't offer much protection against dropping.And aside from that, it's awkward to remove and is mostly just flat, boring plastic on one side with a texture on the other. Frankly, while I'm not into status symbols and designer labels, I would be a bit embarrassed to carry around this case and show it to my friends who would undoubtedly have far more stylish cases.I'm not often so blunt, or judgmental in my reviews, but I really don't think this case is a good value and you probably won't be happy with this purchase unless all you really want is a super lightweight cover to protect it from scratches and to provide a handle. And even if that is all you want, I'm sure you'll feel you paid way too much. Two stars is rather generous.Keep shopping... you'll find much better options.

It is a shame it's not included with the card, but for me it was worth it. Adds significant class to the look of the card.  (see my pics). Lowered my temps perhaps 1 or 2 C at load. I mostly bought this for the aesthetics. Looks great through a case window. Comes with good installation instructions and screws. Highly recommended. EVGA delivers again.
Works great.

Beautiful case, but my first purchase came defectiveUSB 3 ports and audio jacks were not aligned to match the topof the case.Also all this models are missing 5.25-inch drive bays for optical drivesHow in the world am I supposed to install my Win 8.1
summary: Beautiful case, but my first purchase came defective USB ...

reviewText: a wonderful grip. works well very well, looks very nice, balances the camera also. For me this is a no brainer, I get a full days use out of my camera, I dont have to take the grip off and I love the look and feel. You only get about 700 shots, so some may want more. Its also reasonably priced.
Great grip really keeps the Fuji X-T1 balanced well.

For me personally, vertical grips are almost a necessity. I just cannot maneuver cameras as well without a bottom grip, and I shoot nearly a 50-50 split of horizontal and vertical shots--sometimes even more vertical depending on the subject of course (portraits, bridals, basketball). I pre-ordered the battery grip at the same time as the body, because I knew I would just have to have it to work well for me ergonomically.It isn't cheap. I mean that both ways: The price is kinda high for what it is, we all know that. Camera companies probably make more money on accessories than the actual bodies anyway. Lenses, grips, batteries. But it isn't cheaply-made either. It seems solid. The fit is just perfect on my X-T1. You need to take off a plastic cover over the contacts on grip(20!)and the rubber gasket over the contacts on the body and put the rubber cover into a recessed hole in the grip, align two strong pins on the edge of the grip that go into the body's bottom plate, then screw it down onto the camera. Easy enough.There is a leathery-covering over the top plate of the grip. It something I haven't seen much of on other grips, but it looks nice for the 10 seconds you see it before attaching to your camera. And I do believe it may be functional. The very assuring way the grip aligns with the body as the grip is mounted is nice. There are NO squeaks once the two parts are perfectly joined. The grip does not ever feel loose or move around any. It's just the way it should be.It does LOOK a bit big for what it is--which makes the camera look even more like a DSLR. That could be good or bad, certainly makes it taller, but its pretty slim (the cameras girth in general is much less than a DSLR). I wonder if there is extra space inside there, if there was some way they might have been able to fit TWO batteries in the grip (would probably be nice for extended shooting) but I don't think it would work. The battery kinda slides into the grip at an angle strangely, but its of no concern at all, just different.You keep one battery in the camera body. I chose to keep the battery I got with the camera inside the body, making sure it was fully charged first. With all my grip-enabled cameras, I try to just use the body battery as necessity, not for general shooting--'cause its a bit of a pain to unscrew and dismount the grip to change out the battery in the camera. But it is easy to change the battery in the grip. There is a little slide release that opens the door on the left side (from shooter's position) of the grip/camera. You have to slide it BACK into position, there is no spring-loading--just like the battery cover on the camera. There is a spring-loaded clip inside, that holds battery in position, also just like the camera.The controls work well. They basically duplicate what is on the camera. From top (vertically-arranged on the left) Focus Assist (abbreviated "F.A."), AE-L, and AF-L. Above and to the right is the selector wheel. All the buttons and the wheel look and feel exactly as the ones on the body. The SHUTTER  RELEASE is also very similar. Same size and pressure-release sensitivity. There is a lock ring around the shutter button that mimics the ON-OFF switch on the camera. It of course just locks the release, does not power the camera on/off. The shutter seems almost the same trigger-feel as the body shutter release--maybe just a tad bit harder or longer (I may be imagining it)--it's so close you will not worry about it. And maybe I just need to shoot with it more and loosen it up a bit.The grip on the camera FITS my hand very nicely. It feels solid, makes holding the camera in either position (H or V) more comfortable and grip-able (yea, that's what its for, huh?)I think your hand rests even less on the selector dials on the camera with the grip attached (the D-pad that is too recessed making it hard to maneuver--hmm, maybe they shoulda just designed a built-in vertical grip that was slightly smaller and then made the D-pad on the camera work better!).That's about it really. I'm sure if you are reading this you already figured most of this out, but I hope it was helpful anyway.I have already shot some product shots that I will attach here with the review or on the X-T1 body review. Maybe they will be helpful for SIZE COMPARISON, as many might like to see how the camera compares to a few others in terms of size.Thanks for reading ;)
summary: Makes the FujiFilm X-T1 even more DSLR-like...  ;) or :(

reviewText: The Razor Adaro Stereos – Analog headphones are comfortable with great sound quality and a sturdy build. There were a couple of draw backs however, nothing that would prevent me from purchasing them.Current headphones: Bose Quiet ComfortPro’s-The sound quality is excellent. This set of headphones has better low range sounds than my current Bose headphones.-Exceptionally comfortable for long-term wear.-The pads that cover your ears are soft enough to allow the wear of glasses and avoid air gaps.-The cord is thicker than my current headphone and seems to be better built.-Appearance: I like the old school studio feel.- The 3.5mm jack head is small enough to plug into an iPhone with case. It might sound silly but I’ve purchased a couple of sets of ear buds that I couldn’t use with my iPhone or iPad, when the device is in a case, because the hole in the case covering the headphone port is small.-Straight jack head vs. curved.Con’s-They don’t come with a protective case. I travel a lot and want a way to protect them when they go into my messenger bag.-They don’t fold or compact. Again, it goes back to storage during travel.Neutral-The noise canceling is ok. After owning Bose headphones with active noise canceling, passive (analog) noise canceling is never going to be good enough.Recommendations-With the vast adoption of Bluetooth across laptop’s, phones, and tablets; I would skip the analog version of these and go straight to the Bluetooth set. For $50 additional dollars it would be worth it not to snag the core on everything you come into contact with. Not to mention, $150 is cheap for wireless headphones when you compare them to Bose or other wireless sets ($300 - $400).In the end if you want a wired set of headphones these are a great option.
summary: Great Sound Quality and Long Wear Comfort

reviewText: For the level of comfort and sound quality you get with these headphones, I am very impressed with how these Adaros deliver.  Sure, they're nowhere near as good as Beats by Dre, but for 100 bucks you can do a heck of a lot worse.  I've been using these for nearly two months now, and I really like these headphones.First thing I noticed when I got these was how comfortable they were.  They have an adjustable track and can fit any sized head.  The headband is somewhat plush and padded, and very comfortable to wear for extended periods of time.  I have found wrap-around headphones at this pricepoint to typically have good sound but lacking in comfort, but not so here.  I've been wearing these at work for 8-hour stretches, and I pretty much forget they're on my head; big plus in my book.These don't lack in the sound department for this pricepoint, either.  They're a tad lacking in the treble department, but nothing that will bust the deal.  I listen to primarily electronic music, but I've also listened to classical, jazz, rock, and hip hop, and all sound more than serviceable in the power department.  I use these headphones with an iPhone 4, so whatever device you use will determine the playback a little, but if you plan on using these with an iPhone you won't be disappointed.I also like the neon green cord!  I've gotten some stares and comments on it, but it definitely gives these a further unique feel to them.All in all, I'm really enjoying these headphones, and I've used them every day since I've gotten them.  Very comfortable, they sound great with a lot of range, and they look cool.  What more do you need?
summary: Very comfortable and affordable with a very nice sound

reviewText: I was really impressed by these headphones. The sound quality is amazing compared to the small earbuds I've been using, and they're very comfortable. Highly recommended.
Can't get any easier or smaller eSATA enclosure.Don't like the white usb3 cable. Should have been black.Did like the logo is quite small vs the huge logo's on competing products.Works as advertised.
summary: Love the product-Hate the White connector

reviewText: I bought this product and left with junk from bestbuy.  I was hoping for a better signal but, ended up just shutting me out constantly.  It is not windows8 compatible and it is a very disappointing wifi adapter.  I will never recommend this for anyone.  Cheap is cheap.

I took this devise, plugged into my computer's USB port.  It recognized it, then began searching for driver software.  It found the correct software and installed it.  I pulled the ethernet plug and instantly I was cruising the internet wirelessly. (you need to have an internet connection for it to find the correct software as this comes with no software)  Works great with very high transfer speeds.  What more can you ask for.

These are the best headphone with mic I've ever owned.  They work great with a Bluetooth adapter I also bought at Amazon.  They pair easily, sound great, and people on the other end of my Skype conversation say I sound very clear.  There is a short lag when I first start a call where the sound is very loud and hurts my ears but then is normalizes.

I really enjoy listening to these headphones.  Bass is strong, volume is good, nice clarity in the vocals.  Headphones are well protected in the included case.  Paring was easy, to the Galaxy 4.  Recommended purchase!

I tried many of them and almost all were crap. This one works great! Signal is very stable, no interaptions, no hissing.My be not the best headphone, but consider it wireless it is great!A mic is a big plus -you can listen and talk.

this microphone has very bad sound and should not be used with DVC cameras. It picks up the cameras motor. all in all the sound was very bad. The internal mic on my camera is way better both in sound and it actually picks up less camera noise.

It will keep some people from seeing what you are doing, angles are very important here.However, it is very tight fit for the iPad, making it difficult to use.Closing the cover was a problem too.Having to struggle to use the item isn't a great idea to me.

The Leitz Privacy Cover Portrait with Stand for iPad 2/3/4 works well and goes on easy. It will keep peoples wandering eyes from seeing what you are viewing or working on. The stand is also useful.I also have the 3M Easy-On Privacy Filter and Screen Protector for iPad 2 and iPad 3rd/4th Generation - Bubble-Free Application- Portrait. The 3M costs a little less than the Lietz but there are some differences. The Lietz is a stand as well as a cover, where as the 3M is just a screen that attaches to the device.Both the Lietz and the 3M are really good products. The Lietz cost bit more but has more features and works well at what it was designed to do.I am pleased with the way the Leitz Privacy Cover Portrait with Stand for iPad 2/3/4 performs.

This "Leitz Privacy Cover Portrait with Stand for iPad" is my 4th iPad cover (I have a 4).  They fall apart too quickly, they show dirt too readily, they slip over the switches and camera lens,... I want a clean, professional looking cover with a tight fit.I am really liking this model.The stand is efficient (although there is no stand for a vertical orientation... ding!), the privacy cover works well (except you do have to push harder on the touch screen to make finger contact for using your controls... ding!), and it is good looking.  It is a problem that I can't use the "light touch" that I am accustomed to, but I am now getting to the "heavier touch" that this screen requires.Now let's see how long it holds up!The Leitz iPad cover with stand protects your iPad with a sleek, stylish design and the added functionality of a kickstand

Summary:This is a re-post from Head-FiAs part of the pre-release tour, these observations are based on a relatively short experience with the X5, but I think that I got a good impression of what it offers. The X5 is a solid DAP. If you like the Fiio house sound, the X5 will delight you. It has some great festures like dual mSD slots and a good UI. The Texas Instruments DAC provides great instrument placement on the sound stage too. The onboard amp didn’t wow me. It is solid and certainly acceptable, but it seemed too warm for me, with some bass bleeding into the low mids. Overall, it’s a good DAP, but I prefer a different sound sig from me equipment.My context: I use my DAP’s primarily at work, or while working around the house. I want a DAP that’s small enough to comfortably fit in my pocket, and is easy to use without looking at (mostly meaning change the song, pause, and adjust volume while its in my pocket). Up to this point I have been using the iBasso DX50 with a C&C; BH2 into Vmoda M100’s.My Music: I did the testing with about 60% FLAC, 30% 320 mp3’s and 10% 128-256 mp3’s. I included the low rez files because I have some legacy music that I cant/don’t want to pay to replace and was interested how it would do with low bitrate files, but these were not factored into how I think the X5 sounds. I only tested one 24/96 album and no 24/192, as I hear no improvement from super hi-rez music.Ergonomics:Looks: Personally, I think this thing is ugly. I heard someone compare it to a 90’s Aiwa CD player, and I totally agree. I guess they were going for a turn table appearance, but it doesn’t really work for me. This is fairly unimportant though. Also, for those of you that are going to rubber band an amp to it, there is very little room between the screen and the wheel for the rubber band, and it gets in the way a little bit. You may be better off cutting out a square from the back of the silicone case and Velcro-ing your amp to it.The Wheel: Personally, I am not a big fan of the wheel for navigation. The wheel seems solid enough, but I have concerns that small particules (sand/lint/grit) could possibly become wedged between the wheel and casing, or possibly get underneath it since the wheel physically spins, unlike an Ipod which is stationary. I work in a machine shop where micro sized metal chips are common. I could see one getting wedged in the wheel at some point, although this was not an issue at all on my unit. I’m just thinking if you’re taking this around to less clean environments, it may be an issue. Other than the wheel itself, I thought it took a long time to scroll through long lists. I only have around 50 albums on my SD card, but it took quite a while to get to the bottom, so those of you with large directory lists will get a good thumb workout.UI: I’ve been spoiled by a touchscreen for a while now, and going back to the wheel took some getting used to. Navigating the UI will get easier with time I’m sure, but I was not a big fan of it. It is fairly slow to get back to the Now Playing screen to change the song when you’re in the menu. Using the EQ with the scroll wheel is also somewhat tedious, but once it’s set you don’t really adjust it much, so I don’t foresee this as a big issue. Besides the interface, I like all the options included in the UI. It had some handy ones that the DX50 does not, like “power on volume”, left/right balance, and an integrated instruction manual. These are all great features.Another big plus for the X5 is a properly working random play, meaning; Next Track button plays a random song, Previous Track plays the last track that was played. On the DX50, the Last Track button goes to the song immediately behind the current file in the directory, not the last track played. This drives me nuts! Another feature I like more than the DX50 is the FF/RW function. It skips ahead at a good rate with minimal delay. The DX50 FF/RW is overly slow, and its much more useful just to poke at the progress bar until you get the time in the song you’re looking for.Timeout: The X5 only has a 8 minute maximum time out/shutoff which I thought was too short. I commonly get interrupted at work for more than 8 minutes, but less than 15 or 20. I have my Dx50 set to timeout after 20 mins, and don’t have to turn it back on frequently. With the 8 minute limit on the X5, I was turning it back on frequently, which was kinda annoying.Silicone case: If you change cards a lot you’ll want to note: the silicone case covers the card slots, so you’ll either be taking the case on and off a lot, or you’ll want to cut out slots for the cards. Also, if you’re going to use it Amped all the time, the silicone case has 2 little tabs that cover the LO and Coax out which kinda get in the way. I would cut them off and just buy the silicone 3.5mm plugs to cover the unused HO/LO/Coax ports.Play: there is a couple second pause between pushing the play/pause button and the player responding. Its about the same as on the DX50. The power up is slightly faster than the DX50 though. I like the menu option that allows you to choose how/if it resumes play where you left off.Weight/size: noticeably heaver than the DX50. Not massive by any means, but its substantial. Its boarder line of too big, but hasn’t quite crossed into that territory yet. Without an amp, its fine; with an amp, its pretty big and no longer portable IMO. It becomes closer to a portable desktop rig.Volume/Power: I used my M100’s for most of the testing, but also used Phillips Stretch headphones for a small comparison. I used High gain at around 35-50 volume. 40-45 was loud but comfortable. The M100’s are exceptionally easy to drive, so I cant really comment about the X5’s ability to drive 250-300 ohm headphones. One thing I like a lot more on the DX50 is that the Volume + and – buttons are separated by a quarter inch. On the X5 they are each half of “1” long button. I like the DX50’s 2 distinct buttons because they are easier to feel through your pants and easier to adjust without looking at the player.Now, on the the important part: The Sound.Do not have a large palette of high end DAPs to compare this to, mostly just the DX50, but have used Ipods, Sansa Clip+, Creative Zen, Zune, and the X3. For my comparison, I did No EQing to best compare one to the other (I mean, EQ off).First off, I think the Texas Instruments DAC does a good job of imaging and instrument separation. Most of the time I thought this was a plus, but in some recordings, it made the sound stage too wide or localized. I specifically thought that the guitar and drums on Dave Matthew’s Lie in our Graves were almost too localized.To me, the general signature of this DAP seems to be strong lows and mids, laid back highs. By that I mean the bass and mids stand out, with the treble taking a back seat. Sub bass ( <40hz) wasn’t as strong either.To my ears, the Lows on the X5 are boosted. They seem more present than on my DX50. This really comes through with things like a bass guitar, and the lower notes metal guitars with distortion. I think I heard the upper lows bleeding into the lower mids on a lot of rock songs like Godsmack’s Bad Religion, Weezer’s Pork and Beans, and Disturbed’s Voices.The Mid’s also seem very prominent to me. The vocals come across very nicely in general with a good, natural sound. Once thing I noticed: there is a certain frequency in some rock songs, a medium-high guitar note, that really pierces and seems overly loud. I noticed this in some of the rock songs mentioned above, and specifically in Korn’s Reclaim My Place.The Highs could use a little EQing up in my opinion, but I think this about most setups. I did about the same boost with my DX50 and got both players to sound about the same.I did some testing with the C&C; BH2 and the Fiio E12 via the LO too. I thought both the E12 and BH2 provided a better (to my ears) sound sig than the onboard amp. It seemed flatter/more neutral in general. The prominent lows and mids via the HO seemed to be more even via the LO to either amp. Comparing the LO of the DX50 to the X5, I highly doubt I would be able to tell one from the other in a blind test. 1 thing I do like about the DX50, is that the LO volume is variable. I know people go both ways on this, but I personally like it because I have sensitive headphones. With the X5, I could only use around  to 1/3 of the volume knob before it became too loud, and when in a very quiet environment, I only needed 1/6 to 1/8 volume. On the DX50, I set my LO volume to 230/255 and then I can use  of the volume knob. I know that technically you want the highest source voltage and lowest amp gain for the best THD ratio, but I still cant hear distortion using it like this. If you have higher impedance headphones, this wont be an issue, as you need more power to achieve the same volume. Overall the LO on the X5 is very good and clean. It will be a great source for any amp you strap on it.Final thoughts: The X5 is a solid player. Personally, I like my DX50/BH2 combo better at the same price point. I think the X5 has the “Fiio house sound”, and the people who like that will love the X5. I chose the DX50 after my co worker had me listen to the X3 and DX50. I instantly liked the DX50 more and have been in the iBasso camp ever since. I know lots of people like the Fiio sound though, so if you have liked their players in the past, im sure you’ll love the X5, especially if you’re coming from an X3. All in all, Im glad that I got to hear the X5, but it didn’t sway my love for the DX50.

Spotted this FlatWave Amped at a local warehouse store for forty bucks, and decided to grab it up as I've reviewed theAmazonBasics Ultra Thin Indoor HDTV Antenna - Made in USA,Mohu Leaf Ultimate Amplified Indoor HDTV Antenna,Mohu Leaf Paper-Thin Indoor HDTV Antenna - Made in USA, andWinegard FL5500C FlatWave Amplified Razor Thin HDTV Indoor Translucent Antennaversions previously, using the Mohu Leaf Ultimate currently to pull in over-air HD instead of using cable.The rating on the box indicates a gain of 20 dB, from this USB or AC powered amplified tuner, with a range of 35 miles.  I use the Mohu Leaf Ultimate at present as it has a 50 mile range, but I needed another flat antenna for our home gym and decided that the one channel I can't pull in (tower is 45 miles away) I would be OK not having in the gym.Hook-up is very easy. Just connect it to the cable in port on your HDTV, hang it up (you can lie it flat too) and do a channel search on 'air'. I can get 14 channels in the rural area I live and this antenna picked up 13; one is just out of range.  As with all the flat antennas, placement is key to successful use.  I powered the amplifier by the included AC adapter (connect the USB to the AC adapter), but you can easily power it via a USB port on your HDTV too.  NOTE:  I find that by using the constant AC power I have to do channel scans and auto tuning less frequently than when I use the USB port.As expected this antenna picked up all but one channel that was simply out of range for this antenna to pick it up.  NOTE:  Be sure that when comparing antennas to take special note of their range, as I've found them to be quite accurate.I pick up all the HD over-air channels (digital) and standard definition over-air that are available in my area with this antenna.  I'm sold on the 'amped' versions versus the non-amplified ones, as I think they provide a more reliable signal.I've yet to discover a flat antenna that doesn't do the job better than the old rabbit ear-type antennas, but be aware that your success with these antennas (Mohu, AmazonBasics and Winegard brands) will depend upon the following factors.1. Your location in relationship to the TV towers in your area.  You have to be within range of the towers to receive the signals, and the antenna you choose must have the power to reach out and grab those signals to send to the digital tuner in your HDTV.2. Placement of your antenna is key to gaining consistent quality signals and all the channels that are available.  Take the time to figure out what works best in your location.  Tall buildings, trees, mountains, the building you are in and tower location will all factor in.  NOTE:  If you live in a city, you may be able to get lots more channels than in a rural area, but the quality of those channels may still be affected by the previously mentioned factors.You need to do a monthly channel auto-search and save to get the best reception. Weather can affect over-air channels, so be aware that the reception you get may be pixelated or unavailable at times when cable is not.You CAN cut out cable TV bills by using this antenna.  I cut the cable cord and now use flat antennas (both Winegard and Mohu products...) to save $80 a month.  I use flat antennas for network channels and supplement with Amazon Instant Video, Netflix, Hulu Plus and other channels off Roku and Apple TV devices.I'm impressed with this USA made FlatWave Amped.  It's not very big, can be hidden behind a curtain or wall hanging, and has a generous 18.5' cable length.  It works as expected, is well constructed and comes with clear directions.  If it's priced right, don't hesitate to snap one up for your home, office or travel trailer.TIP:  If you want to hide the cable that's attached to your antenna, consider getting a paintable cable management system that can be adhered to your drywall.  About twenty bucks for around 12' seems to be the going price.UPDATE: 4/23/14I received so many questions about how to use flat antennas and get free over-the-air TV that I wrote a book on it.Simple Guide to Over-the-Air Free TVshows you how to setup your flat antenna, what to expect from cord cutting, how to supplement with streaming media and more. A non-techy book written for real people who want to save money and watch a little TV.
summary: 35 mile range is accurate, works great for pulling in over-air TV

reviewText: Easy to attach to the tv, works great in the Memphis area.  I had tried two other power boosted antennas (because they were cheaper).  This one works better.

It's an okay product. Nothing great about it. To much of low sounds and not enough highs. This is not a Sony headset. I am keeping this product just in case something goes wrong with the Sony headset I just got last week from Amazon.

I had this camera about a week and so far not taken that much with it so will add to these comments about later after a 2 week trip in the South West. This camera is a Point & Shoot so is not the cameras I will be relaying on, but its still a serious camera.As a pro photographer I'm not going into the camera specs or comparisons - you can get specs elsewhere for the pixel peepers as well as detailed reviews here. I am just going to give you my impressions of "feel & quality".Coming from a G11 this thing is much heavier and is not a "pants pocket" camera. Too big and too heavy, my pants would be around my ankles within an hour!! It feels really well made and will probably come close to DSLR image quality and it has features my Nikons don't. Well a lot happens in a couple of years.I bought it as the G11 was getting a bit long in the tooth and I was never happy with its noise levels or a 28mm wide on the lens. This camera is better at 800 ISO than the G11 at 100 ISO  and has a 24mm W/A lens. And that's what I really wanted. Try looking and see what you can find - not many.Handling: I have  problem with my left hand as I want to place my forefinger on top of the flash. OK if you don't use flash which I would avoid anyway preferring to let the camera set the ISO it needs. My Nikons I always shoot in Manual mode but this Canon will be in Auto for what it is used for. It seems to try to keep the ISO as low as possible. In fact you can limit the ISO highest number.I'll add more after 2 weeks of travel and use.Oh, one important thing I nearly forgot - I cannot connect this camera to my Samsung phone running 4.1.1.
