Nice concept. At first it worked great. Then it started to slid down on its own. Now it fell off the TV. It fell off right after the return window. Waste.
summary: For a while it's pretty good, and then...

reviewText: This is a great little contraption to keep my Apple TV stationary. I like how you can put it on the bottom to hang under your TV or on the top above the TV. If you don't like have boxes stacked on top of boxes ie: cable box, DVD/blue-ray player and anything else you might have, this is the perfect solution.

I'm not a gadget person, but I love this little charger!  It is small and easy to charge.  It charges your cell phone or tablet quickly and without having to find a power outlet.  I was taking video and pics of the ceremonial start of the Iditarod (in Anchorge, AK March 1, 2014) with my smart phone and my battery ran out.  I was able to hook up the power bank, put the phone and the power bank in my bag and let it charge.  It took about 2 hours to charge, but, hey, you can take it with you and let it charge while you go on your way.  I will keep it charged up and in my purse/backpack/bag where ever I travel!
I picked this up and I have to say it works really well,  Surprised me.  Recharged my Kindle without having to plug it in.  Very handy.

This device is perfect to carry around in my purse just in case my iPhone or my 3DS or my Kindle Fire run low on batteries. It's especially good for long days away from my car or outlets and I can still use my electronics without worry. The power button sometimes doesn't work right away, but it charges my devices wonderfully and holds a charge for a long time. Very convenient and easy to use.

I originally bought a Vizio, the new 480i 48" tv. I must have gotten a lemon, as the picture color is not consistent from station to station. The Sony Bravia I had before had wonderful color, no matter what source. This Samsung has that same wonderful color quality as my old Sony. I also love the remote... what a kick! It's like using a mouse on your TV! It's also very responsive to channel changes, souce changes and even quickly turning on. Both my old Sony and the new Vizio took a long time to turn on. Also there was a lag in changing channels or pushing buttons on the remote. I love to use the mute button, but did not like the time it took to engage, and then release. Not so with the Samsung... You turn it on... and wow fast picture. You push a button on the remote and instantly you're doing what you chose to do. Plus... you should see what they use for packing instead of styrafoam peanuts. What a kick and an innovative use of recycled paper! They're cute little 3 dimensional triangles!
summary: I know have a "room with a view"

reviewText: After going through my own setup experiences, I think the biggest problem is Samsung doesn't give much written info, but has you step through their process of how to set the unit into operation. After putting the stand assembly(which swivels)  on the TV unit and plugging in, they start a step process to get everything running. And one of the things that came up early was getting the remote working to control my receiver from Direct TV. I wasted a lot of time because the instructions just keep telling you to give it another try in order to get a response from the receiver. So I exited from that and proceeded to get the TV online where it was a 'dumb' TV basically. Then I tried with the apps for Netflix, Amazon and Mgo, which are the places where I might rent movies. All did good after I went through the sign-in. I stopped for that day, and resumed early the next day. As I powered up the TV, I received a message from Samsung that an update had been sent, and also from my DirectTV provider. I also noticed my cable box wouldn't transmit a 1080p resolution because I was using the component jacks instead. So after re-connecting to HDMI1, my picture came in like never before! And then re-tried the remote control on my DirectTV receiver, and now it worked just fine! I should comment about the sound, because my old HDTV had the problem where when I played a HD dvd, the output volume was so low I had to buy an amplifier and speaker set for a boost on the sound level. Well, the quality of the sound from this unit is very good, but the same problem exists for a dvd playback. So, a sound bar is probably in my future. There was a couple other features mentioned on the Amazon site for this series model about voice commands and hand signal recognition. I didn't need them, but it is not on this model anyway.(need to go to 6400 series) Overall, I have to say the picture quality is terrific and , for now, makes me happy with my purchase.--Update 4/22/14-After a week or so, the only problem I encountered is the "anynet+" feature which is supposed to let me control any other Samsung device with one remote. I do have a Samsung BluRay player, and it did control it as claimed. But it also added some kind of quirk where it reports to the TV every 10 min or so, and in the process blacks out whatever you're watching until the select button restores it. Don't know the reason yet, but I turned off that feature and it has worked well without it.
summary: I read many of the reviews on this model(UN48H6350), and it seems many had problems mostly with the 'smart' end of it.

reviewText: My family and I have had excellent experiences with everything Samsung, so narrowing down our choices to just Samsung was a no-brainer.  I'm not a tech expert but I did consult with my tech guru friends, who gave me great advice on what to look for.  They said to make sure it was 1080p and 120Hz for a better picture, among other suggestions.  I tend to research major purchases to death, and I was very pleased with the consumer evaluations and reports, showing this to be reliable and user-friendly, with an excellent picture.My parents are thrilled with the size, quality, and high performance of this Samsung, and my kids love it so much that they started a Samsung fund for our own next TV purchase.  Highly recommend it.UPDATE:  I'd like to add a few more details, since I've had more experience testing out the new TV.  The setup was very user-friendly, and the overall use is very intuitive and easy to manage.  My parents are older, so they are very intimidated by technology, but this was easy for them to get the hang of, and now they absolutely love it.The picture on this TV is something beautiful to behold.  We have gotten used to HD, but this is on another level.  Positively brilliant images, smooth moving, and almost an artistic experience in itself.  Who knew watching TV could be so breathtaking?My parents love to watch travel shows, and we frequently join them, talking about where we've been and where we'd like to go.  Seeing the incredible images of scenic destinations makes it almost seem like you are right there viewing it first-hand.  We are just thrilled with the picture quality on this Samsung, and very happy with our choice.  Hope this review helps someone.  Thank you for reading.
summary: UPDATED. My parents are intimidated by technology, but they quickly got the hang of this.

reviewText: I purchased a 55 inch Samsung LED TV from Amazon. Amazon was great. Fast and easy delivery. Unfortunately after 10 months, the TV stopped functioning at all. It made a clicking sound when you pressed the power button, but no image or sound. Fortunately, it was still under warranty. I contacted Samsung. They sent out a local repairman who fixed the TV. He mentioned it would have cost $1000 for the repair (replacing 2 circuit boards) if I was paying for it. It took him <3 minutes to switch the boards. The TV worked again. Now 2 years later - same problem. I called Samsung. They very politely told me that I was screwed. They would not fix the TV, provide parts or even a provide discount on the repair or parts despite the fact that it was the same problem the TV experienced 2 years earlier. Beware - if you do not want a very expensive paperweight after 3 years time, look at another manufacturer for your next TV.

The frame is very thin, so it's hardly noticeable.  The picture is amazing, and I'm very happy with the features of this TV.  If you're not interested in a 3-D TV, but want a high-quality TV, this is the TV for you!
summary: Beautiful Picture and Lots of Great Features

reviewText: Got this to replace a Samsung 28 inch from many years ago.The picture is outstanding, and the set-up was easy. The picture is ultra-clear, and almost 3D in a way-- you see "into" the picture.This seems to be top-of-the line for Samsung 32's.  Perfect for my condo - I think sometimes people get huge TV's that over take a room.  This is hardly the least expensive, but it does perform, and looks good.Then sound on this one is good to begin with, and immersive, but I did add a BOSE unit ( because I had one, not mandatory).Some may say 1080P is not essential on 32's, but I noticed a huge difference. 120Hz is hard/impossible to find on most 32' set's, and is very welcome.Multiple HDMI and USB ports are a plus, too.  Samsung SMART TV app's work, but you can easily add Amazon FIRE TV, andROKU, even ChromeCast, with ease.If you are gifting/replacing a TV for a friend or family member, this might be a higher-end choice . Worth it.Update 07/06/2014:Sorry about the 3D comment, which may have confused some.. but what I mean is the screen is ultra clear, and immersive, a vast improvement over my last TV. Of course this is NOT a 3D TV.I have played around with the settings ( see Jeff's suggestions in most helpful reviews) - his suggestions are spot-on. Lots of options here, almost too many.
So far so good! Amazing picture quality!!! Love it

This 55 inch tv replaced a 5 year old 52 inch Samsung, in order to get a larger picture.  But I found that this tv had a better picture in addition.  As with all tvs, the picture has to be adjusted to the owners preference and environment.I did not try the web browsing or any apps because I am not interested in these features. The picture quality and the price made this purchase a bargain.  The set was delivered on time, set up, tested, and packaging removed by shipper (Pilot).

Just what I needed!  A previous mini usb drive I had, only contained 4 GB and was not enough for the job I had in mind.This was perfect.  Even though I'm not a basketball fan, it is still cute.Works well and simple to use.

It works. You can easily store files on it.  It is easy to use with my computer.  It looks just like the picture and I have no reason to doubt it has the 8G capacity stated. The flimsy thread and ring thingy didn’t do much for me.  I would be afraid of the thread breaking and my losing the thumb drive.  Also I’m not personally blown away by the close-up decorative shot of a basketball.  But this is perfectly functional and that’s the main thing.
summary: Mine works fine, looks like the picture

reviewText: A nice surprise as I was expecting it later this week.  Upgrading from a Canon 7D and using it in conjunction with a Pany AF100.  Will be testing this baby over next couple of days, but I am waiting for an upgraded SD card for some compressed 4k shooting. :-)  Probably the most excited I've been about a camera since the AF100.  I do mostly video work, but shoot a  lotta stills.  Will do some comparisons between the Canon 7D and G4.  4 stars are just for being here ahead of schedule.Update:First impressions out of the box, coming from the viewpoint of an old Canon 7d user:I am comparing a Canon 7D with a EFS 17-55mm lens and the G4 with a Pany 14-140mm.The obvious:  The G4 is about half the size and much lighter but it still feels solid in the hands.  Crop factor is 2X (goes up to 2.3 in some 4k movie modes).  Interface is a nice step up from the 7D, although I'm having to get use to not accidentally touching the LED touch screen and going into some menu mode.  Oddly enough, the Canon zoom above is about twice the size of the Panasonic, but when comparing a Panasonic 100mm-300mm to a Canon 55mm-250mm, the Panasonic is about the same size but weighs more than the Canon.  You do get some usable reach with the increased crop factor which makes my Panasonic 100mm-300mm equivalent to a 200mm to 600mm telephoto.The articulating LED is definitely a nice feature compared to the 7D's fixed backplate one.  When opening the LED up on the G4, it feels a bit flimsy.  It seems to actually push up on the LVF rubber eyepiece.  I wonder how much use it will take before becoming a problem?The back video record button (used when not in "movie" mode) is not as easy to turn on/off when you have big thumbs.  It's nice that it crops the LVF frame when you are recording so it's real easy to tell if it is recording video or not.  There is a slight lag when turning video recording off so it's easy to hit the button twice because you thought you didn't stop recording at first.  The "movie" mode is nice in that it gives you the proper framing from the get-go in the LVF, and now the shutter button starts and stops video recording.  One thing I do NOT like about this is that apparently you lose the ability to shoot stills when shooting video.  And that goes for shooting video while in the "still" modes.  So in order to shoot stills in the middle of a video shoot, you have to end video recording and then shoot the still.  If you are in "movie" mode, you have to change modes.  I might be missing something as I seem to recall that you can shoot video and shoot stills at the same time with the G4.  I guess that's what the manual is all about. :-)Silent shooting mode is truly silent...7D has a quiet mode, but the mirror is still moving so you hear it pretty loudly.The LVF is a pleasure to use.  Nice and bright and unlike the 7d, you can use it for playback as well as menu selections.One thing that drove me crazy with the mirrored cameras is that when in live view mode using the LED, shooting a high speed set of stills basically disabled your LED.  I use an attached Zacuto EVF on the Canon LED and would shoot sporting events through it for video purposes, but every now and then I'd like to shoot a bunch of high speed photographs and this would often blow it for me as I would have to either take the Zacuto off and then look through the viewfinder or spray and pray using the blacked out LED.Looking forward to using the internal time-lapse feature.  The remote timer is another piece of gear I no longer need in my bag.I have had one problem so far. Some odd LED screen-to-black blips has been happening as I move the camera around.  The LVF does not do this, but there have been at least a dozen times when twisting the LED and rotating the camera body, the LED screen goes "off".  I'm at the point where I can pretty much replicate it.  I'm in manual mode (although I don't think that matters) and I will slowly raise the camera to about 45 degrees towards the ceiling with the LED maybe twisted at about 15 degrees.  The screen goes off and then goes back on about 1 second later as I continue in my arc.  Will test it further and take a video of my action.  Not a deal breaker, but it makes me concerned that there's something not right with this particular camera.  (I almost think it's the LED thinking I'm reversing it around to 180 facing because it only seems to do it when I'm raising the camera up slowly and putting a slight twist on the LED).Anyway, besides that one concern, I am looking forward to doing some comparison shooting, both video/stills with the two cameras.  Do not have a high speed SD card yet for 4k, but it's coming in the mail.  Will update this review when I get some of that done.
summary: Got mine just a few minutes ago (4/29/14)

reviewerName: Darren Levine "He shoots, He Edits, He freque...
reviewText: The GH4 builds on the success of the gh1/2/3, the GH3 many felt was a sidestep as opposed to being a forward step, but Panasonic did a few things to please the crowd, namely: the codec. the GH1/2 were great because of the hacks that gave them high bitrates, panasonic embraced this and gave the GH3 built in high bitrates, they've done it again with the GH4, makes hacks unnecessary.It's still early, and i'll update with more info as it comes.Some tasty highlights:-200mbit 1080 bitrate, no hack needed!-100mbit 4k (the AX100 tops out at 60mbit)-10 bit 4:2:2 uncompressed output, WOW! finally affordable 10bit!(well, other than blackmagic)Pair it with the Atomos Shogun-96fps slow motion, no it's not an fs700, but 96 is very nice! twixtor can do a LOT with that-All the fixings such as peaking, zebras, timecode etc...Even curves!-Ability to use speedbooster adapter-Addon unit for extra features/portsSome things im not quite onboard with-The Addon unit is huge, needs power, and i just don't see a use for most people's needs-Wish they would have figured out an internal ND filter, even just 1 would have been great-micro hdmi connector on the body is annoying, but not a deal killerSharpness/resolutionI haven't gotten a test chart in front of it yet, but the resolution looks pretty darn satisfying, they are taking a full sensor read instead of line skipping, so it's probably getting pretty close to that 4000 line mark.Moire/AliasingLooks well controlled, haven't seen anything horrible appear yet.Colors/CurvesI like them, feels warm overall and pleasing. And something i've been waiting for for a long time: a gamma curve to control shadows/highlights! It may not be as expansive as prosumer/pro video camera controls, but it's a very nice thing to have. The ax100 has basically nothing, just a cinematone on or off.10bit 4:2:2 outputFinally!!!! 8bit is remarkable for what it can do, but many have felt 10bit wide adoption has been overdue. It's tons more information and gives you far more to work with to grade your image. The cheapest recorder that can handle it at the moment is the $2000 atomos shogun, but hopefully we'll see some other options soon. Now if only they chose anything other than that hdmi micro connection....Lens choiceIs huge, you can adapt tons to this camera, including the speedbooster which as the name suggests, gives you a faster F stop when using larger format lenses. I'm also eager to try slapping on an old b4 zoom lens which i've tried with the c100 with mixed but encouraging results, and the smaller sensor of the m43 should be a big step towards usable with that. Or hopefully panny will come out with a power zoom version of the 14-140 and i'll be pretty darn content for event shooting.
summary: SOLID 4k 'budget' cam, Perfect? no, but really nice overall package

reviewText: I have always been dubious about "boosters" for signals, or "accelerators" for CPU's, and this device sounded like a "too good to be true" late night TV ad.  But I read good online reviews and I was desperate: stunned by outrageous Internet access fees from my land line carrier and knowing that Verizon had expanded 4G LTE service in my area, I had canceled my office land lines, upgraded my iPhone from a 4GS to a 5s, and eagerly awaited the blazing fast wireless broadband I'd get, basically for no extra charge.  But in one office, the 4G just CRAWLED, and was in fact much slower than my old 3G iPhone 4GS.  The awful truth dawned: while the iPhone 5s, used as a secure WiFi hotspot, did indeed deliver blazing fast broadband at one office, in an urban area, by various speed tests it was often slower than an old dialup modem, despite only one less "bar" (dot, actually) of reception.  Then this device arrived and saved me!  It's much cheaper than other solutions, about what I was paying for one month of Internet via land land DSL, yet it sets up instantly, fits most smartphones with its adjustable cradle (and instead of a dock, it wisely has a universal USB port), and as for performance--it ROCKS.  It boosted downloads to as fast as 14 Mb/s, and uploads to as fast as 10 Mb/s (by Ookla Speedtest).  Even with Safari, not always the fastest, web pages load instantly.  I'm very happily amazed.
Works as advertised. The signal strength went from 1 bar at 3G to 3 bars at 4G. Weaker areas of 1X to no signal went to 3 bars of 3G.

I purchased this product for use with my Dell Venue 8 Pro.  Although the Dell Venue 8 uses a micro usb slot for the power supply, my phone chargers were not powerful enough.This product powers my Dell Venue 8 as well as the charger that came with it.  It also charges my phone and other products that use a micro usb slot.
Nice cable nice price. Fits my Galaxy 5 phone

Purchased the Ionic 3.0 USB Data Cable for my Samsung S5. The plugs fits very snug (I Like). Charging works Great. Cable Lenght is 40" great for the Car and My Bed side Desk Also Traveling.I will Buy 3 More cant hardly beat the under $3 buck price for a Quality item.
Exactly as described and was delivered quickly.
These cables work really well.  Let's you charge your device in multiple places without lugging the cord around.  Great buy.
I could not tell the difference between the factory cable that came with the phone and this one that ordered from Amazon. It works great and saved me $20 if I would have bought it at the phone store.
I ordered this cable as an extra usb cable for when I travel with my tablet. It arrived fast and fit perfect. I have no complaints about this cable from this seller.
its just like the original Samsung cable.

I installed this in my wife's 2013 Kia Sportage because she didn't like the look of the stock receiver.  I was going to purchase this receiver from Crutchfield, but amazon was much less expensive and with prime I had it in 2 days.  Neither amazon or Crutchfield said I would be able to keep the steering wheel controls, but I found a wire harness from axxess I believe that worked.  Overall the receiver is fine.  Picture quality with the 20 dollar camera and the dvd I tested were good.  The screens when using the radio or bluetooth are pretty boring and I've found that the only way for the receiver to control either an iphone 5 or galaxy 4 is to have the music playing and then power down the receiver then turn it back on.

I bought this camera because it has so many positive features and attributes. However, it is saddening to see Panasonic choose to use a proprietary cable to charge camera battery inside the camera. I am surprised a this for a couple of reasons:  1) sometimes these batteries expand if accidentally overcharged. In this case, this would render the battery likely to be unremovable from the camera. Second, since the charger connects to any USB power supply, any supply could be used, therefore tempting the possibility that the battery could be overcharged in the camera.There are many OEM battery chargers out there than can charge the battery ... but Panasonic does not offer an OEM version of an external charger ... very sad.

Seems to lower temperature.  It has some soft rubbery, I'm guessing heat transfer pads that cover the RAM on the back, so it probably helps lower their temperature a little bit.  I didn't too a ton of testing before/after, so I can't be sure it's dropped temperature, but I THINK it is.  This backplate does get a little warm so I'm guessing it's at least spreading the heat from the RAM on the back and wicking a little heat off of the card.Install was easy.  It comes with two sets of screws, one for the 'reference' cooler (blows air out the back) and the ACX models.I have the reference cooler and I think I removed 5 or 6 screws, positioned the backplate, and used the replacement screws supplied.Definitely protects the myriad exposed components on the back if you swap cards a lot.Given the potential for damage from swapping this card or the others around it, I think backplates like this should be standard on all cards.  (I also feel the same way about motherboards-one accidental scrape against metal standoffs can kill the mobo).
summary: Should just be part of the card

reviewText: So heres the thing. i tried to think on how a metal slat would make something look better? Sure I figured it would help dissipate heat but how would it make it look good, like the ad says? Well it did just that, after I got it on the card it looked far better than I had expected. It also does cool it down an additional 2-3 degrees c during high loads and up to 5 on idle!Con: It should of been on my card to begin with!Pro: It does what it says it will do, both in looks and heat adjustment!

Early Impression (before using Traffic): I got this device from TomTom to review it. Both of our cars (1 and 2 year old) have built-in navigation, one of them with a touch screen, and our phones have turn by turn navigation too, yet TomTom provides a better experience with excellent information display, a fluid touch response, smooth graphics, and a familiar interface.I can already say, if you have an aging TomTom GPS, and are looking to upgrade, this is definitely a good time. If you are coming from other brands, you won't regret switching. If your car's built-in navigation is no longer up to date, you are probably used to older technology, and this GPS will blow your mind.Long story:Our last two GPS devices were TomTom (Go 720 from 2007, and XXL550TM from 2010). We tried other brands, but we always returned back to TomTom. I am very picky when it comes to the look and feel of the interface for things like GPS devices and video streaming devices, which do just one thing, and they have no excuse for not getting it right. TomTom had it right on the devices we owned before, I liked the way that icons are big, shortcuts are where they need to be, and things that you may want to see, are either already there or are very handy. I am glad to see that they are sticking with what they got right.The highlights of Go 500 for me are:0) Natural way of entering addresses. After so many years of using GPS devices, I didn't realize how stupid it was to enter an address in the order of state, city, street, number till I used the new Go 500. What a relief! It saves tons of time too, because the device takes care of figuring out how to map the address to its parts.1) The capacitive touch screen (like in your smart phones) is far easier to use that the pressure touch screens.2) I don't know if this is a real thing, but I feel like my mind is more comfortable looking at the smooth animation of the map, compared to the inch-by-inch jumpy scroll of other navigation devices I own. Perhaps the anticipation of how the map will refresh at every second unconsciously keeps the mind busy, or maybe it is just an aesthetic improvement, but you will not want to go back to anything that doesn't have smooth graphics, including the built-in navigation of some high-end cars.3) Distance to gas stations on the right vertical column. This is the best display of POI information I've seen. It gives you how far you are from a gas station at a glance, without needing to interact with voice or touch. When you are panicked, getting lost in the POI search menu is the last thing you'd want to do.4) The way the device attaches to the cradle is super easy, finally. I got used to the old way of turning a large flat screw on the back of the device. It worked when you got it right, but was an ergonomic torture. Now, there is a docking plug (like ipods used to be) and a catcher dent in the back, which together hold the device in place. Installing the GPS is as easy as putting your ipod on a dock.5) It is super fast.Cons:1) The round shape of the TomTom is their signature, but if the bottom and back could be flat, it would be much easier to use as a replacement for built-in navigation of my car. There is already a huge display on which I can temporarily place the gps.2) Voice commands are nice for simple things, like "go home", but you cannot just say the address.3) You need to scroll through the icons for navigating the main functions. The screen is big enough to have three rows of icons, it is needless to have to scroll through the main function icons. When driving, if I don't see a function, it is as good as it is not there.I will update this review as I get to use it more. I am especially curious about how well the traffic function works, as it seems like traffic is at the center stage in this model.
summary: Excellent information display, a fluid touch response, smooth graphics, and a familiar interface.

reviewText: I've looked around between the Nikon P330, Coolpix A, Sony NEX-5T, NEX-6, and A6000. Basically, I personally found the P340 to be the best value. I bought the P330 two weeks ago and thought that I could save $$ by just buying the P330 & the wifi adapter (WU-1a). I was wrong. The P330 was ok but having a wifi dongle was somewhat of an inconvenience because it's an extra accessory that you have to hang on to and bring everywhere, not to mention trying not to lose it since it's so small.I had to return the P330 but was stuck between the Coolpix A (imported) and the NEX-5T, which both are around the same price. I like the Coolpix A but aside from the fix(prime lens), you would also need to buy a wifi adapter. Downers.The NEX-5T was good, but the EVF and dial modes on the NEX-6 was a no brainer. BUT, I found out that the A6000 will be coming out soon, and will have everything the NEX-6 has plus few added features like higher resolution, more focus points, etc. But at the same time, it is about $800. More than what I originally wanted to spend. I mean for just a couple more hundreds i could get a D7100 DSLR.So I decided that I would opt to just exchange the P330 for the P340. And so far I'm really glad with the decision. Main difference between the two are the built-in WiFi (aside from transferring images, you can also control and take photos using a compatible phone- I use an iphone 5 and didn't have problems connecting, transferring and taking pics using my phone. Another is the control ring, where you can assign it's function from zoom to focus to aperture. And I really like that feature. It adds manual control of the camera.I kinda don't like that when you use it for focusing the image on the display zooms in to the area of focus and then zooms out when you're about to press the shutter, but I can live with that. I also noticed better/faster focusing on the P340 than the P330, as well as better image quality overall than the P330.This is my first impression so far, with just a few hours of play with the P340. I like the build quality, the user-friendly controls, the color, the simplicity. Cons for the P340 are the relatively slow writing of images, slow menu navigation/processing of changes, double confirmation prior to deleting images (which may be a good thing but I wish I could turn the double confirmation on/off), manual focus with the control ring or the in-camera controls, and relatively low battery life.Overall, I would still recommend the P340 for those looking for an affordable, quality-built compact camera with built-in wifi, RAW and full manual control,

A great review on the P340. [...]Nikon has not improved on the build quality or on/off and menu lag that the P330 sufferers from.By far the P310 is still king of the hill when it comes to build quality and functionality and and half the price.  The P310 produces no real world difference in image quality despite it's slightly smaller sensor.Either get a P310 or wait another year for the p350.
summary: Suffers from all the sakes things the P330 did. P310 still king of the hill.

reviewText: I purchased my Nikon P600 a week ago and returned it today. There were a few things that concerned me before I bought it, but I didn't see any one of them being a show-stopper. Using the Nikon P600 made me rethink my concerns and I discovered a couple other issues that were show-stoppers, at least for me.Concerns before I purchased it:No way to add any accessories to this device, not even a lens filter for protection and no lens hood option.No RAW format.Concerns after I purchased the Nikon P600:No lens filter available at all:The first day I took the camera out for some shooting, it started drizzling. It made me realize just how many times I clean my old camera's lens filter every day I use it. A lot! Dust, rain, whatever, I am always striving to keep it clean. I thought about the fact that I have no way to protect the lens of the Nikon (except a lens cap, of course) and every time I cleaned it I introduced the chance of a scratch or worse.No lens hood available at all:It didn't take too many shots with the Nikon P600 before I realized that I was seeing some of the same kind of wash-out in some shots that my wife gets with her Canon SX30 with the same kind of sunny sky shots. I take the same shots with my Panasonic FZ-100 (with a lens hood) and I get no wash-out at all.No RAW format:I didn't know if I would miss RAW or not, although for the past year I have been shooting nothing but RAW with my Panasonic FZ-100. But I realized right away that I did miss it. Knowing that with the jpegs, any editing I do causes some loss of data started to bug me some. Why Nikon doesn't do RAW is beyond me!Showstoppers:1. The LCD display on the Nikon P600 works beautifully indoors or in the shade, but try looking at a shot in full or very bright sunlight and the screen washes out so bad there were times I couldn't tell if my shot was in focus or not! That got irritating very fast!2. The zoom. Yes, I know, the zoom - the very thing that makes this camera so attractive also was, for me at least, a major issue. When it works it is amazing, really. You can take a photo of an object that is so far away! Unfortunately, the zoom would shift into and out of focus all the time! Not just at the distance shots either. Most often I would be forced to press the shutter half-way to get it to focus at all. I know this action is supposed to "lock in" the focus, but neither my wife's Canon nor my Panasonic make you do this to get any focus at all. And what was really irritating was that this happened with video all the time, too! It made video shooting a pain.So, when I added up all of the issues above, I came to the conclusion this camera was not for me, so I returned it today. I'm going to now wait for the Canon SX60 to come out. In the meantime, I'll stick with my old and trusty Panasonic FZ-100 which still takes great photos, even though it can't zoom as far as the Nikon could.

I purchased 6 Nikon SLR cameras including 2 DSLR (D70 and D300) in my lifetime because of  very easy to use , best picture quality  and the dependable product.I am very disappointed that the Nikon produce  such a poor P600 camera.I return the camera after 3weeks of try and replace with Canon SX50HS.I am  reviewing P600 by just Pro and ConPro: 1)Very light camera to carry around.2)Able to zoom in to  equivalent to that of 1440 mm lens in 35mm format3) Video quality is very good as long as  not zoom in during the video recording.4)Day light Picture quality is  good as long as not zoom in too much. Better than SX50HS.Cons:1) Auto focus is very  slow and very difficult to focus at 4x digital zoom range andsome time unable to  focus  compare to the SX50HS2) Very difficult to position  a subject at center of frame or where you want be at 4x digital zoom even using the  tripod  because of camera movement  when press shutter release button( need a remote control but not optional)3)Zoom in and out is very slow but quiet compare to the SX50HS(SX50HS is very noisy).4)Does not focus good when zoom in during the video recording compare to theSX50HS5) in/out zoom does not stop immediately when release the zoom button  during the  video recording. It is very difficult to set the  zoom position exactly the way you want the close up  compare to the SX50HS6) The Raw file is not available. (SX50HS have the Raw file but unable to use at Auto Mode)7) Macro focal length is pre set only at 4.3mm therefore  unable to take the  very close up  flower and insect etc. but the picture quality is  good.8) Very Poor picture quality at 4x  digital zoom and  very high noise(very Good at 2x digital zoom better than SX50HS)9) There is a moon picture mode but quality is unacceptable, SX50HS is much better quality.

I love this camera. It's kinda the perfect point and shoot for travel. There's just one strange thing in the firmware they really should fix. If an Eye-Fi card is inserted and the settings are set to use the Eye-Fi you can't use the "Connect to Device." That makes perfect sense. but if you disable the Eye-Fi, you still can't "Connect to Device." In other words, The Eye-Fi when disabled should act like a regular card but it doesn't. Come on Nikon--update your firmware. Also update your lame iOS app. Looks at Samsung's for pointers.
summary: Love it but doesn't play entirely nice with Eye-Fi and iOS app is barely useful. Come on Nikon, make this the best P&S ever!

reviewText: First off, this is an upgrade to the fairly popular AW-110, and there's a ton of YouTube videos that list the features and show comparisons to other cameras. I suspect that Nikon wanted to compete with the Olympus TG-2 with this model, which has similar features. The biggest upgrade here is the 24 mm wide-angle lens and faster maximum aperture of 2.8. The Olympus still has an F2 lens. There is of course a GPS, and Wi-Fi. I don't much use my camera as a compass, so this really wasn't a big deal for me. I can see where the Wi-Fi could come in useful for remotely controlling the camera.  Nikon has also added a number of new video formats. Admittedly at highest resolution you're going to generate some humongous file sizes. Even a short video can run 500 to 600 megs. I suspect most people would be happy with the 720 mode.I would not get too wrapped up in megapixel rating as the sensor sizes are generally very small in point and shoot cameras.  More megapixels does not necessarily equate to better images. In fact, it usually means more noise. I'm not sure how this camera stacks up against other point-and-shoot cameras in its class as most of my other gear is pro equipment. To me, I see a fair amount of noise even at ISO 400, but again I think this is pretty common for this price level camera.There's a number of things that do bother me about this camera. One is the zoom. I don't know if I have a defective camera, but the zoom is very jerky, and not smooth at all. Occasionally (Frequently)  it just zooms all the way out or all the way in instead of settling at an intermediate step. I'm going to contact Nikon about this as again, I may have a defective camera. I have been unable to take any professional looking, smooth videos.The focus is fairly fast. I will have to play a little bit with post production with the images, but the camera needs lots of light for best results.  I really would like to see an even faster lens. As to apertures, there is basically two. I believe it's 2.8 and 4.2. (Fireworks mode does stop the camera down more, but also changes the white balance). There is no way(mode)to stop the lens down further for greater depth of field or any kind of creative effects. The cameras is capable of slower shutter speeds, but you would have to put some neutral density filters in front of the lens if you want to access them for creative effects. I believe the Olympus has an advantage here.My understanding was that the older 110 model came with a filter adapter to allow you to use 40.5 mm filters, but this new does not include one. I'm not sure if they are available as an accessory or not.  There are quite a few "Scene modes" and then an easy auto if you really don't want to think about anything. Namely the camera will do its best, based on its programming, to get you a good picture. The auto mode (different than easy auto mode and scene mode) gives you much greater control, and you do have the option at least of turning the flash on and off, using fill-in flash, or slow sync, redeye reduction, timer, macro mode, etc. each scene mode add some kind of attribute. The party/event mode for example adds a redeye reduction, the close-up mode puts the camera into macro mode, the sports mode uses a high shutter speed, the fireworks mode turns off the auto white light balance, and puts the camera into a different color temperature and stops the lens down more and decreases shutter speed, the list goes on. The more you know about photography, the less you would be likely to use these modes, but I'm sure many people will appreciate them.If you're interested in more of the auto features I think these are very similar to the older model, and you can read about them in other reviews. I actually wish there was more manual control, but not very common with point-and-shoot style cameras. All the buttons are very small and pretty tough to read. I think you may be able to press the shutter release with a pair of gloves on, but other than that you would have to remove gloves to operate. Here again I think the Olympus has an edge.I was able to see the screen in sunlight, but it does tend to wash out. You can see well enough to compose your shot. I believe Nikon also attempted to improve the image stabilization as I see there is a "hybird" mode now. I really can't comment on how well it works over previous models, but my handheld videos look quite good.Color accuracy looks quite good, and I suspect resolution is decent for this class of camera. Again, don't be fooled by the 16 megapixel rating. My eight-year-Canon D-20 takes much better pictures at eight megapixel with less noise. Of course, this started out as a $1500 camera, so not exactly an apples to apples comparison.I would say for the price this camera has a lot of outstanding features. It's small, lightweight, has some pretty nice video with plenty of options, and image stabilization seems very good. The scene mode gives you loads to address most situations, but don't expect manual control here as you're not going to get any. I would say the still modes would give you good enough quality to produce a very nice 16 x 20 print. I even tried a 24 x 36 print last night and it held its own--impressive. The fill-in flash mode worked very well in my few test, whereas used as a main flash it's a bit harsh. Again, pretty typical for a point-and-shoot.I only tried a few underwater shots, and did not even have the camera set to the proper mode, and got some good results. I think this camera could easily replace something like a Go Pro, and you can actually frame and see what you're shooting! Overall I think it represents an excellent value. Oh, I will add that I accidentally dropped the camera from 4' (thought I had it attached to the tripod screw and did not-ooops!) and it bounced a couple of times on my laminate floor. Not even a scratch!I'm taking off one star for the very poor zoom function.if you would like to know about any specific feature please don't hesitate to post a comment.Beat out the Black addition of the Go Pro:See [....]

I've had the camera for almost month and took a lot of pictures in Las Vegas. The last day there I noticed that the focusing was not working and the image in the viewfinder was flickering back and forth. When I tried to take a picture it was blurry.The main reasons I bought this camera was for the WiFi and manual modes. The camera has a lot of bells and whistles but I'm very disappointed in the way it all of a sudden had these malfunctions.I have several NIKON cameras (DSLR w/lens & Point & Shoot) that I'm very happy with. This one I sent in today for warranty and I'll see how that goes. I'll amend this review after I get it back and get to use it for a while.I give it 2 stars because I think overall the camera has great potential, but the one I got in particular has issues. Hoping for the best.06-08-2014 - EDIT: Getting the camera to warranty was painless, easy to do via NIKON's website. So far so good!
summary: Not real happy with this camera at this point... (Edit)

reviewText: Like them cheap and useable, tho do not drop it it gets broking fast. Make sure u have screen and case for its safety

MeMO pads are out for a while, but this particular model seem to be a new design from Asus with a new processor. I bought 2 of these to replace partially broken Acer iconia A100 and Asus Transformer TF101.  Compare to those two, the MemMO pad havepros:+ better screen, the ips screen is sharp and have good colors even it's not a high res screen+ the 1.6GHz Rockchip quad core processor (see image) made the MeMO pretty fast, more responsive+ lighter and smaller due to smaller black bordercons:- Have not run the battery all the way down to zero, but battery life seem to be a bit worse than the other 2 by look a the percentage left after an hour of use- only have pink color. I bought kmbuy cases to cover most of the pink- no HDMI outsame:= the camera for all 3 about the same => not that greatOverall a very good  tablet for the price.  The price for two is still less than most the tablet out there.
summary: Good value for a perfectly usable tablet

reviewText: My son bought this for me as a birthday present, and I am honestly thrilled with it.  It has the same Android operating system that my phone has, and I can use all the same aps on both.  I needed it primarily for viewing TV shows and movies via Netflix while I walk on my treadmill - so it is part of my at-home exercise program - but I will also use it for reading books via the Kindle ap, and numerous other things.  I would rather use this instead of my phone for most things, because it is so much larger and easier for me to see.  My only complaint is the sound is weak.  If the room is quiet I have no trouble hearing it, but my air conditioner is kind of loud so I struggle to hear my TV show.  I might get some little add-on speakers.
summary: Arrived in perfect condition, works beautifully, love the color.

reviewText: Excellent screen and sound ...fast processor ...everything you need you'll find on it. If looking for something by this price it's the best.

When in the market for a windows tablet, it took me a while to compare the options, concerning price, quality, etc... I decided on this one mostly because for under $400 and what it offered, seemed like a no brainer if it performed decently.I am a gadget freak, have iPhones, Windows Phone, Power gaming laptops, Macbooks, iPads etc..... I primarily wanted a windows tablet due to my work being based on windows programs in the intranet and the office student inclusion was a huge plus for my school. So, quick list, no big explanation...ProsSmall but good viewing screen and brightKeyboard docking included (my version from best buy was $350, didn't include the 500GB)Tablet itself is really responsive to touch, no hold ups, rotates fairly quicklyWindows 8.1, fully functioning OS (have iTunes installed, few games, and also connect my Nike+ watch amongst other things)MS Office student is huge, works greatThe thing overall just runs smooth, can have multiple apps running, no hold ups, and the tablet based games are pretty awesome and good graphics surprisinglyDecent battery lifeConsThe keyboard, though at this price point I shouldn't bicker, is just bad.. It's clunky, loud, mouse pad buttons are like firing a BB gun.it takes forever to charge. I know I've read this somewhere else, and I've tried several different plugs, surge protectors, etc... to no availAt the end of the day you gotta take it for what it is, and be pretty impressed. ASUS has always come out with quality affordable prodcucts, and this adds to their list. It's a sub $400 fully operating Windows 8.1 (not the dreaded RT) tablet with a dockable keyboard. The tablet itself is pretty sweet, and the keyboard, though flawed, is a plus. It's a great quick work - email - news tablet, and also functions as a decent news reading, games etc...Is this the end all tell all tablet / laptop / netbook thingy? No probably not. I'll still hold on to my gaming cyberpower laptop, the MacBook for editing and my iPad for everyday use. But this will definitely add to my arsenal of work, play, photography etc... Decent grab for anyone just coming to the market space or wanting to add something extra to their list
summary: For this price point, this thing is worth it IMHO

reviewText: I did a bit of research before choosing the ASUS T100 2-in-1 (I'll just call it the T100 from now on). I wanted something useful, current and affordable. The T100 was the best choice, and it has received good reviews all over the Internet. I received mine a few days ago and, like many other reviewers, will share some tips and ideas. Many items below have been mentioned in other reviews here on Amazon, so thanks to those reviewers for their advice (of which I followed!). I've updated some information based on those tips as well.1. You'll be extremely eager to use your T100 out of the box. Don't. Use it, that is. You can be as eager as you want. The user manual -- apparently updated recently -- specifically states the device must be charged for a full 8 hours prior to use. Charge it. 8 hours. No less.2. My model, the T100-TA-H1-GR (32GB with 500GB hard drive), came with an AD adapter -- no USB adaptor as mentioned by others. The user manual -- very generic -- states that different models of the T100 come with different types of adapters. I'm perfectly fine with the AC adapter. It's a microUSB adapter, so many standard chargers will work. (Though the charging may dwindle to a slow trickle)3. Don't dis Windows 8.1. I've been using the Metro/Tiles screen, and I rather like it. You can easily switch back and forth between that view and the normal desktop, though. I've yet to confuse myself (and sometimes that's pretty easy to do). It also walks you through an insanely easy "set up" system the first time you log on. Just have your network password ready and your Windows account information if you have one.4. Check your BIOS version prior to doing anything else. Here's how you do this: Click the Start button, choose Run, and type in "msinfo32". On the screen that pops up, one of the lines will list your current BIOS version. The latest ASUS  BIOS is 304, and that's what was installed on my system. In fact, everything ASUS was current.5. As stated in another review, you should go into your settings and change how Windows Updates works. Choose the "download updates and let me choose whether to install them". This way, you can ensure you're plugged in and have enough power. When I first checked for updates, I had over 46. It took a while. And quite a few "reboots." Once that's done, you can start having fun.6. Somebody mentioned a program called "StartIsBack". It allows you a better Start menu in the desktop view. I tried it. Loved it. Bought it. It's currently only $2.99, and I think it's well worth the cost. At least until Windows fixes the Start menu.7. I think the 32GB version is plenty. Why? I have a 500GB hard drive and I also put a 64GB microSD card on the tablet portion. Important to note: If you detach the screen/tablet from the keyboard, you do NOT have access to the 500GB drive, so your apps and documents MUST be saved on that microSD card. 64GB is plenty of space for my music files, as my normal documents are all stored in the cloud (I use DropBox and much prefer it to the Microsoft OneDrive system).8. The touchpad and keyboard take some getting used to, but I've had zero issues with either. Again, know what you're buying. This is NOT a full-sized laptop.9. Get a stylus. Period.10. The screen resolution is FINE. I know this is a huge deal for many. If you're that hung up on it and you're a power user, why are you buying this in the first place? I Facebook, email, browse the web, listen to music, watch movies on Netflix, and sometimes use Office. This works great for all of those.11. Yes, the full version of Office 2013 (Home and Student) is included. This is a great deal, btw. You can use the Windows appstore for apps (hugely disappointed in their selections right now, though) or install full versions of software providing you have space on either the microSD card you install or the hard drive. For music, I have iTunes on the hard drive and use the Music app when I'm in Tablet mode. (My files, remember, are on the microSD card on the tablet portion).12. Get a good screen protector. While a case/cover isn't necessary (at least for me), a good screen protector is just a necessity with any piece of touchscreen technology.Main issues?1. The small keyboard. Not a design flaw, though. Merely getting my fingers in the habit of using a smaller keyboard!2. The tablet/on-screen keyboard is HUGE and I can't figure out how to change it or if that's even possible. Nor can you "swype" on it. (Though the handwriting feature is kinda neat.)3. The Windows app store is less than stellar. You can, though, have "tiles" for regular programs and files.If you're still unsure, go to a big-box retailer and check one out so you know what you'll be getting. I did, and an hour later, ordered it from Amazon.
NOT WHAT iI EXPECTED.  I READ IT WRONG AN IT JUST WASN'T THE RIGHT TABLE FOR ME.I WANTED A WINDOWS TABLET NOT A CHROME TABLET.

If you are buying thing with the awareness that it's not going to give you theater-like experience, then for such a price I believe you're getting a good sound system.  While I've had much higher quality sound come out of even a single soundbar, that soundbar cost $1,000, not $250.  In the world of audio system, you get what you pay for.Here, you get rich lows and crisp highs.  It won't blow you away. The lows will not make your seat rumble and the highs won't pop your eardrums.  But for a decent sized room and a normal night at home watching a Friday night movie, believe me, this is perfectly fine and should suffice for just about anyone's small "theater system".It was easy to set up and hook up and without a doubt  produces a better sound than any built-in sound system I've come across for flat screens (minus any new 4K TVs).
summary: Great sound for what it is.

reviewText: It's a good sound bar for being in this price range. The set up was easy even with the poor instruction manual. Best thing I can tell you is to leave the unit turned off until you have the digital audio cable plugged into the unit and the TV and then plug in the bass unit before you turn the power on to the bar. I did it this way and everything synced up as soon as I put power on.The reason I only gave it 4 stars is that it does have some issues, but they are all really minor:1- it does not recognize my IPod when I plug it into the USB port.2-the USB port is right in the middle of the front of the bar - this makes it look really bad when you have anything plugged into it3- the display stays lit when power is on - this is distracting when you are watching a program it constantly says "optical 1" below it4- the 3.5mm jack is on the back and is almost impossible to reach with the bar mounted to the wallBut even with these issues, I would recommend it just for the sound quality
summary: It's a goodvalue for the price

reviewText: The LG Electronics NBN36 280W 37.4 Inch Sound Bar with Wireless Subwoofer and Bluetooth is a well made and easy to install device. I had no problems connecting it to my tv. Also it has the feature of allowing you to synch up your smart phone to play music through it when not watching TV.The device is very adaptable. It has an input in the back to plug any non-bluetooth device in such as an mp3 or the like. It does not come with a cable for this, so you must supply your own, but seeing how inexpensive a 3.5mm cable is this is not an issue. Also you can plug a USB drive into it with music on it and it will read it and play. Nice options to have.The sound is very good for a soundbar. This, of course is NOT a 5.1 or 7.1 home theater system. Its a 2.1 soundbar, so once you set your level of expectation of what type of audio it should provide you will be quite pleased. The key is make sure its in a regular sized room, and the positioning of the Bass Speaker is very important. It may not sound all that deep in one spot, but if you move it to a different one you will get a noticeable change in audio. So the key is to experiment a little with where you place the Bass in your room.I must say that this device from LG really is very well done. Easy to use and has a lot of good features and audio is nice. If you are looking for a decent sound bar for a tv that just dont cut it in the audio dept and you want a better sound when viewing, then this will do the job.
summary: great sound, easy to set up

reviewText: Having owned one of each of the last four generations of Logitech Harmony remotes, I should be immediately called out as a homer on the brand and concept, and I am. But I've had quibbles with all of them over time, and I'll go over some of those quibbles - and why they've been eliminated from the nearly perfect Harmony Ultimate One.The first quibble was size and feel. It was difficult to reach buttons on larger versions of the harmony without swinging it two-handed like a broadsword. This version is easy to manipulate, from top to bottom.The second was the touchscreen. With old Harmony remotes the odds you could get through a TV session without accidentally brushing the touchscreen and landing, inevitably, on channel 1 were next to nil. This one does an excellent job of disregarding inadvertent contact with the screen. In addition, the screen is much more useful, with swipe motions to go between the four major functions (touchpad, number pad, function screen and channel screen).The third was the setup. This is the main selling point for the Harmony, the ability to make all your devices function with one touch for an activity. Previously, this required a lot of manual finesse. One example: my receiver needs about 5 seconds after turning on to boot and receive additional commands. With the old remotes, I had to manually program in the delay. With the Ultimate One, the delay is accounted for. I can't imagine how much product testing and research by the logitech team went into the presets that accompany each device you add, but I haven't had to customize the remote's interaction with *anything.* It just works.
summary: The only remote you'll ever want.

reviewText: I have used nothing but Harmony brand remotes for the past 8 years. I currently own and use a pair of Harmony One's as my 'go to ' remotes. They are VERY durable if properly cared for with one of my two 'One's” lasting more than 6 years old now and subjected to DAILY heavy use!  Needless to say I am a Harmony fan and was eager to try this new Harmony Ultimate One out and see how it stacks up against my beloved original Harmony One.Before reading more you may wish to read this disclaimer:“These remotes are NOT for the technically challenged OR the chronically impatient! The website/software that allows you to custom program your Harmony Ultimate remote features unlimited combinations that you can use for both your devices and your “Activities” (macros), but also features one of the WORST software interfaces currently in use.  It took me a good few months to find my way around the software enough to get fast with it. At this point it is all 2nd nature to me but honestly if you are not willing to spend the time and trouble on Harmony programming, you most likely should look elsewhere. On the other hand if you are willing to learn and spend a bit of trial and error time, you will be greatly rewarded with a remote that controls all your devices exactly the way YOU want it to.”Ok, end of disclaimer.......  Now back to my review.........This particular Harmony is the IR model and will not shoot commands through solid objects, etc. This is for 'Line of Sight” control.*** You can upgrade this remote by buying the Smart Control unit which will add RF capability to this , and more.The until itself is very well made. It is smaller and lighter than my original Harmony One. Like the original 'One', it is rechargeable and includes a recharging base. You can control All your devices (up to 15) and create custom “Activities” to turn any number of devices on/off and change them to the appropriate inputs in one button push.  All the functions work as advertised, although the gesture control will take a bit of getting used to. I am sure it will be a very fast way to do certain things, once I get the knack.  Smart Phone users should have no trouble at all using the touch screen and the associated gesture controls.Honestly, for what it is, the new Harmony Ultimate One remote works exceedingly well.  I have a complex system consisting of up to 9 devices and have encountered ZERO programming/operational glitches.  What I mean to say is that IT WORKS!I honestly only have one major complaint/problem with this remote.....While I like this new Harmony Ultimate One, in my opinion it is far from BEING ultimate.  I still consider the original Harmony One (discontinued model) to be the best product they have ever turned out.  Here is the main reason:Basically the Harmony line of remotes underwent a drastic layout change just a few years back. The greatly loved classic configuration of the button/touchscreen layout was scrapped and replaced with new models that moved the touchscreen to the center of the remote and the most used transport buttons to the top. This just a plain bad idea when it comes to ease of use.  It is just too easy to activate the touch screen on the way up to your transport controls and when you DO wish to use the touchscreen, functions that USED to be controlled by dedicated buttons are now requiring a glance or two to operate. I am spoiled and used to using my Harmony One by touch alone, but that doesn't cut it with touchscreens.. Also, having to reach to the very top for transport functions is uncomfortable at best and at times requites two hands instead of one. (at least for me it does)<<<<Sigh>>>>>  Oh well, I am sure Logitech has heard this from MANY people already, but my feeling is IF they could give back the classic button layout while still shrinking the product, they would have a real winner.IF you have never used an original Harmony One or are NEW to Harmony remotes, then this new Harmony One Ultimate should both please you and serve all your remote needs with ease.  BUT if you are like me and are still clinging to the older version, you are bound to miss the classic button layout with the touch screen at the top. It really IS the best layout and for many, many reasons. Be that as it may, THIS is the new top of the line for Harmony remotes and while I don't find the layout  easier to use, it IS well made and all the functions remain, just implemented differently and found in different places on the physical remote itself.AS you have probably surmised, I am a real Harmony Fan.  The day I put away all my remotes for good was one to remember. I even use my Harmony to turn on/off and adjust my AC and room lighting. The Logitech database is vast and you will most likely find ALL your devices on it.If you want to control ALL your devices with one remote and be able to make totally customizable control layouts and multi-device macros, then this Harmony One Ultimate will bend to your will. You just need a bit of patience and determination, plus a touch of imagination to turn this remote into YOUR Ultimate remote.Again, I don't care for the new design, but this device is top of the line with great construction, good looks, and the ability to perform each and every function on every electronic device you currently use for stereo/home theater.As such, it IS recommended by ME, Marty G !
summary: Good Solid Unit! (but I still love my original Harmony One!)

reviewText: This is my third harmony remote. Setup was very easy, I was above to migrate all of my old settings from the previous remote to the Harmony Ultimate One. Multiple remotes are now supported under your harmony account so macros can be shared between remotes. Setup would be better if it were not dumbed down forcing you to answer questions. I would rather have the option to write macros.The learning curve for using the remote was very minimal. The touch screen is both nice and a hindrance. The touch screen is very customizable, but items cannot be selected on the screen without looking at it. Battery life has been excellent.In my opinion this Logitech remote is still one of the best universal remotes available despite its shortcomings.

This works nicely and has enough adjustments that it can be made to replace probably any remote you have. But you have to consider several things before buying:It takes a while to set up; you need patience. But you should have to set it up only once.The touch screen is small and unless your fingers are very small, it can be very clumsy to use.You have to use two hands to operate the remote for most functions.Support is willing but not very knowledgeable--put another way, it does not pass the Turing Test.The design has a variety of other quirks that will matter to some and not to others.For example, I, like a number of other folks, wrote in that the backlight for the buttons turns back on after the unit had been on the charger or a while.After a week dealing with Support, during which time I was told the problem would be fixed and I was told to reset, reboot, update firmware (which was already the latest version), create new accounts, re-setup the units from scratch, provide additional info and was given incorrect instructions on how to change settings, and then I was told that the problem was bumped up to the next higher level of Support, after all that I was told that the behavior is a "nomral function." The backlight is supposed to come on after the unit has been on the charger for a while --- why? Nobody knows!It took a week for support to figure out that the behavior was "normal function"?  What kind of management does not supply Support with with proper information or provides it with believable answers.Also, I'd like to ask the designers why the heck they want the item burning electricity needlessly. If the backlight coming back on while on the charger it's meant to be a night light, then why isn't it lit the whole time that the unit is on the charger? If it's meant to indicate that charging is complete or some such thing, then why have such an indication when the instructions that come with the remotes say, "leave on charger whenever not in use so you know where to find the remote."This is situation is at best downright silly no matter how you try to look at it.If you can live with all that, and are well healed, this might be a prudent way to cut down on all those remotes.
summary: Works reasonably well-- A few important caveats--Support is wicked unknowledgable

reviewText: Like most people I hate having seven remotes to control my system so combining them into one unit is a great idea. I appreciate the opportunity to review the Ultimate One and compare it to my two-year-old One with the failing buttons. Although the Ultimate One is pretty smart and quite functional in many ways, Logitech misses the mark for me on several important points.Software: Try finding Roku for the Harmony. There are several classifications to look under but none of them make sense for Roku. It's listed under "DVD." Go figure. Try Apple TV. Good luck with that one. Brand new hardware (Ultimate One) with the same old crappy software. If they spent a couple of days with a new software team leader in charge, maybe they'd come up with a better system, but this one has irritated me since I bought the old One more than two years ago.Hardware: Improved the shape and size over the old One so that now it stands up in the charging stand, taking up much less room on the table where it sits. Also added a textured back to make it easier to grip. They got rid of the superfluous buttons that cluttered up the old One, but also removed some pretty useful ones. These buttons are now accessed through layers of a touch screen. Sometimes this works out well, and sometimes not. Really depends on your equipment and the type of controlling you need to do. For me, I still keep the original remotes close enough that I can use them to do the more intricate things I don't want to bother setting up and troubleshooting on the Harmony. Yes, troubleshoot. Not everything works right the first time.Some inconveniences: Ever hand your remote to someone so they can control things? Well, be careful with the Ultimate. About 1/4 times one of us will accidentally activate something on the touchscreen during transfer from one hand to the other, and we're being careful. Also, for some reason they put the playback buttons (play, FF, REW, etc) above the touchscreen. Try using those without activating something on the touchscreen!Set up: Since I already had a Harmony One that was fine-tuned to my system (which took months to finesse!!!), set up was just a matter of transferring the information from the One to the Ultimate. Easy-cheesy. I don't look forward to learning how to set up the Ultimate for a new piece of equipment after seeing that the software is still the same: lame. For now, the Ultimate controls most things fine with no fuss on my part.If you want to get rid of all of your remotes the Ultimate One could be your solution. For me it wasn't. If you want the convenience of controlling most of the common functions of a lot of equipment and don't mind the limitations, then this expensive remote could be a great addition to your collection. We now have nine remotes instead of the seven that came with the equipment. The old One is still on the charger for my wife's use (she doesn't care for the lack of buttons on the Ultimate). The Ultimate is for me, most of the time. The individual equipment remotes are stashed close-by in case I need to access something I can't find on the Ultimate.If Logitech would update their software to the 21st century (they still have Laserdisc but don't have a proper category for ROKU) and put the touch screen at the top with all of the buttons grouped together, I'd love the Ultimate One. If they don't make changes to the software I won't buy a new One when this One wears out.

For virtually everyone, this is the only universal remote you will ever need. With it’s huge database of remote codes, the possibilities are almost limitless. Unfortunately for me, I ran into one of these rare exceptions when I upgraded to a state-of-the-art LG TV with a crazy, voice-activated remote. I guess this means I’m stuck using two remotes for the foreseeable future, if I want to take full advantage of my new TV’s remote. Talk about your first world problems! Seriously though, until I got this weird new remote, the Harmony Ultimate One was perfect, and seeing as most people aren’t going to run into this issue, the LHUO (Logitech Harmony Ultimate One) is everything you will ever need.One initial point of clarification, since it has seemed to provoke confusion amongst inattentive shoppers: This is an IR remote, not an RF remote. That means that you need a clear line of sight between the LHUO and the component it is controlling. It won’t shoot through an opaque cabinet door. If you want that functionality, Logitech makes an RF version of the LHUO, although it sells for almost $100 more. There are a handful of electronics that use RF instead of IR. The Dish Network remote is an RF remote, so that’s an important exception to be aware of. Otherwise, IR works just fine for most people. Seriously, if you can’t be bothered to keep your cabinet doors open, then you probably won’t mind spending extra for the convenience of RF.Every setup is different, but I’ll describe mine here as briefly as possible. The specifics of what I’m doing with the remote are, obviously, less important than the overall idea of how much it can do. I have a TV, a Blu-ray player, a DVD player (it’s a long story why this is still part of my setup), an A/V receiver, and an Apple TV. It’s a pretty standard setup, but it involved me using five different remotes, which is a drag. The LHUO took care of all of them with ease. Programming the remote on my Mac was incredibly easy. Everything just worked. It was such a non-issue, that I don’t feel compelled to write much more about it!As for the physical aspects of the remote, I must say that it’s fantastic. It’s weighted nicely for perfect balance and feels substantial without being heavy. Basically, it feels like a well-made product. You might think this is totally secondary to its functionality, but since we spend so much time holding remotes, having something this well designed does make a difference.The buttons are clear, the layout makes sense, and it’s not packed full of obscure, unlabeled buttons. I’ve seen a lot of universal remotes that give you tons of assignable buttons, but realistically, there are only so many functions you can remember when something isn’t labeled. Picture yourself as a technophobic spouse, and that number drops even more. Every button needs to have a function that is intuitively expressed through its labeling if anyone other than you will use it.If you’re a guy (yes, it’s a cultural stereotype, but chances are, if you’re reading this, you are in fact a guy), you probably have a wife or girlfriend who wants to watch TV occasionally in your absence. Whether she embraces technology or not, if she didn’t program it, she’s going approach this with skepticism. I’ve seen my parents go through this song and dance many times. My dad thinks his new universal remote is the most intuitive thing in the world and my mom is so turned off by it that she uses all the old remotes both out of stubbornness and out of necessity. The beauty here is that there are actually very few buttons on the remote. Everything makes sense, just by looking at it. If you hand this to someone who didn’t program it, they’re probably going to be able to figure it out. That’s a design element that is almost invaluable.The touch screen works well, and this is probably why the remote can afford to be so simple. If there are weird features that you don’t need to access regularly, you can tuck them away in the touch screen menus - a place most other users (other than yourself) will ever need to venture. The only downside here is that the remote needs a lot of power to function. I prefer the simplicity of a basic, battery powered remote. The LHUO needs a docking station to function because it’s rechargeable batter needs to stay juiced. You don’t need to keep it in the dock all the time, and the charge actually lasts quite a while. But, you do need to have the dock accessible periodically and that means an extra power supply and an extra cable. It could be worse; the dock is minimal and looks decent. I just wish I didn’t need yet another piece of gear to tuck away somewhere.Overall, the LHUO is an incredibly well designed piece of gear. It’s well built, it’s easy to program, and most importantly, it’s intuitive enough for other users to grasp. I cannot over emphasize enough how important usability is for people who are not yourself. You’re awesome; you’re buying a universal remote. You’re excited about programming it, and you’re dedicated to learning how to use it most effectively. Everyone else just wants to watch TV in the simplest way possible. This actually IS simple enough that they won’t protest. Buy it for the functionality, but also buy it for the clean, logical layout.

This is a pretty amazingly powerful computer.  It is also huge, weighing in at about 20 lbs.  On board fans keep it cool while you play and surf, and my son (an avid and knowledgeable gamer) has been very impressed by the FPS (frames per second).Alienware ALW18-750sLV is a beautiful piece of equipment.  A unique thing about this computer is way the keyboard and laptop itself can be lit up and customized with all manner of different colors using Alien FX, a custom feature.  You can even light up the touch pad.  Wonderful for playing at night or simply in a darkened room.  But I wouldn't suggest leaving this in your child's room.  They might never come out!  My son has almost completely abandoned his XBox for the laptop.  However, Alien FX can be glitchy at times. Sometimes Alien FX has problems connecting, and tends to go on and off when you don't want it to.  This is an annoyance.The physical computer itself is very nice.The touch pad is really nice for surfing, but get a mouse for gaming.  It's easier and more responsive that way.Alienware can play any game you throw at it.Planetside 2 kept around 60 FPS on maximum graphics, which is very impressive because we didn't expect a laptop to be able to keep up that FPS for the whole game.  But this is no ordinary laptop.On WarThunder, it goes beyond 100 FPS.  Incredible gaming experience.  The graphics are gorgeous, and it really makes playing a much more immerse experience.  It has an AMD dual graphics are very nice, but many games (particularly on Steam) are powered by Nvidia (like Planetside 2), so there might be some graphics glitches.The camera is ok for skyping and basic needs.Audio is excellent, but it is still a laptop, so my son was a little surprised.  He felt the speakers could be arranged in a better manner for maximum sound.Plenty of ports!I have used it for surfing and it's fast and a nice experience.  A little heavy for on the lap, your basically trapped under it for the duration until you're ready to move. Definitely best on a table.When I told my son we were getting a gaming laptop, the first words out of his mouth were, "Is it an Alienware?"  Totally the cream of the crop!  But not a laptop you'll be hauling to class or the library.I would rate this 4.5 stars, because for the money you'll be shelling out on this computer, it isn't quite perfect. But it is a great computer, and as far as it being a gaming computer, I highly doubt you could do much better!
summary: Powerful, giant laptop that will delight avid gamers.

reviewText: I've never had an issue with a Lexar Professional memory card that was due to a faulty card. These cards also came with the latest software of Image Rescue 5.

It's not a bad card, but I have had some problems with it.  First, any time there was a power outage, the dual monitors would not work.  It would be fine up until the "Starting Windows" screen and then both monitors would go into low power mode and I couldn't do anything.  I had to unplug the input cable from the secondary monitor, force a shutdown, and let it boot with only one monitor until it got to the logon screen.  Then I could plug the secondary monitor input back in.  I ended up buying a UPS just to avoid this in the future.The second issue I notice is video hanging.  If I am watching a YouTube video or a Netflix or other streaming service, the video will hang for a second or two as the audio continues on without issue.  Then the video kind of fast forwards to catch back up.
Love this card its not 770 but the quality is great for the price

I have used this on 2 of my computers, allowing me to charge several items at once  including a USB keyboard, a light,  my iPad and iPhone, a Kindle, an external hard drive, and a GPS.This really powered things up but, more importantly, it did so faster than I expected, to all advices, at once.My computer kept up, undeterred and without slowing down either.One USB turns in to many--what more could you ask for?  In today's world one can never have enough USB slots because more and more items are being charged that way.Product provided by MPowReview is my unbiased opinion
summary: Faster than many multi-USB power ports, works well
