I was paying $4.99 a month for the only version available, a low end modem, from the cable company here on Hawaii.  Take that and tax, you're looking at $5.22 a month in a fee that also required me to purchase (or rent) a router.  Boxes and wires everywhere.This item, the Netgear N600 (C3700), is super.  I no longer pay a fee to the cable co. and no longer need a router.  It comes with a cable co. coaxial cable input, power cord plug, and two outputs to Ethernet cables.  I am using both outputs, and also have a wireless desktop, wireless printer, 2 Wi-Fi Blu-Ray players, a Nexus 7, and an iPad Mini running off this modem.  It's perfect.  No longer a dropped signal, never slow regardless of units online, as was the case with the rental.  I have Pandora music on all-the-time and no problems.  Smooth sailing and you should research this modem further prior to buying so you know what you're getting... although I've already stated its positives and NO negatives to it.  It pays for itself in around a year (in rental savings) and then you're completely free riding from increasing cable co. fees and taxes on a low-end, always something requiring "resetting" garbage modem connecting to a router.  Enjoy!
summary: So much better than a "rental" from the Cable Co.

reviewText: I have had a few days to play around with this little sound bar now, and I am pleasantly surprised by it. Let me start with the good aspects that I discovered.There are the now-standard optical, RCA and line-in connections. There are only one of each. The Bluetooth, SD/MMC card reader, FM radio and USB add some additional flexibility which was nice. Connection from my TV with the included RCA cables was a breeze. The optical cable is not included, but setup was just as easy. I had no problems pairing my phone and my tablet to the sound bar via Bluetooth. The SD/MMC card reader, as well as the USB connection is located on the end of the bar for easy access should you mount this on the wall.Now, the items that were not as good:If you are planning on using the line-in connection for devices, wall mounting may provide a hindrance as the connection is on the back of the sound bar. This may not be an issue if you don't use this input, or if you don't mind a cable hanging out the back and dangling on the wall. FM radio was a little tricky to program the presets. It wasn't too bad, though, after reading the instructions. The volume of sound generated is somewhat lacking. If you are in a room larger than a standard bedroom, or a dorm room, it might not be enough.  While the mid and high ranges are crisp and clean sounding, at higher volumes, the sound starts to distort. It has a built in subwoofer, but It would benefit from a dedicated subwoofer for some solid low end rumble. The remote is fairly easy to use, but the range on it is horrible. I had problems getting the sound bar to respond to the remote at just over 10 feet away.Overall, this is a good option for a budget minded purchase as long as you temper your expectations. Bluetooth connectivity is a very nice option and easy to setup. It provides connection options beyond the TV itself. It is a step up from the horrid internal speakers of most TV's on the market today. It is not however, going to blow you away.
summary: Seiki SB102N Super Slim Bluetooth Sound Bar

reviewText: Lexar and San Disk are the preferred cards for me. Use them for different reasons, but both are great.  Outstanding for writing speed and down load speed. A few dollars more, but you get what you pay for!!  To me getting the fast cards saves time and keeps you from loosing shot because you recover so quickly and are ready to shoot again!!

Did some research and narrowed my card search to the lexar. I took a gamble and ordered 2 sets. Upon receiving I did some validation tests by first formatting the card, and then zeroing it. I then used F3 for mac osx to benchmark the read/write speeds and to verify the capacity of the card.Using a macbook pro w/ the included usb 3.0 adapter my results were:CARD 1:write max: 38.02 MB/swrite avg: 37.86 MB/sread: 64.02 MB/sdata capacity: 29.81 GBzero corruptionsCARD 2:write max: 39.15 MB/swrite avg: 38.00 MB/sread: 63.95 MB/sdata capacity: 29.81 GBzero corruptionsConclusion... good value, solid performance, reliability remains to be seen. Will update if any issues arise.
summary: Good Value Card for Go Pro Black +

reviewText: I popped this into a Sony Handycam (that shoots in HD) to use for filming and it's been working perfectly. Pictures and video go straight onto the microSDHC, and I've seen absolutely no sign of errors, quality problems, or anything that would lead me to believe that the Lexar card is giving me performance that's any worse than the camera's own internal memory does.The fact that it comes with an adapter that's designed for USB 3.0 is nice to have if you're planning to move video files around regularly.On the whole this is a very nice little product. The only thing I can think of to complain about is that it would have been ideal to throw in a matching SD adapter (I had to use one to put the microSDHC card into the camera). On the other hand, a lot of people probably have a few of those lying around already (I did) and so adding both one of those and the USB adapter could be wasteful. I'm fine with just the USB adapter.

When you read the fine print, it says the 95Mb/s is the read speed. Measuring it with CrystalMark, they come real close - 85.96 MB/s on USB 3.0. Write speed is a very respectable 42.76 MB/s, which is more than adequate for use with GoPro, iPhones, Samsung Galaxy S- series or other devices for stutter-free video.With a product like this, it's all about speed snf this card is fast at reading writing. The lifetime warranty is reassuring, but durability can never be predicted.Overall, for anyone shooting video on a device using a microSD card, this card is blazingly fast. With an appropriate adapter, it can also be used as an SD card. A bit on the pricey side, but you are getting considerable bang for your buck.Jerry
summary: Comes real close to meeting advertised spec.

reviewText: *****At first I was confused by this product, which I thought was something entirely else, but it turns out it's a MicroSDHC card you can plug, optionally using the USB 3 adapter, into many devices such as your phone or your tablet to record or transfer data.  But it's so fast that its highest and best use is to record video from a camera.  When you've made your recording you can plug the card into the USB adapter and download the resulting file to your computer for further processing.It's a Class 10, which is why it's fast.  Well, I got that backwards.  It's very fast at transferring bits, so fast that it is rated as a Class 10.  The one I have holds 32 gibabytes, which is enough to record really low-res video for practically ever.  There're also a 16-gig size and a 64-gig size if you want to spend less or record more.*****Using the exact product I have -- and I assume this would apply to any one you buy -- you can record video of your kid's birthday party or your dog's catching a Frisbee, whichever you prefer.  It does not successfully withstand being snapped in half using two pairs of neddle-noise pliers.The Lexar High-Performance microSDHC 633x 32GB UHS-I Flash Memory Card LSDMI32GBBNL633R can be used to store anything in bits and bytes, of course, not just video.  You can store photos, music, word processing files, databases, and maybe even one or more entire backups of your computer.  You cannot use it to store the entirety of Wikipedia, which as of this writing is well over 32 gigabytes.I simply have no complaints about this product, so I give it the whole five stars.*****

Works as it should. It's fast and the size makes them easy to store and possibly misplace as well. Having the adapter is a bit of a pain as that too is easy to misplace. Smaller and faster is the way technology evolves.

This antenna is ultra thin (as advertised) and works great. My other two antennas are from different companies, but this one picks up the same channels as they do. I have mine positioned flat next to the TV. No problems!
It's effective and looks good.  It's a great solution for anyone who wants network and local over-the-air channels without paying for cable or satellite TV service.

This antenna is quite simple in design and appearance, but works surprisingly well.It is very simple to use.  Just plug it into the antenna connection of a digital television or to the digital conversion box for older sets and then adjust placement of the antenna for best reception, preferably near a window.  The permanently-attached cable is about 67 in. (1.7 m) long and one adhesive cable clip is included.The antenna has a suction-mount base that works fairly well on smooth surfaces, but it is light enough to be held in place with a thumbtack or piece of tape as an alternative.I live in a dense urban area, but it managed to pull in several channels that I could not access without an antenna.  The signal quality is very good, although better for digital channels than for analog channels, as would be expected.1Byone provided an antenna for evaluation and review.
summary: Easy to setup and works well

reviewText: Used this to build an new file server box using Server 2012 x64 Standard.  Thought I would be ok for drivers since Windows 8 and Server 2012 are close in builds.  Driver base not so great, but 80% of drivers could be loaded from those provided.  No additional support from the website.  I didn't have to do firmware updates prior to installation and I loaded the OS directly from USB 3.0 flash drive.  I would have ding'd the board a star for drivers, but honestly its my fault for not looking into it further.  I am quite surprised by the pep of the dual core 2.41s.Paired with:Coolermaster Elite 130Kingston 204 Pin 1333MHz SODIMM 4GB x2Corsair 600 watt PS (overkill I know but its what I had already)RocketRaid 2300Kingston HyperX 128SSDWD 2TB Black Ed x3

What a pain in the @$$...  I've been building systems for over 20 years now, and I think I had more trouble getting an OS installed on this board than any other I've worked with.  To be fair, it's a system with no optical drive built in (so I was installing from a bootable DVD in a USB attached optical drive), but it still gave me a lot more trouble than anticipated.Based on other recommendations, I first tried to upgrade the BIOS.  However, the BIOS doesn't have an upgrade option in the BIOS setup, and it is a pain booting a flash drive on here, particularly with the shipping BIOS I received.  First it had to be configured to boot legacy storage instead of UEFI, then I had to reboot it again to get it to recognize the flash drive, then reconfigure how it treated the flash drive (floppy disk vs hard disk vs optical drive).  Never mind the hassle just making a bootable MS-DOS USB flash drive in the first place.  After getting the BIOS flashed, then the next trouble was getting it to boot a USB optical drive.  Again, had to tinker with various options for UEFI vs legacy (in this case, booting it UEFI vs the flash drive which was legacy).Other bizarre behavior I've had I'm not sure whether to attribute to the board, Windows Server 2012 R2, or some combination of both.  For example, occasionally on some reboots my drives show up with RAW partitions when I know those partitions were formatted ReFS.  At first I noticed it only on my external USB 3TB drive, and figured maybe there was some wonkiness there, but it's now done it with internal drives as well.  Given I've never seen another server build which does that, I'm leaning towards some bizarre interaction with the board.Also, while I didn't bump into an issue, be wary of the memory voltage.  I've heard of other reports of people having issues with 1.5V memory.  I can't confirm those for myself, but opted for 1.35V memory to be safe.The board itself does seem well enough constructed though, has been stable.  It isn't the fastest machine out there (by a long, long ways), but that's expected - it's dual-core, not a fast clock speed, and not running a CPU that's the most efficient clock-for-clock in the first place.  As long as your expectations are reasonable though, it performs fine.In the end, since I'm out of my return period, I'm considering this a sunk cost, and buying a different board.  I've got an i5-3570K sitting around from another system, so I'm picking up an LGA 1155 mini ITX board, accepting that I'll need a fan on the CPU, and calling it a day.  It isn't worth the time I've spent futzing with this thing.
I use these from my computer screen my tablet my phone my glasses to my tv and they clean really well

I thought the general ones from this company were amazing and larger in size...then I got these. These are ginormous! Super soft, great surface area for the TV or Computer or whatever your microfiber cloth needs are. High Quality, thick. Work amazingly well. A must have for any gadget owner.

I've started cleaning my ipad and phone screens pretty much daily now that I have these. I love that they work so well for getting the screens beautiful and clean. It's a great value and I highly recommend them!

ive got the Thor one an its amazing came in a actual box with the company's name on it looking great with a arted mouse mat. an full software. working turbo fire. options to change an set the color to breath light or station it. suck that china will will make something nice then make a million copies with little less stuff. i think the price of this is truely right. $10 an the thor is $24 with better software addons an working fire. an a website with support.........kinda lol
summary: this is a remake of a dragonwar thor

reviewText: great mouse, everyone in the office asked me: whats with you transformer mouse? LoLfeels great and works great as well, even though i have big hands i just feel i need to get used to it, but it works perfectly fine.its lightweight (despite its looks), i needed extra buttons and higher dpi to use with autocad, but since it doesnt come with drivers or software, i ended up installing "X-Mouse button control" (google it, its free), and you can set the extra buttons to work any way you want in every different program you use.you wont be disapointed with your purchase, oh, and the shipping time was awesome, in my case only took a couple of weeks with regulr shipping, where it said it would take up to a month to be delivered. im very happy with it.
Works very well to cool a laptop that tended to run hot.  I highly recommend this product.

The Philips SB365/37 wireless Bluetooth speaker is excellent.First, it's incredibly easy to set up. The Bluetooth matching is seamless. The reach is quite strong. It certainly goes at least 30 feet. To some extent, it can even work through the separation of walls, though I found that the signal could be lost from one room to another. As a practical matter, though, the speaker is so light that there's no problem moving it from room to room.The sound quality is excellent. Philips has not disappointed in this. The bass is very good for a such a small speaker.Perhaps the most telling, recurring criticisms from some Amazon.com reviewers relate to the power supply.The speaker does consume batteries at a rather rapid rate. One might install rechargeable batteries. They tend to be expensive and limited in performance, so that's not ideal. Depending on your needs, it's important to understand that there's not a built-in recharge capacity as with some portable speakers.The practical effect of this is to limit the real-time capacity of this speaker as truly portable. Given the battery consumption, one would likely not want to deploy it for regular use outdoors or other places without access to electric outlets.The portability is also limited by the design and construction of the speaker. Its size is just large enough so that it would be pretty challenging to carry in a small bag or case. So, too, it doesn't strike me as sturdy enough to put through the rigors of travel.On the other hand, for regular use in a home or office, using an electrical outlet, this unit can be a good choice.In the end, perhaps one should factor in the various compromises that various speakers include: cost, power, design and construction, sound quality.For many people who use this Philips product in one setting, this can be a versatile, high-quality, low-cost speaker.If you want durable portability--including smaller size, tight design, rechargeable power, good sound--you may want to compare this with other options. They will generally have higher price tags.In sum, for the uses as outlined, this is a fine product. Whether it's the best fit for you is about your needs every bit as much as the it's about the speaker.
summary: Excellent Product -- Think About What May Work Best for You

reviewText: Philips SB365/37 Wireless Bluetooth Portable Speaker (Black)Category: Portable Audio & Video...Always on the look-out for state-of-the-art tech devices that are wireless, portable and Bluetooth/NFC compatible.This speaker, SB365, delivers superb sound in great style. Includes NFC pairing, stream music from your phone wirelessly over Bluetooth for effortless enjoyment. It also charges any smart device using USB.Notes after using the Philips SB365/37 Wireless Bluetooth Portable Speaker for a couple of weeks:In the Box one finds the Philips SB365/37 Wireless Bluetooth Portable Speaker, AC Power adaptor with 6' cable, an 18" 3.5mm Audio-in cable and a Short user manual containing the serial and model numbers, plus a link to a dot com support page with lots of detailed information -- which is an added Plus.Weighing in at a mere 1.4 pounds, the (4 x 10 x 4 inch) Black Philips SB365/37 Wireless Bluetooth Portable Speaker is made of a very hard plastic (on top and bottom) with a metal mesh covering the speakers and surrounding the rest of the unit. Both metal and plastic have a satin-like finish that resists fingerprints.  All the corners are rounded and very smooth. The bottom, of the unit, has 6 slip-resistant dots -- which grip very well on a (dry) smooth surface.The instruction pamphlet is easy to follow -- graphics are large, clear and bright. Wording is concise. I like that -- even if one has never "Paired" with BlueTooth or doesn't know what NFC technology (for fuss-free and easy usage) pairing is! :)With this unit, one either uses AC Power with the included AC adaptor (which has a polarized plug -- one blade is wider than the other), or inserts four fresh AA batteries (not included) in the battery compartment on the bottom of the unit. The speaker will automatically go into Stand-by mode if there is no BlueTooth connection, or audio input, for more than 15 minutes.On the top of the speaker one finds the Power On/Off (green LED when on -- fades slightly when in Stand-by mode), Bluetooth indicator (which is a blue LED -- flashes when searching for BlueTooth/NFC unit to pair with...stops flashing when Paired), Volume +/- and a good sized NFC receptor icon. All buttons are flat. There is a slightly audible click when pressing the Power and Volume control buttons. On the backside, of the unit, one finds the 3.5mm Audio plug-in, a USB (for charging Only) port and a DC In port (this is where the included AC Adaptor plugs in).  The bottom, of the unit houses a 4x AA battery compartment. That's It!Android OP (new Samsung Smart devices) and laptops using Windows8 were used for this review:  following directions, Pairing with BlueTooth, or NFC, was Super Fast. I needed to swipe (instead of Tap) My NFC enabled SmartPhones, but the connection was made, and the device stayed connected. note:  The speaker can memorize a maximum of 4 paired devices.One can use the Philips SB365/37 Wireless Bluetooth Portable Speaker as an external speaker with non Bluetooth audio devices by jacking into the earbud/headphone connection, of said device, with a 3.5 mm audio cable (included) and then into the Audio In port on the back of the speaker. When this is done, one simply controls the speaker via the settings on the linked into device.The, very handy, USB (for charging Only) port quickly charged all My Smart Devices and little mp3 players (that are not so Smart).I found the sound delivered through the Philips SB365/37 Wireless Bluetooth Portable Speaker, with NFC, to be phenomenal over a wide range of musical genre. Crystal clear highs, lows, bass and voice. The Bass Reflex Speaker System delivers a powerful, deeper bass. It can be very loud, if that is what one wishes.*smiles, sips espresso*Does the Philips SB365/37 Wireless Bluetooth Portable Speaker, with NFC, sound like what you may be looking for? :)  Would make a Fantastic Gift!  Highly Recommended!  --Katharena Eiermann, 2014
summary: ...Crystal clear highs, lows, bass and voice! :)

reviewerName: Kilgore Gagarin "Those who believe in telekin...
reviewText: By "tethered unit" I mean that this is pretty much designed to be used constantly plugged in. It DOES come with an AC adapter, but to use as a portable you'll have to buy 4xAA batteries. I ran it for 8 hours on a medium volume before the batteries started to flag. I was using standard alkaline double A's from the supermarket.The sound is noticeably better than standard for this class of speaker, which is actually pretty good. Small dorm, room, or apartment this works great with more oomph than you'd expect. I played the Beatles LOVE album for testing because of wide range of instruments, sounds, and treble/bass dynamics, and it sounded great on this unit.This does NOT have NFC Bluetooth connectivity which I don't think is a minus at all. It connects as easily and readily to an array of devices in the standard ways (my tests: Android Moto-G ; Apple iPad ; Blackberry Curve ; Asus laptop).This is what I'd call "luggable" rather than truly portable. Because of the need to replace batteries, or find a place to plug it in, you're likely to just install this somewhere permanently.With all that in mind, an excellent Bluetooth speaker which would make a fine gift for your ungrateful teenager.
summary: Pretty good tethered unit, I got 8 hours on (not included) batteries

reviewText: I shied away from putting a protective screen cover on my Galaxy S5 because I didn't want to lose the feel of the Gorilla glass. Boy was I wrong. Tech Armor feels very natural and I would buy when Galaxy S6 comes out next year.

I guess I should have known since the price was low on this item, but I went ahead and ordered it. The case itself is worthless and there is no way its going to protect your phone. Also the screen protectors are cheap and after following their video instructions on how to install it, I found myself hopelessly trying to get the bubbles out of the screen. Tried it several times and I could never get it to fully get rid of all the bubbles. Contacted Tech Armor's customer service which was complete waste of time. No offer to help and wanted me to send it to them on my on dime. At least Amazon offers to pay shipping and refund the complete order. If your looking for quality then make sure to look somewhere else. Avoid this brand, as you will be very displeased.

Got the ballistic glass. Haven't attempted to scratch it yet but I can tell this glass is strong. Smooth too. Very quality. Easy to apply because it includes everything you need for cleaning and application. Zero bubbles.

I recently ordered this product. It arrived and upon installation, the top right hand corner of the screen protector would not adhere. It was just the top right hand corner as the remaining part of the screen protector worked good. I immediately contacted Amazon. They have already refunded my purchase. I have bought a replacement since, but am still waiting for Amazon to ship the item to me.

I have no idea what the naysayers are writing about. I charged it, it plays - I don't charge it, it doesn't. I brought this out to the pool area just for S&G's - worked great. Only issue I had was when it was in the bathroom charging, I forgot to turn it off, while in bed I played a YouTube video on my iphone and the sound came through the speaker 35 ft away. scared the crap outta me.
Mine didn't seem to want to ever turn off so the battery constantly died. Not impressed, I ended up using a different one. Wish the quality of battery or use was better.

First of all, I measured my Samsung tablet wrong so this is about 1/4 inch to small to fit the tablet.  I was replacing my old case.  The WAWO case is very thin, and would seem to offer little if any protection to a tablet if it was dopped etc.  I would not recomend this to anyone.

The quality and material used for the case is first rate and it comes in many colours.  I would highly recommend this unit.  It offers good protection with an attractive look.  Do keep in mind that the folding stand is not too sturdy, but it is still 5 stars.
summary: Very Good Case for the price

reviewText: If you don't mind a little assembly this is the product for you.  I'm not real technically astute but I was able to figure it out by watching some videos.  The Zenmuse Gimbal is wonderful and does exactly as advertised, giving a very stable video.As a novice flyer the Phantom 2 is a dream to fly.  If you just follow the instructions and let it hook up with enough satellites it's easy to fly.  I would recommend this product for anyone.

Experience has led me to this.. purchase new only. I've decided to purchase new after reading and experiencing many issues with used units. I pretty much gave up on the idea of saving a few bucks and buying used. Just spend the money and get new.
summary: This is a product to only buy new.

reviewText: It's an amazing little machine really. So easy to operate even for beginners. You just need to be a little gentle with it at the start and it takes care of everything else. Love the failsafe return to home feature as I needed it twice so far.As with all great products, there is so much room to expand with aftermarket stuff...cant wait

I've been using this Bluetooth HD Audio Receiver for several weeks and it's been working great!I'll upload pics when their system is up.Packaging is very simple and clean with only the necessities.Unit itself has some nice indents for finger grip and hides the Aux output and a USB output at the bottom to clear it from dust bunny collection.Small blue LED in front allows you to know the connection status.I have a decent stereo system that was before the time of Bluetooth and yeah...had to run this stupidly long wire to it around the room from my devices. Of course I did not want to spend more money to buy a more updated version.I usually have my computer plugged into it or the iPhone 5 or Samsung Galaxy S4 to output some music or to hear something a bit more louder.Now the cable clutter is clear with the Bluetooth connection from PC or Phone to speaker.This makes my room much cleaner than previously.I can see this being very nice for a cleaner surround sound and for a better connection for those lower tier Bluetooth devices.I did not have any issues from being in different rooms. Perhaps it depends the composition of the wall / drywall that affects those who have issues.Overall, it works wonderfully for those who need a better Bluetooth connection or need one with the non existing sound systems.Hope this is helpful for ya!
summary: A great help to clean up wire clutter!

reviewText: I needed a Bluetooth receiver to send music to my powered speakers from my iPad in my screened, dining porch.  This works perfectly.  After the initial connection, the iPad and Mpow pair up automatically when within range of each other.  I haven't noticed any degradation of sound quality, probably due to the Bluetooth 4.0 and the aptX decoding added.  Though, I'm not that versed on the various differences between the updates of Bluetooth technology and not at all familiar with aptX.From what I see in the 'answered questions' section, the USB input appears to be for charging only.  I haven't the need to use it, so I really cannot comment on it.  If it is indeed for charging, it could be a good thing if your speakers need a USB connection for power.I'm extremely pleased, overall!

This thing works reasonably well -- I set one up in my 1-car garage, to stream music from my phone. When I'm in the garage, I keep my phone in a side pocket, without anything around it that should interfere with signal strength, but if I'm more than half the garage length away from the bluetooth receiver, audio will start to cut out. My garage is barely long enough for car+workbench, so it's not like I'm very far away. Line of sight back to the device, and I'm using an iPhone 4s which has never shown any problems with bluetooth.The major pairing complaint isn't an issue for me, since it's on a power strip I turn off when I'm not in the garage, but the poor signal strength has been a pretty major gripe of mine. I'll be in the garage, completely focused on whatever I'm doing, and all of a sudden a song will start dropping frames and I'll be completely distracted by it. I've actually switched back to using an old AirPort Express, sending audio through it instead.Maybe I'll rip this apart and turn it into a 12v car version. Not really sure what other use I have for it.
summary: Works fine if you're < 10ft away from it... not so much any further than that.

reviewText: I have to say I really like this TV and am glad I picked it. The smart remote is interesting and really seems like a logical progression from the old large remotes. For anyone not in the know it puts a pointer on the screen that you can move like with the Wii. I upgraded from a 7 year old Sony I purchased back when 720P was the affordable option. The picture quality difference is immediately obvious even on just digital cable channels which I really wasn't expecting. As others have stated setup is quick, easy and cute with it's childish cartoon graphics. I had no problem finding my 5ghz wireless N network. Once connected via the setup wizard (about 20 minutes with channel searches) each app I tried immediately prompted me for updates. the updates took a minute a piece including download, installation and then firing up. mine included the LG Store and browser right out of the box or it updated immediately without my noticing. Netflix. Amazon, Vudu and Hulu worked flawlessly upon first use. The Amazon interface is fare better than the Xbox 360's.The one thing that drove me nuts was where to find the settings so you can change the sound and picture and that's because it's a small icon on the top left of the home screen while you're looking at the bottom with all the app options. It also has what I would consider a weird channel layout. It keeps all the cable, digital cable, antenna and digital antenna channels separated so you can't just flip through them in order. It seems absolutely counter intuitive to me.One final thought... remember that stupid 3D craze that you absolutely knew just wasn't going to last long well I guess it's over because none of the major brands have affordable 3D T.V.s this model year. I really don't want to care except that all the other components I purchased are 3D ready and now that I've stepped up my game and there are a litany of 3D movies available for home viewing I kind of would have liked to have made a family 3D movie night out of it but oh well. They really should have removed the darned 3D button from the remote. I could have purchased last years model if that was a big deal to me but the $80 price drop and updated hardware and the slightly better power consumption seem like a good trade off tbh.
summary: Excellent choice for the 2014 model year.

reviewText: I purchased my TV from another vendor. At the time I was buying amazon was out of stock and my old 58" Samsung plasma was getting worse and worse.Before you read too far. I do not use the streaming services at this time, so I will not write anything about that. I did get them figuring at some time I might want to add them to my cable package. I also have a 7.1 surround sound systems so will be using that for audio.Unboxing TV. This was done by delivery service. They also plugged it in and checked that it turned on.I had help installing the TV to the wall. TV weighs only 48 lbs, but the size is still too big for one man installation.You will need to purchase M6 screws to mount your bracket. I had to run out and get these because the old Samsung plasma TV was 85 lbs. and used big screws maybe M8. The M6 screws cost a couple of bucks for 4 and I got hex heads.  After mounting TV to the wall on to setup.Set up was very very easy although long. It also took a little time getting used to the magic remote. It works like a wireless mouse except it is used in the air. You need to shake it to wake it up if it goes into sleep mode.First thing you must do is pair the remote with TV then you can start programing TV setting. (HINT - I turned tv on and hit joystick to make remote show up on screen, just playing with remote out of box did nothing. Wasted over a minute on this one. I dont read instructs I fiddle first)The on screen prompts walked me through setting up my fios set up box. One programed it could work my fios box. All this turned out to be real easy. I don't like the energy saving feature at all. Turned on by default and after a few seconds the TV dims too dark for me. Turned this setting off and TV picture looks great.Watched my first 3D movie at home. I purchased an LG 3d Bluray player and some 3d movies from amazon. Will hook that up later this week and see how it that looks. All the on line reviews claim the blurays look better than the 3d on demand.Over all I am happy with my purchase the picture is much brighter than my 2008 plasma model.  I wish I could have bought this TV without the wifi and streaming for a better price but that isn't the way they make them today. I also wanted a faster TV for sports, we watch a lot of hockey in the house and was worried about blurriness because the puck moves so fast. So far so good. I will update this review as time goes on.05/06 - Used my Ipad as a hot spot and updated the shipped firmware from 3.01 to 3.23 It didnt use too much data to do so and was very easy. It did make some changes to the tv not sure what all of them are but some of the on screen set up information is now bigger and set up icon changed from left to right side. Could not find anything on line to say what update does.
summary: Must be one of the lucky ones, so far.

reviewText: I decided to purchase this television (65LB7100) for several reasons. This tv had most of the features that I wanted in my living room. The primary reason why I selected this tv was the passive 3D and WebOS. I honestly believe Samsung makes the highest quality tv, but they use active 3D technology. Also, the comparable Samsung 2014 model to this tv did not support wall mounting (VESA mount). I am not rating this tv 5-stars because the app market is still lacking when compared to Samsung's market. Also, I wish the dual-play feature supported two inputs at once.
summary: LG Wins Because of WebOS and Passive 3D

reviewText: This TV has some mixed reviews, so I will try to address most of these issues when I describe my experience with the LG 55LB7200.Picture Quality -This is obviously the most important feature. I’ve had a fairly nice Samsung for years, and I always always happy with the picture quality, but the LG is even nicer, I think. The picture is brilliant, clear, bright - pretty much everything you want in a TV. The colors seem natural. It works in all light levels. The viewing angles are impressive. It basically looks the same no matter where you position yourself.  I have absolutely no complaints.I’ve noticed some reviewers commenting on uneven backlighting, weird color artifacts, and some sort of dimming issues. I’ve not experienced any of these. The picture looks great all the way to the edges. The TV will change the brightness level of the backlight in accordance with the ambient light of the room, and this can be annoying. The solution is easy: if you turn off the energy saving feature, the screen maintains a constant backlight level, and the dimming issues go away. You’re using more energy, but the picture is consistent.Sound Quality -Does anyone seriously use the built-in TV speakers? I see people complaining about the TV speakers, but common - don’t blame the LG. I’ve never seen a TV with good built-in speakers. They play loud enough to be usable, but they’re not amazing. Who cares. It’s like complaining that the speakers on your laptop don’t have enough bass.Remote -The remote is pretty cool. Instead of limiting you to a four-direction arrow key thing, you get a wii-mote-style cursor that allows you to click wherever you want. This is really nice because it saves you so many clicks when navigating menus. It’s probably cool for some games as well, although I haven’t purchased any from the apps store. If you have a Wii or a second generation Roku, you know what to expect. The remote is slightly more responsive than the Roku remote and the cursor moves a bit faster.Of course, if you don’t like using the cursor, you can use to the knob in the center kind of like a tiny track ball. You can press it to scroll, and you can move it side-to-side. There is a voice activation feature, but this is usually more trouble than it’s worth.The only downside to the remote is that it’s so unique that if you want to use a fancy universal remote with your TV, you lose some cool functionality. Thus, you’ll need to have at least two remotes for your AV system. It’s not a big deal to me - I don’t mind switching remotes - but it is to people like my parents who love their single remote system.Menus -The menu system on TVs varies greatly. The Samsung menus are pretty basic, but you have to click through a lot of submenus to get what you want. The Sony menus are a bit better, but not by much. The LG gives you a horizontal list that pops up anytime you hit the home button. My complaint here is that I would like to rearrange the menu items. I rarely watch things on Hulu, and yet it’s always my second option. It’s way more common that I watch a Blu-ray movie, but this means I have to move to a second screen to see the option. Other than that, I find the menu system to be very intuitive. Without reading the manual, I was able to navigate to any feature I wanted on the first try. As long as you have a typical amount of GUI intuition, you’ll find the menu system to be logical and user-friendly.Hardware/Software -My parents use a Sony system where everything runs through the Blu-ray player. It’s a nice, simple AV hub, but it feels a bit sluggish when compared to, say, a PC. It takes a few seconds for various things like Netflix to load, and it takes a bit of time to power on. The LG is surprisingly spritely. Startup takes maybe 10 seconds, but once the TV is going, the apps load quickly. Netflix pops right up, as does Hulu, YouTube, and whatever else you try.Interestingly, the LG keeps apps running in the background, which allows you to switch between video sources quickly. Say you’re watching Netflix, but you want to check out a YouTube video. Hit the home button, navigate to YouTube, return to the home menu, and Netflix appears in your recent apps section so that you can pick up right where you left off. This is way cooler than the Sony system where you have to completely exit Netflix to do anything else.Each app works a bit differently. The YouTube app is the worst by far because instead of giving you a grid of characters, you get a single row of letters. Searching takes forever. However, this is not, as some have claimed, LGs fault. Apparently, YouTube supplies electronics manufacturers with their own software. The LG YouTube interface is exactly the same as on my parents’ Sony and my old Samsung. Fortunately, YouTube allows you to pair the TV with your smartphone or computer very easily, so you can bypass the apps annoying features entirely.3D -I think 3D is a gimmick. I don’t like paying extra for 3D in theaters, and I don’t care to pay extra for 3D blu-ray discs. Whatever. It’s my prejudice. The TV works just fine though. I don’t have enough bandwidth to stream 3D movies through Netflix (although it’s possible to do so), so my experience is limited to Blu-ray discs and HD broadcasts. Playing through Blu-ray looks amazing. The TV will simulate a 3D effect for HD broadcast input. I don’t get many stations over the air, but I did watch part of an episode of Ellen (it was all that was on the afternoon that I tried it), and it actually looked kind of decent. It’s not something I’d do every day, but it’s a fun gimmick to show friends. The glasses are just regular, 3D glasses like you’d wear at in a movie theater. No batteries required. You get two pairs, and extra pairs are kind of expensive. You could always just hold onto the 3D glasses you get next time you’re at the local multiplex.The only thing to keep in mind is that if you’re hoping to stream 3D movies through Netflix, you’ll need a lot of bandwidth. I pay for 5GB/sec from AT&T;, but realistically, they never give me more than 756k/sec, and that’s not enough. Make sure you are getting more like 1.5g/sec if you want to use this feature.Mirroring / Sharing / Pairing -Screen sharing is available via Miracast. I have Apple products, and they use Airplay. It’s not a huge deal because I can just connect through my AppleTV. If you have an Android device, you should have the functionality built in. I had a friend test it out, and he was able to connect very easily.Setup -Setup was a breeze, although it helps to have two people. Some TVs allow you to set up the base, which the monitor part slides onto. The LG involves screwing in two feet, so you kind of need someone to hold the monitor while driving the screws.Once you power it on, the software setup is fast, intuitive, and easy. An animated penguin character guides you through various steps. It’s mostly graphical, so you don’t have to read any obscure instructions or decode any jargon. It’s quite easy.Design -The appearance of the TV itself is difficult to comment on because with the incredibly narrow bezel, the frame virtually disappears. Essentially, it looks like a big plane of black glass until you turn it on. The minimal design works very well. It has taken me a little while to get used to the apparent lack of a bezel because I’m used to seeing the image framed by a black rectangle, while with the LG, the picture appears to go all the way to the edge, in a manner of speaking.Overall -Overall, I’m very pleased with the LG. It’s the nicest, best looking, most full-featured TV I’ve ever owned. At this point, I have no substantive complaints. Everything works as it is supposed to. Everything looks beautiful. If something changes, I’ll update the review. For now though, I’m going to get back to watching movies!
summary: Great picture, great features, great TV

reviewText: I received this the other day and wanted to try it out to see how well it worked.Upon opening the box,the keyboard is wrapped in plastic and already has batteries installed in it.I like it when companies include batteries.Under the keyboard is the usb receiver and there are instructions which you most likely wont need.I use this with my laptop but I guess you can use it for other things.Its simple to use and I had it working in a couple minutes.Its smaller than a regular keyboard but it works fine for what I will use it for.I hunt and peck so I cant say how it is typing.I guess there are some keys missing for typing.The keyboard was responsive and I didn't have any issues with the touchpad.It seems to work fine for me and I have no problems with the cursor moving around.This is the first time I have used a wireless keyboard with a touchpad and I am very happy with it.I hope this helps you to decide if this is for you.Thank you for your time.

No idea what people are complaining about. This works and works well. None of the quirky issues some others have found. The only thing I ding it for is that I wish it was backlit. Other than that it does what I want it to do.
summary: No idea what people are complaining about. This works ...

reviewerName: Livin' La Vida Low-Carb Man "Jimmy Moore"
reviewText: Microsoft is a brand people know and trust, but they've not done themselves any favors with this All-In-One Media Keyboard. Aesthetically this keyboard looks like it would great. Normal keyboard, natural feel, and everything you would want a keyboard to be. Unfortunately, looks can be deceiving. The execution of this keyboard falls way short of my expectations. When you have a name like Microsoft, you expect things to work well. Sadly, that doesn't happen. FIX THE TOUCHPAD PLEASE!!! This product isn't worth bothering with until Microsoft improves this glaring flaw in their product.

reviewText: I have been using a cheap wireless HP keyboard/mouse for my living room computer/home theater setup, and it was driving me absolutely nuts. There were countless missed keystrokes, lag, and stuttering with the mouse.Let me tell you, this media keyboard is amazing. It works perfectly with little to no noticeable input lag. The size is perfect for a living room TV/PC setup. The touchpad works great however I wish there was a way to manually adjust the pointer speed for only the pad.
summary: This is exactly what I've been needing.

reviewText: Love this product. Wish it came with the original Apple products. Six and a half feet is quite long but better too long than too short.Works great and I recommend it.
Worked for 2 weeks, and then iPad said that I was not using an Apple Certified accessory and it stopped charging the iPad.  Returned.
summary: Worked for 2 weeks and then...it didnt'.

reviewText: It gives the required service.  The length has proven to be an asset as it allows for good maneuvering in my situation.

The case is very thin.  Good for minimal space, but feels kind of flimsy.  The biggest issue is that it does not actually work as a stand.  The photo is misleading -- I have no idea how they got it to hold in place like that.

Great case for the money. Don't expect Otterbox protection, but this light duty case is very nice. Tab4 snaps snugly in base and the magnetic cover that awakens and sleeps the Tab4 is a welcome feature.

For the price this camera is very good.  I have a more expensive camera; however, it is too heavy and the size prohibits convenient carry.  I picked this one up to easily carry in a pocket and use for longer distance shots than my smart phone will make.The only complaint so far is taking pictures of waterfowl where a quicker zoomed focus and stabilization is needed.  The camera will start very quickly; however, when zoomed there is a period of time for the auto-focus to adjust an then for the stabilization to take affect.Otherwise I have very good results from closer waterfowl that are swimming or stationary.  I was very happy with the results when I used this camera at a classic car show to photograph various classic vehicles.  I have not had the opportunity to try all the settings; but, this camera is very easy to carry with me when photographic opportunities arise.If the camera cost twice as much I would give it 4 stars; however, considering its low cost and features it deserves 5 stars.
summary: Very Good Camera, especially when considering its cost.

reviewText: We ordered this to use with an older style tv where we did not have a cable hook up available.  With Time Warner we are able to use the roku channel to see most of our available channels from cable.  It works perfectly and looks brand new.  Cannot even tell that it is refurbished.  Very pleased with this for the price.  I may send this with daughter to college in the fall and order another to keep at home.
Fun to use, reliable and best of all there is some free shows, too.  It is easy to set up, just put in your wifi password.

This USB 3.0 hub from Tek Republic has two advanced super charger USB 3.0 ports, each supplying up to 2.1 A of power, in addition to five universal USB 3.0 ports on the other side, each supplying up to 1 A, but with a shared 5.9 A of power output in total.  The five ports are lined up horizontally 3/4 in. center-to-center and the two fast-chart ports are 1 in. center-to-center and are clearly labelled 2.1 A.The hub measures about 4 1/8 in. by 2 3/16 in. by 5/8 in. with four non-skid feet underneath.  It can be used with the included USB 3.0 cable for fast data transfers from all seven ports plus up to 0.9 A power and if using the hub for charging devices, there is also a power cable with an wall adapter with 5.0 A output that is about 4 1/8 in. x 2 in. x 1 3/8 in.There is a discreet blue LED indicator on the top for power status and smart circuitry for safety and to automatically adjust the power output to the super charger ports.It ships in recyclable, frustration-free packaging.Tek Republic provided a sample for evaluation and review.

This USB hub looks like a 5 + 2 hub (five data ports, two dedicated charging ports).  It's not.  All seven ports can carry data.  The two charging/data ports are supposed to be 2.1 amps.It is a self-powered hub, meaning it comes with an AC adapter.  Can it be bus powered (i.e., will it run without an AC adapter)?  Yes.  Just be sure the devices you plug in are not power hogs.CHARGING PORTSBoth dedicated charging/data ports are labeled 2.1 amps.  Charging a generic Android tablet, I can get 1.47 amps.  It doesn't matter if I'm using a charging port or not.  I'm not sure why the two 2.1 amp ports are marked as dedicated.  They act just like the other ports in every way.These results are not consistent, however.  My iPhone sometimes charged at no more than 0.3 amps and my Kindle at 0.4 amps.  I am not sure why the huge variability, but the charging speed is very noticeably affected, to the point that the iPhone charging indicator does not light up.  At those times, I check the values against my 2.1 amp wall charger and see a huge difference.COMPATIBILITYWhat it works with:* Eikon fingerprint reader* microphone* Bluetooth dongle* ScanSnap scanner* flash driveWhat it doesn't work with:* Logitech Universal Receiver* handheld keyboard dongle* 2 different SD card readers* iPhone 4SSPEEDI do not get USB 3.0 speed from this hub:* moving 1.71 GB to a flash drive on this hub: 57 seconds* moving 1.71 GB to the same flash drive on another USB 3.0 hub: 31 seconds* moving 1.71 GB to the same flash drive on a USB 2.0 hub: 1 minutes 16 secondsOVERALL IMPRESSIONI've owned a lot of USB hubs.  I consider this one underwhelming.  Charging speed is variable.  Charging port is not truly dedicated (I would like it to be dedicated).  Too many devices are not compatible.  It's half the speed of other USB 3.0 ports for data transfer (though faster than a USB 2.0 hub).The good thing is it can be self-powered or bus-powered, so I can charge devices when the computer is off or when I'm not connected to a computer.  This also ensures I won't be underpowered.This product was provided for review by Tek Republic.

This is a Fast Tablet, no question about that. It has though its short comings, some spots of the screen you have to click and click to get a response. All in all it's OK, but the price factor makes it attractive nevertheless. I downloaded several apps to it and they worked. I tried giving it a 4 start but the fact that the screen misbehaves at times convinced me not to. Also the battery runs out very quickly. I drained it completely and now left it to recharge for a good 24 hrs period to see that's a solution. It has a 1yr warranty so that's a good thing. I'll update my review in few days.Update:After removing the screen protective plastic, and wiped the screen with a stick-remover solution (alcohol+water), the spotty click problems have disappeared..(Will add update on Battery issue)
Not as advertised

First off, I ordered a black one and was shipped a white one.  Not worth returning it over though.I am undecided between 3 and 4 stars.  It works and is a usable tablet.  It's light-weight.  Wifi works ok, seems a little slow but I haven't tested it enough to be sure.  I did watch some streaming video over wifi and that worked, so it can't be too slow. Browser works ok.  Touch screen responds ok.  For $55, I think that's about all one can expect.My only real complaint is the screen.  It's like the OS doesn't know what the real size of the display is.  Things are slightly stretched out, like when someone stretches out a 4x3 movie to fit a 16x9 screen.  Not that bad, but enough to be noticable.  Also the screen has to be almost perpendicular to your line of sight to be readable.  But for a $55 tablet, I expected things like that.

I've never been as surprised with a product as I was with the C720.  Chrome has come such as long way in such a short period of time.  If you can get a refurb for $149 on Amazon, you'll never get more value for your dollars.When I want to do more, I've tried Chrubuntu and Crouton.  Crouton was my favorite because it allows you to run linux on top of your Chrome OS without dual-booting.  My favorite method was using the guide for Crouton with ElementaryOS that you can find on the web.16GB is good enough for almost anything.  Don't forget that it comes with a USB 3.0 port and an SD slot if you need more space.  My battery life has averaged out to be 8 to 9 hours.
summary: Stick Crouton and Elementary on it!

reviewText: Love it. Light, long batter, runs Linux. Does not have windows drivers but I dont care. Get it, nice toy.

The refurbished Acer Chromebook C720-2802 is a good value at one hundred fifty dollars if you primarily plan to use it for web applications such as browsing, email, media, and so on, and aren't getting it for an intensive user who likes to keep 30 tabs open (think about more memory for them).  It's a good match for children or other basic users, or as a second device.  It's designed to be easy to setup, use and maintain.The hardware is limited but adequate for the uses above, and better than most other Chromebooks.  The upside of the hardware limitations is the long 8 hour battery life (as a laptop, or for displaying video about 6.5 hours).This is a newer model (the C720 series was introduced in fall 2013) with a number of improvements from the older C710 series, including longer battery life and smaller size.Other than being dinged for the bland design, it has gotten very positive reviews in late 2013 and early 2014.  Look for the Endgadget C720 review page for links to a number of reviews.  People like the trackpad.PORTABLE AND SMALL:  The compact size and light weight make it very portable.  However, the screen size and keyboard size may be too small for some users, depending on their hand size and their eyesight.  It's a 11.6" HD Widescreen LCD display (1366 x 768 resolution) with a matte coating.  The keyboard is smaller and has less "travel" (up and down range of motion) than larger computers, but I found it easy to get used to and have no trouble typing on it.This laptop measures 11.3" by 8" x 0.8" and weighs 2.76 pounds.CHROMEBOOK:  In case you don't know, a Chromebook is not a Windows or Mac computer.  It's based on the Google Chrome suite, and the operating system is Chrome OS.  This works fine if *all* the applications you need are on the web.  But note that it will not run Skype (a Microsoft product), or let you install any other software (including drivers for mice or printers).  So printing is somewhat cumbersome (depending on your setup) and not all USB drives and devices will work.However, the Chrome OS and Chromebooks have some substantial advantages, besides the price:  you don't have to buy any software or hardware; you don't have mess around with Windows for software updates, dealing with problems, etc.; virus protection is built in; and if you have issues with software you can easily re-load all the software with a "PowerWash."FAST BOOT:  Because this uses Chrome OS and a Solid State Drive, it boots very quickly - less than 10 seconds usually.ACER:  Acer is the fourth largest computer company in the world, after Lenovo, HP and Dell, and ahead of Asus.  They also sell computers under the Gateway and Packard Bell brand names.REFURBISHED:  Computers sold as refurbished aren't new.  Sometimes they've been repaired, sometimes they are just returns.  Some may have cosmetic damage - but they should not have any functional issues. You do need to be prepared to return the item if there's a problem, so it may not be for everyone.  But for most people, it's a way to get a great value on a laptop that will work as well as a new one.  You'll forget it's refurbished.90 DAY WARRANTY:  As a refurbished computer, the warranty is only 90 days.  Typically problems appear early on, and there aren't many moving parts in this computer.  But the shorter coverage is one reason why this costs less.2GB OF RAM, MAXIMUM:  The maximum amount of memory that can be installed is the 2 GB that this ships with.  That's enough for most web applications, but not enough for intensive applications like complex photo or video editing.  It is fairly fast PC3-12800 DDR3 memory, though.MODEST PROCESSOR: The Intel Celeron 2955U dual-core processor runs at 1.4GHz and has a CPU benchmark score of 1533.  It's fine for the uses described above, but only comparable in processing power to the netbooks that were so popular a few years ago.  However, it is a newer processor (released Fall 2013), so the Intel HD graphics are improved and the newer Ultra Low Voltage processors extend the battery life.  It's also a more capable processor than some other Chromebooks, which use tablet-quality processors.LIMITED STORAGE SO USE THE CLOUD: The 16GB solid state drive won't hold many files; about 10GB of the space is free for your files.  So plan on using the cloud and/or flash drives for your storage needs.  There is a built in SD card reader as well.USB 3.0: You may not think this matters to you, but it does.  If you want to use flash drives, external hard drives or a memory card reader, USB 3.0 is far faster than USB 2.0. There's one USB 3.0 port and one USB 2.0 port on this laptop.SOME NICE FEATURES:  The C720-2802 includes the essential features -  wifi, stereo speakers, a basic webcam - as well as as well as some nice features not found on all low price computers - Bluetooth 4.0 for wireless connections to a phone or speakers; and  HDMI to connect video devices, displays or a TV.  However, as with all of these tiny laptops, there is no optical drive (DVD).
summary: Great value for money for basic web-based uses

reviewText: I bought 3 units because of the price, performance and weight of this Chromebook.  Never see anything like it.  The weight is lighter than a Netbook, speed feel like an i5 w/ SSD, and each cost $150.  All three units like brand new w/out any damage anywhere.This Chromebook is for anyone as a backup laptop since it is not a Window Machine.  But for me is more than enough since I only do things w/ cloud computing.  Next order for this baby, upgrade to 240Gb M2 SSD, this is a beautiful world w/ all these wonderful toys.......The new gen. of mainframe computing is here.

This Aeon Z-Wave product worked perfectly with my Raspberry Pi + Z-way (Z-Wave Razberry-Pi GPIO Daughter Card) setup, I highly recommend it (and their Multisensor PIR too) if you are wanting to control Z-wave devices around your home with a Raspberry PI.Z-way had no issues configuring this, it worked immediately with no issues.

This works well. I have several of them mounted, one of which is about 20 meters from my controller. I can't comment on battery life as i'm still on the original set.If you have trouble getting it to pair, first go into your controller and "un-pair" the device. Then try and pair again and it should work. I had to do this for one of the 2 sensors that I installed.Don't feel you need to use the screws to mount this thing; the tape that comes with it is extremely strong. I found this out when I decided I wanted to move one of them. It was quite hard to get it back off even though it had only been stuck there for a minute or two.
summary: "Un pair" first if you have a problem pairing. Feel free to use the tape

reviewText: I used this with my MacBook Pro and it worked very well but I decided to return it because there isn't a Link and Activity light. I ordered thedodocool 3-Port USB 3.0 multi-function Hub with 1 RJ45 Gigabit Ethernet Lan Wired Network Adapter Compatible with USB2.0/USB1.1 Support IPv4 & IPv6 COE(USB 3-Port HUB with gigabit ethernet)because it has these.
summary: No link and Activity light, otherwise works well.

reviewText: *** Update 4-23-2014 ****I managed to download additional drives from the manufacturer's website for my Macs. Once I had done this, the adapter worked with both Macs and Windows computers. the performance with Macs was very smooth and fast. I am leaving the original review below.*** The original review. ***The main laptop that I use is a MacBook Air. It is a really great device, very portable, well engineered, and very fast for the purposes of the main tasks I use it for - word processing, email, web surfing, some light photo and video editing. However, its lightness and portability come at a price - MacBook Air is extremely ports-deficient. It has only two USB ports, one SD card slot and a small headphones jack. Most of the times when I use it none of this lack of ports bothers me, but there are situations when I need to use more than two USB devices at the same time, or connect to the Internet via a wired connection. This small Inateck USB/Ethernet hub seemed like an ideal accessory to have around. Unfortunately, I couldn't get ethernet working.I am running Mac OS-X Mavericks on all of my computers. I've connected bot my MacBook Air and Mac Mini to this adapter, but neither one of them was able to recognize the ethernet connection. (The USB hub part was fine.) The adapter comes with no printed instructions, and the pdf manual is very sparse and very clearly geared to Windows computers.In order to see if I didn't by any chance get a defective unit, I connected this adapter to my Windows 8 machine. The adapter was recognized immediately without any need for the installation of the driver software. The Ethernet connection was extremely smooth and fast, and I didn't see any difference as compared to getting online through the dedicated Ethernet port.The three USB 3.0 ports have functioned splendidly, both on my Mac and Windows computers. They really help with the additional connectivity, without the need for external power. The USB strip is fairly compact, so you would not want to connect any bulkier USB devices to it.This could have been a really great overall adapter, but unfortunately right now I cannot recommend it to any Mac users out there. The users of Windows ultrabooks, on the other hand, should really appreciate all the additional connectivity that this adapter offers.**** Product provided for review purposes. ****
summary: Update: Works with Macs and Windows Computers

reviewText: I tested this product in a Windows 7 environment and was extremely impressed.  Anyone using an ultra-book or a tablet with a USB (or micro USB) port will find this product incredibly useful when traveling.The product arrived packaged very well.  The build quality is very good (solid) and will definitely survive travel.  All the ports are solidly built and I doubt they will come loose.  The design is also very stylish as the manual says and is also easily portable. The connection cord (USB) is anchored very well to the device. Installation instructions were sufficient.  I did not have to use the included driver (CD Rom) in a Win7 environment. Of significant note, no additional power source is required.Installation was extremely simple in a Win 7 environment.  Both my desktop and laptop recognized the device. However, on a friends system, which was also a Win 7 OS, we had to install the driver.  Once installed, we had immediate access to 3 additional USB ports and an Ethernet port.The product package includes an On the Go (OTG) micro USB adapter making it useful for those tablets, or other devices that have a a micro USB connection.  This is a device that will find a place in most road warriors bags.
summary: Innovative quality product for mobile users (Win 7 environment)

reviewText: I bought a refurbished unit. It looked like new. Worked perfectly. I am glad I stuck to Linksys as they make great products.
summary: Easy Setup, Looks Greats and a Great Value

reviewText: worked fine for one day  then no more wireless. have to use wired for connection reloaded software several times, bought new  linsys adapter still no wireless. Maybe should never buy refurb
summary: worked fine for one day then no more wireless

reviewText: The unit that was sent to me did power up, however it never did anything more than that.  I tried resetting it at least a dozen times and never could get it to register even to the point that it was visible as a source to connect to.

This thing crashes constantly and requires unplugging and replugging all the time.  If you look through the reviews you'll see that many many people have this problem.  It could probably be fixed with a firmware update, but there isn't any firmware update available.  I've been using routers and making my own repeater setups since 1999 and this is the worst I've ever run into.  Save your money and get something else.

Pros are that is was easy setup and when it works, it works great. Unfortunately it has to be frequently unplugged and plugged back in to work since it keeps dropping signal. I know it's not my router since I have multiple devices hooked up to it and no problem. I just wanted to get a better signal on the other side of house.  Was to quick and threw out the box otherwise would have returned it. Keep looking if you want a range extender that doesn't have to be reset constantly.

When my review sample arrived I immediately installed it because I have some WiFi dead spots in my home that sorely needed a signal boost. This did the trick and did it quickly and effectively.I opted to use this as a repeater versus an access point. You have both options. I needed it to extend my signal to a room that was getting a very marginal one according to theWi-Fi Analyzerapp I used to measure it.Before installing this range extender I was getting a signal of about -45 dBm near the primary wireless router and -80 dBm in the dead room. After installing this extender the signal boosted to -50 dBm in that room, which was a dramatic improvement and also eliminated the unstable WiFi connection messages I was getting on my smartphone when I was in that room.Installation is exceptionally easy if you follow the very clearly written and illustrated instruction manual that comes this this device. You need to select whether you want to use this as a repeater of access point. Either mode will work and I tried both. You can configure this from your browser, so no additional software or drivers are required.Some aspects of the installation and configuration are technical, but even a non-technical person can perform the necessary steps if the instructions are followed to the letter. What impressed me was the instruction manual had a card enclosed with a support number in Los Angeles, a support web site and email address. I did not use the email to test response, but the support site had a downloaded app for Macs and Windows that will assist the staff in analyzing problems. That level of support speaks volumes about the quality of the overall operation.Performance exceeded my expectations, especially considering the less than twenty-bucks this cost at the time or this review. It definitely works as described and can be up and running in less than ten minutes if you are reasonably technical and not much longer if you follow the instructions that come with it.
summary: Easy install and works exceptionally well

reviewText: Installing repeaters and other network devices is often not so easy, and is generally not something for the non-technical user. Sabrent's unit is one of the most easily installed appliances that I've evaluated. (I received a review sample from the company.)Other repeaters that I've tested required a wired connection to a laptop or desktop for initial setup. That's a bit of a nuisance and requires at least some networking knowledge. But this unit can be configured over the air. I tried that, using the instruction booklet supplied with the device, and had it set up in just a couple of minutes. It really can't get any better than that.The unit's box, and the web advertising, don't point out that this unit will also operate as a wireless access point, a wireless router, or a "wisp" router (if you use a wireless internet service provider). While the instruction booklet does well enough showing you how to enable it as a repeater, the access point instructions aren't so good, being not very complete and containing errors. The other modes aren't described at all. However, if you do have some networking skills, it's not hard to figure out. But the instructions could have been better, putting the unit more in the reach of the less technical user.How well does it work? Pretty well, actually. The repeated signal is strong enough to be quite useful. Positioning the unit is important. It is supposed to be halfway between the router and the target reception area, but I find it's better closer to the router. The unit wants a strong and stable input signal. It certainly puts out a strong output signal, so be sure your input is good and you'll get good performance.The unit plugs directly into a wall socket. This might put it near the floor when it would be better if it were higher up. For a permanent installation, you might rig something up to get more "altitude" for the unit. A higher location usually helps with both pick-up and transmission of the wireless signal. (Of course, if the router's on the first floor, the repeater's on the second, and the target is the third, you don't have to worry so much about this.) And by the way, when plugged in the unit restricts access to the second socket of a typical two-socket outlet. You can route a cord over the top ridge of the unit and into the outlet, but it's not convenient. The physical design of the unit could have been better.I wouldn't call this an especially portable unit, although it's lightweight. It's just a wee bit bulky and the outlet prongs don't fold. In any case, you'll probably put it in a fixed location.Bottom line: four stars for good performance and ease of setup. One star off for documentation and physical design.
summary: Exceptionally easy setup and quite versatile

reviewText: Good value, easy to configure, has been running 24/7 without issue for months
I initially had issues with drops connection, intermittent loss of network.They contacted me direct, and was provided a replacement device that has been stable.  I do appreciate them trying.
summary: got a replacement and now working

reviewText: Like others looking at this product, I wanted a travel case for my Bose SoundLink Mini.  I wanted a case that could hold the speaker in it's soft cover along with the AC adapter, bonus points if it could also hold the charging base.  I didn't want to spend $45 on the expensive Bose case so I purchased this one.This case holds the SoundLink Mini in it's soft cover though the fit is a little tight.  I took my speaker out of the soft cover and it fit better but I quickly put the soft cover back on.  The case also holds the AC adapter but not the charging dock.  That wasn't really a killer feature for me but it would have been nice.  The zipper is a little difficult to fully close with everything in the case but it still works.  All-in-all, the case does the job but it would have been nice to see some breathing room in there.  I like the semi-rigid design as, to me, it appears to offer more protection than a standard soft case.  For this price, I really don't think you can go wrong as it's $20 less than the one from Bose yet holds the same content.My only big complaint is that this case smells awful.  It has a processed plastic smell that takes a while to air out.  I highly suggest immediately taking it out of the plastic wrapping, opening it, and putting the case outside overnight.  Then bring it back in, stuff it with some dryer sheets, zip the case up, and let it sit for a few more days.  I have had mine for almost a week now and the smell is just now coming out.Edit:I am updating my review after three weeks of ownership.  I could never get the smell fully out of the case.  It was so bad that it spread to the soft cover of the SoundLink Mini making that smell too.  I've tried everything, including Febreeze on the inside, but the case still smelled.  It wasn't near as bad as when I first opened the case but it was still pretty bad.  The zipper also broke just after 3 weeks of ownership.  I took it on one trip, the zipper busted open, and I could never really get it back.  The case is just a hair too small to hold the speaker in a cover and AC charger (even though it has a pouch for the charger).I recommend people save up their money and buy a more expensive option even if it is the $45 Bose case.  It's better than this $20-ish case and won't break after a few weeks, plus it doesn't smell like processed chemicals.

I replaced a lower wattage Seasonic unit with this.  When looking at 850w power supplies I was immediately drawn to Seasonic do to their great reputation.  Then I saw EVGA's new lineup based with good reviews and stats and decided to give it a try. It runs silent, and has not given me any problems, powers my rig without breaking a sweat. 4770k @ 4.2ghz, 780 @ 1163ghz, 16g ram @ 2400mhz.  When purchasing I wanted to make sure I had enough wattage to sli 780's further down the road.  It also comes with 4x 6+2 pci-e connectors which the 780 uses 2 of.
summary: Great Power supply at a competitive price.

reviewText: Used this power supply in a new build and i haven't regret it since. its whisper quiet, the build quality is outstanding, its really heavy and not made of some cheap material. it has a matte feel to it.  Roughly 7 inches long so it does have some size to it but fit perfect in my Fractal Design R4 blackout edition case. Plenty of wires and great length. It also comes with a mb cable adapter for testing and if u have a WC build it makes it easy to get that reservoir filled. while plugged into my battery UPS system im running at 64 watts idle with monitor off. its really power efficient and id recommend it to anyone looking for a quality power supply built by a high tier oem manufacturer SUPERFLOWER.specs for my build.i5 4670kasus z87 pro motherboardevga gtx 680samsung evo 250gb ssdevga 850g2 power supplyh80i cpu cooler16gb corsair vengeance pro 1600mhz ramFractal Design R4 Blackout Edition

This power supply came to my interest after reading reviews from johnnyguru and other sites that actually dissect and inspect the components. It got very good reviews across the board so I decided to buy it to upgrade my rig. I had been looking at the Corsair rm/hx850, Seasonic X-850 and XFX PRO 850W also, and this one seems to be the best for value.The power supply looks great in person and is phenomenally packaged, with a nice bag covering the psu and velcro bag for storing unused cables. The 850G2 is a great looking unit with its unique fan grill and textured finish, and feels quite substantial. Cables are just ok though, with ribbon cables sleeved quite lazily with quite a bit of of the heat shrink showing. It would have been better to leave the black ribbon cables bare. The connectors are good and plentiful though; much better than my last XFX units.The power supply is quiet even when not in the hybrid fan mode. I would recommend just leaving the fan on all of the time to avoid reducing the lifespan of the unit. It does come with a 10 year warranty though, so this may not concern you. It is running smoothly and is stable at full loads on an overclocked i5 high end rig with crossfired 7950's. All of my components are pushed to the max overclock not including memory and this thing still runs pretty quiet. Keep in mind that I run it intaking inside the case though.Overall I am impressed with EVGA on this unit, and I hope that they continue to offer this kind of quality at this price. I want to add that I also purchased the premium cables they offer on their website, and they arrived quickly. The cables are much better than what come with the unit, so I am left with the feeling that they skimped on the stock ones with the hopes of luring you to the premium cables (which come in at 90$). This is my only gripe about this unit. I still highly recommend it.
Looks awesome, very heavy duty, and puts out the power it says it does. Will keep buying these for high end builds.
summary: As good as it gets for power supplies.

reviewText: Fantastic if you have 1 video card.  I couldn't be happier with this powersupply it had everything I needed at a great price. It looks nice and the presentation was very nice too. It comes with a nice bag to put anything in extra that you need and I keep all the extra screws and what not from my motherboard in there too. Perfect Power supply so far.

I searched all over the web for an amazing gold PSU. this new 750G2 unit from EVGA has a long list of awards. I am extremely impressed. Don't hesitate to buy this power supply over the 750G. it's about a 10$ difference but the quality difference is immense. I was also looking at corsairs RM750 model only because it has silent operation and stays below 30db at 100% load. In the end though the high ratings and better efficiency of this unit won me over.

If you have any problems with the machine you are in real trouble.I have had a bad experience with Asus.I wish I had read this on the BBB about Asus before purchasing any product.Direct From the BBB"We have identified a pattern of complaints concerning service issues. Complaints processed by BBB claim that 1) products sent to the company for repairs are still not working properly when returned to the consumer.On June 29, 2012 ASUS responded to the issue by stating: We continuously enhance our repair service levels across the board, but in specific response to the repair quality concerns addressed in this letter we have strengthened core processes which may have been at the root of the matter and ASUS valued customers, with non-component systems products will benefit from the enhanced RMA process and instructions.BBB again reviewed this company's file for complaints. As of January 14, 2013 the issue of products sent to the company for repairs still not working properly when returned to the consumer still remains." - See more at: [...][...]
