I have fat hands - maybe they need to go on a diet - so I have a little trouble using this thing.  But - it's better than trying to press on the screen.  Anyhow, this is a rechargeable x-box-style controller for your iphone/ipad.  It works pretty well, considering it's size.  I have trouble using the bumper/trigger buttons, as they're really close together and hard to tell apart by feel (for me, at least), but overall it's a neat controller for your ipad/iphone games.  I bet an 8 year old would love this.  Mine had a slight defect in that the cover which also acts as an extension for the rear of the controller doesn't stay on.  It doesn't want to clip on, so I can't use it unless I hold the controller in a death-grip.  But, overall I do like the controller!
summary: Neat device - kinda small - meant for kids I think

reviewText: This controller is made for iDevices. Simply turn on bluetooth, turn the controller on and push the button in the back and you're all set. The controller is similar to a Xbox one but much smaller. It's about the size of my iPhone 5s. Buttons are quite firm so I think it'll last you a long time. Built quality is decent. Overall, cool gadget for your iDevices. 4 stars due to the expensive price tag.

The SteelSeries Stratus Wireless Gaming Controller may be a teensy-weensy devise, but it pairs nicely with medium- to small-size hands; the drawback, of course, would be for users who have larger hands.  So, larger-hand users take note that this device may not be a benefit to you!Overall, the controller is easy to maneuver and makes for a flawless gaming experience. Thumbs up too for the pressure-sensitive, color-coded buttons and overall, easy-to-navigate design. The extended battery life 10-hour feature is a pronounced perk, and helps justify the weighty price. A nice addition to any gamer's experience; the controller is a great gift idea too.Stacy Lytwyn, Marketing Guru/Motivational Speaker/JournalistAuthor: CONSUMMATE CONNECTICUT: DAY TRIPS WITH PANACHEAce Blogger: WTF: Where's the Faith, wtfwheresthefaith.wordpress.com
summary: The SteelSeries Stratus Wireless Gaming Controller for iPhone, iPad, and iPod Touch - Small in Size, Big in Gaming Performance

reviewText: Very decent sound quality for the price, I used for a few hours and my 7 year old used for 4 days so far 6 hours per day on Skype and really loves it.  So it fits kids heads pretty well and adults heads, is a little tight at first but flexes in a day or two without causing too much discomfort.  The foam padding over the ears is comfortable but small,it rests on the earlobes rather than around them which feels a little odd for an adult head but works well in helping it accommodate smaller heads.Microphone quality is decent, Skype voice is clear, picks up sound well.  Great for not tying up a USB port if you are USB Port limited and works with any device that has just a 3.5mm headphone and microphone jack.  Recommended, but can't speak for durability yet as we only have had it for 5 days.
summary: Good Sound for the Price and Fits Adult and Kid Head Sizes

reviewText: I have more BT speakers than I care to mention, but let's just say a LOT.  I don't try to collect them, but in my search for The One, I have gone through (and still use) many.This one ranks up there with the better ones if you consider the size.  You're not going to want this as your main BT speaker, since as I mentioned, there are so many out there, and if you don't need the portability, then you will easily get better sound in other options (for not much more $$).But this is the smallest one I have used, and if you wanted something for travel, or even something to carry on your bike, for instance, this would be the one I would use.I doubt I would ever get a second for the stereo effect, just due to cost, and again, if I am going to pay that, and get that extra bulk...there are much better sounding options out there.Love the weather-resistance, build quality is VERY tight, very impressive, and most important, the sound is quite impressive considering the small size.Very highly recommended if you specifically need an ultra-small BT speaker.
summary: Love the portability, sound is good for size

reviewText: The SOC design keeps the associated AM1 mainboards very inexpensive, especially if you buy them as a combo with the CPU from certain online retailers. If you compare it to the budget Celerons available for similar builds, the Passmark scores are right on par, the AMD uses less than half the power, and at least in my case, the CPU+mainboard combo came out cheaper. Granted, the Celeron will smash it in single threaded apps, but from what I can tell, the most important stuff is multi-threaded now.While the included fan is initially noisy on first boot, as long as you set up the SmartFan settings in the BIOS, you probably won't hear it again. While maxing-out the CPU on benchmark software, it never got hot enough to need even a third of the fan's maximum speed. The CPU itself is still somewhat pricey. Drop the price by $15 and it becomes a clear cut winner vs Intel in my opinion. Also, the heatsink mounting system was a bit of a hassle the first time through, but I managed to figure it out.AMD may have a really good thing going with this CPU. It seems to hit a nice sweet spot in efficiency between Intel's Bay Trail (which is non-socketed, and severely limits mainboard options), and the more power hungry Celerons. While the 10W TDP of Bay Trail allows it to be passively cooled, and makes it a great choice for battery powered applications, it can't match the performance of the AMD, which in some ways, can keep up with the bigger Celerons, due to the quad cores.
summary: Makes for a great budget build

reviewText: Great low-power media PC CPU. Has kept my wife and I entertained without breaking the bank on hardware or electricity. Also nice as an extra couple of cores for distcc compilation.
summary: Great low Has kept my wife and I entertained without breaking the bank on hardware or electricity. -power media PC CPU.

reviewText: These are good, solid headphones. I can't say they blew me away, though.Surprisingly, the frequency response is very flat. With "Street by 50 Cent" on the box, I was kind of expecting them to be seriously bass-heavy, but that's not the case. I listened to quite a variety of different music, and was pleased with their performance across the board.I hesitate to refer to "noise canceling," since there is no active NC going on here, but the ear cups do a decent job of blocking out outside sounds. They are soft and have smooth covers, and I can go about an hour before they start to get uncomfortable. Not bad, but could be better.The Star Wars themed design and accessories are pretty cool. This Boba Fett model will only be recognizable to the hardcore fan, but the design is nice looking anyway.
summary: Good sound; decent sound insulation; relatively comforable

reviewText: Ha! So that is the question.I've reviewed quite a bit of high-end headphones, and I'd say that the answer might be $50 to $80. They do sound great, to be sure, but not better than other brands I've tested in the $100 range. This being said, that doesn't mean they're not worth $200. On the contrary, if you are a huge Star Wars fan like I am, these First Edition Headphones are definitely worth the cost of admission. Of all four designs, the Boba Fett model is definitely the most old-school looking and depending on your tastes, this can be a good or a bad thing.The packaging that this set comes in is extraordinary for sure. Think of the way your iPhone is packed. Everything fits together perfectly, the box is well-made, emblazoned with hologram stickers proving its authenticity. They have even thrown in some swag as well, which is a nice touch.The earphones themselves feel great. The leather ear-pads are buttery-soft and do a great job of keeping outside noises out.In regards to the sound, I find them to be a bit bass-heavy, which is different than other reviewers I've read. In fact, these are the first headphones where, when I put on hip-hop and turn up the volume, the earphones vibrate like my car did in the 1990's.All in all, I think this is a great buy for a Star Wars fan or anyone who wants to add some style to their head when they listen to music.
summary: So how much are you paying for the Star Wars marketing, licencing, packaging, and design?

reviewText: Let me start out by saying that the cost of these headphones is pretty steep.  But, the new trend now is professionally tuned headphones.  What with Dr. Dre's Beats headphones and all, these phones, made by 50 cent and SMS Audio is another set to hit the market.Packaging.  Very, very nicely packaged.  Really nice case.  Comes with a special carrying case that looks like a football.  Unzip it and get the phones.  They fold inwards to fit in the case.  It comes with a cable that you connect to your PC, iPod, MP3 player, PS Vita, or anything that you plug in a mini plug cable for audio.These are very well made.  The padding on the top and the ears are soft and so feel comfortable.  They don't quite fit over your ears, but they are nice.  They do cancel out surrounding noise, but not all.  I wore them at work and while someone was talking to me, I could only see their lips move.  I wasn't being rude, the person was helping me try it out.I notice that these produce nice high frequencies and nice Bass as well.  Good balance.The outside cups are decorated with the Boba Fett insignia.  More than just a decal, they are molded plastic.  They do adjust to fit your head/ears.It comes with a certificate of authenticity and a cleaning cloth as well.  Very nice.Now, I am a musician.  I use Shure in-ear monitors for practicing, recording, performing.  They are really great at cancelling out everything except what you have in your monitors.  I decided to do a test.  And that is to use these to record and play back.  I noticed that playing the drums, the noise of the drums bled into the earphones making it almost impossible to use these as recording headphones, so the noise cancellation may only work with low sound pressure levels.  I plugged in my Shure in-ear monitors again and what a difference.I know it's unfair to compare these to in-ear professional monitors, but I thought I'd try it for those musicians who are considering using these in their studios.  You shouldn't.It would be great if these were wireless.  That would be fantastic.  But, these are what they are.  They are good sounding headphones.
Great cables, work well, and even though I'm not a fan of the locks, it's at a great price.

reviewerName: John Ryan "One man and his Kat"
reviewText: Don’t know about you, but I’m on my mobile or iPad almost from when I wake up to going to bed.  Of course, this also means I can’t spend more than 24 hours away from a power socket - that is until now.Here’s why…..What is it and what does it do—————————————This terrific little, beautiful white box of tricks is an external battery pack for an iPhone or Android Smartphone or an iPad or Android tablet computer.  Basically, if you’re out and about (on a long rail journey or away camping or at a rock festival), you can re-charge your phone up to 4 or 5 times back to full charge.What's it like?------------------In a word, beautiful.  Wrapped in a white hard case, and just slightly taller than a iPhone 5 or Nexus 5 (but a lot narrower and reassuringly heavy), it has a fantastic top quality feel about it.It comes in at 5.5 inches long by 2.5 inches wide and under half an inch deep.  Has a reassuring heft, and a lovely top quality finish with two USB ports (means you can charge two devices at the same time), and a single button which lights up 4 blue LED lights to indicate how fully charged it is.You’d be forgiven for mistaking this from a Apple designed product, as the quality and finish are top end.  Even the packaging, a custom designed box lined with a black inner case, and a white Micro-USB to USB cable and instructions inside.What will it charge?-------------------------Well, just about anything with a Mini or Micro USB or a cable with a full size USB plug - which is pretty standard on nearly all battery powered devices. A little research shows it's good for:-* Apple iPhone 5, 5s and 5c. (Using your own USB-Lightening connector)* Apple iPhone 3, 3G, 3Gs, 4, 4Gs. (Using your USB-30 pin cable)* Samsung Galaxy Note 3 S4 S3 S2 Note 2* Blackberry, HTC, LG, Motorola, Sony android Smart Phones and Tablets.* Google Nexus 4 and 5 smartphones and Nexus 7 and 10 tablet computers* Kindle Paperwhite Fire HD, GPS and just about anything else with a USB connector.Does it work?------------------Glad to say, yes. it charged my Google Nexus 5 from absolutely flat to 100% in under 2 and a half hours.  What’s more, the 4 lights (which each indicate 25% charge) didn’t even move, and I’d expect it’ll charge another 3 to 4 times before fully flat.The battery is rated at 10,400mAh (the higher the better) which means it should charge a smartphone several times before finally needing to be plugged in.For example, here's the battery capacity (mAh) of some popular smartphones:-* Google Nexus 5 - 2,300* Samsung Galaxy S3 - 2,100* Samsung Galaxy S4 - 2,600* Apple iPhone 5 - 1,400* Apple iPhone 5S - 1,570* Apple iPhone 4S - 1,432So (roughly speaking), you should get around 4 to 5 full charges out of an iPhone 5 before you need to re-charge the unit.What's Good about it?-----------------------------* Absolutely top quality build and packagingSolid and sturdy with a nice heft.Comes with a felt draw-string bag and USB to Micro USB cable* Enough power to charge a standard smartphone 4+ times.What's not so good?---------------------------Not a lot really.  You need to use your existing charger to power it up, but it comes 100% fully charged straight from the box, and if it came with another charger, it’s just yet another charger to lose.Conclusion---------------Fantastic little charger.  Absolutely love it.  Highly recommended.Disclosure: I was kindly sent this by the manufacturer to give an independent unbiased review.  I do hope you found this review useful.
summary: Fantastic!  Beautiful, top quality smartphone or tablet charger.  Highly Recommended

reviewText: This USB charging hub is cleverly shaped like a book and can be used in a vertical or horizontal position.  Dimensions are approximately 4 1/8 in. x 4 in. x 1 1/4 in.  It has a nominal 45 in. power cable with heavy strain relievers and a polarized plug.Power is controlled by a rocker switch of good quality located in the rear.  On the front are a bright blue LED indicator for power and four USB ports generously spaced at 5/8 in. center-to-center and labelled A through D.  Each port provides up to 1.5A of power and all four can be used simultaneously.  There is smart circuitry to automatically adjust output and ensure safety.This hub makes a nice charging station for personal or shared use.  It ships in frustration-free packaging with a plastic insert.

Traveling this day in age requires too many cables and chargers.One for the smartphone, tablet, laptop, bluetooth speaker, portable battery, smartwatch...  not to mention for those traveling with you.The outlet plug snaps out of the way when not in use, giving this a compact form.The outlet plug is snug, and this doesn't fall out of the wall socket.  The plug is lightweight.Others have done the amp-current testing.

Pretty good charger, several companies seem to make this same type.  It is most likely just one manufacture.  So far, it has worked as expected, being about to charge my iPad, my phone, and my external battery at the same time without issue.  It thing is much bigger than you would expect.  It is 50% bigger than a pack of cigarettes.  I do not smoke, size just for reference.  It does have a problem with holding itself up when pulled into a looser wall socket.  Recommend using it with a horizontal surge protector.

Inateck’s USB charger is reasonably priced and works well. Upon receiving it, I tested it by simultaneously charger my iPad and my iPhone. The charger supplies a higher amperage than a normal charger, so it charges more quickly, at least in theory. It’s tough for me to say whether this translated into charge times that were meaningfully faster. I can certainly say that, if nothing else, it didn’t charge *slower* than other chargers.Irrespective of the charging speed, it’s very convenient for someone with multiple devices, especially when traveling. My iPad comes with a hefty charging unit, and if I try to use the standard iPod/iPhone charger, it takes forever. The Inateck allows me to bring only one charger with me.The build quality is good, and after using the charger for a couple weeks, it’s still going strong. I have every expectation that it will last. I'm deducting one star because there are a range of similar USB wall chargers that offer four USB ports at the same price. Overall, however, I highly recommend it.

The charger works well and is built well.  The downside is that it's frickin huge.  I was lazy and didn't check the dimensions, but it's about the size of a MacBook Pro power brick.  That was about 3x bigger than I expected and way too big to travel with as I had intended.I'm keeping it since it works well but sadly it won't be in my EDC.

I'm very pleased with these ear buds. The quality is nice, the cord length is perfect, and most of all I love the carrying case. This is the first pair of earbuds that I actually put back into the case consistently.I use this for my Galaxy Note II for both music and phone when I don't feel like being on bluetooth. The good thing about a quality set of headphones like this is they never need to be charged like a bluetooth, so I usually keep these in my purse as a backup to alternatives like Bose headphones or a bluetooth.These are good, reasonably priced multi purpose headphones that you do get what you pay for. These don't seem like they'll fall apart like some candy named headphones, and you will get great sound quality if you are wanting to listen to music.This is a great choice for adults who can take care of things and not lose them.

Quality in-ear headphones are tough to design. Their small size means that there is hardly any room for sound to propagate so bass tends to be weaker. Because they are in the ear rather than over it, that "the music seems to be located in my head rather than in a real space" feeling is a common complaint. I am not much of an IEM listener, favoring over-the-ear headphones for their superior characteristics but I am always on the look-out for a superior IEM.I spent several hours listening to the new Denon AH-C120MA in-ears: playing all kinds of music and experimenting with different sizes and composition of ear-tips. I switched portable devices between Apple made iPods and iPads, an iBasso DX90 DAP and an Amazon Kindle Fire HDX 8.9". My impression of the Denon AH-C120MA In-Ear was generally quite good.Switching between ear-tips, I finally settled on the pair of medium sized Comply foam TX-400M ear tips included in the box. I found them more comfortable than the three pairs of silicon ear tips that were included, considerably less rigid and with a slightly brighter sound. A good seal is imperative when listening to IEMs so I moistened the ear tips slightly before insertion. This seems to create a firmer bond and the addition of evaporating water vapor allows more molecules to be set into motion in the ear canal, which seems to enhance the bass and lower mid-range.The AH-C120MA in-ears have an exceptionally wide sound stage. They are successful at eliminating that "in my head" sound because they create a real sense of acoustic space. The soundstage has a real illusion of width which I found impressive. This is coupled with a nice transparency and an exceptionally pleasant brightness in the music. There wasn't the slightest sense of fatigue after an hour or two of listening. Instrumental music benefits from this spacious presentation, though the mid-range was sufficiently forward to showcase vocals to good advantage as well.Where I found these slightly deficient - as expected - was in the lower-mids and bass. You know they're present but they lack the thump or slam of over-the-ear headphones. Since my listening tastes run mostly to Classical and Jazz, I was not particularly perturbed by this. If your tastes run mostly to hard rock, metal or hip-hop you probably put a premium on bass slam so you should be aware of these intrinsic limitations. Nevertheless, because of their impressive spaciousness, transparency and life-like sound, I thought these in-ear headphones a good value and a solid replacement for generic IEMs.
summary: An exceptionally wide sound stage and nice musical transparency highlight these IEMs

reviewText: I had to look up what made this model any different than the previous one and the only major difference I can see is the 4k 60hz support!  (Also saw that supposedly Onkyo is the FIRST to feature a receiver with full 4k HD passthrough)Now I don't actually own a 4k TV yet - but I do hope to in a couple of years after prices have dropped.  And if you are lucky to own a 4k TV now, then there's no reason you shouldn't get the only receiver that supports the 4k passthrough - this one (and it's bigger 7.2ch brother) and both are available right now.This NR535 replaces a nice Yamaha receiver that had Bluetooth support, but didn't have Spotify, Pandora, XM, etc built into the receiver.  Nor did my old receiver have built-in WIFI.With 90w per channel, this is an excellent and modern receiver.  It's about as easy to setup as any other receiver and produces wonderful sound (okay, so that's really my speakers...) but all of the nice things built in make this a perfect addition to a man cave or media room alongside the finest in speakers, projectors, HDTVs, etc.  (Yamaha....uhm, not so much)No complaints or gripes thus far!  (Will update if I do)

The TX-NR535 is Onkyo's new 2014 entry level A/V receiver, and is the successor to the popular TX-NR525. New this year is the addition of support for HDMI specified 4K/60 Hz video.Out of the box, the TX-NR535 is noticeably well built. It's a clean design, and all the inputs/outputs are well laid out. For testing, I replaced my already setup Denon AVR-E300 with the TX-NR535. I'm using the Klipsch HD300 Speaker System. Getting setup was quick and painless. The menu system on the TX-NR535 is pretty basic and easy to navigate. The GUI looks like something form the 80's, but it's not a big deal. I chose the settings for my speakers manually, and did not use the "AccuEQ Room Calibration". I found a minor issue setting up a Verizon FiOS 4 device remote. There is no code for turning the receiver both on and off. One code will work for turning it on, and another will turn it off. I did a quick Google search and found that this seems to be an issue with many Onkyo receivers. It's not a big deal to me though. The TX-NR535 has built-in WiFi and BT support, which is great. My Denon  AVR-E300 required a wireless adapter. Once connected to my network, I had access to my Sirius/XM account, along with several other music services. I was able to listen to music stored on my PC via DLNA streaming. There is one thing that the TX-NR535 doesn't have which to me is a disappointment. It is built-in Apple "AirPlay" support. I store my entire music library on my iPods, and I love using AirPlay to connect them to my system. My Denon AVR-E300 Receiver which is older and costs about half of what the TX-NR535 costs, has AirPlay built-in. There is an Onkyo iPad/iPod app which allows connecting and streaming from your Apple device. It is a little slow and buggy, but it does work. There is a similar app for Android too. My other minor disappointment is that the TX-NR535 doesn't have a built-in graphic equalizer. All you have are basic tone controls, "optimization", and bass boosting options.Once everything was hooked up and tested, I got down to listening to some music. Overall I was pretty impressed. Despite not being able to tailor the sound with an equalizer, everything I listened to sounded great. I started by watching Led Zeppelin's "Celebration Day" Blu-ray. I was impressed by the highs and lows. I then listened to some New Age music by Kitaro, and some EDM by Deadmau5. I can't complain about anything I heard, and I missed the equalizer much less than I expected. All in all, I'm very happy with the Onkyo TX-NR535. I'm disappointed that some features are missing, but it's still a high quality A/V receiver for the price.Pros:Well designed and built.Easy to setup.Built-in WiFi and BT.Built-in Internet Radio, Sirius/XM, and Streaming.Nice sound.UltraHD 4K/60Hz support.Good value.Plenty of HDMI Inputs.Cons:5 channel instead of 7 channel.No built-in AirPlay support.No built-in graphic equalizer.Archaic GUI.

This is the 4th Network AV receiver I've used the last 4 years. This is also the highest specs/most featured one. Previously I was using a Denon AVR-X100, before that an Onkyo TX-NR515 and before that a Harman Kardon AVR 2600.Pros:1) 7.2 ability - I believe my Harman Kardon had 7.1, but I didn't have the speakers for it. Now I do and I love 7.2 sound. My set up uses 2 high and wide speakers up front. For movies and shows created to use 7.1, the effect is epic. I wasn't sure if it would make a difference, but it did and it's nice to have. The ".2" means you can add 2 subwoofers, which I'm beginning to really get curious about......2) Easy set up and network connectivity - This is something that has been improving with each new receiver. Lately it seems like I just have to connect to the network and everything just shows up. I think DNLA enabled devices are the easiest to use. It just seems like everything that can be used is easily found with no extra tinkering. Wireless and bluetooth work fine, too3) Good internet streaming source list - Good list and includes Slacker, my favorite. The Denon had the fewest choices4) Auto speaker set up software - This is something my last 2 receivers had and I really like it. You use an included microphone to get the best sound adjustments. This model of Onkyo uses their own version of software but it is unclear if it is a version of Audyessy. While I like it, read on in the Cons about it5) Lots of connectivity options - I think this is what you get the more you pay. This one has plenty of HDMI in and 2 out. I know my Denon did not have an input for our Wii, which used RCA connectors, but this one does.6) Zone 2 - This would be an important feature for me because I also have outdoor speakers I use as Zone 2, but I am now using my old Onkyo as a dedicated outdoor amp. This Onkyo has a powered Zone 2 feature (important if you don't have a separate outdoor amp). I haven't tried Zone 2 on this amp, but the previous Onkyo remote had a Zone 2 controls I never did get down. There does appear to be some changes to this Onkyo's remote, so maybe they made Zone controls easier (maybe other reviewers can touch on this)7) Good sound - I am not an audiophile, so I can't go into the technical aspects of this receiver. All I know is that the thing is powerful and it sounds great. It helps to have a bunch of good speakers, though. I think if you just need a really competent AV receiver, this level of specs/features has just about everything you need. They claim it is future proof because it supports 4K video, 21:9 display format, HDCP 2.2 and a bunch of other stuff I'm not really up on. But, I guess if I get them in the future, I'm ready8) Workable smartphone app - I actually prefer using it to the remote sometimes. It also impresses your friends at parties the first time they see you use itCons:1) Auto sound settings software - In my review of the Denon, I praised the ability of the Audyssey MultiEQ XT. Onkyo has been a client of Audyessy for a while, but now they are using either a completely new software of their own or a modified version of an Audyessy product, AccuEQ (the fact they use "EQ" in the name hints it might be an Audyessy product). I do like it the AccuEQ, but not nearly as much as the MultiEQ XT. It lacks the "3D" effect of sound seemingly coming out of nowhere, filling the entire space from all directions. I miss that. AccuEQ is good, especially handling 7.2 speakers, but it just doesn't have the same sonic effect on my ears. I will continue to tinker with it, but it is a let down (of course, if you never used Audyessy before, this will still seem like a big improvement)2) Lack of ability to display anything but music from network sources - This is an odd inability. It took me forever to confirm it wasn't built to do it. My last 3 AV receivers could do it. I just expected a network AV receiver to display images (though none display video from network sources, which also seems odd for an Audio Video receiver). To add to the confusion, when searching network sources, it lists audio, images and video categories, and search results will show (and take time to download in the list) image and video files, but if you click on one, it doesn't work. I really think this stinks, especially for the level of model it is. I can still get images, but not video, to display, but I have to go to a connected device (Roku, in my case) to do it. I really can't believe this inability from this receiver3) Poor user interface - This is really an industry wide issue. I have yet to see a truly easy to use and understand user interface. It's take a long time to figure out where everything is, how to get there, what it does and how to use it. In addition, there is inconsistency in the graphic design. Why can't any AV receiver manufacturer create a user interface that is easy to use and looks cool?4) An issue with the volume button - Perhaps it has something to do with the mix of components I'm using, but if I don't turn on the TV, DirecTV box and receiver in a certain order, the volume button doesn't work right. It "flickers" between mute and volume. I figured out that I need to turn on the receiver, then TV then DirecTV box in order for it to work. I can remember it, but it's hard for others in the house to do itBottom line is, if you are set to upgrade your system and spend some money on a good network AV receiver and want it to last a long time, being compatible with new technology as you add it in the future, this is a very good receiver to buy.

This Logitech Bluetooth (BT) Audio Adapter was great for hooking up my 20+ year old stereo system to my Android phone, wirelessly!  It's a small box 2"x2" and about 1" high.  It has a USB power port (wall adapter included), 1/8" stereo output jack, and standard red and white RCA stereo plugs.After hooking up the power and audio cables, Bluetooth paring was simple.  On my Android 2.3 phone I went to Settings, Wireless and Networks, and turned on Bluetooth.  Press the Bluetooth logo button on the Logitech BT Adapter and then tap Bluetooth settings on your phone.  Under Bluetooth devices you should soon see a new device, something like "Bluetooth audio."  Tap the new device, wait a second or two, and the pairing is done.  I believe once this initial paring is done your phone will automatically connect to the Logitech BT Adapter whenever you have it on and BT is enabled in your phone.Now just play some music on your phone and you will hear it on your stereo system/speakers.  For me the audio was completely crisp and clear with no static.  If you turn your stereo/speakers volume up fairly high then you can control the music volume with your phone.  It's quite satisfying to play DJ from your couch or anywhere near your stereo/speakers, controlled by your smartphone.  A laptop or desktop with Bluetooth should work fine as a Bluetooth audio source too.

I'm a Ham newbie, and I decided to keep my entry into this new hobby as easy on the wallet as I could. After a bit of research, I decided on this HT to get me started. While I'm still figuring out/learning about this radio and radios in general, I'm extremely pleased with this handheld. The transmit is obviously limited considering this is a small 5w ht, and if I had had enough money to plunk down on a more powerful radio, I might have, but I'm very happy with this entry-level radio so far. Manual programming is a bit of a chore, but I picked up the programming USB cable and use Chirp software to program it, and it has gone very smoothly for me. The website miklor.com has been a huge help.I've seen a few complaints in the reviews about the inverse screen, and it made me a little nervous when ordering this model, but I didn't have anything to worry about. Besides looking pretty slick (actually it was one of the reasons I chose this model over other Baofeng models), it is very easy to see in all lighting conditions that I've used it in. Maybe the other reviewers' eyesight isn't what it used to be, or maybe it's just that I'm a young buck (26), but I have no problem seeing the frequencies on the screen after the backlight has turned off.One last thing, make sure you do your research people! You need a amateur radio license to transmit on this handheld, it is NOT a basic walkie talkie. It also covers more frequencies than Ham operators are legally able to transmit on, so you have to be aware of the frequencies you are using. I've seen some people complain about these cheap Baofeng radios being misused by the general public because they mistake these models as basic walkie talkies because of the price point. They complain that these people are ruining Ham radio, and I can understand where they're coming from. However I would argue that these cheap radios are a boon to amateur radio, as the lower price of entry into the hobby is allowing new people into the hobby that wouldn't have been able to afford it otherwise, like myself. So make sure you're doing your job as a consumer and understand what you're buying. This is a great little radio to get started off with.

I have gone through around 5 replacements of these radios from seller BaoFeng Tech, here is what I've found:1. The rubber for the CALL/PTT/MONI buttons are of poor qual. My third radio replacement's MONI button tore after a weeks use of the radio, I possibly pressed that button a maximum of 5 times.2. The TX/RX performance seems to be deficient. My first two radios had poor RX/TX performance when testing with my power meter and sig gen setup.3. My fourth radio was OK but the headphone accessory had a tear at the base of the plug. I regret sending this back as the radio was probably the best out of the bunch.4. My fifth radio has cosmetic defects, I'm probably going to live with it at this stage. These defects are that the lcd screen is on an angle (display is tilted), some keypad buttons do not shine the light through and the fixing ring for the SMA male connector at the top of the radio seems to screw itself off with the antenna.I noticed that the one good radio I received came with an older BaoFeng Tech sales label and didn't have the Pofung (BaoFeng's rebranding in 2014) brochure inside, all the other radios had their new label along with this brochure. I speculate that these shoddy radios are a new batch. The new batch also seems to have narrower numbering on the keypad, the old batch radio had a bolder font for the numbers.Maybe I'm asking a bit too much for this cheap product, but I've had enough of playing QC for BaoFeng Tech.
summary: Poor QC on these radios, possible problems with a new manufacturing batch

reviewText: First a little about me and the way I use my computing devices. I am a business traveler who spends 80% of his time on the road.  I fly every week.  I own a Samsung Note 3 which is my go to device for communication and email when I'm not at a desk or hotel room.  I use it constantly and since most of my time is spent with only the phone in hand, I do a lot of document reviews on the Note 3.  I also have a Kindle Fire HDX8.9 which I love for its speed, size and integration with Amazon Prime as I watch a lot of movies to kill time on my weekly flights.  I also own but don't use the original Samsung 10.1 Tablet which I retired when I purchased the fire.  So I'm pretty familiar with Samsung mobile products and Touchwiz.  My laptop is a Asus Zen Ultrabook which is an I7 machine with 256k SSD.  The computer's processing power is great but the weak points are the display and the keyboard.I  played with the Note Pro 12.2 LTE a few times and quickly noticed how fast it was in comparison to my original Samsung Tablet.  Opening up 5 windows at a time didn't phase it and I have never experienced any lag to this day.Since I mostly review Office documents, Word, Excel, Project and Powerpoint, I was anxious to see how the included software, Hancom Office, performed.  So far so good.  I'm typing this review in Hancom Word and have been reviewing both Powerpoint and Excell files these last couple of days with Hancom and I'm more than happy with both its display and editing abilities.  I have a couple of Project apps which I bought for my Note 3 which I have yet to try on this tablet but I assume they will work.You may not know this but Microsoft has released it's Office for Android product but as of today the Play Store shows it as incompatable with this Note Pro.The part of my workflow which I have not overcome yet is email.  I have an antiquated email server which I connect to with Outlook and download mail to my computer.  Of course I can do that with any number of Android mail apps but here's where I've run into a road block.  My email server only goves me 100mb of server space and that fills up quickly with all the attachments I get.  So what I do on my Ultrabook with Outlook is to move those emails off the server into Outlooks local file folders.  What I cannot find in Android is any mail client which allows the creation of Local Folders.  Many will allow you to create IMAP folders biut those folders are then synced with the mail server so that wont do me any good.  What I've settled on for a while anyway is creating 3gig or less in size .pst files which I have copied over to my Tablet.  I'm not copying my whole work are as it's huge but I am trying to get the last couple of years of email over to my tablet.So other than the mail snafu, which is pretty unique to my situation I would think I've been able to migrate over to the tablet.The multitasking is great.  I really dont see myself opening up 5 windows but I have been using two pretty regulaily.  What you see in the ads and reviews is that you can open up four windows, one in each quadrant.  While that's true it is not the way I use it.  What I found is that by sliding open the tray from the right side to uncover your apps, rather than a long press and drag I can simply tap the icon and a resizable window pops up.  This window has the look and feel of a WIndows window and can be resized and placed anywhere on the screen.  It works great and is more flexible than the fixed position multitasking which is often talked about and noted for its inflexibility.So for the included apps, email, Chrome, Youtube, Hancom, Gallery eand a multitude of others have worked just fine. I've not had a single issue.One concern with the Verizon model is that it is only available with 32gig.  That means you really need an SD card if you have a lot of work data or movies to store.  I made the mistake of purchasing a fast UHS-1 80gb/sec Class 10 card which was twice the price of a 30gb/second card and which benchmarks out in the mid teens for both read and write, both in the tablet (tablet storage to ext sd card) and out(PC to tablet file transfer).  I also benchmarked it in the tablet against another card I had, a Class 6 card.  The speed difference was minimal.  Bottom line, dont bother to buy a fast and expensive micro SD card.Unlike the wireless version the Verizon Note does not come with at least two of the freebees, RemotePC and Evernote.  Those two subscriptions are not included with this tablet.  All the other offers are.I did also purchase the ZAGG Cover-Fit bluetooth keyboard and it is a pleasure to type on as compared to my Zenbook.  This accessery is well worth looking at.The tablet has a USB 3 cable/charger and it charges in a few hours if you leave it off.  It will not charge while connected to my Zenbook even though I have it plugged into a charging USB jack.From my perspective the Note Pro is pretty light, feeling half the weight of my Zenbook.  The screen is great.  The speakers sound OK for a tablet but not as good as my Kindle Fire.  The stereo separation is great and you music will sound good if you can live without the richness.My intent on getting the LTE model was to use it in a pay as you go kind of scenaerio...which I discovered Verizon does not have for ths tablet.  I have two accounts both with unimited data so I was reluctant to make any changes but there was no way around it.  I converted the account with the least average data use to a share plan and then added the Note Pro.All in all I think I made a good decision and I'm happy with my purchase.
summary: Great tablet and for me an Ultrabook replacement

reviewText: I have been very impressed with the sound quality of these headphones.  Whether I'm using them with my iPhone or connected directly to my PC, the sound is excellent.  They are also very comfortable to wear for extended periods of time, which is something I can't say for any earbud style headphone I've ever tried.  Although they don't completely encompass my ears, the pressure of the pads on my ear is not a problem.They don't have a volume adjustment on the cord, which would be nice, but they do have a simple pause/answer button, which works out very nicely when a call comes in.  The sound quality of the microphone seems very good, I received no complaints from anyone I was on the phone with.  I now keep these headphones at my home office desk for use during the day so I don't need to switch to a headset if a call comes in.Great product!I was provided with a free copy of this item for testing and my fair and honest evaluation

I have done 40+ SSD installs and for some reason could not get a 120GB M500 w firmware MU05 to work. I threw up my hands and broke out my wallet and got this newer M550 and it cloned and booted first try. Loving it.
summary: Worked in my Dell Inspiron 3138 where an M500 did not

reviewText: If money is no object for you (you can buy me one also) and you want the best performance from your PlayStation 4 this drive will work. Now personally if money is a concern go with a 1TB plus drive they can be had for under $100. I will link a few down below but here are the directions for upgrading your PS4 using this hard drive if you want to.If you are wondering if your notebook is compatible with this hard drive just see if it has SATA in the specification information. If it says that then most likely can handle this drive no problem. Almost everything nowadays without internal hard drive is running on the 2.5 inch SATA specification. Another rule of thumb if your hard drive is over 100 GB at present most likely it's a SATA hard drive because of that size and above is when they started utilizing the interface.UPGRADING YOUR PS4 TAKE LESS THAN 30 minutes - You need to download the firmware from Sony*. If you need better instructions just google "PS4 hard drive replacement"Step 1: remove the gloss section of your PS4. It's the part above the Blu-Ray slot.Step 2: Remove the 500gb drive (requires 1 screw to be removed) Unscrew the 4 screws holding the drive in the cage.Step 3: Put the PS4 back together.Step 4: Insert your usb flash drive into the PS4 usb slot.Step 5: Press and hold the power button on the PS4 for 8-10 seconds.Step 6: Choose the bottom selection (I believe it's number 10) Reinstall firmware.Step 7: That's it you are done only about 30 minutes and done.*One thing you need if you're replacing a hard drive on the PlayStation is the latest firmware update from Sony's website and you need a 1 GB plus thumb drive formatted in fat32. And you just set up your thumb drive with a folder called PS4 an inside that folder another one called UPDATE. Then inside the update folder you place the firmware.If you have a questions just ask them and I'll try to help.I'd get this external case for your old 500gb drive:Vantec NexStar TX 2.5-Inch SATA to USB 2.0 External Hard Drive EnclosureATM it' only $7.00.  Takes only 3 minutes to install.Here are two other drives to consider for your PS4:This is 7200rpm 1TB drive:HGST Travelstar 2.5-Inch 1TB 7200RPM SATA 6GB/s 32MB Cache Internal Hard DriveThis is a 1.5TB hard drive:HGST Travelstar 5K1500 1.5TB 2.5-Inch Mobile 5400 RPM 9.5mm Internal Bare Hard Disk Drive 0J28001PS personally I went with a 1TB 72000rpm drive in my PS4.
summary: This drive will work in the PS4.

reviewText: If you haven't converted your HD drive to SSD yet, you're missing out. It's absolutely amazing how fast this is. It should be a recommend for any PC now.I do wish it came with a kit and wires at this price, but that's a small thing.

I had considered the switch from HDD to SSD quite a few times in the past. The faster speed, the relative ease of application, and the promise of never having to worry over hard drive failures due to over heating were all big sellers, but I'm old school and the switch was (still) a hard sell. Hearing enough of SSDs failing shortly after purchase and the concept of limited rewrites, along with not wanting to actually transfer all my data (and re-install all my applications), I was pretty reluctant to use this SSD at first.Let me say this ahead of time: those worries were absolutely foolish and if you have the chance to get an SSD get one IMMEDIATELY!Transferring and reinstalling just about everything was still a pain but the faster speed, especially for those using newer editions of Photoshop or playing graphics heavy games, makes it so much worth it in the end. I wish I would've switched to an SSD years ago!
summary: Absolutely worth it in every way!

reviewText: Loving this new SSD. Upgraded my laptops HDD to this new SDD to speed things up.  I also bought a "2.5 inch sata enclosure" on amazon to put my old HDD in and just use it as a portable hard drive now.

Coming from a 7200RPM SATA III 500Gb HDD, This has made the largest speed difference I've experienced yet. I can't believe I hadn't switched to SSD before now. I'm a 15 year IT (whatever/everything) guy. PC Mark Benchmark test before on my optiplex 7010 was 1450, after install is 1810. I have no idea about longevity, I cloned and installed it today.Recommend to everyone.
This drive is speedy and works well. No issues to report.

I boot up in 12s. This a great SSD at a great price. Be careful if you try to install Windows 7 with other SATA drives installed. Windows 7  could see the drive but would not format or install. I figured out that I needed to change the drive order in the BIOS to drive 0. It seems that Windows reorders the drives it sees although it was connected to my SATA 0 port. Once I got this figured out (and no, you do not need SP1 to install) installation was a breeze with my other 3 SATA drives and flash attached. Buy it if you want a fast drive. I want to buy a terabyte drive as my data drive now, chuckle :)
summary: Damn! hope this is not censored

reviewText: I want to keep this review simple... there are a lot of folks who will post read/write times, discussions of SSD lifecycles, etc. So let me just say that this drive is FAST. My computer, which is only a few years old and still very powerful, was freezing and crashing a lot. I followed the lifehacker articles on cloning your current drive to a SSD, and swapped out the 7200rpm hard drive with this SSD. I removed the old drive, installed this one, and my system booted right up. I DID have to make a few tweaks in the system config for it to know to boot from the SSD, so do your homework up front. But the lifehacker articles are great, and this drive will probably last you 10 years or better unless you are an extreme user (in which case you'll likely buy a new computer first). It's AMAZING how much better my system performs now and how much faster it boots and loads my profile on logon. THIS is how a computer is supposed to perform. Five stars, all the way!
Solid performance

I got this as a replacement for a Sandisk version of this model type. The Sandisk never worked out of the box. This one is smaller and worked instantly. I don't think it is mentioned, but the middle of the drive has a rectangular "loop" that allows for a key ring teather (which is included). Tested this unit out on 2 Win7 PCs, a Nexus 7 and Galaxy Note 2. All worked w/o issues. Highly recommended for every day carry data storage.

I was hoping I could get my Kindle Fire to use it as external storage in the micro USB port, but the port isn't set up for that. However, that's no fault of the drive, which works fine as a tiny USB drive. Would work well with a laptop, only a tiny bit bigger than many wireless mouse dongles, barely sticks out from the port. I'd recommend it to anyone who needs to transfer info from micro USB to std USB or vice versa and can add external storage on their device
summary: Wish it worked with the Kindle Fire

reviewText: I used to carry an OTG dongle for my phone into which I'd plug a thumb drive for transferring music, photos and other files to and from my phone without using a computer. Now, I've eliminated all that with this tiny self-contained OTG drive that fits on my keyring.  I first connected a tiny keyring through the hole in the plastic sheath of the drive and then threaded that keyring onto my regular keyring.  This allows me to easily use the drive without removing it from the keyring.  If you ever find yourself in need of OTG storage then you should definitely consider this unit.
Exactly as listed -- compact.

My kids broke one of the two front USB ports on the front of our XBox 360. Since they have Skylanders, Disney Infinity, controller chargers and USB drives formatted for back up storage there was a problem getting it to all work together with only one port. Plugged this in and started plugging in all the extras and everything was recognized and running smoothly. No extra power needed no special work around just plug and play.
having trouble viewing attached hdd's

This is a basic USB 3.0 Hub,  It does not have an external power connector for higher current demands.  There is a blue LED indicator that is on when the USB Hub is plugged it and operating.  Not much more to say, plugged it into my notebook with a number of external devices (keyboard mouse, printer) and it just worked.I received this product free for my testing and review

Looks good.I like the diamond head shape meaning fat USB plugs don't interfere with each other.I tried having an external 2.5" hard drive AND an external 2.5" SSD connected at the same time, and it didn't work without external power, but that is not a fault of the USB hub.  In fact - whilst I've not used the feature yet - the hub even has a little hole that I'm pretty sure you can plug a third-party power adapter into and voila, suddenly your unpowered hub can become powered if you want!When using the external drives separately, it works very well.Realistically, the kinds of devices that will go faster on USB 3 than on USB 2 are also likely to have higher current draw, and so realistically in some ways there's not much point having four USB 3 ports with a combined power delivery capability of one port from the host computer, but there are some use cases this can be useful - especially if you have something like the Surface Pro with just one USB port and want to be able to run an external USB 3 storage device alongside some other low-current-draw USB peripherals.Or probably (though I haven't tested) you'd be able to run multiple USB 3 SSDs off one USB port's power - SSDs use a lot less power than hard drives most of the time.Do note that I'm not sure what speed impact might or might not occur by mixing USB 3 and USB 2 peripherals on the same hub at the same time.  But even if there is a slowdown for the USB 3 devices (I haven't tested), that's largely the nature of USB hubs, not a fault with this one.

This SABRENT USB TURBO CHARGING ADAPTER for powered USB ports is an inexpensive little device, but it's hard to tell how useful it really is.  I was interested because it's supposed to allow you to "(u)se a standard USB port to charge a Tablet PC or iPad".  I tried the adapter with a USB port on a Belkin surge protector (seeBelkin Surge Protector) that would NOT charge my iPad2, and it did in fact boost the port's power so that the iPad2 began charging.However, the device didn't work for charging an iPad 2 from a powered Belkin 4-port (USB 3.0) hub (seeBelkin SuperSpeed USB Hub).  The failure was apparently the hub's fault, because plugging the iPad2 into the hub by itself  (without the Sabrent adapter) caused my Win7 system to produce a power surge warning (saying that the device's power request exceeded the port's capability).  Adding the Sabrent adapter didn't change anything--the same power surge warning came up.  So it would appear that this adapter will not necessarily work with every single powered USB port.For me, it's easier to charge iPads and tablets using dedicated 1A ports (as found on newer charging stations, e.g.,CHIL PowerShare Reactor Charging Station) than to use an adapter to try to speed up charging.  Still, this little adapter (only 1-3/4" long) is very portable, and might be just the ticket for a traveler's needs.  Because it's inexpensive (about $6) and performs somewhat as advertised, I rate it at 3 stars ("It's okay" on the official Amazon scale).Disclaimer note:  This review is based on a product supplied to me free of charge for review purposes.  I have no financial interest or business relationship with the manufacturer or seller, and this review represents my independent opinion of the product.
summary: Boosted Power on Belkin Surge Protector's USB Port

reviewText: Disclaimer: I received this product in exchange for a fair and honest review.Anyway, Sabrent was courteous enough to send two of these to me for review, so my wife and I both tried it out. Additionally, I have used this at home on my gaming rig (a Cyberpower PC), on an old Lenovo laptop, and at work on a shoddy Dell laptop, in addition to also having tried them on a multitude of wall chargers and even some portable chargers. This has worked perfectly on all of them actually. I was more than a little surprised that it even boosted the portable chargers actually.Anyway, it definitely increases the power of any charging port, and upgrades them to 2.1 I guess, since I could charge all my devices, including my Vita which is pretty fickle generally when it comes to charging it. iPhones, Kindles...works for everything so far.It's also nice that it doesnt data sync, which can be an incredibly annoying thing when charging devices on computers. I really like this feature as well.All in all, a winning item in my opinion. Useful, portable, inexpensive.
summary: Works great and is quite handy

reviewText: This solves a problem that I wasn't trying to fix as I didn't think there was a solution to it. The Sabrent USB Turbo Charging Adapter allows me to charge my iPad on a normal USB port on my computer, where normally I'd only get the Not Charging message because there's not enough power going to the USB port.My normal routine is that I can charge my iPhone in a regular USB port on my computer, but I have to use a power plug for my iPad charging (unless I want to let it sit connected for a day or two). This device promised to allow me to charge the iPad via the USB port, so I did a timed test. My iPad was at 75% at 6:00 am this morning when I plugged it in with the adapter. It recognized the power source and was up to 85% an hour later. For a comparison, I then unplugged the adapter and attempted to charge the iPad for another hour from the USB port. I got the Not Charging message, and after an hour I had only gone from 85% to 87%. Granted, it's not as fast as a power plug, but it's the difference between being able to fully charge the iPad via USB in 10 hours instead of 50.One thing to keep in mind, however... When using this adapter, it will *only* provide power to the iPad. It will not sync data like it would with a normal connection. In my opinion, this is so easy and quick to plug in, I could run a quick sync and then switch over to using this adapter. It wouldn't be that big of an issue for me.This will be sitting on top of my computer next to the USB plug for those times when I want to do a quick top-off of my iPad and don't want to find a power plug (or unplug another cord that's already there).Disclosure:Obtained From: ManufacturerPayment: Free
summary: This is very handy to have around if you don't have a USB power plug readily available...

reviewText: This one is exactly as advertised - great quality, feel, and function.  Read the other good reviews - I bought this item based on the reviews and was delighted to see the item was just as good as the reviewers claimed....  I did do as one reviewer recommended and replaced the small carabiner with a larger one to be extra safe.Very happy with this one.

This integrated three (3) port USB car charger is in a class of its own.  Besides it's sleek sophisticated look in silver and white, it easily allows you to recharge your favorite mobile gadgets in your car by offering 3 ports with different amperage to suit your needs.25W or 5.1A shared by three ports as follows:One port is 2.1A which is perfect for iPad or iPad Air.One port is 2.0A which is suited for Android, Kindle and Samsung TabletsOne port at 1.0A which is perfect for any smartphone, digital camera, MP3 player etc.Comes with a blue LED light to show power is on and best part it is not too bright so no need to put a piece of black electrical tape over it!  Intelligent circuit design that is built to protect against over-heating, over-currents, and over-charging. Best of all charging stops when battery is full.Comes with a one-year manufacturer warranty.Link for gold option:UNU AX Tri-USB Port Car Charger - [Black / Gold] 5.1 A / 25 W Portable Travel Charger Rapid Car ChargerSample provided for review.
summary: In a class of its own

reviewText: This is a small and compact car charger with lots of features:Things I like about it:- Has 3 ports. They are 2.1A, 2.0A and 1.0A ports. It's very useful in that they've fitted 3 ports into such a small space but also that two of the ports are 2.0A and above and useful for charging your larger devices. I received this as a sample and I've used it to charge my iPad and Kindle. It's a very fast charger.- Compact.- Has safety features that prevent over heating, over charging, short circuits and stops when the device is fully charged.Overall, just a very nifty and functional car charger. Highly recommended.

Five FUNCTIONAL Stars! This white/silver color uNu AX Tri-USB Car Charger works great and is the best of the four car chargers I own: one of which is difficult to remove from the outlet as well as too small, one of which is an excellent similar dual-USB port car charger, and the third is too large and cumbersome. This uNu charger for automobiles provides the convenience of charging three items simultaneously, for items such as smartphones, coffee cup warmers, GPS units, radar units, and smart tablets (via 2.1A, 2.0A port and 1.0 A ports) while driving around, eliminating the need for "pre-charging" the gadgets, swapping gadgets around, or carrying a bulky charger in the car. Plus it is just the right size to allow access to other areas around the center console ashtray area. The big difference with this equipment is it has a bright blue LED that lights up when plugged into the cigarette/power charger outlet to "confirm connection". This is a bonus at night when driving: one quick glance and the user can locate and plug in the smart gadgets for charging, although it is preferable to do so after starting the car but before driving to locate the correct port. In addition, when stored, the white color makes it stand out in a glove compartment or center console, amid all of the other darker objects stored there. Chargers should be used after the car is started to prevent power surges from the car's battery and the ports are designed to stop charging when the devices have reached full charge, although I prefer removing the cable from the outlet once the gadget reaches 100% charge. Highly Recommended. Five MOBILE Stars! (uNu Tri-USB Port Car Charger, 0.9 ounce, gadget connector cables are not provided. This item was provided by the manufacturer for testing and an impartial review)
summary: UNU AUTOMOBILE TRI-USB PORT CAR CHARGER GOES A PORT AHEAD OF MANY OTHERS

reviewText: The Uni AX series charger is a great device. It is higher priced than similar devices, however it offers 3 ports to charge and can easily charge 3 devices, including an iPad, at one time.There is a 2.1 A port for Apple products, 2.0 A port for Android devices and a 1 A port for everything else. Every port works, though depending on the device you may have a slower charge time if you use a lower than expected port, but they all work. I've plugged my Lumia 1020 and iPhone 5s into every port, and while the 2 and 2.1 A ports charge both faster, they charged in all three ports.The styling is nice, and if you decide on the Unu, you have to make a choice between white and silver or black and gold. I like the look of the black and gold, but the reality is the devices are exactly the same except for the color.I am not a huge fan of blue lights in my car - I find them distracting. For me, red would be the best choice, however, for most people red means "bad," so I am OK with the blue.Overall, the Uni Ax series is a great 3 port USB charger and I would recommend it to anyone looking for a low profile, pretty device that brings great performance.Highly recommended.I received a free sample for review purposes from the manufacturer.

The uNu AX Series 5.1 amp 3 USB port car charger is one of the highest quality and highest output car chargers on the market.Pros:-5.1 amps of output power (this means that when all the ports outputs combined they add up to a max output of 5.1 amps)-1 of the USB ports, labeled "2.1A", has a max output of 2.1 amps which is great for charging tablets like an iPad Air (this port is designed for Apple devices like an iPad but will still work with other tablets and smartphones)-1 of USB ports, , labeled "2.0A", has a max output of 2.0 amps which is great for charging tablets like a Samsung Galaxy Tab 10.1 (this port is designed for Android devices like Galaxy Tabs but will still work with iPads, smartphones and other tablets)-1 of the USB ports, labeled "1.0A", has a max output of 1.0 amps which is great for charging smartphones like an iPhone 5/5s (this port is designed for all smartphones like an iPhone 5/5s or Galaxy S4)-Comes in 2 cooling looking colors (it comes in white with silver metal where the USB ports are and it comes in black with gold metal where the USB ports are [both look amazing but I like the gold one better, in my opinion])-LED status lights indicates that the car charger's USB ports are ready for use and it is not bright to light up the car (in other words, it will not distract the driver)-Tight fit in the cigarette lighter socket which means it will not slide out easily during use-Tested on a car ride and it worked great for charging an iPad Air, an iPhone 5 and a Galaxy S4-Small for its very high output of 5.1 amps-Protects against over-heating, over-charging, over-current and short circuits-Overall, this is a high quality car charger that has a very high output that works very wellNo cons that I can find about this car charger.My wishes:-Add multiple LED's so the USB ports are visible in the dark (LED do not light up the car, just the USB ports)-Make it have a 7.2 amp output, so 3 tablets, like 3 iPad's, can charge all at once at full speedThis is an excellent car charger and it works great. I highly recommend this wall charger!Watch my video review.I was supplied a sample for test and evaluation, for free to keep, and I promised that my review is fair and honest.
summary: Excellent car charger with a high output and it comes in 2 cool looking color combos!

Works just as I would expect it to.  High quality feel, and charges fast.  Bought 2 for each of my cars, and use them with my Samsung Galaxy s5.

Five POWERFUL Stars! Maxboost Dual-Port USB Car Charger packs a bigger power punch than most. The lightweight (.8 ounce) white charger unit has a soft plastic upper area which is perforated with holes around the side for easier grasping. At just under 3 inches long, it can be inserted into the cigarette lighter socket and allows more access to the center console coin tray and ash tray areas than some other dual-port car chargers. It has a low power blue LED on the top allowing the driver to see the USB port areas in darkness. The USB ports are rated at a total of 4.4 Amps, with one port rated at 2.4 Amps/12 Watts targeted for iPads and iPhones and the other port rated at 2.0 Amps/10 Watts for Android devices, but I've charged iPhones successfully off of both ports with no problems. The ports are inverted so the 'USB cable symbols' on the heads are actually facing away from each other. In testing the charger with the car engine running, a newer generation power-depleted iPhone was `up for use' in 5 minutes and an older generation power-depleted iPhone was `up for use' in 6 minutes using this USB dual charger. The ports are marked with their amperage but blend into the surrounding colors making them difficult to read: but if the LED is positioned to the left, the higher rated 2.4 Amp port is above the other port 2.0 rated port. The ports are designed to stop charging when the devices have reached full charge. Highly Recommended. Five EFFECTIVE Stars! (1- Maxboost dual-port car charger. User manual. One year warranty. This product was provided by the manufacturer for testing and an impartial review.)
summary: MAXBOOST's NEWEST DUAL-PORT USB CAR CHARGER HAS MORE POWER
