summary: Perfect for my Samsung Galaxy S5

reviewText: I got the Logitech X100 Mobile Wireless Speaker (Orange) to use when I am working out on my treadmill.  With the included hanger, I can hang the X100 from the arm of my treadmill and wirelessly listen to music from my (3rd gen) iPod Touch.In summary, the sound quality is good - this is a single speaker so you can't expect it to reproduce sound with the same clarity and separation as high end equipment.  Yet the sound it does deliver is rich, clear and powerful.  You can use this as a speakerphone if used in conjunction with an iPhone or other smartphone.  I have tried it with an iPhone 4s and the sound quality was good.The X100 specs claim a 30 foot range but I am able to get around 20 feet before the speaker drops out.  Pairing is easy although initially I had trouble (once) pairing the device with my iPod.  Although the iPod could see all the other Bluetooth devices nearby, it could not see the powered-on and discoverable X100.  After some fumbling with the X100 I was able to pair.  I have not had any trouble pairing since.The speaker itself is solid and seems durable.  The hanging strap is strong but the connector is flimsy and doesn’t always want to “click” into place.  Other than this I have no issues with the size of the speaker or the weight.  Battery life is good – on par with the advertised battery life.  I think this is a good buy and something that will get some use if you like to listen to music but hate headphones.

If you're looking for a Bose quality speaker, feel free to move on - at this lower price point, the Logitech X100 is a good unit to have when hacking around the beach, carrying while biking, and basically anywhere you want to go without having to worry about accidentally bashing apart your speaker.  The speaker is very lightweight, is about the size of a small roll of packaging tape, and the sound is quite clear.  The sound quality is really quite good for this size, and the volume is loud enough to entertain a small group of people easily.  While the speaker touts a 30 ft range, I found that it was more like 20 ft, but this wasn't a huge issue as the MP3 player was always close at hand.The few issues I have with this unit is the durability, the controls, and the small loop to carry the speaker with.  The long term durability of this unit is questionable as it's pretty much all plastic.  Because it's a cheaper unit, I'm not sweating it too much, but I'm really not sure if this speaker would survive a couple of drops.  The controls on the X100 are okay, but it's generally difficult to determine how high the volume is.  It will beep once you get to the highest level, though.  The last problem encountered is with the rope carrying loop.  This loop is very cheap and I can imagine it popping off when clipping this speaker to a backpack or something.  We ended up getting a more durable tie (luggage tag type belt loop) and it works just fine.  I would consider changing it out if you're planning on backpacking with this speaker.Overall, the speaker sounds great and is very portable/lightweight.  It's great to take when you're traveling.  Recommended.
summary: Very Good Speaker for the Price

reviewText: The Logitech X100 is a fine speaker for backpacking, gardening, or on the beach. It connects to the Bluetooth on your smartphone or iPod. And it works rather well.The buttons are simple: Power, higher or lower volume, disconnect. It's very easy to work with. The plastic body appears durable. There is a cord with a snap for attaching it to your backpack. I would avoid using it while bike riding because it just doesn't seem that strong. I did learn that the advertised 30 foot range from iPhone to speaker is much shorter if your phone is in your pocket and you turn away from the speaker; it's about 20 feet at that point.We've been using it while gardening, or listening to music in our bedroom. My husband discovered if you turn the volume to it's lowest setting, it can slip under your pillow for music listening at night-no more ear buds!We have the blue with orange colored speaker, but it comes in other colors. Good price for a sturdy looking device that performs well.

Bose has a well-earned reputation for making some of the best finest sound equipment on the general market.  Their CD players, radios, turntables, amplifiers and speakers have long been regarded as 'top-of-the-line' by audio enthusiasts.As a rule, their equipment is not in the "Cheap" category and often reminds someone who purchases their first BOSE product that while there are many, many choices that cost less, you often DO actually get what you pay for.This is, indeed, the case with these new BOSE Freestyle earbuds. They do not look like other earbugs, they do not sound like other earbuds, they are not built like.other earbuds - and they do not cost what most other earbuds cost. If your first priorities include both the quality of the sound that comes from your device into your ear and the comfort of that is on and in your ear to receive it, then (providing that you have the money to spend on them) these BOSE Freestyle earbuds are for you!Misc:The case is interesting, attractive and functional, including amply room for extra earbud covers. The microphone and built-in controls functioned perfectly with my IPhone5. No issue with the jack working through the case-cover that I keep on my IPhone. Visually (I am not sure why this matters), they are striking as obvious effort went into modifying and making more visually distinctive a design that has become 'routine.'The Sound:Everyone's hearing is different, so what follow is my subjective experience.The full range of sound is accurately and clearly transferred from the electronic file to the actual sound.  Basses were deep, trebles obvious and the mid-range of the sound spectrum shares equal dominance with the others. IN many lesser earbbuds (or headphones) the mid-range tends to dominate.  I am not an engineer, but the sound sensation is like having small, full-range speaker inserted into my ears,This sound accuracy and fullness was consistent with soft, classical music (acoustic guitar, Gregorian Chants and Yo-Yo Ma), a wide range of folk and blues music as well as with my collection of classic Eric Clapton. No distortion anywhere that I could discern.The Feel:As a rule, I have not been an earbud fan.  There is something about the shape of my ears that makes them all feel somewhat insecure and hard to fit correctly. It took me a few tries to work there cleverly designed ear-pieces into the curves of my outer ear. I actually found the sketches printed in the margins of the fold-out insert quite helpful and not can easily and quickly slide them into place. Once there, they are light, secure and comfortable.All-in-all, these BOSE Freestyle earbuds were a real "ear-opener" for me.  My long-time good headphones are being retired and the drawer-full of cheap, ill-fitting and inadequate earbuds I have accumulated are all find their was to a local Thrift Store today.
summary: A Truly Ear-Opening Experience. BOSE Does It Again!

reviewText: I originally found the sound quality of the Bose FreeStyle ear buds to be only slightly above average.  The gel tip for the ear buds provided very little isolation from environmental noise and I found that they didnt fit very well.  However, Robert Esposito (see comments below) suggested that I try theBose StayHear+ tips - medium (2 pairs)instead of the gel tip that came with the ear buds.  It was a brilliant suggestion.  For ten dollars more (the cost of the gel tips), the sound isolation was improved and more importantly, the sound isolation improved the sound quality of the ear buds dramatically.  Plus I find that the StayHear+ gel tips are more comfortable.  If you buy the FreeStyle ear buds, please also buy the StayHear+ tips in your size.Original Review -----------------------------------------------------------I have several Bose headphones and ear buds and I have always been impressed by the Bose products.  Impressed that is, until now.  Although the FreeStyle earbuds reproduce a wide tonal range including bass despite not having a good seal around the earbuds, the sound quality is only a bit better than average which is not what one would expect for the price.Fit and ComfortBose earbuds are different than other brands because they include an extended flexible wing which is basically a extension of the gel cover that sits on your outer ear to add stability and therefore comfort.  I never feel the flexible wing once it is in place, but I do feel that it does help to keep the earbuds in place.What Bose calls the StayHear Tip is a gel cover for the earbud.  Three different size StayHear Tips are provided with the earbuds.  The gel material is soft and supple.  The tip is formed into a funnel shape and the funnel extends into your ear canal when the earbuds are in place.However, although I tried using all three size tips, I never felt that I could get a good fit in my ear.  I also have a pair of Bose 20i earbuds and the gel tips for the 20i are very different.  The gel cover of the 20i forms a cup around the earbud which gives a very good seal around the earbud which has the benefits of making the 20i very comfortable to wear and sealing off the ear canal from outside noise.  In contrast, the FreeStyle gel tips never really feel like they sit properly.  They are still comfortable and the lack of a tight seal means that I can wear them all day.  However, the lack of a tight seal means that the FreeStyle gel tips provide very little noise isolation.CordThe cord of the FreeStyle earbuds is relatively short (a little more than 3 ft long) compared to headphones, but this makes sense since the earbuds are meant for use while being active and you dont want a long cord bouncing around while you are running, for example.  There is a bright, red clip on the cord to hold it in place.  There are also controls on the cord for use with Apple products.  I tried to use the controls with my Android phone and although I could stop and pause music and answer calls, I could not control the volume using the controls on the cord.Sound QualityI have been using FreeStyle earbuds for the past week while listening to different types of music.  I have found the sound quality of the FreeStyle earbuds to be uninspired.  There is nothing really wrong with the sound quality in that they give a well rounded, wide tonal range from the sub bass of dubstep to the highs of classical music.  But, although pleasant enough, the sound is not rich.  The lows are there but dont stand out and the highs are not bright.  Although these aren't studio headphones, the sound is probably close to a flat response.  At this price range, I would expect to be amazed by the sound and I wasnt.I compared the sound quality to that of my Bose 20i earbuds and they were a world apart.  The sound quality of the 20i was so much better.  However, to be fair, the 20i have an inline amplifier for when the noise canceling is on.  But, even with the amplifier off, I thought the 20i were still better.SummaryOverall, the Bose FreeStyle earbuds are average earbuds.  The sound quality is good but not great.  I found the fit of the earbuds to be a bit off.  Nor do the gel covers provide much isolation from environmental noise.
summary: Average sound quality but for a few dollars more, the sound quality can be dramatically improved

reviewText: Very versatile and dependable. In ear design stays securely in place through workouts or regular daily driving. Clear call quality in listening and delivering voice on calls. Just the right amount of cord length. Provided toggle is very useful in avoiding cord tangling. Cool color combination. Weight light enough to not bog down.
summary: Provided toggle is very useful in avoiding cord tangling

reviewText: Note: Based on reader input this review has been edited and the product rating increased by one star to a total of four stars.Bose has been a famous name for years and I've always followed their products with interest, as back in 1968 Dr. Bose was my instructor for my first class in circuit theory at MIT. He was a brilliant man and many of his company's products reflected that brilliance.This, alas, is not the case with the Freestyle earbuds. While they have many good features, they have some surprising shortcomings, as I'll describe. Here's a capsule summary of my experience thus far with these earbuds.Although I'm not so fond of ear-canal listening devices, because for me they tend to either fall out or else be so tight as to cause discomfort, I have to say that these earbuds are the most comfortable I've ever tried. I hardly even know that they're in my ear. The design includes a small exterior plastic arm that presses lightly against the ridge of your ear to keep the earbuds from slipping out. It's very clever and it really works.Bose is justifiably famous for high-quality audio design. With earbuds, there's not a lot to work with. Most earbuds deliver horrible sound. The Bose Freestyle break that mold and deliver sound that's decent enough. The definition and clarity are outstanding, and the high end is all you could ask, as are the midranges. But it stops there; the bass is largely absent, which is surprising in a Bose product. It's very hard to get earbuds to put out much bass but the Bose engineers could have done better. (I have reviewed another brand and model of earbuds that delivers reasonably good bass; see my other reviews if you're interested.)The end result is that the sound is skewed toward the high end and seems unnatural. Do keep in mind, though, that I did professional sound recording for quite a few years and I'm exceptionally fussy. You might like the sound of these earbuds, as it's very bright and lively. Audio is subjective and no one including a so-called expert can tell you what to like or dislike.I also thought the build quality could be better. The color scheme is a bit unusual, but I can take it or leave it. The problem is the thinness of the wires. It just doesn't look particularly durable, and at the price, you won't want to be buying it more than once. Some readers have, however, reported that the long-term durability is good, so I reserve the right to further edit this review when I have more months of experience with the product (initial Vine reviews have to be completed within 30 days).The last thing is the plug. Now, this headset is advertised to work with iPads and other i-products, and it does, and works well with them. To accommodate remote control through a switch on one of the earbud leads, the plug is TRRS, or four elements, not the common three element TRS stereo mini-plug. This means the headset works fine on nearly all smartphones and tablets. With normal stereo output from a TRS jack on laptops, hifis, etc., I got mixed results. Some devices work fine. Many do not and give single channel output or monophonic output. To fix this, I needed a hard to find and not inexpensive adapter.Readers have told me that in their environment, the TRRS plug works fine with all their devices, and point to older devices as being the ones at issue. While this unfortunately wasn't the case in my own environment (and I have nothing older than 2007 and some very new items), you may not encounter a problem, and if all your listening is on a smartphone or tablet, it's a non-issue.What's the bottom line? These are good, and I'll go four stars, but for less money you can get something better. Dr. Bose, I apologize, but these just aren't up to the high standards you set for yourself and your students.
summary: Decent performance and design but some real issues

reviewText: I've tried a lot of earbuds, including expensive bluetooth ones.  Nothing compares to the overall quality int these babies.  Perfect balance of low/mid/high frequencies.  Extremely light and comfortable to wear.  I have the expensive Bose noise canceling headphones .. Normally wear them on flights. These are extremely close to that quality.You cannot to wrong with Bose.  These are simply awesome earphones.  Just as a point of reference.  I am a musician and have a rather expensive recording studio. I am very fussy about sound quality.

Be sure to check the different sizes on this hard drive because of the time of writing this the 500GB version was only three dollars more than the 320GB version. This hard drive will work in MacBooks, PC notebooks even PS3 and PS4 and it's a good choice if you're looking to speed up your device as it 7200 rpm's.If you are wondering if your notebook is compatible with this hard drive just see if it has SATA in the specification information. If it says that then most likely can handle this drive no problem. Almost everything nowadays without internal hard drive is running on the 2.5 inch SATA specification. Another rule of thumb if your hard drive is over 100 GB at present most likely it's a SATA hard drive because of that size and above is when they started utilizing the interface.Personally I love 7200 RPM hard drives, for years upon years I have always upgraded my hard drives in my laptops and play stations because I always want to have the fastest load speeds. Now you could invest in a solid-state hard drive and you'll see a better load time by the time of writing this review they are more than five times the price. And most of the time people do not want to drop that much coin if they're just upgrading an older laptop or PS3.Now one thing you might want to do is invest in a larger hard drive at the time of writing this review 500 GB was the max you get on this hard drive at a price of around $65 but on Amazon you can get a 1 TB 7200 RPM hard drive for around $90. To me 500 GB can be a little small but I do a lot of video editing also. But for most people 500 GB will be fine but I always recommend getting the biggest hard drive you can afford.One last thing be sure to buy an external serial ATA case like this one for your old hard drive:Sabrent Ultra Slim 2.5-Inch SATA to USB 2.0 External Aluminum Hard Drive Enclosure EC-UK25 (Black)And then when you replace your hard drive you can put your old hard drive in this thing and use it for backup and file sharing. Plus the only seven dollars that's pretty awesome.If you have any questions feel free to comment on this review and out trying to back too soon as possible.
summary: A good choice if you want to improve your laptops speed BUT you may want a bigger hard drive.

reviewText: I was looking for a bigger hard drive to replace my laptop's smaller 320GB drive, and I must say that this hard drive does fits that description perfectly. It was packaged extremely well when I received it, with no play in the packaging whatsoever. I'm using the drive in my laptop, but you can use it for a ton of other applications as well. You can buy an external case and use it as a portable external driver, or you can upgrade your PS3 or desktop's hard drive.Pros:Speed - 7200RPMSize - 500GBPackaging was very secureCons:No cons as of this time.Overall, this is a great hard drive for money. There's nothing really negative that I can say about it. Go ahead and buy it if you need it.
summary: Packaged very well! Great Price for a great Hard Drive

reviewText: This was a no brainer.  Got this drive for a newer laptop that required a thinner drive.  Fit perfectly and loaded up without incident.  Very happy.
This unit works better than any other adapter I have purchased.  No installation problems, no problems with the computer.  Performs perfectly Quick delivery too.

I have several bluetooth items , speaker's, keyboards, headphones etc. most of my computers are bluetooth ready however I do have 2 samsung netbooks and 1 laptop that is not bluetooth ready.I really wanted the ability to stream music to my speakers and headphones from the netbooks. This little device does the job extreemly well. It's compact and is pleasing to the eye. Very easy to install ; either use the disc provided or go to the webite listed on the package to download the software. Had it up and running in a couple of minutes.The price seems to be very reasonable as compared to other options for bluetooth.I was given this item for a honest review and was not compensated in any way except I get to keep the adapter.I recommed this adapter highly for people that want bluetooth at a reasonable price.
summary: Amazing - allows bluetooth on non bluetooth devices

reviewText: I really didn't know much about Bluetooth adapters before I was asked to try this out in exchange for an honest review by TaoTronics. I figured why not. It would be educational for me to find out what this is all about and how special this little device really is.I have 3 laptops. One has bluetooth and so I didn't need this device for it. But I did have 2 other laptops one w/ Windows Vista and another w/ Windows 7.0.Decided since I use my Windows 7.0 Laptop to try this in it.Was a bit nervous as to how this would work but it was relatively as easy as plugging it into a USB Port and installing the software from the disc.The only downside I have is I also have a Mac that's not bluetooth and this won't work on it but that's ok b/c I've decided to sell the Mac anyway.It's very easy to use and it truly made a nonbluetooth laptop totally bluetooth!Again i did receive this at no cost for my honest review of this product but in no way was I compensated financially for trying this product!
summary: TaoTronics TT-BA03 Bluetooth 4.0 USB Adapter makes it EASY to turn a Laptop w/out Bluetooth into Bluetooth!

reviewText: These wireless headphones are great if you are a very busy on the go type of person or if you exercise a lot!The sound quality is crisp and clear but I found them to be a bit snug and quite uncomfortable at so therefore I couldn't wear them for a long period of time. The set up was very easy and simple, once fully charged you can get up to 8 or 9 hours of play! Very nice and convenient but also takes some time getting use to.
summary: Very convenient..but fits kind of snug.

reviewText: Albeit a bit pricey, but for a special occasion, or a special active someone in your life,  these would no doubt be appreciated. These good quality earbuds will stay in the ear, even when the wearer is on the run, literally. The men in our family tried them while jogging, kick boxing, and in the gym.  They all agreed they were comfortable enough, with different size earpieces to choose from. No one complained of discomfort.The sound quality was not exceptional if one is used to Beats, perhaps, but good enough to enjoy the work out. The best part was that they stayed put, and are wireless, so they don't interrupt or get in the way of a good active work out.
summary: Great gift idea for a favorite athlete

reviewText: My initial impressions of the BlueAntPump were very favorable.  I liked the device packaging which neatly arrayed and labeled the different ear plug tips and stabilizers.  I liked the possibility of the BlueAnt being fully waterproof, provided the battery charging cover is closed.  (**Note, the battery charging cover appeared to have a somewhat flimsy construction, so take note! of this potential longevity issue.)  Battery life was impressive and a full charge took just 2 hours.  Sound quality, while not spectacular, was fine for my workouts.  Charging via micro-usb (cable provided) was helpful.  The wireless bluetooth connection was very convenient, and took just a few seconds to complete.I unfortunately found the sportbuds uncomfortable to wear.  They constantly pinched my earlobes, despite attempts to adjust them, and were painful after just a few minutes of usage.  I suspect that individual comfort will very subjective, so YMMV.  Controls were ok, but slightly awkward to use and adjust.Based on the other reviews which speak highly of the BlueAntPump comfort, I suspect my experiences may be in the minority.  I'd rate these 3.5 stars, rounded up to 4.
summary: Very good, but may be uncomfortable for some

reviewText: It's clear that BlueAnt done their homework really well by studying the competition to come up with a spec, a fitment, and accessories to make everybody happy. Arrived in a very impressive packaging, their presentation showed almost realistic-like 3D water droplets on top of the tray where these sportbuds were sitting. I was honestly expecting to see yet another variation of two earbuds connected by a cable with in-line remote. To my surprise Pump HD has a behind the ear design, but it looked very slick and modern, not like some other headsets I've seen in the past that resemble a hearing aid. I also noticed how lightweight Pumps felt in my hand and hardly even noticeable once placed around my ears. One common problem with earbuds is finding proper eartips for the best fitment to seal your ear canal and also to make sure they won't fall out of your ears during extreme activities. Here, though Blueant included a very generous selection of a total of 7 pairs of eartips (doubles of each S/M/L pairs and a pair of Comply premium awareness tips), and 2 pairs of stabilizers, and a separate cable zip - all this was to enhance the sound isolation and customize cable length. The fitment itself was taken care of by behind the ear design.The headset itself has IP67 rating which guarantees to withstand heavy exposure to wet condition. With a Teflon coating and Kevlar shielding, it blocks water, salt, dust and sweat from entering the headphone set. Also, the micro-usb recharging port (with a high quality cable included in accessories) has a durable seal cap. All the Bluetooth button controls are sealed as well. The included blue eartips seems to be made out of durable silicone material and with a right size selection provide a decent noise isolation. But if you need to be aware of your surrounding, Blueant also included a pair of premium Comply Awareness tips that allow background noise. To compliment it's durable built, Pump also includes a durable lasting battery for up to 8hr of play - a very impressive performance!Wireless pair up was very easy, and it got connected to my phone and media audio without any problem. It supports all the common Bluetooth profiles, such as A2DP, AVRCP, HFP, and HSP. Using multifunction Play button, easily distinguished by raised profile on a side of right earpiece behind your ear, you can play/pause and pick up a call with ease. Volume up/down buttons, shaped as plus and minus, are used to change the volume and also to skip tracks next/prev. The wireless range was very impressive as well, I was about 50+ feet away from my phone across 2 rooms and it was playing without a problem. Blueant claims 100ft wireless distance which I still have to test, but in my opinion it's probably in the open area and with hair out of the way without covering headphones. I also run a number of calling tests, and it sounded very clear on both ends.Now, let's see how this sound translates into steaming audio. Here, things got a little more interesting. Though using Bluetooth 3.0, Pump actually supports AptX and AAC codecs to provide high quality audio without a typical wireless compression. As a matter of fact, this is a first time ever I have seen a non-audiophile company to disclose frequency response of their headphones. They are definitely very proud of their 12.5mm customized dynamic driver, and v-shaped sound tuning. But for me it was a mix bag of impressions. It's not fair to judge sport headphones comparing them to audiophile in-ears, but sound is as important as the durability and design appeal. These headphones has a very high emphasis on deep punchy bass. When you exercising - beat is driving your motion, and Pump will really pump you up with a strong beat! Mids were recessed, typical for v-shape sound, but then toward the upper mids and treble instead of going back up, it rolled off down killing the clarity and the sparkle of high frequencies. As a result, overall sound has a nice driving rhythm but it's veiled with overpowering bass and not enough clarity and details in vocals. So what does it mean? By default with your smartphone audio player without any EQ setting the sound might not be your cup of tea (it wasn't mine). The good news - it can be easily corrected with EQ by boosting upper mids and highs around 5k region.  I guess this is just a general comment for a lot of sport headphones where I would prefer to have a more balanced sound with some default bass enhancement and let me tweak EQ further to fine tune it, rather than tweaking EQ setting for different headphones in order to enjoy it from get go.If you are into pushing yourself to the limit while exercising, if you find that you have to go through a new pair of headphones every few months because they break under your sweat, if you have to constantly adjust the fitment of your current headphones because they don't stay in place, and if you are not getting enough of daily "bass" to drive you to your next workout goal - Pump HD is calling your name!
summary: The most durable sport headphones with a great bass to pump you up! :)

reviewText: I have owned quite a few stereo Bluetooth headsets (Jaybird Bluebuds X, Denon WorkoutFreak, Plantronics BackBeats, etc).  This is the first one that I can give a full 5 out of 5 star review.  Many of the other headsets worked well, but had 1 or 2 things that bugged me about them.  Overall they have good batterylife, stay on my head even during very intense workouts, and the signal doesn't cut out no matter where my phone is located on my body. The sound quality is good for bluetooth.  Not as good as a wired headset, but still better than a lot of other Bluetooth headsets out there.Pros:- Battery Life (I can get around 6-7 hours of continuous music / AudioBook before needing a charge)- Fit / Comfort (multiple size earbud options)- Connection Strength (I can basically walk around my house without losing connection from my phone.  Also can have it in any pocket and not have signal cut out)- Sound Quality- Button Placement- Water / Sweatproof- Short cord connecting earpieces (won't  flop around or snag on your neck)Cons:- Microphone (people can hear you fine during calls, but it also picks up all the background noise around you)After 1 week of use, I am very pleased with this headset.  The sound quality is sufficient for listening to tunes while working out or mowing the lawn, and that is good enough for me.  I also picked up a 2yr extended warranty via SquareTrade as I have yet to own a Bluetooth headset that didn't break after a year.  Maybe this one will outlast all the others.
summary: Great solution for hands free Stereo Sound

reviewText: I consider myself a professional hobbyist.  Until recently, I've used very small and light weight travel type tripods with fixed heads.  This head with the collapsible handles, bubble levels for any angle, and awesome quick plate makes this photo head a must for anyone who wants more creative control over your shoots. I put it on a 055 carbon fiber tripod.  The head is by far heavier than the tripod itself, but that is not a negative.  The construction is magnificent. I don't use magnificent as a descriptive word ever. It's got substantial feel and function. You will not be disappointed in this photo head.

I'm new to a high quality head, but so far, this is fantastic.  I have big hands and I'm comfortable with the handles.  They expand out for more leverage and for a more smooth video.  I can see where even longer handles would accentuate this.  They fold up perfectly in my bag.  Tilt is extremely smooth. It locks tight to the base. The quick clip is very secure with the safety switch. I am confident this will hold a heavy lense and camera.  The three levels are nice but it's important to get the tripod level first as you change the axis, your level on the head gets altered.This combined with my Manfrotto 055XPROB Triood gives me a lot of confidence that I will not have any camera shake.  That alone is worth the extra nickels.  Great product!
summary: Smooth, secure, compact, and pro feeling...

reviewText: it is fast, well much faster than my 2 year old windows 7 desktop anyway, but dont assume that just because it has usb ports that you can plug in usb peripherals and have them work.  Mice, keyboards, thumb drives and external hard drives work in my experience but dont expect to be able to plug in your cd or dvd player.
summary: fantastic but dont expect all your usb peripherals to work

reviewText: This computer replaced my aging computer running Linux Mint.  I have had The Asus Chromebox for a week and went to all of my websites, minor issue is a couple websites video start's pixelated for the first 5 to 10 seconds and then everything looks and sounds great, but 95% of the time there is no pixelation issue.  Also, I have had this Chromebox connected via HDMI to my 46" Samsung TV and all four sides are cropped off, so you would not see the back button, tab bar, etc.  I tried all four of my TV's HDMI ports with the same issue.  The workaround is to go into Chome OS setting and manually  adjust the image which lowers the resolution or go into the TV settings and change video from 16x9 to "fit screen", I ended adjusting the setting on the TV and now the screen looks good, I wonder if that lowers the resolution? YMMV good for you if you don't have this issue.Asus Chromebox does not have a setting to adjust the screen saver, well because it does not have one :)  And you cannot adjust when the monitor turns off.  But I found a easy work around, install Webview Screensaver and SimpleExtManager at the Chrome Store.  Go into SimpleExtManager and make a group with just the Webview Screensaver that way you can easily toggle the screensaver on and off.The Asus Chromebox is cheap, has low end hardware, and this linux distro is a work in progress as Google is adding new features to Chrome OS all the time :)  Overall I'm very happy with my purchase, just remember you get what you pay for.Sooooo, which one to buy? You got this one, the Asus Chromebox with the i3 variant, or you could roll you own with a NUC with the same i3 and add Linux Mint or Ubuntu.  If you don't know what a Ubuntu is then forget the NUC and if you don't have a 4K compatible TV/monitor and receiver, then forget the Asus i3 variant.NOTE: I did not drink too much Google Kool-aid or Haterade when writing this review, just the facts ma'am.

I recently "Cut the Cord" and needed a way to watch shows the day after they aired.  The Chromebox was just what I needed.  I found one available in a local store (prefer purchasing from Amazon but was backordered).  I also purchased a Logitech K400 wireless keyboard.  I connected the Chromebox to my Samsung 55H6350. WOW!!  This baby takes place of every Smart App my tv has!  So far I have only used 2 Tabs at a time and havent experienced any performance issues.  Sure Logging in every time you turn it on is an extra step, but I'm okay with that.  I can now watch any video I can find online; youtube, NBC, ABC, HBO, Slingbox, etc...  The question now becomes, do I buy one for every other TV in my house?????  A good problem to have.UPDATE:  Reduce my rating to 4/5 stars.  I continue to find websites and applications that are not compatible with Chrome/Chromebox.  For example, Skype does not work (no workaround).  Also watch.Slingbox.com is not compatible (work around is to use the slingbox app on a Roku).  Everything else on the chromebox is fantastic!!!
It toke some time to get working but is working well and isn't running very hot.I'm quite happy with it.

This antminer works fine but, my self and others do seem to have to overclock it to get the 2gh/s. with cgminer 4.3.3 I set it at--anu-freq 280 which runs it about 2.2gh/s per ASIC miner. That setting keeps me at about 4.450gh/s which varies from time to time but still a steady average of 4gh/s (two U2 miners). I use p2pool and not going to get rich, lol but makes 50+ cents every 10 hours. I just order two more of these so yes I am pleased with their performance. I will mention that running it using cgminer4.3.3 I do get HW Errors but I just pay no mind to them because 1 can't find a way to get 0 HW Errors and as I read this happens to many people and their miners are doing fine.  2nd performance of this and probably any miner is dependent on your system as a whole. I run Win7 Home Pre. 3ghz 8gigs ram 64bit w/slow DSL internet(2+mbs dwnload). I am waiting for all parts to arrive and will soon be using my Rasberry Pi with MinePeon to run miners..

reviewerName: Jeri Zerr "formerly a Road Warrior of the Nth...
reviewText: The WD My Cloud Mirror is a GREAT solution to today's home or small office storage needs.  It's like having a cloud of your own, since you can access your files on the My Cloud Mirror from your other computers, tablets, smartphones, etc - with NO monthly fees.  Personally I found the My Cloud Mirror set as RAID 0 (to allow the full use of all the storage space instead of half in a mirrored configuration) to be ideal when also using another off-site backup provider such as BackBlaze or Carbonite - the best of both large cloud-based storage at home as well as a backup copy maintained offsite should the unthinkable happen.The WD My Cloud Mirror was easy to install and setup.  Just follow the direction and you'll be backing up your files in no time. I used the 2 USB 3,0 ports to attach a couple additional drives I had of data, they readily synched into the drive allowing me access to my files from literally anywhere I had WiFi access.* Centralized dual drive storage for all your content* Mirrored data protection - 1 drive is used to store the data, the other drive is a backup copy (so a 4TB configured as Raid 1 allows for 2 TB data storage. Yet this drive allows for RAID 1, or spanning mode, to use the full capacity* Automatic backup* Expandable storage - TWO USB 3.0 ports allow the addition of more external drives* Fast File Transfer - gigabit ethernet* Reliable and secure* Photos and videos* Anywhere access - connect via your phone or tablet while remote from your network.* Connect to Dropbox and more - it allows easy transfer of files from your personal cloud, Dropbox and other clouds.My Cloud Mirror is available in the 4TB, 6TB and 8TB configurations, I reviewed the 4TB Cloud Mirror.

We have a similar device already (My Book Live Duo) from Western Digital that has worked well, and this is similarly well equipped to serve as a good NAS device.Like the My Book Live Duo, the My Cloud Mirror has streaming media services (DLNA and iTunes), various RAID options to suit your needs, access via mobile apps, and many configuration options.  However, There's definitely a lot of additional functionality that is available on this device that isn't on the My Book Live Duo, such as the ability to set up backups to other drives on your network or even remote (cloud) storage services like Amazon S3.  Even more impressive is the selection of applications that you can install via the Administrative UI that can make your My Cloud Mirror into a kind of internal web hosting platform - WordPress, Joomla, and some other content management options I was not as familiar with.While the UI between the two devices is very different, I think I prefer the one on My Book Live Duo.  It seems a little more straightforward, but perhaps that's because there are fewer options, I don't know.  I did have some difficulty initially setting up because nowhere does it state that the admin account initially has a blank password, it just prompts you to set up a wd2go account (for remotely accessing the drive).  I had to call WD's tech support and felt really dumb when they suggested I just not enter a password.  Once I did this and then set a new password and other users, everything worked fine, but it's something that someone not very familiar with setting up these devices should be aware of given that it's lot indicated in the directions or software that one can download for the device.For a home user, the number of options available are a bit overwhelming, but good to know that they are there when and if needed.  I figure many of these options would be very valuable in a corporate setting or simply a home that has developers and/or system administrators in it.  But that doesn't mean it's overkill for the general user, since one can easily use this as a simple way to back up your files from your PC's to a device that you can access remotely fairly easily.
summary: Great option for NAS - both simple uses and more complex

reviewText: This comes under the category of "Why didn't they think of this earlier!" This is a universal cell phone battery. And the reason why this is universal is that the charging contacts on this charger can be adjusted. As long as your batteries contact fit, you will be able to charge your battery. I received a sample for review purposes.I'm thinking that this is best for those with more than one type of phone. As long as you're not charging more than 1 battery at the same time, you can charge all brands of battery with this. And not only that, there's a USB port on the side and you can charge with that at the same time.Some features: Only charges at 1A. Automatically recognizes battery voltage and polarity. Lifetime tech support!Overall, just a very useful charging device. Two thumbs up.

The Blurex 24 Port Unmanaged Gigabit Switch comes is less expensive by 10 dollars than its nearest competitor and offers an additional feature, called disk cloning, that is not available on any other device in its price range. I set this switch up on a network of two Macs and a Windows 7 computer and all of the computers worked perfectly. I had no trouble at all. The speed of the network seems to be just as fast as the wireless equivalent I was using before so there is no slowdown from the switch. Indeed, for a switch this device works just fine, but with the additional feature of disk cloning, which allows an entire disk image on one computer to be transferred to another, I think this Blurex switch is a really good buy. One caveat is that the manufacturer does not provide much information about how to use the device. This is fine for using the device in its regular mode to just share an internet connection between up to 24 computers, but, since I do not know very much about disk cloning, and there was little or no information provided by Blurex, I was not able to make any use of this feature. I think it would be a good idea for the people at Blurex to put an online tutorial on their site that explains how to use this feature of the device. Finally, I should also note that I received this device for free from the manufacturer, who contacted me with a request to review this product.
summary: truly plug and play in standard mode - and very inexpensive for the features

reviewText: QUICK SUMMARY:  Easy installation, quiet, expansive Ethernet switch could be the only Ethernet switch you'll need.  Recommended.BACKGROUND:  In my tech-infused home, this 24-port Ethernet switch was a welcomed replacement to a Linksys 4-port Gigabit I was using.  Before installing this Blurex 24 port switch, I had to unplug/re-plug Ethernet cords into the 4-port switch depending on what I needed to be connected.  Now, I've got everything connected with plenty more ports to use later.WHAT I LIKED:- Great performance at gigabit speeds.  I moved 2GB and 4GB files very quickly, with burst speeds of 150MB/sec and sustained speeds of around 80-100MB/sec.  That's consistent with what I would expect given my hardware.- No fan means quiet operation- Thankfully, Blurex decided to use well-lit green indicator LED lights rather than the blinding blue lights so often used- While this is rack-mountable, I used the supplied four rubber feet to place this atop my roll-top deskWHAT COULD BE BETTER:- The ports are positioned in a 2 row, 12-port configuration.  The indicator lights, however, are not intuitively positioned in a similar 2 row, 12 light configuration; rather, they used a 4-row, 6-light configuration, and port 1 is in the bottom left corner, not the top left corner.  Maybe that's how switches like that are normally labeled, but it's not intuitive.- The labels next to the lights are easily confused because the labels are essentially between two lights (is port 4 on?  or port 8?)- The labels themselves are in a very small font- Because my installation doesn't involve a rack, the cables come up over the top of the switch to connect to the front of the switch.  I would welcome a design that would allow either connecting cables to the front OR the back of the switch.  To do that without having 24 ports both in the front and the back, just allow users to insert a power cord either from the front or the back, and having 24 LED indicator lights on the front and back, both.  Then, for installations like mine, where I'm connecting a bunch of devices on a computer desk, the cables are connected to the back of the switch, not the front.Likely, this unit will be purchased by businesses with an Ethernet network that is larger than the typical home user's network.  If you're a home user or small business user, think through how this switch will be installed and make sure you're okay with the end result.CONCLUSION:  Buying a switch is a install-it-and-forget-it device.  Or, it should be.  Now that I've installed this Blurex 24 port switch into my home environment with gigabit speed performance (in a real world setting), I hope to forget that it's there.  (Review unit supplied by vendor).
summary: Great for rack-mounted environment, good for other environments (eg, home users)

reviewText: it works very well and i am happy with my purchase

This beats out so many tablets I just can't say how much this is the best tablet for under $200 you can get.  If you need more tablet than this you should just get laptop, as you just be throwing money out there.

This is a very well made tablet. Its performance with the Quad core processor stands out.The screen resolution produces clear sharp images, and the apps from Google Play make this a very useful tablet. It was so nice, I bought a second unit for my wife. She has hers in a case with a built in, wired keyboard. The TabSuit 10.1'' Tablet Folio Keyboard with Stand, Universal PU Leather case for 10.1'' Tablets is very comfortable to use and at $12.99 its very affordable. If you want the performance of the name brand tablets at an economical price, you should give this one a try. Now for the downside, this tablet is now being shipped and sold by Matricom, and unfortunately its more expensive than the first one I bought at $155.00 from Amazon with Prime, free shipping. The unit is more expensive now and you must also pay for shipping. That was my only disappointment.

I've had several cases for my ipad, but the problem I had with most of them is that once you snap it on your ipad you can't easily get it off again.  And when I say easily, I mean I've had to break one of the cases to get it to let go off my ipad!  Since I use my ipad in various situations (film production, teaching, etc.) I have several different mounts to hold it in position, none of which accommodate a case.  So, though I like using it in a case most of the time, I often have to pop it out of the case to put it in a mount so I can't use a case that I can't easily remove my ipad from.This case is the perfect solution!  My ipad easily slides into and out of it - it provides stylish protection but doesn't become a permanent feature of my ipad.  It's very nice looking and has a high quality feel to it.  Best of all it has a keyboard that works with it but isn't permanently attached to it.  The person who designed this was definitely someone who uses an ipad regularly and really analyzed what works and doesn't work with most cases.  The only thing it doesn't do is allow you to use your ipad in portrait.  Sometimes when I type I flip the ipad upright so I can see more of the page, but this case doesn't accommodate that type of use.  Definitely not a deal-breaker for me, but it would have been nice.Smart case, nice quality, good price.  Trifecta!

The case was bought for my daughter's Miix tablet. Everything fit perfectly in it and the magnetic clasp that some people were saying didn't work well seems to be holding up. The one downside is that it doesn't allow the Windows 8 touch gestures very well because it covers the edges of the screen that allow them to work. Not bad but it does take some getting used to.
summary: Nice case for a good price

reviewText: A very nice case for the money. My gripes about it are minor. The stand mode is not highly stable. Also, the cutouts for edge touches are fine except for the top. It would be very easy to just remove the material between the top cutout and the main opening. In fact, I'll do it myself with a sharp knife.

For the last few years, I have been using my Bose OE2s as my default pair to plug into my laptop for casual listening while I work (or at least tell myself I'm working because I'm on a computer).  I have been quite happy with them for what they are.  The "SoundTrue" on-ear headphones are a modest update, and fill the same niche.  Consequently, my thoughts on them are pretty similar to my review of the OE2s.That said, let's start with what the SoundTrue on-ears are, and what they are not.  These are not for your hardcore audiophile.  What they are is remarkably light and comfortable, with sound quality far better than what you would expect for that.  This is what Bose does better than anybody else.  Can you get better sound quality?  Absolutely.  Can you get it for less money?  Yup.  But, and there's a big "but..."  For most users, it won't matter.  Here's the dirty little secret about sound quality.  If you are listening either to compressed files, or even lossless files through your computer's built-in digital-analog converter (DAC), you get what economists call "diminishing marginal returns" for better headphones.  The biggest impediment to sound quality if you are listening through a computer rather than a regular stereo is the computer's built-in DAC.  Most just aren't very good, so even really high-end headphones won't give you an ideal listening experience.  Plug your Bose headphones into a regular stereo with either a cd or a well-cared-for vinyl, compare them to some respectable but cheaper pairs, and you can get better sound quality for the money.  Run that comparison on your computer and the differences become negligible.  Your built-in DAC is what limits your sound quality more than your headphones once you get to decent enough headphones.  This particular line of Bose headphones nearly tops out the sound quality that you can get from many computers' built-in DACs.  Plug a really high-end pair of headphones into your computer, and it won't sound that much better than these.  So why are you paying more for the Bose?  For the comfort.  Pure and simple.  These are ridiculously light-weight, and you can hardly notice wearing them.  And yet you get the kind of sound quality that is about as good as you'll get without an external DAC, particularly if you are listening to compressed files (which you shouldn't do, but I digress).  If you want sound quality, don't listen to compressed files, and don't use your computer's build-in DAC.  Then, you can get better sound for cheaper.With that out of the way, how do these compare to previous Bose headphones?  The design is basically the same as my OE2 headphones.  The sound quality is at most a modest improvement-- they sound pretty similar, although the same volume setting on a device gives me lower volume on these newer headphones.  I think they want me to think that I can hear more of the quiet details on these newer phones.  If so, the difference is pretty subtle-- I'm not sure how much more I can hear.  In terms of sound quality, any improvement over the OE2 is minor at most.There are two design differences.  There is the volume control thing in the cord, which is nice to have.  However, the jack no longer angles the cord.  The cord now sticks straight out from the jack.  I find this irritating.  Plugged into my laptop, that means a cord sticking out to the left farther than I would like.  Plugged into a mobile device, it could get jostled around in your pocket.  Yes, it's a minor thing, and I would probably never pick a pair of headphones based on the angle of the cord at the jack.  At the end of the day, this is basically the OE2 with a few updates.  They are remarkably comfortable, and with better sound quality than you would normally expect given their size and weight.  Sound quality doesn't get dramatically better if you are listening the way most people listen these days anyway.  You are paying for comfort.  I like them, but only for casual listening.  Hardcore audiophiles-- look elsewhere (but you probably already knew that).
summary: Not much different from the Bose OE2:  comfortable and light-weight with decent sound, for a high price

reviewText: I love the construction of these headphones - the way they unfold from a compact pouch - it just feels like a very high quality product "right out of the box".  As for the audio, it's really stunning - I am listening to Mahler's 6th on Spotify as I type this and I'm finding it hard to concentrate on anything but this music.  I prefer this "on-ear" pair to an "over-the-ear" pair I reviewed recently for office use, because it allows me to hear a little of the ambient sound near my cubicle (the "over-the-ear" model is practically a cone of silence) but the audio experience on both models is really captivating.I haven't decided yet if I would prefer this pair on my next flight compared to noise-cancelling headphones - the advantage of "non noise-cancelling" headphones like these is that no additional power is required - I'll probably bring these and my Sennheiser's on my next trip - I expect the experience to be comparable.

Reviewing headphones is a difficult challenge. Everyone has his or her particular tastes, and what sounds "phenomenal" differs from person to person.  Variables such as the genre of music preferred, purpose of the headphones, (ie watching movies, listening to music, or the spoken word in general) and personal preference regarding balance of sound, must also be factored in.I recently reviewed theBose SoundTrue Headphones On-Ear Style, Purple/Mintand I was able to compare those with two other models of headphones on the market. I was not able to do so with the over-the-ear since the only over-the-ear cans I have are a pair of Sennheiser HD 598's which are an "open" headphone (and sound amazing), whereas the Bose SoundTrue are "closed," or more of a noise-canceling headphone. This would not have been a fair comparison, in my opinion.I compared different genres of music in differing formats; all were MP3@320kbs, FLAC, or regular CD's. For solo instruments such as piano or classical music, the Bose sound excellent. Artists such as Miles Davis, George Winston, and other instrumentals sound really great. It was when I listened to genres with vocals or a wider, fuller spectrum of sound that my enthusiasm for these headphones waned. I found the Bose to have excellent lows and bottom end, but the vocals and the midrange suffered greatly.  The midrange was virtually non-existent, and the highs lacked brightness, clarity, and the crispness that I prefer. It's like the highs have a film or veneer that prevents the brisk, bright, clear sound from coming through. Vocals reek of a bit too much bass for my taste.Bose have a reputation for a signature sound that people often either love of hate. I gave these 4 stars (3.5 for sound, 4 overall), partly out of respect for people that do subscribe to this particular sound. As stated, the solo instruments like piano and horns, as well as classical music, sound pleasant.  Personally, I would not shell out $179 (the current price as I am reviewing) for a sound that is this unbalanced.Other good things about these headphones are the noise canceling quality. Also, the headphones fold compactly, fit neatly in a case included, and the cord detaches and has volume +, -, and pause buttons for convenience.3.5 stars for sound, 4 stars overall
summary: Not for all types of music, in my opinion

reviewText: For the size of the headphones, they slide easily on and off, and stay with the most gentle of grips around head. Sound quality and voice quality is excellent. Did not notice the bass insufficiency, as pointed out in reviews, until brought to attention.Performs well with laptop, tablet and smartphone. Cool carry case is well designed. Cord does not tangle in any situation. Allows just the right amount of noise, to keep you connected and alert to ambience. Higher volume ranges cancel out all outside noise.Great for any situation and attractive color
summary: they slide easily on and off

reviewText: I returned mine.  Many bugs including screen locking and losing bluetooth connection that Garmin had to have known about.  When the screen locks you also lose all your data as well.I should not have been surprised since bugs and lousy software are a known thing with Garmin.  I'll continue to use my Edge 510 under the Polar V650 comes out and them be done with Garmin forever.

Cute, works great, takes AMAZING photos. The only reason I didn’t give it five stars is because, in my opinion, these are not user-friendly or intuitive. I’m used to my iPhone for pictures and I love just about everything Apple makes (okay, everything) and am used to things that are intuitive.

I was fairly impressed by this camera and lens.  The setup is pretty easy.  The photo quality is good but it takes JPG only.  The autofocus is fast.  The noise ratio is not bad up to about ISO 800.  I would have liked to see the ability to do RAW capture.  The touch screen works well and has a good viewing angle.  The 9mm lens included is fairly sharp and works but of course has no manual focus.

Nice quick grab camera for a walk in woods or local party.  Much better pics than my point and shoot, but not nearly as good as my Nikon D7000 (which is obviously expected).  When collapsed camera fits nicely into a small purse, but not really in a pocket unless a jacket.Likes: Size and image quality for type.  Nice modes built in.Dislikes: very few lens options and not great in lower light. Flash is included, but it is detachable and cannot live on camera.  If they make a low light prime lens, I would be all over it (now can only use with a fairly expensive adapter)
summary: Nice quick grab camera for a walk in woods or ...

reviewText: If you already have x6 or even x5, save your dough and wait - at least till they work out the bugs in a few updates. Also BE SURE TO ORDER THE BOX VERSION ONLY! If you get the download version (at the same price) you will not get the several hundred additional fonts, clipart (if you have any use for it) essentially ALL the "content" willl be available ONLY if you sign up with Corel Corp. and then to be downloaded one at a time. Further more their is "premium" content and even worse "premium" features that are only available to "Premium" (annual paid subscription) members. That's right, actual program tools that are only yours for yet additional fees.
summary: Too much for too l;ittle - AND hidden costs

reviewText: I work for the biggest entertainment company in the world producing some of the most seen graphics ever. Thousand of people a day see what great world class graphics look like. The problem, they don't know it's CorelDraw. Not Illustrator. Oh... we have a choice, both are available. Draw is more productive then the other guy. Takes less steps to produce a beautiful drawing, I've chosen to use Draw for the last 28-29 years. Illustrator is frustrating. Egghead didn't even have a chance to put Draw on the shelf before I grabbed one. So I know of what I speak.........absolutely the best deal in town. Looking for a great drawing application, look no further. Draw!

Very easy to upgrade and I enjoy the new features. I started using the upgrade immediately and actually started designing a new web page header for a contract and everything fell right into place. Very happy to have upgraded.

I have use the Adobe creative suite's for years; Almost a decade to this point. I use them for Adobe Premiere and Photoshop mostly. With that said I am completely disappointed that Adobe has moved to the "cloud-based subscription fee" for all of their creative suites. Basically Adobe does not sell boxed versions of their software any longer. So for me I will not be purchasing another Adobe product as I don't want to pay $40-$60 in monthly fees.And that's where I think companies like Corel can finally steal market share. Now over the years I've dabbled in Adobe Illustrator but I'm not proficient at vector art at all. With that said X7 in the little bit intimidating but I think I'll get the hang of it as it has a really nice user interface.I always recommend buying the box versions of software.But in my opinion companies that that used to exclusively use Adobe Illustrator will be looking at products from Corel to replace Adobe's stupid subscription-based service. I'm of the opinion that Adobe at some point will start selling boxed versions again as they have officially lost customers like me.Thanks for readingPS Be sure to download the demo version from Corel's website as you can see your way around the software package.
summary: Now is Corel's time to strike Adobe and X7 can do some damage.

reviewText: CorelDRAW Graphics Suite X7 is a powerful graphics suite. There are few visually obvious major improvements from the previous version, but in combination with the many minor enhancements and internal refinements, Graphics Suite X7 is an exceptional tool.I welcome the newly introduced enhancement to Object outlines, which, centered by default, may be modified to appear either outside, or inside the lines of an object.Probably the most noticeable of features includes the new fill capabilities. Fill is much more versatile with elliptical and rectangular attributes which default nicely relative to the applicable object’s dimensions, while the Docker within the Object Properties panel puts fine-tuning controls in one convenient place. The fill for an object can also be manipulated from an Object control, for interactive movement for angle, skew, size, and positions of color tabs along the gradient axis with real-time visual feedback. I love it.Transparency options may be assigned as usual, with the addition of fountain, vector, or bitmap patterns, in any of several styles that may be selected from the dropdown list within the Transparency section of the Object Properties panel.Several new Docker panels make workflow much more streamlined. One such favorite is the accessibly convenient panel for Alignment and Dynamic Guides. The work space may be as free of clutter as I wish, simply activating desired angles from the list populated with common angles, or with those added from the custom angle entry. There are buttons for selecting or deselecting all angles for simplicity.The user interface enhancements are cool. X7 includes presets for users who are accustomed to an Illustrator workspace. The user interface looks clean and well-organized. When working on a larger monitor, I appreciate the ability to select from small, medium, or large default button sizes. There is a button on the Dockers window that opens a divided-by-category list of available Docker panels.I am underwhelmed by Font Playground. I do not recall previous versions of this software not showing a font preview…I suppose I just didn’t notice. Of course, it is nice to see how a font will look before selecting it, but it seems Font Playground simply acts in a similar manner to the drop down list of fonts within Microsoft Word. I would have expected to be able to select blocks of existing text in my document, and then go to Font Playground to play with them for immediate feedback. Font Playground is simply a Docker window for font previews.Having moved up from the previous suite version, I would have been happy to have gone the upgrade route for the fill tools, and many of the new Docker panels. The addition of Visual Studio Tools for Applications should open up possibilities for many. Website Creator is said to have been worked on, though I do hand-coding, so I did not explore its features. Photo Paint has been given a decent amount of attention, with a Smart Carver that is much more effective and easy to utilize, the artistic capabilities of the liquid tools that were introduced into Draw X6, new brush tools, a generous handful of Effects, image straightening, and several options that elevate Photo Paint to a new level of creativity.Whether new to digital photo editing and illustrative design, or a long-time user of these or similar editing tools, this newest version of CorelDRAW Graphics Suite has plenty to offer. Though quite powerful, this is not software for instant gratification; it has a learning curve to master before one will be effectively joining curves and creating precise, complex objects. Despite its learning curve, this software is a creative powerhouse for anyone who takes the time to master the fundamentals, and the possibilities grow exponentially, the more familiar the interface and its tools become while exploring. This is a well-balanced suite of capable graphics tools, at a price that is quite reasonable for what it offers.
summary: Brilliant Enhancements for a Powerfully Creative Suite

reviewText: NOTE: Yes there is a new version X7, but sold here on Amazon for $499.99. If you buy X6 here for $265.47 and like it, you can upgrade at Corel.com to X7 for $199.00, total $464.67. Reason to buy box set is at the end of the reviewCorelDraw is a pretty intuitive vector program that has a lot to offer. Please note I have been using one version or another since it's first release. It does some things Illustrator still can't and many essential things (such as curve and line edit) much more easily. There are also a lot of things Illustrator can do that CorelDraw can't (e.g. - non permanent effects, filters, line effects and fills).CorelDraw is also a proprietary format which can have drawbacks - good luck getting some other software to open, import or view a CorelDraw file. Also there have been occasions when a file decides to "become" corrupt (no power outages, successful save, no apparent issues, all good but..) and will no longer open AT ALL, meaning it's do over time. Corel has helped overcome this by supplying some excellent filters for importing and exporting to different formats. There is also a "Publish to PDF" option (why not under "Save As"? - too much like right?) that works pretty well though can be hinky with some effects (tranparancies, drop shadows) but these can usually be successfully worked around.That said, Photopaint, while a very capable program, seems as confusing as Draw seems easy. Photoshop, by comparison, while it can be very complex, seemed easy breezy to grasp the essentials and get going. Capture (for me) sometimes works, sometimes doesn't. Font Manager I have never used myself, though some like it a lot.Why buy the boxed set? Well if you don't, you don't get any of the extra content - fonts, clip art, patterns, etc. except it seems by downloading one at a time and only then if you sign up for a free "membership" which encourages you to be signed in online at all times (mmmmm data). Likewise you can download updates (fixes, improvements- you decide) but not install them unless you are on line and logged into your "membership".
summary: Draw is great for vector work. ALWAYS BUY THE BOX VERSION, SAME PRICE AS DOWNLOAD AND YOU GET EXTRAS

reviewText: I picked up this Samsung 32GB SDHC Memory card for my new Samsung camera. If you've been around digital cameras long enough to shoot stills and video, you no doubt know that not all memory cards are created equal. this particular card is class 6, boasting transfer speeds of up to 24 MB/s. This will work fine for most at home or novice applications. If you're looking for a card with a higher data transfer rate, you may want to consider either the class 10 cards with a higher transfer speed rating.This card offers good bang for your buck. At the time of this review, the cost of the this memory card averaged a mere $0.56 per gigabyte. It's amazing how much more affordable this type of storage has become in the past few years. I remember paying 3-4 times as much for a card with 1/8 of the storage only a few years ago.My rating is 5 stars.
summary: A quality and affordable memory card for your digital camera. Highly recommended.

reviewText: I needed a larger SD card for my Canon M30, so I ordered this one to see how it works. I find it to be as fast as other class 10 cards, and about average for downloading the files.I prefer using the SD card for my Canon because it is faster to remove the card than to connect the camcorder to the computer via USB. I wasn't sure that this one would work (I'd not used more than 16 Gb before), but it works fine in my device. The recording went well, and there were no errors; I didn't notice any difference between this and my other Class 10 flash drives. I put the disc into an adapter and transferred the files to my computer, again without errors. Transfer back to computer is going to be dependent upon the speed of the port and adapter being used. I didn't notice it being any faster than my other class 10 cards, but I suspect it is the adapter, which is rated as USB 2.0, but always transfers at 20 Mb/sec. So while I did not see the advertised read speeds, I am not detracting any stars because I believe it is my Windows 8.1 system in combination with this particular SD adapter that is causing the slowness.The card is advertised as being good despite being x-rayed, getting wet, etc. I did not test these features out!Summary: No surprises, which is a good thing when dealing with video and picture files. Highly recommended.

I used this memory card in my Canon DSLR and it has been fantastic so far. The 32 gigs provided plenty of space for images and HD video. Pictures and videos both came out fantastic. I really like that they're waterproof, temperature proof, and x-ray proof. I feel confident that my images will stay safe and sound in my camera on this memory card.

One problem with digital cameras taking such large pictures is that it takes forever to write to the disk, and I can't take another picture right after taking the first one.  OK, some has to do with my camera, but a lot has to do with the card.  This does speed up picture taking.And it holds a zillion pictures.
summary: Holds lots of pictures & saves them quickly.

reviewText: Seems faster in my D7100 than my previous cards, benchmarks 3x faster in Linux with a USB3 dongle. I guess that means it actually is faster.

I own a few other 64GB SDXC cards and thought I'd go for a speed test on my Mac using Disk Speed Test. The cards were all connected using my trusty Anker USB 3.0 card reader, on my MacPro.I tested the following cards:Sony Class 10 UHS-1 R40KomputerBay Professional 600XTranscend 300XPolaroid P-SDX64G10GEPOLI took the measurements several times, removed outliers and averaged the rest.Here are the results (MB/s)READ  WRITESamsung  88  67Sony  40  12KomputerBay  88  25Transcend  88  42Polaroid  88  55In conclusion... the Samsung card is well above the rest of the pack, sometimes drastically, and clearly justifies its PRO moniker... and the price premium that goes with it. If you need speedy memory performance, this is it. Highly recommended.
Great memory card! Now I can record videos with no stops. Before buying this memory I was able to record only for about 14 seconds with a Canon 70D. I really recommend it!

Whether traveling abroad, cross country or at home on staycation, my camera is always locked and loaded. Since obtaining  a digital camera, the idea of taking as many  pictures as I want to get the one great shot is easier than ever with Samsung Electronics 16GB PRO SDHC Class 10 memory card. This disc will record as many pictures as you can shoot, no problem. When I put this disc into my regular digital camera, it automatically put the camera in the video recording setting.This is where this disc shines, with a class ten, it can record high performance action.You can't beat the price under 30$ for a disc that has great resolution at an excellent speed and high capacity.Add to that it's waterproof, temperature proof, magnetic proof and x-ray proof. With all that going for you, why would buy anything else?

reviewText: I couldn’t be more pleased with this Samsung memory card. It works perfectly. I’ve mainly used it in an HD camcorder recording at full 1080P. It also keeps up with a Go Pro Black at all video settings. In short, it has no trouble writing fast enough to keep up with the video. The Samsung 32GB Micro SDHC card Class 6 card is a great performing memory card at a great price.  If your device doesn't require class 10 speeds then this performs extremely well and costs less.  The bright colors are a great way to prevent the card from being lost in case it is dropped or misplaced (Trust me I have lost a few all black Micro SD cards this way).  The downside to this card is that it only costs a few dollars less than the equivalent class 10 micro SDHC card so in reality you may be better off paying a few bucks more now so that in case you buy a device that requires class 10 speeds you wont have to buy another memory card.

Data transfer speeds are fast, and all devices recognize the unit properly.  I'm glad I spent the extra money and purchased a high quality unit.

The S4 records full HD video to the card without any issues.  I've not performed any speed tests but file transfers seem fast, much faster than the old Sandisk class 4 card. reviewText: Great performance and compatibility. I previously tried some Kingston and Snadisk cards with not-so-good results. It works great with my Note 3 and my Galaxy Note Pro 12.2

Uploading to this chip is at least twice as fast as other chips (Class 4 and 6) that I currently have.The most distinct feature of this chip is its built quality. reviewText: Summary - performs very well compared to Sandisk, which tend to consider the gold standard for microsd card performance and stability.I tested with 64bit  CrystalDiskMark and it's very close in performance.  The Samsung writes a little faster but reads a bit slower.  As a rough metric I combine the read/write speeds, since you usally need to do both to transfer data  - the Samsung is 40 while the Sandisk is 44  about 10% faster overall.  If you're using this for a video camera, then the write speed is more important and the Samsung outperforms the Sandisk.As far as long term stability of the card, I've had a lot of off-brand cards and even after several years I've yet to have a failure, so I'd imagine the Samsung is every bit as good as the "no-name" cards.>>>Samsung EVO Class 10Sequential Read :  23.568 MB/sSequential Write :  16.343 MB/sRandom Read 512KB :  23.056 MB/sRandom Write 512KB :  21.477 MB/sRandom Read 4KB (QD=1) :  6.702 MB/s [  1636.2 IOPS]Random Write 4KB (QD=1) :  1.609 MB/s [  392.8 IOPS]Random Read 4KB (QD=32) :  7.376 MB/s [  1800.8 IOPS]Random Write 4KB (QD=32) :  1.389 MB/s [  339.2 IOPS]>>>Sandisk Ultra Class 10Sequential Read :  31.053 MB/sSequential Write :  13.109 MB/sRandom Read 512KB :  27.086 MB/sRandom Write 512KB :  0.574 MB/sRandom Read 4KB (QD=1) :  3.217 MB/s [  785.5 IOPS]Random Write 4KB (QD=1) :  1.390 MB/s [  339.3 IOPS]Random Read 4KB (QD=32) :  3.073 MB/s [  750.1 IOPS]Random Write 4KB (QD=32) :  1.419 MB/s [  346.5 IOPS]
summary: Test results show this to be comparable to Sandisk class 10

reviewText: As another reviewer has already reported you do have to make a simple modification, but otherwise this adapter is a nearly perfect solution for adding storage to the Lenovo Yoga 2 Pro.  Like the Macbooks, the Y2P has a half-depth SD card slot so it is not practical to leave a full size SD card installed.  Enter the Nifty MiniDrive to save the day.The modification simply involves filing down the ends of the aluminum cap so that the ends do not extend beyond the plastic of the adapter.  Look at a picture and you will see what I am talking about.In case you are wondering about removing the adapter, don't worry.  If you look at one of the pictures where you can see the "front" of the aluminum cap you will see two grooves separated by a solid area.  There is a hole under that area.  You stick the little removal hook they provide into that hole and pull the adapter out.  I have not tried it, but it looks like a hook formed from a paper clip or other small gauge wire would work in a pinch.  Heck, you could thread a length of heavy thread or fishing line through there, too.
Decent weight compared to the S Pen for my galaxy note pro. The pen is a little bulky but again, works way better than the included stylus.
summary: works way better than the included stylus
