Excellent case and great color. Great price too!

***Updated July 2014***After a few months with this sound bar I noticed a deficiency in the available I/O options.  Specifically, there is no headphone "out" jack.  If you are using this in a bedroom scenario and want to hook up a pair of wireless headphones you are left with rather ugly external add-ons as your only recourse.  Not a deal breaker and I would have still selected it over the other options, but it definitely is annoying for a device firmly targeted at "second room" viewing to miss this feature.I was shopping for a soundbar to give me better sound quality on my secondary TV (bedroom).  I picked the Sony 370H over the Vizio 2451 (5.1  w/ wireless sub), Sonos Playbar, dedicated 5.1 system, and older Sony units on sale.My buying criteria: (in order of importance)-Good sound for a 10' x 10' room-Able to handle my current setup (cable box, Apple TV, and Xbox)-Ability to mount on the wall-Minimal wiring hassleMy TV has 2 HDMI inputs.  Most soundbar vendors (Vizio and Sonos in particular) seem to design their systems with the idea that the TV will be the A/V switch and pass audio to a "dumb" soundbar via the optical out.  Reliance on  the optical out on a TV immediately makes it a mixed proposition whether 5.1 audio will be passed to the soundbar (some TV vendors do, some don't, YMMV).  If your TV doesn't pass 5.1 via the optical out then any 5.1 soundbar has greatly reduced value.  You can potentially get a small HDMI switch and mount it behind the TV, but it is one more reason to look at a dedicated 5.1 system.h/t to CNET for providing the following testing on TV vendors that pass 5.1 over the optical out:[...]Choices I evaluated:-Sonos Playbar-Vizio 4251-Dedicated 5.1 system-Older Sony units (260H or 660)Why I picked this year's Sony soundbar (370H)...I'm a Sonos customer (3 different Sonos purchases throughout the house since 2011).  I really wanted to find a reason to buy this soundbar.  I think they make great products.  Unfortunately Sonos falls under the "dumb soundbar" paradigm and relies on the optical out scenario.  Not worth it for a $700 soundbar (more for the matching sub).Vizio 4251 (or it's 2.1 cousin).  I read The Wirecutter reviews (as well as others).  The Internet seems to sing the praises of the audio quality of this soundbar.  It unfortunately also falls under the "dumb soundbar" scenario with an optical out dependency.  This makes the back speakers more or less useless from my perspective.  I ruled out the 2.1 flavor of this soundbar because I needed the HDMI inputs on the soundbar.  If I didn't have a strong preference for a built-in HDMI switch on the soundbar I would have considered the 2.1 Vizio.Dedicated 5.1.  I scratched this out due primarily to laziness for running wires cleanly to the back of the room.Older Sony's (260H or 660).  Both are marked down significantly now that this year's units are out.  The 260H didn't have enough HDMI inputs for my setup (though I like it and bought one for my parents for Christmas).  The 660 had the right number of HDMI inputs, but seemed to have a handful of user experience quirks (e.g. hexagonal speaker doesn't mount as cleanly as the rectangular 370H).The 370H didn't have a ton of public reviews when I made the decision to buy.  I bought primarily based on the fact the 260 had so many great reviews and hoped the audio quality was at least "good" for it's succesor.  My hope was rewarded and the sound quality is superb (for a soundbar).  The 300W is more than enough power for my space (negating any serious consideration to spend $100 more for the Sony 770).  The subwoofer is wireless so it makes placement supremely easy.  The sub also has a nice feature that allows it to be placed vertical or horizontal.  Maybe the wireless connection to the sub has some degradation in sound, but for practical purposes it's negligible.  Finally the 3 HDMI inputs on this make it perfect for my setup.Minor nitpicks:-Sony includes mounting brackets, but no wall mounting hardware.  You will have to buy your own drywall anchors.  These don't have to be heavy duty anchors, just enough to hold the soundbar.  It would be helpful to have slightly longer screws to give yourself some space if you are running HDMI cables below the device (see below).-Mount leveling.  I did this around the same time I was putting in some bathroom fixtures that included a convenient little "post-mounting" level option.  Sony has a simple keyhole wall mount on this.  If you don't measure carefully you will likely end up with extra holes in your walls.-Input / Output placement on the soundbar.  The HDMI output (to TV) and HDMI inputs are on the same side of the soundbar (top side, when wall mounted).  In my setup (from top to bottom) I have TV -> Soundbar -> Sources.  It makes sense to have the output to TV on top of the soundbar, but the inputs are a bit annoying to also have on top of the soundbar.  I would recommend you use longer screws when you wall mount so you can give yourself a bit of space to hairpin the HDMI cables back down to your sources (assuming your sources are physically below the soundbar).  I'm also going to see if a right-angle HDMI connector can minimize a wiring rat nest.All in all, this soundbar is definitely top tier and when evaluated against it's main competition it definitely deserves a top billing.
summary: Decided between Sonos Playbar, Vizio 4251, and older Sony units (bought the 370H)

reviewText: The Sony HT-XT1 2.1 Channel Sound Bar with Built-In Subwoofer is for this user a real winner. I have to say that this is a type of product that has been way overdue in coming to market. I am a long time fan of Sony sound bar/woofer systems, and have owned several different models. Although this unit is not intended to replace an AV receiver and speakers setup, or even one of the higher powered super sound-bars, it is perfect for the type of use that many people want a sound-bar for: to provide decent sound beyond the usually dismal audio output of most flat screen TVs.The feature set on the Sony HT-XT1 is very similar in many ways to other Sony sound bars, with the same basic HDMI input switching, sound profiles, controls, etc. But this time they have folded the whole thing, including the woofer, into a fairly unobtrusive and stylish slim box that acts as a pedestal for TVs, but is still thin enough to be tucked into a shelf below the TV level if that is needed. The system also has Bluetooth connectivity with NFC, digital audio decoding for most DTS HD, DolbyTruHD, PCM, Dolby Digital+ modes, an optical audio input and analog audio input, and the now almost obligatory tie in to an almost relevant smartphone app. Sony promotes this as a pedestal base for TVs to sit on. I personally would be a little worried about bass vibration at higher volume shaking up the TV components over the long haul. But for a TV with a wall mount, or for average level listening, or with the unit placed a level lower there should not be any problem.Although it doesn't have super bass, it has more than enough for the sort of bedroom and small living room use it is obviously designed for. If you have a McMansion sized living room or a bedroom the size of an entire 60s tract home then this might not be the best choice. But for more intimate viewing situations, in a small to medium sized room with the viewing/listening position within ten feet or so of the TV, this is a very good choice.Although one can debate the relative bass output of this unit compared to systems with separate sub-woofers, there is no denying that the loss of the separate, usually bulky and hard to place sub-woofer speaker is a big plus in fitting this enhanced sound system into a small living room, den or bedroom. It visually blends in very well with most TVs, sounds great, and is affordable. It's a great addition to the ever expanding line of Sony sound-bar systems. I am happy with my Sony HT-XT1 2.1 Channel Sound Bar. RECOMMENDED.
summary: A sleek sound-bar system that easily fits into most living rooms and sounds great

reviewText: I had the Bose Solo TV and the sound was good but I wanted better. I saw a review for this speaker on Cnet and after their reconmendation and much research I purchased the Sony Soundbar. I love it. The sound is great and my Blu Rays sound excellent. It's very easy to set up and the sound is good. If you are interested in getting a soundbar and want something that has great sound this is a must bar.
summary: Better Speaker that the Bose Solo TV

reviewText: Pros:- Separate Bass and Treble controls- Near Field communications (NFC )- Good visual/industial design- Smaller and easier to accommodate than a sound bar space wise.- I love the compact, trick remote.Cons:- Bluetooh missing Apt-x codec.  Recently purchased Sony STR-DN1050 AV receiver does have BT with Apt-x.- Honestly,  you're only going to get so much sound out of small speakers.  The XT1 makes the best out of what it has.- Sony could've went with two woofers and two tweeters along with a sub in a case of this size instead of 2 midrange and two subswoofers in a case of this size.- Small sound chambers = limited low frequency response.  Physics are physics.This was purchased for use in a bedroom to replace a Samsung HW-E450 which died prematurely.  I am using the XT1 with a Samsung ES7100 TV, Samsung BD-E5900 Blu-Ray player, Samsung Galaxy player 3.6, Samsung Galaxy S4, and Samsung Galaxy Note 3.  The XT1 plays well with various Samsung devices.I must qualify that the E450 has more power, greater width (and stereo separation), had two tweeters, 4 midrange and a dedicated external subwoofer.  The E450 produced greater bass and more channel separation.  Yet the XT1 seems to be cleaner sounding for music.  I attribute this to the sound field options on the XT1.  The Samsung just seemed to not have any that work as well for music.  On the other hand, the E450 was just plain better for movies, period. There's no replacement for displacement and I would never consider this unit for the living room.  Get a soundbar with a subwoofer...better yet, get a proper receiver, front speakers, subwoofer, center and surrounds.  This unit is best utilized for smaller spaces.The XT1 is a visually pleasing unit with good flexibility (3 HDMI inputs, Bluetooth streaming, HDMI CEC, digital optical input, aux input) and decent sound.  It definitely isn't audiophile grade but one can look at it's size and price point and figure that out.  If you have realistic expectations, you'll be pleased.
summary: A Great Sound Bar Alternate For Small Spaces

reviewText: First things first, this is a portable speaker, and portable speakers on the whole do not have the sound quality of non-portable speakers.That being said, this one has pretty darn good sound!  I also have the Kinivo ZX100 Mini Portable Speaker which I bought on a whim because it was cheap and small; I really just wanted something that sounded better than my phone by itself to play music on while in the kitchen with my kids. The Kinivo is not wireless, but very small so I can toss it in my purse.While this one is larger, it's not so large that it's not portable - it could easily be thrown in a beach bag to go to the beach or pool.  The sound for the Creative Muvo is WAAAAAY better, and the bluetooth is easy to set up.  I am not a speaker expert, but the bass on this one is good too.  I can put this outside and be able to hear the music with much better sound than the Kinivo.For someone looking for a portable easy to use, decent sounding wireless speaker, I really think that his is worth the money.
summary: Worth the extra money if you want better sound

reviewText: This has a very good sound - first this is not a wimpy lil' speaker, there is a good size and fair weight to it, so from the moment you take it out of the box you expect it to deliver on big sound and it does. While the bass won't bend your walls, the overall sound is very well balanced; you can get the speaker to be quite uncomfortably loud in a room before it starts to distort the sound. The speaker feels to be well made and

There's a lot to like about this speaker. It was extremely easy to set up (I use it with my iPhone). It even came with a good charge. The sound quality is very good, and I really like that it can be used for hours without being plugged into anything. It's a nice bonus that you can use it to charge your phone.It is a bit on the bulky side, although very light. I haven't yet found a good place for it in my kitchen, where I most like to use it.Also, the sound cuts in and out somewhat when I'm doing something on my laptop that requires a lot of bandwidth. This is a problem with my internet provider, not the device itself, because I have the same problem with other Bkuetooth speakers. But it's something to keep in mind if you plan to use the speaker while also working online.

reviewerName: Dr A "A reader of biographies, history, and o...
reviewText: The guy was playing his music while working on my roof - a tinny sound from a no-name bluetooth speaker.  I brought out this Muvo, and it just blew gim away - not down from the roof, fortunately.  A much nicer, deeper sound, and just as portable.

Which is fantastic. Rich bass, clean midrange, and just enough high-end to be heard over the crackle of the grill. In fact, I'd say this speaker is just a little too big, compared with some competitors (Jawbox, etc.) But the extra size in the woofers can be clearly heard.
summary: Size matters not...judge me by my sound

reviewText: I've tried many different bluetooth speakers and have found that price is certainly something to consider when evaluating a product. Not all speakers are going to sound like Bose products, but that's not always a fair comparison. Creative Muvo has created a quality product that fits into more people's price range.This particular speaker gets loud and has plenty of bass. It's noisy enough to fill a moderately sized room. This speaker is better suited as a personal speaker as opposed to one that you might try to use for parties, but I suppose it could work with a decent sized gathering. It can get pretty loud.This is a great product for the price. If you're looking for a quality bluetooth speaker and don't want to break the bank, you should be pretty pleased with this one.

- Note - Reviewed using Bluetooth and Samsung Galaxy Note 3 (Android) phone -The Creative Muvo 20 surprised me right off the bat. The first song queued up on my phone was"Go Down Matthew" by Melissa McClelland, and this little guy was on max volume out of the box. I was immediately impressed by the sheer amount of sound that this little guy put out. In an indoor environment, this thing is freaking loud (it was easily maxing out the 82dB reading from the Sound Meter app on my phone from 4ft away).As long as you understand this unit's limitations - there's no real bass, it gets "squirrel-ly" on higher volumes, high notes are piercing - it's a great little portable speaker. It's not exactly small, but not huge - about the size of a normal roll of paper towels.Set up was a snap. The instructions written on the box were simply this - Turn on, press bluetooth button, pair. It was that easy.There is no external charger - the speaker only comes with a simple micro-to-regular USB cable and no usb-to-wall adapter, so you'll need some way to charge after the 10 hrs or so when the speaker dies.
summary: Surprising sound from such a small speaker

reviewText: This is a rather large portable speaker and the design is nice, especially the handle for carrying but still lightweight, too. My husband has adopted it for his own but I noticed he hasn't used it as much as he anticipated and keeps returning to our docking Logitech speaker station. Frankly, I expected the sound to be stronger for the size and price range. There isn't distortion, but the bass is pretty weak overall and the overall sound is a touch fuzzy at lower volumes--turn it up and that disappears with sheer volume. This is not a choice for sound enthusiasts but adequate for the average user and handy. The hubby is keeping it but it isn't going to live on the kitchen counter like it has for the last several weeks. Better for the deck and garage, not the office where you probably need softer volumes at times.

I'm comparing this with a few similar sized products: this is probably the best sounding one. The bass is surprisingly good as well.It comes with just a USB cord (like the similar products).The voice announcements about connectivity and pairing were a welcome addition and took the guesswork out.The sound is really what blew me away.

...between an iPod Nano (7th generation) and whatever is on the USB end.This cable is slightly thicker than the Apple OEM. If you need an extra for the car or your travel bag, it will keep your iPod charged and your tunes flowing.Usually aftermarket cables offer significant savings over similar offerings from Apple. In this case, the savings are modest, but I feel the beefier cord makes it likely to last longer in demanding environments.Select with confidence.Note: this item provided for review purposes.
summary: Passes the basic test: moves data and power...

reviewText: This cable works well and is robust and flexible. Some cables I have bought have not allowed my iPhone or iPad to charge. I get a message saying it is not an apple product but I do not have this problem with this cable.

This is a well built Lightning to USB cable. There are several pros about this cable.1. 6 feet long. For me, this makes it perfect for my office where there are not that many plugs. The plus is far from the place I rest my phone (bookcase) and I don't want to leave it on the floor (someone can step on it! Gasp!). So, this is the perfect solution. So, this has officially become the office cable.2. Well built and well built. This cable is sturdy and thicker. Much more so than the original which starts fraying within a couple of months (this has been my experience). I've gone through a lot of cables. So, I will update this as time passes.Things to note:1. The connector part is a little bigger than the regular Apple cable. So, if you have a small opening in your case, this might be an issue.It has been working great since I started using it. I will keep update this later as to longevity.* Sample provided for review.

This cable works with every Apple device I've thrown at it that has 8-Pin Lightning flawlessly!I use to use an OEM Apple charging cable connected to a USB (3ft) extension cable on my night stand next to my bed so I could use my phone while it charged in bed. Often the USB extension would come disconnected or simply needed to be re-connected to get charging to just initiate. This is no longer an issue thanks to the AYL 6ft cable that is of better quality than the Apple OEM cable.The data transfer speeds this cable are on par with the OEM Apple cable. I've used this cable on PC's and MACs with USB 3.0 and USB 2.0 with no issues so far. Transfer speeds are consistent and fast and charging times are fast and consistent as well. Very good cable. Cable is thicker than an OEM Apple cable which some may hate but its actually far better than the OEM cable because of this reason. OEM cables crimp extremely easily and the OEM cables also fray extremely easily and quickly. Due to the thickness of the AYL cable this isn't an issue at all.Great quality, perfect length, charging times are great and transfer speeds are great. Seriously, no complaints at all. BUY THIS CABLE!----------------FEATURES----------------- Premium Quality Guarantee - The cable material, connectors, design, and package are all directly Approved and Certified by Apple, to meet Apple performance standards under Apple's MFi program. We proudly present AYL MFI Apple certified 8-Pin lightning cable.- Compatibility - Compatible with every Apple Lightning connector device, charge and sync for : iPhone 5/5S/5C, iPad 4, iPad Mini, iPod Touch 5, and iPod Nano 7. It also - supports Mac and Windows PC.- 6 Feet Long is Most Convenient and Popular Length - With the 6 Foot cable, it provides you more freedom to select a more comfortable location for you when your Apple device is charging no matter at home, in the car, or in a store.- Stylish and Slim Lightning connector design that allows it to be used with devices without removing your case- 1 Year Warranty - Please contact us anytime if you have any questions or need assistance. 100% Customer Satisfaction is our Goal!------------------PROS/CONS------------------PROS- Quality- Durability- Fast / Transfer Speeds / Charging Times- Price- Length: 6ft- Warranty: 1 year replacement- Apple MFI CertifiedCONS- None that I can think of-------------------DISCLOSURE-------------------I was supplied a sample for test and evaluation, and I promised that my review is fair and honest with no bias.

reviewText: When the original cable for my husbands Ipod broke i figured id have to go out and get another one at my local store. However I got offered this one and I'm so glad. It works very well and seems quiet sturdy.One of the best parts is that is very affordable compared to the apple brand and from what I can tell actually works better. I had no problem charging from a wall unit, or syncing and charging from my computer. So if you need a new one or just need a back up I would recommend this model.**I received a sample of this product to test and review. All opinions are honest and my own.**
Keyboard didn't illuminate as described, and customer service never responded. Don't waste your time or money.
summary: Don't waste your time or money

reviewText: Works fine. Neat and good design. Best of all, fun to use.

I've purchased and demoed several case/keyboard combo units and I have to say this unit really holds the ipad well, and gives the viewing angle needed for typing and processing.  The connectivity via the Bluetooth is perfect and it charged up effortlessly.  The charge has lasted an entire day so far and I'll test again in a few days to see if the charge is still holding with out having to plug it back in.Key strokes are very clean and precise and the feel of the case is nice but a little slick for my taste.  I'd like something more rubberized to give a better grip, but for average use it spot on.  I love the magnetic keyboard and the ability to remove it have the ipad and keyboard as two separate units.  Excellent design on the overall case layout, look and feel.  I do suggest you purchase a screen protector as the unit does not feature one at this time.As is priced under $30.00 you get a great deal on a quality item.  No need to shop around, it's a done deal with OXA.
summary: High quality case and keyboard combo

reviewText: For under $23, you're not likely to find a better keyboard case - it's not an amazing case, but it's great for the price and you'd be paying close to a $100 for something better.What's in the box: keyboard case, manual, stylus, dusting cloth, and a USB charging cord for the keyboard which would also work to charge later models of the iPad that use a lightning cable.Materials: pleather/faux leather (you're not likely to find real leather for this price). The keyboard is framed in the same faux leather material.Pros:- keyboard is very easy to pair with the iPad via Bluetooth connection. The charge on the keyboard lasts for a while--I've been using it for a couple days now and have not had to recharge- keyboard attaches to the case via magnets so can be easily removed if you want to use the case without it- iPad is securely held in place--I shook the case pretty hard several times and the iPad stayed in place- it's a smart case in that the iPad automatically goes to sleep mode when you shut the case (you have to completely snap it shut)- attached stand makes it easy to prop up the iPad when you're typing, watch videos, etc.Cons:- I'm not a huge fan of the faux leather but as I said, you're not likely to find real leather for this price- When the case is closed, the keyboard protrudes on the side, making the case look misshapen- the frame that hold the iPad in place makes it somewhat difficult to reach the power button

This OXA wireless bluetooth keyboard case is great! It fit my mom's 10" tablet perfectly. It's a bit bulky, but worth it to have a keyboard on hand at all times. It was easy to set up, synced right away.

This is a great way to have a semi universal tablet holder with a built in case and keyboard. The case works great for my Samsung Galaxy Note 10.1 tablet. The four corners have clips on elastic bands so you can capture the corner and stretch it to fit. My tablet stays in place nicely. The keyboard is removable and magnetized to stay in place. The keys are responsive and easy to type (in general). The buckle for securing the tablet closed is good as well. However, there are no cutouts for the camera. There is a pull-out back to prop it at one angle.But this is where I ran into a problem. I easily paired this with my tablet. And then I began typing. I had trouble getting it to quickly take the keystrokes but most importantly, I couldn't get the back space key to work so I could go backward while deleting. I could position my cursor using the arrow keys but then the delete button didn't work. So I am stymied. If those two buttons worked on mine, I'd give this four stars. Perhaps I just had one with a defect. I was sorry I couldn't get it to be more functional as a keyboard.I was provided a unit to test and review.
summary: Some Features are Good, Some are Lacking

reviewText: This golfbuddy is a solid golf companion watch.  Overall it is a really nice smallish size and does not feel too large or clunky on my wrist.  It does not interfere with my swing at all which is important.  I have used it quite a few times, including several times on the same course and it has provided consistent and accurate distances to front, middle, back.  It is great in sunlight so readying it on the course is not an issue.  Voice is good and loud enough although I rarely use it.  Finding a signal does not take that long.  It's always ready and rolling by the time I get to my first tee shot in the fairway.  It's not the cheapest but I think you get what you pay for.  Great size, accurate and seems tough.  I sweat a lot and it has not been an issue.  Overall great product.

The golf buddy is a pretty sweet device that definitely is fun to have with you on the course. After I charged it, I used it on a couple of my favorite courses and it did indeed know right where I was and all the fun info that you'd expect to see on a golf videogame (distance to pin, etc.). The measurements were pretty accurate as well.My only issue with this thing is that it does what so many smartphone apps already do. Add this to the fact that your smartphone has a way better screen, is easier to read, and is in color, and you've got your conundrum. Do you want a dedicated device to help you on the course, or should you just bring your phone with you? For some, myself included, I like to leave my phone in the car when I golf. This keeps me safe from all the distractions (some of whom I love very much!) from interrupting my rare "me" time.All in all, it's a fun little gadget that will definitely be getting some use on my wrist. Just be sure to fire it up when you arrive on the course because it takes at least 5 minutes to get connected to the GPS data.I can wait to try this out on vacation. It'll be sweet to have some help as I tackle a new course. Good times!
summary: Leave your phone in the car!

reviewText: This is a great little PSU. After purchasing several sentey products i would highly recommend them. They have hands down the best customer service i have ever had to deal with. Their products are well made despite the cheap prices.
Only complaint is that some of the connectors didn't fit perfectly. Other than that It does it's job. I've had it for over a month no issues.
The only thing I dislike about this PSU is it's lack of sata power connections. It has plenty of molex connectors which can be converted to sata, but for the price I can't complain. :)

My old 250 watt power supply was dying and I knew it was time for a replacement, so I went searching on Amazon.com and found this 725 watt beast at the great price of $39.99.  My first thought was that it couldn't possibly be of high quality at such an affordable cost; however, the existing reviews were good, so I gave it a try.  I am very glad that I did!  Given its massive wattage and solid construction, this beauty was obviously designed with serious builders in mind.  Installation was a snap.  I checked each connector on my old power supply and made sure that the Sentey was compatible with my ATX system before proceeding.  I was delighted to discover that no adapters and/or extenders were needed.  All of the connector wire bundles are individually wrapped in nylon-mesh sleeves, which makes for a very neat and tidy installation.  After double-checking each connection, I fired up my system and it rebooted without any problems.  This power supply runs whisper quiet, which is a great bonus for such an inexpensive device.  I am totally delighted and I highly recommend this product.
summary: Outstanding power supply at a great price!

reviewText: Great power supply at a pretty good value. There are many connectors and visually appealing.dependability. I really love the modular design which keeps my cables neat. It's quiet and runs smooth. However, the durability is questionable. On two occasion so far over the past 3 months of usage, it fails to start up. I have to unplug all cables and install again before it starts. Hence, I will recommend the following cosair gold insteadhttp://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00EB7UIXM/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&camp;=1789&creative;=390957&creativeASIN;=B00EB7UIXM&linkCode;=as2&tag;=theaventblog-20

Great for my budget PC gaming build.Needed a good power/money ratio.Will probably upgrade in my next build, but it works great for what I need.  Fan isn't loud, and helps circulate air in my case because of the bottom fan, and the top mounting in my case.
My son says this baby rocks, Dad. That was all I wanted to hear.
DO NOT BUY. Dead on arrival. These psu's are cheap and therefore not built well. A 650 doesn't power an Antminer S1. wish I could return them.
Power supply looks good and seems sturdy.  Working great so far would buy again for another budget build.
summary: Looks good, does its job and super cheap.

reviewText: Firstly, this thing has just an amazing price tag for what it does.  Particularly with the APT-X feature which almost none support in its pricerange.  Still, I do have a few minor nitpicks.  The LED is _SUPER_ bright.  Painfully so if you look directly at it.  This can actually be kind of bad at night time if you're driving because you have this really bright light source in your car then...  I had to put not one, but TWO LightDims on mine to make the brightness normal.  (This recent trend of all electronics coming with ultra-bright LEDs just to indicate power or whatever is getting very tiresome.)  Also, someone mentioned that it has quite some heft to it.  This is because they've actually added a weight to the inside.  Whether that's a good thing or not depends on how it's being used, but I can't help but to think that many people could probably just glue something on if they really wanted it to weigh more.  I'm actually velcroing it into place, so I pulled the weight out (and they overdid it on gluing it in -- which probably wasn't necessary at all since it's also clipped into place -- so this was a bit tough.)  It's worth noting here that the extra weight added in is room that could have been used for a bigger battery technically.  (But then a lot of us are just running it directly from a USB plug anyway I would presume?)  It also doesn't have quite as good of a filtering as I would have hoped -- particularly on the power input.  I have to leave it plugged in, but this does add some extra noise to the sound picked up from the car itself.  Also, as has already been mentioned before, you must manually fully turn it on or off.  Perhaps since it's Bluetooth 4.0 it can last a good while while on but not connected, but it has that dinky little battery, so this is still very limited and I think someone has already complained that it runs down frequently enough on them this way.  Oh, and as a really minor nitpick, it takes it several moments to register button presses (but that may be more in how the software on the phone itself handles it, so I'm not even sure it's this device at fault.)Those minor nitpicks aside, it's still amazing for its price and I seriously doubt you'll do better at this pricerange right now.  The sound is actually quite good other than the aforementioned insufficient filtering causing extra noise.  I have a fairly decent quality sound system (read quality, not quantity!) in my car, so while it's not true audiophile level, it still shows artifacts very well and I would have noticed if it sounded like classic Bluetooth (which was the main thing I was leery about as plain Bluetooth audio uses a lot of very lossy compression.)  The range is far better than some were complaining about -- I probably got about 30 feet or so before it started to skip when I tested normally.  I suspect those with lower ranges either have a lot of interference or have phones/tablets with weak Bluetooth signals (I have the Nexus 7 2013 edition and Samsung Galaxy SIII, so both are well build devices that didn't skimp on components.)  It even integrates well.  I never take my phone out of my pocket when I get in the car.  I just turn this on, wait a moment, hit play, and it's playing my music.  The plus/minus buttons can change tracks if I just press, or if I hold them adjust the volume (though of course it's best to use the head unit's own volume control.)I haven't tested hands-free yet.  I suspect that even with its built in microphone it will only work well in a vehicle if you can get it really close due to all the noise (which is less a fault of it and more just the problem of the environment itself.)Overall an excellent bang for the buck and I would recommend it to just about anyone.
summary: Probably unbeatable for the price.  Some nitpicks though...

reviewText: Works great!!! have internal battery, can connect 2 devices simultaneously, Preety good sound quality on 5.1 surround sound speaker.Also works good in car, Mic volume reception is bit low (needs improvement).deserve 5 star!!!
summary: Great product for the price you pay

reviewText: This is a flagship camera designed to do almost anything and for the gadget savy person this is a great toy.  Keep in mind that this camera CAN get you arrested and your camera confiscated in some countries as it will produce GPS coordinates of pictures taken.  Do NOT try this in the middle east!  I own an Olympus E520 and the software looks similar.  Focus is fast and pictures are prompt when the shutter button is pushed, the focus program is quite good as it seeks the face on people pictures.
summary: ... and for the gadget savy person this is a great toy. Keep in mind that this camera CAN ...

reviewText: I have had it less than an hour and I'm very happy with it.Quick Highlights (if you don't like to read big reviews):-I have owned two other Tough cameras.  And love them.-This is a bit heavy/bulky, but still not bad.  Price you pay for wifi.-WiFi feature is great for sharing a picture when not near a computer.  And the shutter/live view feature is great.  Both will come in handy for me and one of the reasons I chose this camera.-Great picture quality!!!-FAST turn on.  Take a picture in less than 1 sec! Amazing.-Some neat, though maybe unnecessary features, like the photo effects. (can always apply them after using your phone app!)-High speed video (slow mo) recording, two speeds.-Don't like the strap.-Has picture orientation. (Take a picture while camera is on it's side, it flips it for you).-Lots of other great features.I have previously owned a Stylus Tough 8000.  I also have a Stylus Tough TG-310 that my mother bought and never used so she gave it to my kids.  We were very happy with the 8000 and it lasted us at least 4 years.  I was washing it off after using it at the beach and then noticed a compartment door was open!  DOH!!!  I opened it up 100% and let it sit overnight and it still worked pretty well, but decided to get a new one just for personal comfort/reliability.The TG-310 isn't as nice as the 8000.  There is plastic on it my daughter ripped.Anyways!  This TG-3 with Wi-Fi!!!  Feels much heavier compared to my other two Tough cameras!  It's bigger and bulkier too.  That's what happens when you put a wi-fi in a camera though, right?  It's convenient to be able to connect my phone to the camera and download a photo!  I wouldn't want to do this often, but for that picture you just want to share, right now! it will be perfect.  On our recent trip (the one where I got our 8000 wet) I used my phone to take a picture of the camera screen to share a photo!  And in the past I have done the same with a video.  So this camera really appealed to me.  And using the phone for a remote shutter will be great!  We have often used timers, but this way I won't have to run into the photo, and I can also use my phone to tell if we're all in the picture with the live view!  It's great!I took a few test pictures and the quality is impressive.  Better than the other two cameras noticeably.  I wish there were more MP options.  You can choose 16, 8, and 3mp (and VGA).  For any of you unaware - anything over 5MP is generally a waste unless you're getting a giant blowup canvas!  5mp takes up less than half the space.  Using a smaller mp setting can make your uploads much faster as well.  I am only just starting to use the smaller mp settings as opposed to the full 12 or 14 my other cameras had.  I would go through each picture and crop and resize anyway.  But - I always keep both copies.  My hard drive is full!  So I will use the 8mp setting on this camera and be very happy with it.I just turned the camera on and hit the shutter and I am AMAZED at how fast I could take a photo!  Instant picture!  Wow!  Great feature!I will finish with saying that I do not like the strap this camera came with.  It is thick and I don't like how it attaches.  I think I will take the cord off the other camera and use it on this one.

First of all, I'm sorry, but the strap design is very ugly. I know that's all personal preference, but think about it.. you have an expensive DSLR - usually plain black -- and you have this flowery contraption on the side...I think they tried to go hip and think it's stylish, I guess they were targeting teens? but it honestly looks silly. It really downgrades the whole presentation of the DSLR and makes you look more amateurish.They seriously would have been better off going with a plain black or more sleek look and materials.I wish they would have come up with an more innovative way to attach this to your DSLR, but even that is unimpressive. A faster way to securely clip this on and to tighten would have been much better than having to loop it around the old fashion way.Very disappointing. Back to the drawing boards...
summary: Sorry, not impressed. Very Ugly design.

reviewText: I really like the camera strap. It provides added stability in those moments in which the camera has to be hand-held—especially with long or heavy lenses. I have asthma and some of my medications cause hand-shaking so I try to use a tripod when possible, as well as taking photos in bursts of three in the hope that one of them will be good. There is nothing more disappointing than taking a picture you thought was good, then seeing it on the monitor as a shaky mess even Photoshop can’t salvage. Unfortunately, I’ve had a lot of those moments.My little video camera came with a strap similar to this one which made camera holding more comfortable and steady. I had long hoped that something similar would be available for DSLR’s. I’m delighted to have found it.Since I started using this camera strap my grip is stronger and the percentage of photos that are steady is really very acceptable. This new way of holding the camera lets me shift the weight distribution in a way that is not only steadier, but also less tiring, and more firm. When I’m shooting, I can put it down and relax my grip but the camera stays secure. The fabric and padding are soft but sturdy; the design is neutral gray on white with black straps that blend with the camera body. It is completely unobtrusive and doesn’t call attention to itself. It attaches to the camera with a screw (where you would normally screw in the tripod head) and a strap that threads into the camera neck strap. You could use it as alternate to the camera strap or in addition to the camera strap as I do. To attach to a tripod, all you have to remove is the bottom screw.I can see how this strap would be a big help to someone who will be photographing a long event, such as a wedding—even if they don’t have a problem with shaky hands. It will certainly cut down on fatigue and allow the person to concentrate on the picture and  to hold the camera more comfortably even when not taking pictures.Now, if one of my photos shows movement, it’s usually because the subject moved. This has really returned a lot of the joy of photography to me and, with both my grandchildren back in town; it couldn’t have come at a better time.I only have two negative comments: that there were no instructions for attaching or adjusting and I had to wing it (which isn’t my strong suit) and I have to check the screw occasionally to make sure it’s still firmly screwed in. It sometimes loosens a bit after a few hours or uses.
summary: Has been a very fortunate find

reviewText: I was excited to get this alert radio to use in our car, since we already have a different model in our home.While the instructions were a bit difficult to understand, and were not always correct, missing steps, I did manage to get it set up and charged. The charge can be applied either through the stand or plugged directly into the radio itself.But that was where it ended. I finally went outside to get clear enough reception for the radio to connect to a NOAA station. Once I figured out which one was best (only one of the two my other station gets came through), I discovered that it only maintained contact in certain directions. If I turned it, even a tiny bit - no connection - no radio - no alert.I need my Emergency Alert Radio to be more reliable than that, especially if it is intended as a travel radio. I will continue to have to rely upon my cell phone when I travel.EDITED - Every alarm in our house just went off ... Except this one. Not recommended as your only source of information in an emergency. Changed from two stars to one star. Not reliable!

I paid $199.99 on TigerDirect. Wasn't gonna pay $279.99 as it currently listed here. It basically makes the Surface Pro last a 12 hour shift watching videos. Just keep the screen brightness down and leave it on power saver. The only thing I do NOT like is the width and weight, as well as no backlit keys. Otherwise, it is a necessity for the surface pro gen one. I would like to thank the review by "Shopper," that review was the most accurate and helpful I have ever used a s a resource in buying electronics. Overall it's a good purchase as long as you pay under $200.00.UPDATE: oh yeah, gives a significant increase in battery duration. Used it for 10.5 hours last night streaming video before I had to charge it. A vast improvement from the 3.5 hours it lasted before.EDIT: Did I mention I had buy a larger sleeve? I increased the screen brightness and it dropped the power drain from 10.5 hrs to 6 hours watching video.
The sound on the speaker is good.  It does not have a seperate volumn control.  The volumn control on my ipad works well with this speaker.

I have been using the Omaker M1 every day when I get ready in the morning, paired with my iPhone 4S.  Pairing was very easy, and reconnecting is even easier.  I just have to turn it on.  Alternatively, we could connect via auxiliary port using the special split micro USB/USB/auxiliary cable.There is no skipping tracks or volume control adjustments on the speaker.  That's all done via the phone.  I can answer calls, pause, play, and last number redial via that one button on the top of the speaker.  It wins for sleek and minimalistic design.Phone calls are poor.  I can hear the caller, but the caller can't hear me.  There's too much echoing and my voice is garbled.Music is clear and defined with good volume, but it lacks warmth.Bluetooth range is good.  I can go down the hallway into the kitchen with wall obstructions in between before losing a signal.Overall, it's a good personal speaker if you like sounds in the cooler range.This product was provided for review by Omaker.

The new Sony 9.1 wireless surround sound headphones finally delivers a home theater wireless solution that an audiophile can write home about.This unit comes with a processor set which you plug all your inputs (blur ray player, xbox, etc) into.  Once set up, you can select the input you want to use or bypass the unit and let it go through your home stereo if you don't want to use the headphones.  Most of the the controls for operation are located on the unit itself which is nice once you learn which buttons do what.  There are some different sound modes like "movie" and "games" which augment the sound accordingly.Overall I'm really impressed with the quality of the simulated 9.1 channel surround sound.  It's quite impressive that the sound source location is as accurate and refined as it, considering it's a wireless set up.  The unit uses a dual band 2.4 and 5.0 GHz transmission and it really works.  This is probably my third or fourth pair of wireless headphones over the last decade and they always have crackling and popping.  These are really clear and set the new standard for wireless sound.The cans themselves are very nice and comfortable.  They don't get tired on your head after 2+ hours nor hurt the outside of your ears.  The build quality is more plastic than I was expecting but they still fill alright and the ear cups are soft and smooth.  My only complaint is that you need to charge the headphones through a usb via a computer which is bit inconvenient.
summary: Fantastic sound quality - these are the wireless headphones you've been looking for

reviewText: You get a lot of bang for your buck for this high-quality kit, which is nicely packaged and made of sturdy materials. The software is easy to install and the calibration is excellent. This is a great investment for both professionals and amateurs alike. Highly recommended.

I am by no means a professional photographer or videographer, but I know my way around photo editing software. My experience with Datacolor SHD100 so far it that the consistency in colors within a set of photos has never been more pure. I do sometimes have to test print to check colors, but I have never been more satisfied with my editing.

I was really surprised when I found this tablet on Amazon for the price. I had been researching products and prices. I have always been an ACER fan and when I found this tablet with 16GB, Quad Core, Jelly Bean operating system for a GREAT BUY! I knew I had to purchase it. I will be back for more.

This tablet has just the right screen size for portability, yet enough to view documents and webpages comfortably. I'm amazed by the battery life, and The processing power is adequate for games, surfing etc. I've not encountered any apps which it had difficulty coping with.The screen resolution is not retina quality, but decently good for me. Looks the same as iPad 2 screens, but it does have a slight yellowish tinge tone. There are no buttons on the front panel, and I like the fact that you can wake the tablet by using touch control by touching the screen with all 5-fingers. No home button which can get spoilt with time.I strongly recommend this tablet, especially since I got it at $100.

I was sold the sound blaster. (I needed an amplifier for my earphones) So I found this item and ordered it. When I connected it to my computer for any updates, I was informed that Creative labs no longer supports this item and I could not update it or get the "Special" items that were offered for it at an earlier time.It seems that this was a "Bait" and switchExtremely disappointed.The only "pro" (from my point of view) is it's small size.

Is there something wrong with me? I am a fan of the Creative MP3 players (the ones made several years ago,...so I gave this a short. Very unimpressed. I got no substantial volume improvement. Returned for refund.
summary: Is there something wrong with ME?

reviewText: Needs work. The biggest negative it has for me is that there is no way to set the amount of time the keys are lit up. They stay lit for 3-4 seconds and then go out until you press a key or touch the mouse pad. Since I use my keyboard in almost total darkness when watching TV or working on my computer, this is a monumental flaw. There is also no lighting on the mouse pad keys so you have to feel around for those keys or the pad itself.The keyboard itself is exceptionally heavy for such a small unit yet the keys feel a bit flimsy. Only time will tell if that feeling will go away or not.There are no folding rear legs like on some keyboards so that you can lay it on a table or desk yet maintain a comfortable finger angle on the keys. I realize that it is meant for use when watching TV so will be used mostly in your lap but it still would be nice to have some folding rear legs in case you want to use it on a desk or table.All in all,the wireless feature is very good (I have been using the LOGITECH consolidated wireless feature for a long time without any problems so this is just another unit for it to control) but work needs to be done on adding options for control of illumination duration and adding illumination to at least the left/right mouse pad keys. Right now I am typing using this keyboard and the mouse pad area looks like a big black void with only the three volume keys at the top glowing.Some may say that the short illumination duration is meant to minimize the number of times and length of time you have to recharge but I feel that it should be my choice if I want the keys to glow longer and pay for that with more frequent charging.I guess it is a matter of taste. The idea of finger proximity that is used in other LOGITECH keyboards would be another option to make the illumination more user friendly. I would take that if setting glow length of time is not a viable option.
summary: LOGITECH has done better than this unit

reviewText: Backlit keys and battery powered, that's the great item here.  This is a good solid form factor, with a nice (although slightly small by Apple standards) touchpad.  Keys feel smooth and spaced out well (although the top row seems a bit compact).Looks quite stylish with it's black and silver subdued motif.  Easy access volume controls, on/off switch.  It's also rechargeable so you just plug it in (and I might suggest a quite long micro usb cable or a usb battery pack for those times you forget to charge it and want to use it...)

This is a very well made keyboard, with good functionality.  HOWEVER...  I think Logitech is needlessly creating themselves some ill-will by marketing this for "internet-connected TVs". The functionality for TVs is limited and is hit and miss.  Better to market this keyboard for PCs or laptops connected to TVs via HDMI cables.For some TVs with the capability (my Panasonic plasma works fine), you can connect the keyboard and get -limited- usefulness from the keyboard on some of the internet related screens. The touch pad did not work...I expected this as there is no mouse cursor on my screen.  Overall... it wasn't really useful for the TV apps.  Besides, the TV apps are so dated that I use a Roku 3 instead... far, far, far better interface for Netflix, YouTube, etc.Where this keyboard really shines is for a PC or laptop connected to your TV via HDMI.  At this point, you may be displaying your computer screen on your TV and THEN this keyboard is very useful.  The touch pad will work, the need for typing will be a lot more pressing.  In this capacity, this keyboard is really quite nice.  Solid feel to the keys, responsive touch pad. I liked the keys lighting up (even through you have to hit one key before they light).There are several serious caveats with this keyboard...- Timing - Releasing this keyboard now - Years ago, this keyboard would have been in high demand for home theater PCs... currently the trend is towards streaming devices like Roku/Apple TV/Chrome Cast/Amazon Fire TV....  which don't function with this keyboard.- Price.  While a great and well functioning keyboard, you can get 90% of the functionality with theLogitech k400for 25 bucks.  Its not as nice and the keys don't light up.  But... well, are lit keys worth 75 bucks?
summary: Keyboard good - Confused by Logitech marketing

reviewText: Built a new pc with a $500 budget.This was the best rated price/value cpu, so I got it. Fastest computer I've had by far, everything runs very fast.

Wow, this is a great dashcam for the money.  No GPS, but for fifty-nine bucks this is a great value.  I would have given this dashcam five stars but for the poor documentation.  The manual is written in "chinglish" and isn't very useful.  Once you figure it all out, it is simple to operate.  One thing you should know.  If you take the dashcam out of the box and connect it to your computer, you get a blue screen which presents two options, "PC Camera" and "Mass Storage."  If you select PC Camera, you get just that, a webcam for your PC.  If you select Mass Storage, you can access the files on the micro sd card.  The  problem is, you cannot cycle through the menu options until either the camera is charged and not connected to your computer, or connected to your vehicle's power outlet.  Would have been nice to know this before trying to figure it all out.Also be aware that pushing the "mode" button switches between video, still camera, and playback, but you need to push the "M" button on top of the camera to select your settings for date, motion detection, loop length, resolution, etc.....  Gems like this that one would normally expect to find in a user's manual.As to the suction cup mount, I have had no problem.  Be sure the rubber cone is clean and be sure your windshield is clean.  Just push the cup against the glass and then push the small plastic "switch" forward.  It's been on my windshield for three days now no problem.Bottom line - Excellent value as the picture quality is very good, night or day.  Just be patient learning how to navigate through the menus.

This antenna proves to be serviceable and easy to use, if not a bit on the flimsy side.  Setup was as simple as connecting the coax cable and putting the antenna in the window.  I'm picking most, if not all, of the local OTA channels, which is the only purpose for this thing, so it's doing its job.  I had a little trouble at first getting the suction cup to stick to the glass.  After a few reattachments, though, it hasn't come loose in a while.  It does sag a bit, though.  It is very thin and light, but when sitting in the warm, sunny window, this translates in to sagging and an apparent struggle to support itself.  I knocked off a star for this, but it seems to function the same, so only one star comes off.  Perfectly good antenna, just not the best.

Your antenna works great in a two story building the reception was great but does not work in a apartment community type on GROUND FLOOR.  If you fix that problem I think it would get a better rating.  I gave it a 3 because it worked great on a two story building which is where I had to put it lucky or I would have returned it for a full refund.  I found the suction pad to work great for me it holds well.

Absolutely awful. This only picked up five channels and they weren't even any of the major networks (NBC, ABC, and CBS). Granted, I live in a fairly large city with several local channels, I even took the television and this antenna outside, and still, no decent reception. I do not recommend this and will be returning ASAP!

The range on this thing is exaggerated.  I had this in a room 15 ft above ground level.  I live in a relatively flat area.  The antennas for channels I wanted are within 15 miles.  However, I couldn't receive 2-3 of the channels without re positioning (and subsequently losing the consistent quality of the others).The claim that the antenna "Catches Any Signal Within a 35 Mile Radius" is false in my case.I've returned it.

This was a complete waste of time for me, to try to set up. I could not get this to do anything. I even tried customer support and sent emails. I could not get access to any files at all. It seems like after awhile I just gave up and wait to see if someone will come back to me.
So far I've had no issues recording every format on the Panasonic GH4. I would definitely give this card a shot.
My wife uses this Lightning cable for her iPhone 5C and she says it works great. This is a lot less expensive than the Apple-branded one and we hope it lasts for a long time.
This is exactly as described at a good price. My husband keeps braking his and this was a great replacement.
Does the job for my iphone 5.
Works well and significantly cheaper than apple brand
summary: Half the price twice the cables

reviewText: Sweet!!!!  Got rid of my wife's Macbook Air and replaced it with this Chromebook.  The Chrome operating system works flawlessly and I love the cloud storage concept... at least it works for us.  My kids won't make the change since they like to play games, but I will soon be buying another one for me to upgrade from my tablet.  I decided to start minimalizing our heavy computer needs and for the past 2 years I have only used a tablet, except for a few instances that it wouldn't work.  I bought one of the original chromebox's and it still works flawlessly with my bedroom TV so I have no doubt the Chromebook will still be viable for years... WITHOUT UPDATES, UPGRADES, VIRUSES, etc.  Lastly, the screen is crystal clear, the finish is superb and it is much lighter the our ex-Macbook Air and nearly as light as my 10" Samsung tablet.

I wasn't sure about Chrome OS. I mean, when it's described you get a sort of "meh" reaction. "So it's all in the browser? It requires being online? It can't run Windows, Android, Mac, or Linux programs?" is what pops to mind. I was in this camp, too. I didn't think a laptop that relies on cloud-based services for 80% of what it does could be useful. Boy, was I wrong!First, though, I'll say a bit about the hardware: Sexy. I know the faux leather top is just a sort of foamy plastic, but it looks and feels nice. The laptop is slim, sleek, quiet, cool, and fast. It boots up faster than anything I've ever owned, save for Android or iOS tablets. The dual USB ports, micro SD card slot (yes, micro, because so few new electronics are bothering with full-sized SD cards anymore), and HDMI port are all nice additions to round out this sleek laptop experience.The keyboard is especially nice. I'm a writer, and to me the quality of a keyboard is important in a laptop design. Equally as important is the quality and sensitivity of the trackpad! I've had laptops with good keyboard that were completely spoiled by the fact that the trackpad was overly-sensitive, causing me to accidentally move the cursor around the screen while typing. None of that happens here. I'm not being hyperbolic when I say this is perhaps one of the best-designed trackpads I've used in decades of computing. I like it even better than the trackpads on my old MacBooks, and those were high quality. It's WAY better than the trackpads on more recently-owned systems like the ASUS T100, the Microsoft Surface Type Cover 2, and my last Lenovo laptop. This was, frankly surprising. I did not expect to like the trackpad this much-- Especially since I've never been very fond of trackpads in general.The screen is sufficient for a system designed for getting some work done. The resolution could be higher, but having an HDMI port built in mitigates that problem if I'm looking to push more pixels.Speedwise, I'm quite happy. It doesn't lag with multiple tabs open and handles Chrome OS games quite well. Web-based games also seem to be snappy. I doubt most people will feel they're being cheated on speed or graphics performance, considering this is a Chromebook.Which brings me to my new-found acceptance-- indeed, admiration-- of the Chrome OS. I honestly didn't think I'd like Chrome OS this much, but I've been swayed over from having a "blech!" reaction to having a "I think I'll do that on my Chromebook" reaction. What I mean by that is that the Chromebook is so quick to load, such a pleasure to interact with, that when I need to do some basic work, get online for any reason, or even check out some media, the Chromebook is quickly becoming my go-to device. it's on -instantly- when I open that lid. Chrome remembers all my settings, and Google Drive transfers all my data from my desktop whenever I need it. It functions just like Chrome on my desktop PC, meaning I can go to my work website and not have to worry about missing plugins or not supporting the web protocols (unlike most Android tablets). It's just a pleasurable, easy experience.Here are some questions I had about Chromebook, along with the answers I learned:► "Can I run MS Office on it?"No, but it comes with Google Docs built in, and Google Docs lets you view, edit, and create MS Office documents. It's not as comprehensive as a fully-featured MS Office suite, but most people don't even use 50% of Office's features, and as I've learned, pretty much everything the average user would need is available in Google Docs.► "Can I watch videos in Chrome OS?"There's a built-in video player, and you can get others in the Chrome Web Store. You can also view movies and TV shows from every major streaming service like Netflix, Hulu, Vudu, Crackle, CinemaNow, and of course YouTube, DailyMotion, and other sites.► "Can I view and edit photos?"Yes! Viewing, of course, is built into the system. Editing can be done with a variety of Chrome apps and extensions, like PicMonkey and Pixlr Editor. Pixlr Editor is very similar to Photoshop.► "Couldn't I just get a regular Windows/Mac laptop and use the Chrome browser to get the same stuff?"Yes, you can access most of the apps and sites from Chrome on any system, but the appeal is the speed with which Chrome OS runs, the fact that you don't have all the other OS stuff running in the background, looking for updates, waiting for things to load, etc. It's the same experience, but on a Chromebook it's MUCH faster and easier.► "If I can't run Windows programs or Android apps, then how do I download an antivirus?"You don't need to!!! That's another awesome thing about Chrome OS-- It isn't vulnerable to viruses, trojans, worms, and other malware by design. Right out of the box, you're up and running without needing to connect to an antivirus service, pay for a subscription, or deal with background scans or downloads slowing down the system. Chrome OS is secure. You never have to worry about all that stuff. Just get online and get work done.► "Can I play games?"Yes. There are plenty of web-based games, and the Chrome Web Store has several games to choose from. Now, you might not have some popular games like Minecraft, but there are still some quality games to play and waste some time. If you're looking for hardcore gaming, you and I both know you're never going to look at a Chromebook as a serious contender, but then, you're also not going to find a super-thin, super-light, super-fast gaming laptop for anywhere near this price.► "Does it always have to be online?"No. There are many offline apps available. Head over to the Chrome Web Store and check out the "Offline Apps" collection.► "What about basic functions?"Calculators, note-taking, calendars, alarm clocks, translators, banking apps, and all manner of basic applications are available, and they are fast!Finally, I asked myself how much of my time at my computer is spent online. I was surprised at the answer: "practically all of it". I honestly don't run all that many programs offline these days. Most of my time is spent on the Web, with lots of time spent in email, shopping sites, work websites, entertainment sites, etc..  If you really examine what it is you do with your computer or tablet, you might find the same thing. I'm not even a big fan of social media like Facebook or Twitter, but I know lots of you folks are, and again the Chromebook is going to handle those tasks admirably well.So who is this thing for? Anyone who needs a fast, light, thin laptop to get online, do some work, watch some videos, play a few games, edit some documents or spreadsheets (Google Docs), edit some photos (Pixlr), edit some videos (WeVideo is pretty cool), do some basic CAD (AutoCAD360), check Facebook, send Tweets, check & send gmail, check & send Outlook mail, video chat, listen to music (Google Music, Prime Music), transfer files between systems (Google Drive, Amazon Cloud Drive, Dropbox, Microsoft OneDrive), and even remotely connect to your desktop PC (Chrome Remote Desktop) and work on it from afar.Who wouldn't benefit from a Chromebook? I guess if you need a laptop that will play the hottest, newest games in 3D, a Chromebook isn't for you. If you need to do super-intense professional video editing on your laptop you'd best go for something Windows, Linux, or OS X based. If you need to run a very specific piece of software on your laptop and can't find the Chrome OS equivalent in the Web Store on on any website, you'll have to go with the system that software was made for.For everyone else, the Chromebook is the nearly-perfect laptop. It combines insane boot/wake up speed, essential functions, and excellent hardware design into a laptop that handles most functions modern Internet dwellers need.I would say the Chromebook is especially great for people who aren't all that tech-savvy. They'll never need to sit through a Windows update, a virus scan, or get a BSOD. They'll never have to figure out some ultra-technical way to make the computer do something, because Google really does make almost everything insanely easy and fast. There's just not much to screw up on a Chromebook!However, I do have ONE minor gripe about the Chrome OS, which is why I'm only giving four stars instead of five in this review. Currently, Chrome OS does not provide an easy way to turn a web page into a desktop or taskbar icon. You can bookmark any page, just like in Chrome, but you cannot drag a URL to the desktop or taskbar and make it into a clickable launch icon without going though some convoluted steps. It CAN be done, but not easily. From what I have read, Google is aware that people want this feature and they're working out how to do it with just a couple clicks. For now, however, you're stuck opening the Chrome browser and clicking the link in your Bookmarks, or finding an official Chrome app/launcher/link that provides one-click access.This is a minor caveat (and as I said, one that Google is working on) and so it's only costing a star from this review. Have no fear, however, about the hardware involved here. The Chromebook 2 is a fine example of sleek, sexy laptopping (I know. "Laptopping" isn't actually a word. I still like it.) and I'm certain that anyone who gives it a chance will love what they can do with the Chromebook 2.► Final Verdict: FOUR STARS.► Recommendation: Unless you're an elitist, professional video editor, hardcore gamer looking for a portable rig, or a Google-hater, you probably want to get one of these to complement your other Windows/Mac/Linux PC, or to stand alone as a simplified way to get online, get work done, and have a little fun. Give it time. You may become a fan.
summary: Turned me from a Chromebook skeptic to a fan

reviewText: The tiniest piece of dust will produce a bubble. Follow the directions carefully. Manufacturer suggests installing in a humid environment so there is less dust in the air. I had trouble at first and manufacturer sent a replacement as per their guarantee. On my second attempt, I worked in the kitchen with some pots of water boiling on the stove. Installed perfectly in 10 seconds.
summary: Works well, be careful installing it.

reviewText: I realize that all external batteries should really only be for an emergency charge but this one ran out of juice really quickly.  It didn't fully charge my phone, even though the lights said it was fully charged itself.  It did charge well enough for a couple of calls, which in an emergency situation would be awesome.  Great to have on hand for that reason, but not for expecting a full charge.

The myCharge Razor Plus is about the same size as a 2.5 inch (laptop) hard drive although a lot slimmer. The case is well made and should last quite a while.Simple to use.  Plug the micro USB cable into the socket and the USB end into a computer or similar and it will charge.  4 lights on the front show you how much charge you have.  When you want to use it, simply reverse the cable, plus the USB end into the myCharge and the micro USB end into your phone and off you go.I've also tried this with my iPad (iPad cable not supplied) and it works also.I have had need to use rechargeable batteries before in an emergency situation and they do come in extremely handy for those type of situations but also use them for when my phone gets low in normal everyday situations (out at the pub for instance).This rates at 3000mAh charge which is enough to fully charge my phone (HTC One) from almost dead and there was still some juice left in the battery pack afterwards (the One's battery is rated at 2300mAh).Overall this is a great little product, easily carried around in a pocket or put in your backpack/briefcase for work but with the glut of battery packs on the market at the moment, the only downside I see to this is that it is slightly expensive in my opinion.
summary: Great little on the go charger but overpriced

reviewText: I have been carrying portable battery packs for a while now and I can say that I love the form factor and I am quite impressed by how much energy is in that small case.That being said, it is pricy.  The current one I have is not lithium but does give me 10,000 mAh which charges my phone at least the times.  Yes it's thicker and heavier but it also gives me the option of charging at 2amps instead of just 1 amp.It's a toss up but I lean towards more capacity with faster charging times for the same price at the expense of weight and thickness
summary: nice form factor and looks...but pricy

reviewText: 1.  For comparative purposes, I've used / own several other battery packs (New Trent) which I use to charge up my tablets / phone when on the road.2.  This product seems kind of like a lightweight, both in size (which is a very good thing) as well as construction... and perhaps with the no brainer method of using it.  With that being said, don't let the power stats or the size or lack of techy type buttons dissuade you;  this is an excellent product.  First of all, it's a no brainer to use.  You use one port to power up the unit and you use the other port to power your device.  There's no on or off button;  very simple.  Furthermore, the very small size is a plus, because although my New Trent may charge my iPhone many many more times, at the end of the day, who really cares?  If I'm on a plane and I'm watching movies or something, all I care about is charging up my device once or perhaps two times and this will do it, without dragging me down in re: weight / form factor.  Each person will have their particular needs / uses, but with the above being said, I'll bring my New Trent on really extended trips, where several devices may need to be charged and I always carry the "MyCharge" battery when I go hiking (in such cases, I often have to refer to my phone apps for photographic purposes), it's very light, very small, and it'll be able to charge up my phone several times if needed.  Excellent product.

I've been using my myCharge for over a month now and have used it to charge everything from my phone, to my kindle, to my bluetooth speaker.  The battery is super thin and easy to slid in just about any bag.  It charges quickly and efficiency, and has saved my phone on a couple occasions where I thought I was going to run out of power.  I'll be taking this thing with me from now on when I travel, and can't remember how I made it without it.

I absolutely love this iPad mini case - it is genius!  I go through a lot of cases but this one was endured because of the brilliant built-in hooks to put on your headrest.  I keep this in my purse and in case of emergency, I can happily appease the kids.  The hooks can also be used as a stand.  The cover is protective, but not removable.  It is ever so slightly awkward when using as a stand.  It can be put behind the case when using in the car.  It is a little bit heavier than your normal case but I have not minded due to the fact it performs 3 functions:  car case, stand case and protective cover on the front case.  The iPad mini can be easily removed from the case and there is full access to all of the buttons and controls while in the case.
ordered two of these since the original Apple USB charger kept failing. So far they both appear to work very well.

.This cable is a little thicker and less rubbery than Apple's cable. Looks and feels like quality. Works fine.Cable Diameter: .132" (Apple's cable is .103")Lightning Connector Dimensions: .229" x .402" (Apple's is .183" x .304") -- I don't think there would ever be a clearance issue with this connector.The cable material is smooth, satin finish, more plastic-like than Apple's rubber-feel cable. Probably easier to keep clean. Pliable enough.I like that there is no logo on the Lightning end. There is a prominent logo on the USB end (helps you orient the cable correctly).Nice-enough price when selling for $11.It looks like iXCC has had some quality problems with their older, less expensive, non-MFi Defender series cables (Still available @ 2/$10). I hope this Apple Certified MX Defender series will be fine.- - - Alternatives - - --iXCC MFi Element series 2-pack(thinner and less expensive)-iFlash MFi-LEPOWER MFi 4-Foot- Non-certified (not MFi) cables (often $5 to $6) Are you feeling lucky?- - - Disclosure - - -The manufacturer gave me this item for review. I believe my review is impartial.~~~ Comments & questions welcome ~~~
Well made and works great with my IPod and I phone 5. Excellent vendor.
summary: Can't beat the price and quality.

reviewText: Works great and at a lesser price than from Apple.

I've ordered several of these lightning to USB connectors and 3 of them have failed (started shorting out) because of poor quality and sloppy connections.  This one has tight connections and seems to be heavy enough wire that it doesn't seem likely it will short out.  It was worth a couple of bucks more to get one that lasts longer.Ken

If you are looking for a Lightning charge cable, and you want to ensure it is Apple certified, the Omaker cable will certainly fit your needs.It's slightly less expensive than Apple equivalent and it works just the same way as the cable that was provided with your device. Plug the larger end into the charger. Plug the smaller end into the phone. It charges.The cable also works just like the Apple cable in that you can plug it into the computer and have the phone or device sync.Works well, works as expected and is slightly less than the Apple equivalent.Highly recommended.I received a free sample for review purposes from the manufacturer.

While this was being installed, part of the screen protector came loose. Once it was put on my iPad mini,it was just fine.So of course I'm NOT going to drop my iPad mini just to see how this works, but occasionally things happen and this has been dropped a couple times. My iPad was just fine. The case kept it protected very well. It's also a good looking case if you like the rugged effect of armor. It looks very serious. It doesn't block the camera or anything you need access to, and the screen is still responsive. I do recommend fiber tip styluses with this protector if you use a stylus.Sample received for review purposes, no other compensation was received and this is my honest experience and opinion of the product.
summary: One minor problem, but mostly just right

reviewText: Fast, cool, efficient. I like it.
Great cpu, great price!

I bought this to make charging easier and not such a mess.  The power wire is long enough to make positioning the charger where you want it.  I travel a lot in an RV and it is so much neater and easier to use than before when I had to carry my power strip with five charging blocks around with me.  I have not noticesdany issues with the unit.  I would highly recommend it.
summary: cleared up a rat's nest of wires

reviewText: This multi-port USB wall charger is phenomenal.  It is a must have for anyone who travels.  I charge my 2 mobile phones, tablet, fitbit, etc. all at once.  it is terrific and works as described.
I bought a bunch of these.  When you have 4 iPhones and 5 iPads in the same house someone is always looking for a charging port.  With this up to 5 devices can be charged at once.  Great idea.

Works great so far for moderate/light on-the-go use.  I use this in conjunction with the ALZO Transformer DSLR Rig by attaching the shoe adaptor that comes with this cage to the bottom of the ALZO Rig.  Works good but a little tight to get off and on  —fits without stressing anything, just have to do a little maneuvering to clip the DSLR (w/ ALZO Rig attached) in and out.  Can't say this provides any specific benefit other than having both options in one kit ...I already had the ALZO, tried it, it worked.Can't comment on durability.  Came within a week.  FILMCITY should loose the red sticker on the shoulder pad as it was peeling off out of the box.  I would help it all the way off and de-goo it but the red part starts to separate indicating it might be better left alone for now.
summary: I use this in conjunction with the ALZO Transformer DSLR Rig

reviewText: ** I updated my rating from 3 stars to 5 based on the stellar customer service of this company. They contacted me about my review and THANKED ME FOR MY FEEDBACK and made note of my concerns about the headsets design and mediocre fit. They didn't debate my opinions, just gave me a thank you for my feedback. I found this not only extremely rare but rather refreshing and it gave me a lot of confidence in the company. I would highly recommend this product mainly based on the way this company values high quality customer service.Also, so far my headset continues to function as advertised, and the pairing is not a problem if you take the time to read their instructions. (July 22, 2014)The Senbowe headset is light and easy on the ears. Sound quality is decent (I use headsets mostly for listening to sports and religious podcast rather than music so sound quality is not a top priority for me). The Senbowe headset is a a good value for the price and thus I would recommend to those looking for a light wireless headset to wear during workouts (not running though).
