The only drawback for me is the ear buds do not fit snug in my ears. To alleviate this problem I purchased a set of ear bud covers (from a dollar store) and this dramatically improved the fit without sacrificing sound quality.There are better quality wireless headsets on the market but none at the price of the Senbowe. So if you are looking a for good value wireless headset, this product will meet your needs.
summary: ** Updated Rating ** Strong Value Proposition Product

reviewText: I've been using these earphones on my daily walks around the neighborhood with my dog.  I love the Bluetooth aspect, because unlike corded earphones, I don't get cord thumb (the sound of the cord rubbing against clothing).Pairing is easy and reconnecting is automatic with my HTC One.  Range is okay.  I can't get as far as usual with my other Bluetooth devices, but I can go to the room adjacent.The earphones stay on and they're comfortable.  Sound is very good.  Music listening is enjoyable.  It has enough depth and clarity to satisfy most listeners.Phone calls are amazingly clear.  There's no echo, no static, no distortion, no cutting off of the first half of a sentence - for both the caller and receiver.  If the person wearing the earphones is moving or is in a noisy situation, those sounds are magnified.  Sitting still in a quiet room, it's superb.These are very good earphones.  My only dislike is the need for a proprietary charging cord.  Other than that, everything is good.  Even the controls are easy to use and easy to reach.  Bluetooth has come a long way.  I am amazed at the quality we can get for the price.This product was provided for review by Focus on Bluetooth.

I'm happy with the sound.  I did have to use the more specific directions to pair the unit with my IPhone and IPAD.  Make sure you do read the revised instructions available on line rather than the instructions included.  Once done right, earbuds paired easily and work fine.  I'll have to find a case but I probably have many small boxes I can use to protect them and charger.  Good sound too.
summary: Good for price, just make sure you use the correct pairing instructions

reviewText: Surprisingly good.  These are very light, and don't feel like the greatest quality, but they work great and are very comfortable.  The sound is very good, but not great.  The over the ear clips are cheap, and fall off easily, but the plugs hold well when in the ear.  The battery didn't seem to make it 5 hours, but they are very small and light.I LOVE that they don't have the power pack and controls dangling on the cord like some others.Over all, I like them a lot, and would recommend them.
summary: Surprisingly good, very light weight head phones.

reviewText: I received this at no cost in exchange for writing a review. Here are my comments.[Note: Based on a lot more extensive use after my initial review, I have downgraded these from 4 stars to 2 stars. See my Update below].1. The included directions are among the worst I've seen, so let me point out a few things.A. The power button to turn this on is located on top of the right earbud (the directions have no illustrations).B. Hold the power button down until it alternately flashes blue and red, which is the pairing mode. On my iPhone 4S the headset appeared as S301 and paired without having to enter any codes.C. This comes installed with medium size earbuds, which worked fine for me; also included are large and small earbuds.D. There are two plastic loops. Attach one to each earbud to keep this in place on your ears.E. The cord connecting the earbuds is too short to wear in front because it was right up against my chin. So I put it behind my neck and this headset fit perfectly.2. The earbuds passed my "chewing gum test"--vigorously chewing gum will dislodge many earbuds, but not these. That makes them ideally suited for running and gym workouts.3. This comes with a clunky AC 2.0 mm charger (2.0 is becoming more common). I have 2.0 USB cables that are more convenient to use.4. The sound is the same quality as a pair of Apple earbuds, which suit many people just fine. Of course there is no lush sound or deep bass, but it's not realistic to expect that at this price point. I turned up the volume on the headset to maximum since I prefer to make volume changes directly from my iPhone.5. The ear hooks can easily come off during handling and are a bit flimsy.Bottom line: For exercise and gym workouts these are very handy. These also work well to drown out loud voices in my office without wearing a conspicuous headset.At this price point I think this headset is a good value. I have not seen a lighter or more compact bluetooth headset. However if bluetooth and light weight are not critical to you, there are certainly better sounding--and more expensive--headsets.Update May 26, 2014: These are more flimsy than I thought. Not only do the ear hooks come off easily, but so do the ear buds. But there are two serious issues I have discovered:1. Even when fully charged, these last no more than 90 minutes. I have gym workouts that often last longer, not to mention my outside runs. Forget this for a long car ride or plane trip.2. The earbuds do not sit snugly in my ears, no matter what size I choose. That causes a deterioration of the sound, which is much better if I hold the earbuds in place. Of course that's not practical and not something I'm going to do.I'm going to stick with myAvantree Jogger Pro Sweat Proof Wireless Bluetooth 4.0 Stereo Headphones / Headsets with microphone for running / sports - Black/Grey. They cost more and are larger, but are in another league in terms of performance and durability.Even at this price point, I think you're better off buying something else.
summary: Updated Rating 5/26  4 stars to 2 stars--Not recommended

reviewText: The radio option opposed to infrared is SOO much better. I have several tv's wired to the same box in my recreational room, now I can change the channel from any room. Works with multiple remotes too. GREAT feature and they're so affordable.
This was exactly as described. Works perfectly as a replacement for the RC65R.  I was important to have the right unit as I have mine DVR set to receive radio frequency commands and not infrared.

I don't like that slide thing they put on these remotes but it does what they say it can do and it's not too hard to set up.  Direc TV will help you set it up if you need them.  They are usually as durable as any remote.

It's the SAME remote; don't waste your money at the retail shop. Buy a spare today; keep it when you can find it, because the old ones eventually go. I did and was relieved to be able to tell my family that I snagged a spare online for around $6 (at the time).
summary: Instead of paying Directv $20 or Wal Mart $25 for this remote, but it here for less than $10.

reviewText: I was having some real lag issues with my Direct tv.  like 10 seconds after you pressed a button before anything would happen.  So fast forward and reverse were a pain to use.  This remote is exactly what I replaced. It did help a lot with those issues.  I looked online and in the manual first but ended up calling direct tv for help programing the remote to the receiver.

Perfect replacement to my old R/F Remote i went with this cause of price and its both IR and RF. RF is what i set it to cause my receiver is in another room hidden and this remote makes it easier. programed it to my old receiver and tv in minutes

I tried to program this remote for my sound bar.  It took me 2 days.  I could not find the code, the on screen menu could not get the soundbar setup.  I ended up moving everything to a different receiver and having that receiver program the remote.  Then I had to move everything back to the original room.It works - but don't expect it to easily integrate into your sound system - this is no harmony.
summary: Product worked - programming was a bit of a pain

reviewText: More expensive than the cheapie cords, but more substantial as well. Allows use of the iPad while lounging around. Very satisfied.
This cord will charge your iPad, but there is no retention mechanism to hold it on like there is on the original Apple cord.
summary: Not like the original, but it will work

reviewText: The iXCC 10ft Apple 30-pin cable is a very high quality and durable cable.Pros:-10ft in length-Very high quality-Apple Certified and works with iOS 7 with no errors-Charges my iPad 1, 2 and 3-Works with syncing with iTunes-Thick cable makes it durable-Great price for an MFi cableNo cons.I highly recommend this 30-pin cable.I was supplied a sample for test and evaluation, for free to keep, and I promised that my review is fair and honest.
summary: Great 30 pin cable that has a very thick and durable cable!

reviewText: So I get this Q-SEE 32 Channel 3TB High Resolution 700TVL camera system from Vine.  I will try to review this product from a chronologic order perspective.Day 1 – System arrives.  It comes via UPS in a 36x36x36 box weighing about 75lbs.  It’s got “HEAVY” and “TEAM LIFT” orange stickers all over it.  I had to drag it into my house, then proceed to open it.  There appears to be another 17 smaller white boxes in this big box.  1 box for the main DVR / Control unit, probably another 8 boxes for cameras (4 in each box), and another 8 boxes for all the wires and power supply. You get the idea.Day 7 – Okay, so I’ve sketched out where to install my cameras.  8 inside the house (just about EVERY room except the restrooms) and 8 on the outside of the house.  That’s TWO cameras on each side of my house for full coverage.  Hmmm… Not sure what to do with the other SIXTEEN cameras.Day  14 – THIS IS THE HARDEST PART OF THE WHOLE SET UP!!!!  Running all the wires in my attic to every part of the house.  I get about 3 wires done. It’s quite hot in the attic.  Maybe I should start earlier in the morning tomorrow.Day 15 – Hire a handy man to run wires in the attic.  There are TWO wires for each cam.  The power wire and the signal wire.  Handy man pulled the remaining wires.  Poor guy.  Did I mention it’s really hot in the attic?  Dusty, too.Day 16 – Well, since the handy man ran all the wires, I decided to have him install all the cameras, too.  Installing cameras is no piece of cake.  You have to lug a ladder around, drill holes, screw in the mounts, then screw in the camera, then connect the cable.  Climb up and down the latter to grab screws, drills, mounts, camera, and multiply that by 16 times.  Woo-wee I’m getting tired just watching the guy.  Think I’ve done enough for today, time to take a break and have an ice cream cone.Day 21 – Today, I take the 16 signal wires, power supply, and Ethernet cable, plug them all in, and power up the unit.  Just to make things easier, I had to pull my HDMI monitor from my home workstation and plug it into this unit during initial set up.  Cameras are working, I can see them on my monitor.  Time for a beer.Day 22 – Chose one of the options for network set up (DHCP, Static IP, Direct to Modem, or DDNS).  I choose DHCP.  Follow the quick start guide closely, write down all the numbers you see, configure your router for port forwarding, and voila, you are now up and running and the world can see what the inside of your house looks like.By the way, I am an IT professional that is quite familiar with networking protocols and gadgets.  If you are not a “technical person”, I have one word for you – forgetaboutit!Day 23 – Once all the networking stuff is out of the way, I can monitor my house inside and out from the internet.  Picture quality is good, very clear.  However, the picture does slow down if you are looking at multiple cameras at the same time, but that might depend on broadband speed.  Everything can be configured using your PC browser.  I have not fully mastered it yet, but I am current in the midst of the “recording” configuration.  The system is has a motion detection feature, where it only records when it senses motion.  This is so you are not constantly recording nothing and taking up hard drive space.  I can use my PC or android phone to monitor my house.Epilogue:After a few weeks with the system, I am quite pleased.  I travel quite a bit for work, so I get to watch home from my phone or hotel room.  It’s quite comforting to know when I have packages, whether the gardener showed up, or if the trash was picked up.  Mostly, it’s like bringing a piece of home with me on my travels.  Once the system is set up, it’s pretty much on auto pilot.I’ve never needed it, but I see that I am able to pull up past files.  All files are date and time stamped, so it’s easy to locate.  I think old files are deleted as the hard drive is filled up.  But with motion detected recording and 3TB of hard drive space, archive files can get quite old.One last thing.  I have to clean my cameras once every few weeks.  At my house, spiders tend to weave webs in front of the cameras.  Those webs really show up during night vision.I’m happy with the system, but your mileage might vary.
summary: Good Home Surveillance System-Takes Time to Set Up

reviewText: I don't have extensive experience with security systems, but I love this one. It's very simple (if time consuming) to set up. I'm able to monitor it from anywhere via phone or tablet. The picture is extremely clear. There are too many cameras for us to make use of, so I think the company should offer something of similar quality with fewer cameras to bring down the price. That said, this is an extremely high quality system. It is worth the money, and I recommend it highly.

I've had the DX50 since around November 2013.  The earlier firmware versions had their issues, however the latest firmware as of this writing is pretty spot on.  This is a very stable high quality player.  I upgraded to this from using my smart phone as a music player and now I can never go back to using a phone again.The 256 steps of very fine volume control this offers is great, can always find that perfect volume.  It has a high capacity microSD card slot that you can access without removing batteries or battery covers for easy swapping between cards.  It is nice having the entire 64 gb - 128 gb of storage devoted to purely your lossless music collection.  Don't have to share it with pictures and videos as would be the case on a phone.  Sound quality is quite a bit cleaner than from the phone also.  Very clean and detailed audio, a pleasure to listen to.The analog line out is great for hooking up to your car stereo, and the digital audio out is great for connecting to a home theater receiver for tremendous audio quality coming from this little thing.  The battery is replaceable with Samsung S3 phone batteries and lasts long enough to make it through my work day plus a little extra.  The physical buttons work great (though the front playback buttons are somewhat lagged in response).  The touch screen UI is simple and clean, a very bare bones OS that gets the job done and you can customize the background wallpaper as you see fit.  The built in equalizer is pretty useful for trying to tweak that perfect sound, and the battery life indicator is accurate.Overall this is a fine piece of unit.  Highly recommended to those wanting to get into the stand alone DAP era again, escaping the annoyances of phones.  This is an entry-level high quality DAP, can't go wrong with it for the price.

This is wall charger will charge all devices at once, need I say more!There are four USB ports that are used for charging an array of devices from tablets to Bluetooth headsets or whatever else needs a charge. In the hand, it has a nice solid feel. The body is plastic, which keeps the weight light but strong. The finish is matte that enhances the grip while in the hand. Also, the AC prongs fold into the charger, which makes it easier to carry in the pocket (less scratches on your leg).This charger plugs directly into the wall, which might be a hang up for some. I do not see this as problem since I am able to charge all my devices at the same time in one location. Before this charger, I would have to charge devices all over the house, now those dreadful memories are a thing of the past.Before use, be sure to read the back of the charger and see what port you need for the device you are needing to charge. You can charge up to four devices at the same time, but the maximum overall output will limited to 4A. This can be seen as a gift or curse, to me it is a gift. Being able to charge a diverse group of devices is a great thing.I use this single charger on my Galaxy Tab 2 10.1, Galaxy Note 2, and Bluetooth headset and speaker all at the same time. Now all of my devices are all in one place being charged, which is much easier.This is a must have charger if you have multiple mobile devices!CONTENTS:iXCC Quad Port Wall ChargerUser ManualFEATURES:USB Output Ports: 5V/2A (2x), 5V/1A (2x), (Max Of 4A When All Ports Used)Dimension: 3.15 x 2.28 x 1.18in (80 x 58 x 30mm)Weight: 3.53oz (100g)I was supplied a sample for the purpose of review.
Did not work.  After 8 hours of charging a Nexus 7 the battery charge went from 33% to 54%.

I often bring work to the office and find that this is a perfect way to wear my office badge and be sure I have files that I worked on at home.  The flash drive itself is very thin but so far this has not been an issue.

This is a great little product to have around.  The Verbatim 8 GB Dog tag USB Flash Drive is easy to use even for kids, although our grand kids are more tech savvy than I am.  This is especially great for school and church class projects.  It is perfect for power points.  It has the look of real dog tags and being on a chain makes it easy to keep up with.
This is a great item.  My son uses it at school and just tosses it around his neck with the included chain.  It has plenty of storage for his school projects.

I had previously bought another hub on eBay that never worked properly. I thought I would try this hub out and it worked perfectly without a hitch. There are updated firmware and driver files that can be found on the internet. Install with the included driver and you can later update with the more recent firmware and driver.This is a well made product with a renasas chipset that has noticeable sped up my USB 3 and USB 2 external drives by doubling throughput from USB 2.For large files with 2 seagate 3TB USB 3.0 drives attached I get about 75 mb/s transfer rates. I am very happy.
There is such a difference in speed with USB 3.0 that this card makes up the difference for older MB's

It's hard to get excited about RAM, but yeah, I plugged it in and it works fine. Maybe if it came in red and had some blinky disco lights on the edge so I could dance to it I would be more enthusiastic about a part that works as advertised. Warning: there is no fury, it's very calm and quiet. Not waterproof! Not recommended for male pattern baldness!

Starters...look at this color....built solid and with the other colors available in the same line, a custom PC is a few clicks away.  Performance is good (it is only RAM people).  Threw it in my son's AMD 6300 rig, timings and speed were detected and bam he's off saving some galaxy or carving a path on a battlefield.  Been a Kingston supporter for a long time, they have yet to disappoint.

I waited 3 weeks for this item, and my luck it is DOA.Item is defective, and I verified by mother board audio code, and by temporarily installing a good DDR3.  To make things worse Amazon did not give me a refund for the full amount paid.Update: I received a reply from Kingston, and it was the right kind of message.I also got the rest of my refund from Amazon with no explanation as to why they withheld it in the first place.2nd Update: This post in not about harming any person or company. I'm just providing feedback on my experience with this one purchase. I don't care whom you buy from, or what manufacturer you purchase from. If you don't agree with my post just move on please.

I've been flying my Phantom 2 Vision (no +) at least three times a day since February.  Today, I got my Phantom 2 Vision+.  In a short time, I had it flying, in exactly the same location as my first Vision.  In three 25 minutes flights, I was never able to maintain a solid GPS lock for more than ten seconds at a time, and it kept going in and out the entire time.  Also, on my second flight, my display turned to solid gray bars for most of the flight.  I never had such problems with my basic Vision.  Is my Vision+ a lemon?  Is anyone else having such experiences?Today I flew my Vision+ alternately with my Vision in exactly the same location three times each.  The Vision was always able to get and maintain a GPS lock; whereas the Vision+ took a long time to acquire a lock and kept losing it every few seconds.  Unless there is something I'm forgetting or doing wrong, I will have to return my Vision+.  Any suggestions?After 5 more flights my Vision+ is still not able to maintain a GPS lock for more than a few seconds.  Once it flew away and landed in a field about a quarter mile away.  These were just test flights, but I can't afford to have such things go wrong when I'm flying it over open water or mountainous terrain.  I have a basic Vision and haven't had any such problems, but the Vision+ camera is much better and can give you straight down shots.  Like many owners, I didn't buy this thing just to fly it over open fields and take pictures of grass growing.  I'm returning it.IMPORTANT:  Please read this, DJI.  Before this drone can be acceptable for use in risky terrain, there must be a BACKUP RETURN HOME SYSTEM.  The drone should continually keep a record of magnetic direction and approximate distance and flight time directly back to the home position.  If the control signal is lost, and GPS is not available, the drone should fly a direct dead reckoning compass course back to it's best estimated home point and hover at altitude until control is regained, GPS is restored, or it is forced to land because of low battery.

I received this item two days ago, and eagerly put it together for it's maiden flight..and put the battery and range extender on charge.  Finally yesterday, (per my procedure, I turned off my home wi-fi) I took it out and successfully calibrated the compass.  However, It repeatedly would connect to my control device briefly, then disconnect.  Reviewed all pre-flight procedures, and ensured the Phantom's wi-fi signal was present.  The signal strength was insufficient to maintain contact w/my control device, and could not be depended upon for a "flight".  I Further ensured I had the latest DJI app upgrade on my control device, but as the problem persisted,I disappointingly decided to return it.
summary: Out of the Box - transmission problem

reviewText: This is my second DJI Phantom Quadcopter. Unfortunately, a windy day apparently ended up disconnecting the control antenna from the board. On the next flight, the quadcopter panicked at 500 feet and plummeted to the ground in an unstable descent. Fortunately it landed in a tree. But getting it down from 45 feet up caused a bad crash.  Taking it apart and putting it back together is when I discovered that the control antenna connection doesn't have a tab or anything to secure it. It's just slipped in.  Bad design.Fortunately for me, Amazon took it as a return and sent me a new one since this was within 2 weeks of buying it. That's why I won't buy something like this anywhere else.Also, DJI released a firmware fix to control the maximum descent rate. It's a bit annoying for regular conditions but obviously I wasn't the only one who had the "sky is falling" panic.If you can get over issues like this, the footage it gets is amazing. The stability of the camera even in 20 MPH winds is remarkable. I showed this to a few people and I think at least 3 of them went and bought one the next day.
summary: Incredible footage. Great flying experience.  Bad when it misbehaves.

reviewText: First, I love this concept. It's amazing. It flies great, has no problems there.  My concern is that the new Gimbal system on this Vision 2 + is going to cause a lot of problems.  Mine twitches erratically, flips up and down, and now it's stuck in about a 40 degree left bank.  I've contacted DJI for any ideas... there's no mention of calibrating it.  It sucks filming sideways!Please fix / replace my gimbal DJI!  The camera quality is fantastic!!  Bad Gimbal ruins the whole experience.Buyer Beware!!! 2 Flights - messed up gimbal.

For the money it is ok. My employees break them so fast that I will not pay top dollar for a Kenwood mic or equivalent. Gets the job done. The dual push to talk is great. I monitor 2 channels mostly and going from A to B is so easy with this mic.

I had to order two of these - The GLAZZ was so well packaged that it survived transit perfectly, but after taking it out of the box I accidentally knocked it off of the desk (before I had applied it to the iPad) and when it hit the floor, it landed on one corner edge just right and the blasted thing spider-webbed.  Yes....it really IS made of glass folks!I had ordered a cheaper film which I applied and used while I was waiting for the second GLAZZ to arrive, and that kept the dust and oils off of the screen while I was waiting for delivery of the replacement.  It did a fine job, but it smeared rather badly.When the replacement arrived, I carefully did NOT drop it onto the floor.  I removed the other film, which lifted clean without leaving any residue on the tablet.I used the hinge method to apply the GLAZZ screen protector - applying removable tape along one long side to be sure of the alignment first, flipping it back, cleaning the screen of any dust using more of the removable tape, then removing the protective film from the GLAZZ screen cover and laying the adhesive side down on the tablet.  This is a stiffer screen protector than regular films - when I flipped it over, it gently laid ITSELF down perfectly on the tablet - no air bubbles formed.  Period.There was one minute speck of dust at one edge that I missed, I was able to lift that edge easily and remove the speck without any trouble.  Again, the screen protector aligned itself perfectly with no air trapped underneath.  I've never seen such a freakishly easy application.But the real difference with this screen protector, and the reason I am happy that I got a second one after messing up the first one, is that despite being perfectly clear, the GLAZZ does NOT show fingerprints!  Once it is applied, it completely disappears onto the screen, protecting it without being visible.  Since I had used another film screen protector for several days before applying it, the differences between the two were very obvious.I will be looking for GLAZZ for my other devices now - there is just no comparison.  (I wish they made a really big cover for my induction cooktop.)Since I had to buy this twice - it gets ten stars.  It's that much better than the alternatives, and well worth the extra cost. (Although I do HIGHLY recommend that you not throw them onto the floor. Chuckle!)
summary: 10 stars! The PERFECT protection for your iPad screen!

reviewerName: S. Naimpally "avid music and movie fan"
reviewText: I had problems installing the glazz.  The seller, handhelditems, agreed to send me a new one.  I'll reserve judgment on the product until I have had a chance to try the replacement screen.

My experience with Yamaha has been with their musical instruments and their electronic audio/video components and thus far it's been quite good. I recently reviewed their Pro 500 headphones. I thought they sounded superb - slightly warmer than neutral with a solid bass - but that they had some ergonomic issues that included a clamping force which was a bit too tight and ear cups that were slightly small. This limited listening periods to about an hour or two before they became uncomfortable to wear.The new Yamaha HPH-M82BL High-Definition On-Ear Headphones have no such ergonomic issues. They are remarkably comfortable with plushly cushioned foam ear pads that sit weightlessly on the ears. I've worn these headphones for as long as four hours without a twinge of discomfort. The twisted metal headband, which I presume is some sort of fashion statement, seems sturdy enough and adjusting these phones to match my largish cranium was easy. There is no worrisome tension on the headband that might lead to cracking (I've had that happen). The rest of the body of these headphones is constructed of plastic that is shaped with a pleasing minimalist aesthetic. These phones are very comfortable and you won't be embarrassed to be seen wearing them outdoors.These are not expensive ($200 and up) headphones and their sound quality is good for their sensible price point. I listened to a broad spectrum of music that included Classical, Rock and Jazz of all varieties. The HPG-M82BLs possess a rather bright treble and a so-called "bass hump" that makes for a forceful low mid-range and solid bass extension: reflecting Yamaha's apparent desire to compete with Beats. Mid-range is unaccentuated so vocals are slightly recessed but sufficiently present so that the music is unaffected. All of these attributes give the Yamaha HPH-M82BLs a sound signature that has a V configuration (accentuated lows and highs with a slightly recessed mid-range).These aren't noticeably warm headphones but their sound is quite pleasing overall. They have a narrow soundstage, like most closed headphones, and musical transparency is somewhat limited. Overall, I thought these better than comparably priced headphones I've listened to, with a well-defined though narrow sound stage and just enough transparency to make listening enjoyable. Good sound for the money and excellent comfort make these headphones a solid entry at this price point.
summary: Good sound at this price point and excellent comfort make these headphones a solid entry

reviewText: I've used a lot of mid-range headphones from sub $100 to $300 and this one doesn't impress me much. The sound quality alone is actually pretty good. It's well-balanced like my trusty Creative Auvana Live! The bass is not overwhelming like other headphones. However, the design really lets me down. The headphones just look kind of funny because of the twisted head-arch design. Yes, it stands out from the crown, but not in a positive way. The headphones are quite comfortable. I watched a 90 minutes movie without any strain to my ears and I have medium-small head. Overall, decent sound and build quality. However, I'm not a fan of this strange design.Recommendation: if you want a similar sound quality with classic design and at a lower price point, check out the Creative Auvana Live ($70). If you want more bass and better sound quality overall, try the Denon AHD 1100 ($100).
This is exactly what I've been looking for... Almost. It doesn't have a female 3.5mm connector. I bought with a coupler, and it's now perfect! I can watch lectures at my desk without bugging others.

I use this with my portable XM radio with an Auxillary-in port and can play my music from my iPod or iPhone through the XM radio speakers.  Very small and great for camping as well as long as the device is fully charged.
summary: Great addition to my XM portable radio

reviewText: Nicely designed, but it really kills your battery. Don't think that you can make a gopro into a regular digital cam. Don't get me wrong, I love my GoPro, but it was just not made for use with an LCD.
summary: Nicely designed, but it really kills your battery

reviewText: Perfect for gopro if you want to immediately view what your getting shots of. Picture quality could be better. Barely HD.  Touch screen is convenient for accessing settings also.

I got this for my new smartphone storage. I did not realize it came with a USB reader and a SD card reader to fit the SDHC micro as well. I could plug the tiny chip into the USB port on any computer or even into my USB on the new car if I had 64g of music on it. Or I suppose I could load it up with my Audible audio books and have them read to me through the radio connection. All the things that electronics can do these days simply boggles my tired old brain. But I'm a gadget freak, and this card is so simple, good quality, and then the USB reader device kicks it up a notch. Nice. I'm glad I chose this particular one. SanDisk is a reliable brand.

This case  is sharp looking.  It's thin and the outside is modern looking with a fingerprint resistant surface.  I have several leather (and fake leather) cases and this one is much thinner and sleeker.  The plastic frame that holds the iPad is also thin and adds minimal bulk.  Rubber pads are on the frame to prevent the iPad from slipping when it's resting at an angle on the base...it's not perfect, but they would have had to increase the cover thickness to emboss some grooves.  Unlike my last Belkin case, the shut-it-off-when-you-close-the-cover magnet is correctly aligned.There's only one thing missing...a wide strap to allow you to hold the iPad against one hand, while you use it with the other. (My wife uses it that way when working with her students.)  If that's important, this isn't the case for you.  Otherwise, this is truly a five star case...
summary: I love the appearance and the ability to rotate my iPad...

reviewText: This is a recent case from Logitech that shows good design and style. First of all, it works. The adjustable angle design works in horizontal (landscape) mode. This is useful when the unit is resting in your lap while reclining and you need a specific angle to reduce glare. The cover will trigger the sleep mechanism every time when closing, and waken when opened. The material on the inside of the cover is a purple suede which grips and keeps the angle stable. If you want to use the iPad in portrait orientation, then the cover can fold flat against the back of the iPad. My only criticism is the white plastic edging on the back case. My iPad is Space Gray, and the white edging is not my favorite. The material on the front cover and back is a stiff fabric 'tweed' that is different from the monochromatic covers that are so prevalent. My spouse says it reminds her a bit of the lab notebooks we used to carry around on campus. All the cutouts on this case are precision cut. The volume, power, and slider switches are easily accessible, as is the lightning port. I think the case is a bit on the pricy side, but that may be what you pay for the quality and style.
summary: Stylish, High Quality iPad protection and case

reviewText: This case / keyboard combo really takes the iPad Mini to a new level.  You will be impressed--I was!  And when you nonchalantly open it up in front of your friends or co-workers, they will be impressed with you.  I got some covert glances, raised eyebrows, dropped mouths, and even some honest "Wow!" responses when I took this to the library.Be aware that both the case for the iPad and the iPad Mini are on this product page.  Make sure you hit the right button to show the correct price and to order the model that you have.The hard case is made of a rubbery-feel, no-slide material.  It feels good in my hand. The iPad fits snugly in the top of the case, the keyboard is part of the bottom of the case.  The hinge really does its job and holds/stays put where ever you position it.  The hinge is a separate piece--not a bendable, fold-over piece of plastic.Granted, the keyboard is small--to match the iPad Mini, but it is still functional.  Being smaller than regular keyboards, it obviously takes some getting used to.  The keys are plenty big enough so your fingers can hit them straight on.  The keys are close enough together that if you are a typist, and if you have large hands, you might not be able to position all your fingers in the starting position.  I have long, narrow fingers and in the starting position, my fingers do fit on the keys, but my fingers touch side-by-side.  It is easier if I keep only my index and middle finger on the keys to start, then my little fingers come down naturally as I type.Easy to charge up.  Easy to set up the BT.*I received a sample product from OXA.
summary: I really nice addition to my iPad Mini

reviewText: I bought this receiver directly from Sony. Sound quality is excellent! you won't regret. Great features and value for money.I have connected DVR, samsung bluray and my tv to this receiver( with pioneer andrew jones speakers). I encountered few issues... I switched to tv audio while I was using an app on my samsung bluray player and suddenly the picture and sound went off. I couldn't get back the sound when I set all the settings back. I switched to DVR but couldn't get the picture and sound back. I had to switch off the unit completely to get the sound and picture back. But I tried few times to replicate the issue but I couldn't. Hope it wont happen again. Recently, on another circumstance the sound was cutoff and I had to switch off and start again to make it work. Also, this receiver doesn't have the All Channel Stereo feature like my Onkyo. Lacks HDMI 2.0(4k/60hz), HDCP 2.2? future proof?update 7/10/14: I never had those issues again. I will have to compare this with my Onkyo TXNR 727 to rate this receiver's sound quality.  HDMI 2.0(4k/60hz), HDCP 2.2? future proof?( this should not effect the rating since the review is based on the product as advertised)

I write reviews for Vine, and when I can, I try to not only review the item at hand, but also contrast it with another viable option (usually of the same brand). With this in mind, let me tell the story of two Hi-Res Audio products: the Sony STR DN 850 and the Sony STR DN 1050 (http://www.amazon.com/Sony-STRDN1050-Audio-Component-Receivers/dp/B00JC31SEI/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid;=1403792980&sr;=8-1&keywords;=str+dn+1050)  Today, the 850 is exactly $100 less than the 1050, at $498 and $598, respectively (on Amazon).Before we get started, some background information:What is Hi-Res Audio?In home theater, there are always people who are looking to improve their experience. (I am one such person--going to the movies is not my favorite thing to do anymore with people talking, on their cell phones, and coughing in my general direction.  But I digress...)High-Res Audio is generally only a marketing term, but describes audio signals that exceed the bandwidth of CDs, and have sampling rates greater than 44,100 Hz and bit-depths greater than 16 (or equivalents).  Their formats include FLAC, ALAC, WAV, AIFF, and DSD (also found on Super Audio Compact Discs--if you've never tried, it, do.  It's amazing).What is a sampling rate?Basically, a sampling rate gives you the number of "samples" of audio per second (in Hz or kHz--one kHz is 1,000 Hz).  The more, the better. The more samples, the greater the maximum frequency (i.e. a sample rate of 8 kHz=3.6 max frequency; a sample rate of 96 kHz=43.6 kHz max frequency).An audio CD has a sampling rate of 44.1 kHz (giving a 20 kHz max frequency). This was thought to be the highest frequency generally audible by our human ear (the older you get, the more this number falls).(A note: higher than 44.1 sampling rates are used to record wildlife and other specialized situations, such as when sound is slowed down, which would in fact lower that sampling rate back to where we can enjoy it at our own limited max value.)High-Def Audiophiles disagree with the 44.1kHz human limitation (and so do I). The biggest detractors saying that High-Res Audio is nothing more than a marketing ploy to get us to purchase the "latest and greatest"...But I can honestly tell you that there IS a difference for me, personally.  I actually have a bit of a hearing deficit and have a tough time with understanding speech, especially on television and DVDs.  When I hear a High-Res Audio sound file, the sounds are clearer and I can easily understand what is being said. I also hear nuances in music that meld together using normal CDs.  Hearing isn't all about one unit of measure, as any hard-of-hearing person can tell you.High-Res Audio files can be retrieved online and via other sources, but you need a unit that can actually play those files.  This is where the Sony devices come in.A first basic difference: the 850 has 150W of power...the 1050 has 165W.  Why is this important?  If you were comparing two different brands, this isn't as important because of inherent variables in the "Watts per channel".  However, given that these two units are alike, the db ratings, distortion, signal-to-noise ratio, dynamic headroom, and total harmonic distortion ratings are all the same, so Watts simply means that you can go louder without losing quality with the 165W unit.  Beware comparing simply Watts across brands (and even within brands if comparing upper-end v. lower-end units), as the louder does not necessarily mean the better (it could be louder, but lose quality in the inherent variables).Sony uses a 2-channel system in their home theater systems (the 850 and 1050).Both use a 7.2 channel configuration that can be set up with different surround styles. Only the 1050 has a two channel analog audio zone 2 preamp (used in Dolby and DTS).The 850 has 6 HDMI 1.4 inputs and one output.  The 1050 has 7 HDMI 1.4 inputs and three outputs (one independent and two parallel).  One HDMI input on both receivers is MHL-enabled (Mobile High Definition= connects smart phones and tablets to your HDTV, supporting 1080p and 7.1 digital audio; yes you an do this via Bluetooth, but it's a nice addition.) Each receiver also has a USB port (on the front) for flash drives or phones, and wired ethernet or wireless wifi for internet and DLNA network connectivity. Both receivers have Bluetooth (with NFC and Apple's Airplay).The 850 lacks in component and analog options.  While the 1050 has two sets of component inputs and one component output, and has an analog zone 2 preamp output, the 850 has neither of these options. (Zone 2 distribution means that you can play your audio in different rooms.)Neither has S-video analog inputs nor outputs, nor any phono input (for you vinyl guys).Both units avail 3D and up to 4K pass-through.  The 1050 avails 4K upscaling).Each unit comes with a remote and Sony has an app for Apple or Android that can control the unit(s) as well.  Sony has a separate app (for both Apple and Android) that can search and control audio files.  Both units have the Sony Cinema Auto Calibration speaker setup program, too.  This is an easy way to tweak your system.It is important to note that the 1050 has a glass resin circuit board and larger power transformer.  I could not find any note of these for the 850.You can read Sony's product description of the 850 here: [...]You can read Sony's product description of the 1050 here:  [...]Between the two of these, I would personally choose the 1050. For the added one hundred dollars, you get a powerful workhorse of a unit, with louder capability and upgraded physical features like that upgraded transformer and capacitor system.  These units will last for years, and over time, that hundred dollars is worth the investment, in my opinion.  (However, if you have a smaller space and have little use for the added component and HDMI capability, then the 850 is a great unit, too.)These units are both easy to set up, easy to use (I love the apps), and will definitely "up your game".  I tested with an LG 55LW8600 using Cinema 3D, iPad, Pandora, DVD, Playstation using Boston Acoustics speakers custom set up with 7.2 configuration.  My room is approximately 20 x 25, with 9' ceilings.I hope this review helps you choose a quality unit for your home theater experience.
summary: Comparison of the 850 and 1050 (the difference $100 can make)

reviewText: The software installed without problems on a Windows 8 machine.  The interface is pretty much the same as it has been for the last several versions.  The big thing I really like about Wordperfect is that unlike for Microsoft Office functions are usually not relocated to different places when a version is changed.  With Office I often have to do a Google search to find out what menu some function has been moved to from the previous version since the help file is usually of no value.  This makes the overall learning curve for WordPerfect pretty easy.The program performed well during a month of testing.  It is a excellent alternative to Microsoft Office and is highly recommended.

This is exactly what we needed. We really only use the WordPerfect and Roxio Secure burn but I am excited to try the other features as well. It was very easy to download and set up. No complaints here!

If you want something that does not restrict you to the limitations of proprietary features of Microsoft Office, this is the choice.  It plays wells with others and adapts to your needs and file formats.  And even though it is to be installed on a Windows platform, the end resulting files can be reason on a Mac without the gibberish effect.  It also imports Mac formatted files quite well and converts with ease.  At least so far, with my uses.And anything to keep as much resource killing and crashing Adobe product off of my system is good with me.  I use Photoshop etc, but dammit if Adobe annoys the hell out of me at times.  In other words, this solves the PDF problem. And does it well.So this "Standard" suite is probably the best choice for most everyone.  Going "Pro" does not offer much else except extensive data management.  I suppose this would be worth it for a growing or larger business, but for most at home offices or small business use, Standard does it all.Keep in mind that even if you are creating a "Quattro" spreadsheet, there is no conflict with opening it in Mac's Numbers or Excel etc.  As well as WordPerfect (the leader in word processing in my eyes) will also work well with Mac's Pages and other word programs.The slideshow creator I have not really had need for, and will probably never use,  but tested it, and it is impressive.  Certainly would work well for presentations and on screen projections.  But I cannot compare this feature to others as I have no need.The integration of Roxio disc burning ability makes it a bit easier to save in various ways without eating resources by opening another program.  The drag and drop method is quite easy, and I love the ability to password protect anything I do, giving it to people for their eyes only.Corel has always been the leader in word processing in my experience for well over 20 years, as I even remember using it during the 80s.  And it always gets better.  Another plus is that their software is always READY, not a program you install, and need to update or upgrade as soon as you get it to remove all the bugs and problems.  Though there are updates of course, it's not a complete nightmare screwing up settings like most programs in this category.  They have been around this long for a reason.  The only reason Microsoft Office is even mentioned is because it's basically forced upon you when buying a PC.  This takes away the ball and chain.I lingered on a 4-5 star rating just based on the price.  I just don't feel like we are at the point they need to have a list price of 250 bucks.  Make it 99, call it a day, and people will have no problem upgrading, even once a year.
summary: The leader in Word Processing, no matter what Microsoft does.

reviewText: WordPerfect has been around since...well, the dawn of the Computer Age. And, in 2006, the WordPerfect Office products got bought out by Corel, which has continued to make them better.I think that X7 is a nice improvement in X6, without losing anything – I hate when Microsoft changes things so much that I feel all lost at sea! This software suite is powerful enough for my purposes and easily used. I have loved WordPerfect Office for years, and am glad that I got X7!(Review of WordPerfect Office X7 Home and Student)
summary: I have loved WordPerfect Office for years, and am glad that I got X7!

reviewText: WordPerfect has always played second fiddle to Office, although for a while I would say that the former program beat Office on ease of use. I was interested to try this out in comparison to Office 2013. My initial opinion is that, while Office has simplified a lot of their complexity (while retaining the ability to dive in deeper and do just about anything you can think of), WordPerfect has retained a lot of the visual complexity and is now a little harder to use. However, there are probably plenty of folks out there who use this alternative for all their word processing and probably have since antiquity - for you folks I say go ahead, it's still every bit as good as you remembered.

I have been using WordPerfect since 1983. Although I use Microsoft Word at times, WordPerfect is still my word processor of choice. My primary reason for preferring WP over Word is that it is much easier to format documents and to fix stuff when it goes wrong.I absolutely LOVE reveal codes. Nothing Word can do can make up for not having reveal codes. You can instantly see your settings and easily adjust any formatting.The main reason to use Word is because everyone else uses it. The main reason to use WordPerfect is that it is the best word processor out there.A few notes on WPX7:I installed it on a Win7 laptop. It took about five minutes to run the installation. I only  installed WP and Lightning, not the spreadsheet and presentation programs, so it would take longer if you installed all of them. Everything worked immediately--no problems, no crashes, nothing.The installation program will ask if you want to move settings from a previous WP installation to the new version and if you want to delete the old installation. It makes life easy when you upgrade.The programs may be installed on up to three PCs.The Home & Student version is a stripped-down version. It does not include a few features found in the Standard and Professional versions, such as the ability to edit PDFs, ebook creation software and disk burning software. It also does not include the Paradox database program that is only available in the Pro version.I have been a huge WP fan for years, and this new version will keep our relationship going for a long time to come.

This program comes with a lot more than I need. I don't use spreadsheets or edit photos hardly ever anymore but if I want too this comes with a great Excel clone.  I like the word processing part - it will open all my old documents that I had in Microsoft Word 2003 (see how often I update?).  It was super easy to install on my old PC with Windows XP.  I like Windows XP and wanted a new program that would work well with it and so far it seems to do that.  The layout looks much the same as in my old MSWord 2003 program, and the tutorial/instructions are very detailed and easily accessible.I don't write much of anything anymore, but it is nice to be able to open documents that my kid's teachers e-mail us using the latest MSWord programs.  Before was a bit of a hassle firing up the laptop that had the lastest Word program and coaxing it to connect to the printer.  This program works very well for that and for the cost, I think it's a great bargain for what you get.
summary: WordPerfect Office X7 Home and Student

reviewerName: Raymond H. Mullen "Trust others, but  pack yo...
reviewText: I remember using 'WordPerfect' back in the 80's.  I liked it then and I love it now.  There are so many 'word processors' on the market today, but this is one of those 'If it ain't broke, don't fix it' programs.  It's numerous fonts and clip art are easy to use and really leaves you with no reason not to produce a good looking document.  It's a perfect match for 'Windows 8' with no compatibility issues.The new upgrades on this 'Office X7' version just adds to an already good product.
summary: An Update on a Great Processor

reviewText: I first ever used WordPerfect 5.1 for DOS back in the early 1990s when I got a desk clerk job at my university and was introduced into the world of computers as a daily office tool. I was in that position for over 4 years and the last year I was there, they made the transition across the university to not only Windows 95, but MS Office. I found the software unwieldy compared to WordPerfect - especially when it came to viewing 'hidden' codes and doing mail merges.I honestly thought WordPerfect had long gone out of business - but I was so happy to discover this was not the case. WordPerfect has not lost its virtues of the past. Being able to create word processing documents, spreadsheets and presentations in the much easier-to-use interface of WordPerfect Office is far less taxing.Opening MS Office files in WordPerfect can result in some wonky formatting, but it's easy to fix.If you remember WordPerfect from years ago and like me, were pained to be forced by school or work to switch to Microsoft, WordPerfect is still alive and well and worth your time to try.
summary: More user-friendly than MS Office, and at a fraction of the price

reviewText: A sturdy word processor/spreadsheet/presentation software is a must for home/students alike.  Apart from database program (equivalent to Access), this suite aims to provide all three essential components.  The word processor is fairly rich with features and could meet the needs for most.  Saving the file in Word format works mostly ok, though very often some of the formatting gets lost when you try to reopen the file in Word. If you plan to send files to others in a different format, you need to factor in this risk  (perhaps better to change to pdf, verify the format, and then send).  The spreadsheet, much improved from X5, may still not match Excel in all the features, but is still a strong contender. Overall, for the price and 3 licenses, this is a good alternative, though entire free options with no licensing needs may also fit the needs for most home/student purposes.
summary: OK choice, but no contender for Office or even LibreOffice/OpenOffice

reviewText: Yes they work... and the sound quality is much better than I expected.My only problem is that these lights are just too big to place in the fixtures that I would prefer.  They either don't fit at all in some downward facing light receptacles, or they extend beyond the end of the track lights.  They are awfully bright as well.If they were smaller, I would love them.  But as things stand now.  I'll probably use them in a limited way.

Nordic Flash makes an awesome GoPro chest strap mount.  This is a useful mount to use when riding bicycles, motorcycles, etc. and a unique filming perspective is desired.  The motion of one's chest tends to be less than the motion of one's head, resulting in smoother and more watchable GoPro videos.  Please feel free to check out http://goo.gl/6KdWgP where I have posted more photos and videos of this GoPro chest mount.  I use this mount for kayaking, bicycling and much more!  It's very well-made and adjustable and the included stuff sack makes throwing it inside my GoPro travel bag with other GoPro and camera equipment simple!
summary: Affordable GoPro Chest Mount with Included Stuff Sack

reviewText: Sharp's little system comes with so many features and capabilities, you're likely to find 'something' in it that makes it useful.It is a little 'large' but something good comes of its size, namely the speakers being far enough to produce some nice stereo separation. The sound quality is about average with the bass a little lacking and the acutes not as sharp as I would prefer.As for features, you name it, you got it. Especially if you are an iPod/Pad/Phone person. Besides Apple integration, the system pairs nicely with most but not all Bluetooth-enabled devices, plays AM/FM radio and AM and FM antennas are required and are supplied and plays CDs if it must but, according to some reviews posted here, not very reliably.Overall, it's a good pick if what you are looking for is a conservative-looking little stereo that's not portable but works well with some mobile devices, especially Apple's and you don't mind the price.

LOVE this Sharp Bluetooth Speaker System.  Looks great, sounds better and connects easily with multiple devices.I'm a huge fan of these bluetooth speakers.  After years of getting different docking systems that would be obsolete in a year, I love that bluetooth removes that issue.  The price is not bad either.  I have a much smaller, portable JBL Flip that I think I spent almost as much money on.The Sharp GX-BT7 is on the larger size of these type systems.  This is a unit you will want to put on a shelf and plug in and leave it where it is.  Its wide, but not tall and has a very nice sleek design.  I love when you turn the ON button on the speakers slide out to reveal the blue EQ lights.  Very cool.The unit paired easily with my iphone, the kids' kindle and my laptop.  I was able to play both my itunes library and pandora no problem.  Sounds great, nice bass and a variety of sound settings to get what you are looking for.  The blue lights move in time with your music which is a really cool feature.My only small complaint with this unit is like a lot of these oddly shaped speakers it doesn't seem entirely stable.  I would probably prefer a square/rectangular shape.  But either way, its still very stylish and cool.  If you have any questions about this speaker system, feel free to post them here and I will be sure to answer.Recommended!

reviewerName: Clark Isaacs "Clark's Eye on Books by Clark I...
reviewText: Sharp has done it again with this great sounding speaker system which operates with Bluetooth items and also with USB plugins.  When you see the USB port, remember, that you cannot plug with a wire to the computer or other device.  It works with the devices which are separate modules.  Great if you download your music from the computer or internet and save it to the module.  Then you can play it with a high quality speaker which has some great adjustable features for treble and bass.  It even comes with a sub-woofer which adds that extra dimension for sound.  Great looking as well and takes up very little space, but don't confuse with a small speaker, this is a full featured system.
summary: Excellent for Bluetooth and I Pad

reviewText: I purchased this a few days ago to fit my 3rd generation iPad. The case is pretty sturdy, seems like good construction. The fit is OK, but not great. It's tight with the smart cover on, and the flap doesn't quite fit flush with the iPad in it. I am able to close the flap and hope as it gets broken in, the fit will be a bit better.
summary: Nice case, fit is a little tight

reviewText: I received this product from Bear Motion for my honest review. I liked the look of this case, but I will probably not use it simply because it feels like I am carrying a clutch. I did however give it to my wife to use and she loves the look of it. The inside does a great job of cleaning your iPad screen and it fits in there perfectly. This is a great product!
Works just as advertised. My only wish is it had more Android ports instead of Apple ports. Everything charges quickly when plugged into the correct ports.

Or rather... it goes with both Apples and Oranges/Androids.EasyAcc sent me a 'for review' unit but no promises of a 'good review' were exchanged or implied. They get 5 stars because they made a good product.This is a great buy if you have both Apple and Android phones/tablets in the house because Apples don't like Android-optimized chargers and vice-versa.EasyAcc's contraption gives you the following ports and you can use them in any combination for an output of up to 5A:- 2 iPad 5V/2.1A- 1 iPhone 5V/1A- 1 Samsung Tab 5V/1.3A- 1 Android 5V/1AI was able to successfully and quickly charge one Android tablet and 1 Android phone, also one iPad and and a Samsung tablet at the same time.The charger comes with a 5 ft. cord and comes nicely packed in one of them Amazon easy to open boxes.
works great. and great for some one who travels and has alot of things to charge
so far , so good. I can charge my cell phone, ipad samsung tab 4 and kindle fire at the same time fast with easy
like it but the thing doesnt stand up very well. it falls over all the time.  but if you lay it on the side you will be ok.

This is so much more convenient than a bunch of one off chargers when I travel.  I only have to find one outlet in the hotel.  My phones and tablets charge at least as fast as with their original chargers, it seems to be faster.  I have not tried to max it out, but it does an iPhone 5S, iPad Air, and Kindle fire all at the same time just fine, along with my little rechargeable pocket flashlight.
I charge five items at a time, great device and it works great.
summary: EasyAcc Great device when using more than one plug.

reviewText: Great item to have. Great for travel especially charging all our (4) iPhones at the same time. It fits in your travel bag, not too bulky to carry around.
It is great, i can use the 5 charging ports at the same time, my Ipad, my Andriod smartphone, a ggogle tv device, my wife blackberry and also my motorola car bluetooth handsfree i realle recomend it
5A is enough to charge my iPad4, iPhone5s and Pebble watch all at the same time. Great for my night stand and when I travel. Bought another one for travel.
summary: Charges my iPad and iPhone faster

reviewText: This device solves a lot of problems especially when traveling with multiple devices.  Most hotel rooms, even high end ones do not have enough free wall sockets to support multiple chargers at once and even if there is a free socket, there may not be enough room for a wall transformer.  This plugs into the wall via a long cord to bring power to the device via a relatively standard two prong socket at the back.  This gets power from the wall to a desk or bureau where you can attach your devices via USB cords of any length. The power cord and the USB cords detach for transport.  I work them into a coil and put them in a 1 pt Ziplock bag for storage and transport.  It home it reduces clutter. There is again only one wall attachment to the charging station. There are limitations.  Maximum output is 5A.  There are two 2.1A ports, one 1.3A port and two 1.0A ports.  If you are only charging 1A devices, phones, you can use all five ports at once. If you attach a couple of ipads and a phone, they will charge optimally but if you attach more devices they will charge but significantly slower.The device is sleek, looks nice, feels solid.  Port amperages are given on the side and back.I have been using it daily for a couple of months with no problems.

Works great, and the ability to charge 5 items simultaneously is terribly convenient! When we travel this has replaced about 5 other chargers we used to lug around. Also makes it easier when you only have that one outlet in the hotel room! Highly recommend, essential for travel if nothing else.
So far I love it.  It's really nice to be able to charge all my tech using only one outlet.
Saves time and effort. Now I don't have to bring four different chargers and an extension cord with me when I travel. Great find.
summary: Great addition to my travel kit

reviewText: The item appears to be very good quality. The white power chord supplied is adequate in length. Samsung phones charge as needed no problems so far.

For bicycle enthusiasts this is an excellent speaker/radio combination that has decent sound and a lot of convenient touches. I received mine as a review sample from the manufacturer.I'll cover the sound quality first. In a word, it's adequate. Not overly spectacular, but sufficiently loud to be heard over road noise while trekking through streets and paths. I do not view the quality as a problem because in most biking environments the sound level is more important than fidelity. Plus, the safety factor of having a hands-free solution is the major reason for getting one of these.What impressed me is when I turned this on all I had to do is scan for bluetooth devices from my phone and it popped right up. I did not have to press a multifunction button and chant, hoping the device would show up like other bluetooth speakers - it was immediately there.Another thing I love is the buttons are on the top of the case and when the speaker is turned on they light up blue. I have stationary speakers which have buttons that blend into the case so well I cannot readily find them, so this feature removes one major distraction when you are on the road. In the dark the lights are soft enough to not affect your night vision. The only improvement that I can think of is to use red lights instead of blue because those would actually promote night vision. Perhaps the designers will do that in the next generation.Some of the other nice touches are the ample inside space for a phone and other incidentals, plus a ring clip on the outside for your keys. I also love the three point attachment to your handle bar and steering post. It is easy to attach and remove. In fact, that takes mere seconds.Having a removable battery is yet another design factor that makes this a value. Most bluetooth speakers on the market have a fixed, internal battery that will eventually wear out. When the battery in this one inevitably dies you can quickly replace it with a newBL-5C Extended Li-Ion Batteryand you are good to go another 500 or so charging cycles.Finally, the semi-hard case, heavy duty zipper and construction are all first rate and clearly designed by someone who understands the rigors of biking when it comes to gear. This entire unit is built to withstand the outdoors in most weather conditions.

I've owned a number of Bluetooth speakers for bikes.  Most of them hold the cell phone and nothing more.  This one is roomy.  There's enough space for the phone and my keys.  There's even a clip on the outside, if I want to use that.The speaker straps securely on the handlebars of my scooter bike.  I've been riding around the neighborhood on it every day, radio or iPhone blasting.FM RADIOI scanned all the FM stations the first time I used it.  This, so I can just press the forward or back button to go to the next station.  Still, some of the static-only stations were accepted in the scan.  I have to manually skip those.I don't use the radio function much, though.  I can tell I'm listening to a radio, because it's not as clear as when I'm using the Bluetooth function.  Riding around town, some stations come in and out, as radio signals sometimes do.BLUETOOTH SPEAKERBluetooth function is great.  It paired easily and it reconnects with my iPhone as soon as I turn it on.  Sound quality is as good as I can tell with all the road noise and nature sounds I have to hear it over.All the controls are on top of the speaker, so I don't have to open the case to adjust volume or skip tracks.  Very nice.PHONE CALLSAmazing.  Considering most Bluetooth speakers do a very poor job with phone calls, I can actually hold a conversation with this speaker.  Both the caller's end and the speaker end are clear.OVERALL IMPRESSIONI'm so happy with this speaker.  It does everything I need it to do.  I love the roominess and clip on the outside.  I like the ease of connecting with Bluetooth.  It even has FM radio for when I don't have my phone, and I can accept the occasional call without fumbling to open the case.  It's a keeper.This product was provided for review by Abco Tech.

A good remote, but it has is nuisances. Sometimes, it repeatedly sends a key press. Also, it would be nice if didn't always wake up with Cursor Mode active. I use only the arrow keys 99% of the time, so I don't like that  I have to actively disable cursor mode EVERY time I pick up the remote after it has gone idle. None are deal-breakers, but hopefully, there will be a firmware update to address these issues.

This is a decent step up from the stock remote for the G-box. But the shift function on the keyboard does not seem to work at all. I had to revert to the old remote to complete some sentences time and time again> i would have given it more stars had it not been for that glitch.

I was so, so excited to get this remote since it had all the buttons on the front that were missing on the G Mouse. My G Mouse doesn't get used because of it's constant loss of sync, and missing button functionality.However, there's obviously a design flaw with this right now, so I'm sending it back. They put this one out to market before it was ready. When I see some confirmation in the reviews here that Matricom has fixed it, I'll buy it again, because I really, really need those buttons on the front !...The problems I've had mirror what other reviewers stated. In my case,-The mouse disable button does not work most of the time, and it will take several attempts pressing it before finally turning off the cursor.-The right (advance) button sends a stream of multiple presses every time. I use this a LOT for advancing to the next song in XBMC Music playlists, so this was the final deal-breaker for me.-Keys on the keyboard often send multiple keypresses. It's annoying, but I could've lived with it. And I could not find a "backspace" button to undo them. I finally figured out Alt + Back arrow did a backspace, which is kind of cumbersome.Well, back to my Logitech K400 keyboard, standard IR remote, and Music Pump XBMC (Awesome app! send him $) Remote on Android for now...I gave 2 stars, 1 because the air mouse worked well, plus 1 more because other buttons, including the red Power on/off button, on the front seemed to work fine. The Power button worked right out of the box, unlike what other reviewers experienced.

This light weight tracker is worn on your belt and there are 18 plastic buttons to screw into the club handle . Tap the club to the little red and black square unit before swinging and you are done. You have a minute to tap and you can backtrack and tap if you forget. The GPS tracks your game and records all the stats for you. Use your iPhone or PC and review, edit  and share your information. Syncs in with Social Media like Facebook and also has the capability to compare your game with friends or professional players. It is listed as being compatible with iPhone or IPad, however I don't know how you would sync it to an iPad, as mine has no slot for the plug.The unit was very easy to set up. Just plug it into the PC and let it charge for a few hours. Then you download the program by going to the web site. You have to create a user name, password, home golf course, handicap and also set up your virtual golf bag. Each red tag gets matched to a club. There is a dropdown menu listing a vast amount of brands and styles of clubs. You can edit the tags to match your custom made clubs and hybrid clubs. Any unused tags simply get slid over into a empty screen for later use or change. One thing that I do not like is, since I downloaded the tracking program, I seem to get redirected to other golf related adds when I am in a browser. My computer is brand spanking new with very little outside programs downloaded. I will have to spend time now to try and track down the source of this unwanted feature. Took away a star for that.My husband is a weekly golfer, aged 66, he owns a dinosaur of a flip phone and cannot even turn on a computer. I would guess that 90 percent of the guys who golf in his local club are in the same demographic. None of them have e-mail, Facebook or Twitter accounts. None of them would have a clue as to how to set this up and use it on their own. Even if a couple of them did manage to talk their wives, kids or grandkids into doing the computer part of the set up and weekly editing of the scorecard, they wouldn't have many friends to share the information with. That being said, this is a great idea for tech savvy golfers, high school and college golf clubs and teams, golfers with patient understanding spouses, or those who are willing to learn something new to add to their golfing experience. My husband loves it, as long as I am willing to sit there and record all the activities of the game with him. The feature he liked most was the stats for the pros.
summary: nice gaget for the tech savvy golfer

reviewText: In addition to the usual powerbank features, this powerbank can be recharged via solar power. While the solar charging feature has some limitations, it offers an alternative approach that is unique and unlike any other powerbank I've used.The device itself is a bit on the large size, measuring about 3 inches wide and 5.5 inches long. However, it's only about a half inch thick, so it's not what I'd consider to be ungainly (although certainly not nearly as compact as a conventional 5000mAh powerbank). The larger size is needed to support the solar panel.The build quality is very good. It's billed as being rain-proof, but not waterproof. In other words, getting some water on it is not a problem, but it's not something that can be fully submersed in water and survive.It has two USB output ports, both rated at 1A. The ports are covered with a silicon cap to keep out water and dust. The device itself is wrapped in a "shock absorbing" case (basically a thick rubber-like coating) that gives it a decent measure of bump and bruise protection. However, as expected, the solar panel that covers the full front of the powerbank is not protected, so you still need to take some measure of care with this.The overall design is pretty nice looking, with light blue accents and a black front and back. The caps covering the ports are anchored into the case so they can't get lost. It also has the usual "gas gauge" to show the charge level left (series of 4 LEDs) and a low-powered, but still useful flashlight. It comes with the usual assortment of connectors/adapters plus a very nice metal hook (spring loaded) so it can be easily clipped and unclipped to a backpack (or pretty much anything with a loop). That's a useful feature considering that this is a good device to have when camping.The solar panel is not intended to be the primary method of recharging, but rather be used in circumstances where you don't have access to a USB charge port. The instructions warn about leaving this in the sun for too long, which is (I assume) due to the fact that it has a Li-ion battery in it, and lithium batteries do not like to get hot.But even if heat were not an issue, it's not very practical to rely on just solar recharging since it is very slow. It took me a few hours to get this solar charged from the 75% level to the 100% level. Still, if solar is the only option you have (such as if you're camping) having a solar panel - even a slow one - is the difference between getting some power or none at all.The 5000mAh capacity and the 1A output make this suitable mainly for phones and small devices rather than tablets.>>>>UPDATE:  The manufacturer contacted me about the above statement and said that the output power is 2A if only one USB outlet is used. That makes the power output better suited to a tablet, but I still feel that a 5000mAh capacity powerbank is not an ideal choice for a tablet. Given the inefficiency of using a powerbank of any type, 5000mAh will not provide for a full charge on many tablets.  For me, the minimum capacity for a tablet powerbank is 8000mAh and, ideally 10,000mAh or more.All in all, it's a very handy device, and brings some unique features to the powerbank table. Well worth considering even though it comes in at a higher price point than a typical 5000mAh powerbank.[Sample provided for review]

I received this in yellow at no cost in exchange for writing a review. Here are my comments.1. I like the way this looks and feels. It's relatively compact ( 5 1/2 x 2 7/8 x 1/2 inches) and has an attractive rugged plastic case that is supposed to be water resistant and shockproof and impervious to dirt.2. This is rated at 5000mAh and has dual 1A USB ports as well as a built in flashlight.3. Included is a micro USB charging cable along with both regular and lightning Apple adapter heads, plus a carabiner clip to carry this.4. There are four LED indicator lights to show the battery status. A green light comes on to indicate solar charging, and goes off when the unit is fully charged.Note: The directions state: "Solar charging only for emergency, please avoid prolonged exposure under the burning sun." However, in response to my original 4 star review noting this limitation, the seller contacted me to say that the reference to "only for emergency" was to indicate that solar charging is slower than electrical charging, and that in fact this unit has been tested for 8 hours on a hiking trip in South China under a hot sun and worked fine. Accordingly I upgraded my review to 5 stars.Bottom line: I think this is great sport charger to bring to the beach, lake or pool. I am going on vacation to a hot sunny climate in a couple of weeks and will see if this lives up to the seller's claim that it can endure hours in the hot sun.Update May 10, 2014: I left this out all afternoon to charge in the blazing hot sun at a hotel in Mexico where I went on vacation. It charged fine and also worked well afterwards. So I have confirmed that this can be left out for hours in a hot sun without any ill effect and will charge.Update May 31, 2014: When I travel I always use the flashlight on one of my power banks as a nightlight, which means it stays on from 8 to 10 hours a day. I was curious how quickly this unit would drain if I left the flashlight on. I was stunned at the results--but in a good way. The flashlight was on 24 hours a day for 7 straight days--and I still had 50% power left. I have much more powerful units that have drained more quickly. Putting aside that this will definitely be the unit I rely on for a nightlight when I travel, it's good to know that in the event of a power failure I have a flashlight that will last more than enough time if I keep it fully charged.Update June 8, 2014: The flashlight has now been on for 15 straight days 24/7 and just now ran out of power. Pretty amazing.

When I was asked to give an honest review this waterproof case, I was a little skeptical that it would be a big, bulky case that I wouldn't get much use of. I was definitely wrong. This case is sleek! It sealed snugly over my iPad and fits like a glove without adding much bulk or weight at all. For me, the best reason to use this case is just to keep my always-being-used iPad from getting destroyed in everyday life. I often read/play games/watch movies in the bath and many times I fall asleep only to be startled away by my iPad beginning to tip out of my hands. With this, I have the security to know that it's going to be safe, even if I drop it in someday. I also like to use my iPad at the beach and pool, and again, this case will keep the sand and water splashes off my expensive equipment. Of course all this security wouldn't be worth anything if it impaired the usability of the iPad, but it really doesn't. The screen is just as responsive and the visibility is just as good with the case as without it.All in all, this is a solid product. If you're like me, you just want to keep your gear safe from everyday life and this will definitely do it for you. On the other hand, if you want to play Angry Birds at the bottom of your pool, you'll have to check another review because that's not how I'm using it! :)

I tested my review sample using an Ipad 2 for fit and function. I tested the waterproof claim by submerging it under one foot of water in a tub - the only convenient means available to me - so I am taking the company's word for the claim that it is safe up to eight feet.Here are my results: the fit of the iPad 2 is perfect.
